SCHWARZ--Richard . June 10, 1939 - August 9,2008 You live here in my chest and everywhere I journey. Deeply loved and missed; but anywhere I sit is a mountaintop and what used to be pain is a lovely bench where we can rest under the sun. Larry Wender
MILSTEIN--Paul. After 3 years, in our hearts and thoughts remembering and honoring your life. Phyllis and Jerry
FRAUST--Howard. Sept. 5th, 1946 - August 9th, 2005 We are still one, as ever and Always, Joan

WILLIAMS--Eugene F.,Jr., former CEO and chairman of St. Louis Union Trust Company and a St. Louis civic leader, passed away at his house in East Hampton, N.Y., on August 7, 2013 at age 90. Mr. Williams is survived by his loving wife of 66 years, Evelyn Neidringhaus Williams. He was the devoted father of Rebecca (Loic) deKertanguy, of New York; Eugene III (Jacqueline) Williams, of New York; John (Lacey) Williams, of Los Angeles, CA.; Evelyn (John) McNiff, of Plymouth Meeting, PA; and Edward (Lisa) Williams, of Ross CA; his fifteen grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. He also leaves his sisters, Georgie (Henry) Lewis, of Essex, CT and Marie (Adalbert) von Gontard, of Greenwich, CT; six nephews and nieces; and many friends. Mr. Williams was born in St. Louis, the son of Eugene F. Williams, a prominent banker, and Marie Wight Williams. He attended St. Louis Country Day School and went on to Phillips Academy in Andover, MA and then Yale University. He interrupted his education to join the Army Air Corps, where he trained as a fighter pilot. When the war ended, he returned to Yale, graduating in 1947. Mr. Williams began his 40-year career with St. Louis Union Trust Company in 1947 as an investment officer and subsequently became President, CEO and Chairman of the Board serving in the latter role until his retirement in 1988. He served on the boards of the Olin Corporation, American Airlines, Bristol-Myers Squibb, as well as Emerson Electric, Boatmen's Trust Company, and the John M. Olin Foundation. He assumed the leadership of NILO Plantation in Albany, GA in 1982. He served as chairman of the board of his family's cattle ranch in Texas and Oklahoma, Pitchfork Land and Cattle Company. In 2002, he was awarded the highest honor from the National Ranching Heritage Association. Mr. Williams' civic contributions include serving as Board Chair of St. Lukes Hospital, Blue Cross Blue Shield, St. Louis Country Day School, and St. Louis Municipal Opera (Muny). He served on the board of St. Louis University. He was actively involved in the founding of Washington University's John M. Olin School of Business. His philanthropy included leadership support of the United Way, the St. Louis Art Museum, the St. Louis Symphony, and the Today and Tomorrow Educational Foundation, as well as establishing scholarship funds at St. Louis University and St. Luke's Hospital. In addition, he endowed a chair at the Yale University School of Management to teach market economics. He was a beloved husband, father and friend and will be remembered for his warmth, compassion and humility. There will be a memorial service in St. Louis in late September. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests memorial contributions be made to the Today and Tomorrow Educational Foundation, St. Louis, MO.

WARGO--Michael J.,Chief Exploration Scientist for NASA's Human Exploration and Operations Mission, died unexpectedly on August 4 at his home in Alexandria, VA. He was 61 years old. Dr. Wargo was the son of Margaret and John J. Wargo of Clairton, PA, both deceased, who themselves were the children of Slovak immigrants. Michael was a leading contributor to NASA's human lunar and planetary exploration program. As a scientific member of many lunar missions, including the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter and the LCROSS satellite, Dr. Wargo helped map resources for human missions to the moon and participated in the discovery of ice in the shadows of lunar craters. In a nearly two-decade career at NASA, he received numerous awards including NASA's Exceptional Service Medal and seven group achievement awards. He was a member of the team planning the next robotic mission to Mars in 2020 and worked gathering crucial scientific information needed to allow humans to be sent safely to the moon, Mars and near-Earth asteroids. Much of his work has helped develop a "roadmap" for human and robotic space exploration for the next two decades. Dr. Wargo graduated from M.I.T., with an SB degree in Earth and Planetary Science and received a Doctorate in Materials Science in 1982. At MIT, he was recognized with the John Wulff Award for Excellence in Teaching and the Hugh Hampton Young Memorial Fund Prize for exhibiting leadership and creativity while maintaining exceptionally broad and interdisciplinary interests. He began his career at NASA by turning a fledgling microgravity research division into a worldclass program. NASA drew on Dr. Wargo's ability to explain complex scientific findings in straightforward terms as a spokesman at agency press conferences. NASA is asking the International Astronomical Union to name a crater on the moon in his honor "so his name will be forever enshrined in the heavens." His colleagues and his friends remember him as inspirational, full of passion and energy, with a booming voice and a great heart. He is survived by his wife, Adele Morrissette of New York, NY, and brothers John, David and Robert, all of whom graduated from M.I.T. Visitation will be held on Sunday afternoon August 11, at Everly-Wheatley Funeral Home and funeral services will be held on Monday August 12 at 12:30pm at Blessed Sacrament Catholic Church, both in Alexandria VA. Gifts may be made to MIT in memory of Michael Wargo for the Department of Materials Science Endowed Fellowship Fund by contacting Bonny Kellerman, bonnyk@mit.edu or at 617-253-9722.

STONE--Elaine, on August 6, 2013. Professor Emerita at Fashion Institute of Technology. Survived by her brother Richard, sister-in-law Anita, nephew Dan and nieces Tania and Ilana. Services: Today, 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam.

SHAMOS--Marion. (nee Marion Jean Cahn). A New Yorker from 1939-2005, Mom left us in Pittsburgh at age 93. Born Schenectady, NY, daughter of Freda Kart and Isidor Cahn, she grew up in Williamsport, PA. Devoted wife of Morris Shamos, with whom she traveled extensively for 59 years until his death in 2002, loving mother of Michael, mother-in-law of Julie, grandmother of Josselyn Crane and Alexander Shamos and great-grandmother of Harlow and Bishop Crane. Marion will be laid to rest with her late husband in a private interment and requested that no funeral be held. The family asks that Marion be remembered by contributions to the Morris H. Shamos Scholarship Fund in Physics at New York University by contacting alan.shapiro@nyu.edu.

ROSEN--Sidney W, 95, distinguished physician of many accomplishments, passed away August 5 surrounded by loving family at his longtime home in Fall River, MA. Born Lynn, MA, Sidney is survived by devoted and adored wife Lorraine Adler Rosen, loving daughter Melanie, son-in-law Mitchell Brooks, treasured granddaughter Gillian, nephew Sandor, brothers Leslie, Richard; pre-deceased sisters Lois Grossman and Winnifred Moller. A graduate of University of Massachusetts Amherst and Middlesex University Medical School in 1943, gastroenterology fellow at Lahey Clinic, Massachusetts Governor of American College of Gastroenterology 1982-86; Sid served his community faithfully, dedicating marvelous diagnostic skills and thoughtful care to his practice. He published numerous JAMA articles, served Charlton Memorial Hospital as Chief of Staff and Medical Director 1985-88, Utilization Director 1966-88, member Massachusetts Board of Utilization Review for BC/BS and many more A US Navy Medical Corps veteran of WWII and Korean Wars, serving on the Howard Gilmore, at the American Naval Hospital Panama, as Commander at Chelsea Naval Hospital. Attended Roger Williams University Law School, received an MPH from Harvard School of Public Health and opened Health Benefit Reviews, a patient advocacy service. Recent work was devoted to research and blogging about carcinogenic bacterium, Helicobacter Pylori, its role in causing cancers and development of Alzheimer's disease, which he fervently hopes will lead to prevention and ultimate eradication. A natural and wonderful athlete, Sid ran college cross country, was an ROTC Calvalry member, an early skier, avid sailor and winning racer of Rhodes19 and J24 class, and loved golf. A passionate expert of the American Revolution. Sid was devoted to friends, family and to humanity; his sensitive and gentle kindness, engaging and mild manner, keen intelligence and unfailingly magnificent medical advice will be eternally missed. Heartfelt gratitude and appreciation to final care givers Beverly Quintin and Community Nurse Service of Massachusetts. Private service Swan Point Memorial Providence, RI Friday August 9.

ROSENBERG--Edith "Chickie," 74, of West Orange, NJ and Killington, VT, died August 6, 2013 at Calvary Hospital. She survived four and a half years with ovarian cancer through indomitable strength and courage and the care of her doctors and staff at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was a graduate of Columbia High School of Maplewood/South Orange, NJ, Muhlenberg College and New York University. Since 1990 she was a snowboard instructor at Killington Resort, the first female snowboarder registered in the Professional Ski Instructors of America-Eastern Division. She achieved the coveted Level II certification from the American Association of Snowboard Instructors. She was featured by NBCs Today show, CNN, New England Cable Network TV, Fuji-TV of Japan, Bill Bradley's Sirius Satellite Radio and The New York Times, reprinted at her website: www.SnowboardngForWomen.com. She published two books, "Snowboarding for Men" and "Snowboarding for Women." For the past 23 years she was a docent at The Newark Museum. Chickie is survived by her husband of 50 years, Paul Rosenberg; daughter Brett Harris and husband Mitch; grandchildren Alicia and Cooper; and brother Dr. Michael Zimmerman and wife Barbara. Donations may be made to the Chickie Rosenberg Memorial Fund at MSKCC, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065.

REARDON--Robert P.,of Garden City, NY, formerly of Rockville Centre, NY, on August 7, 2013. Beloved husband of Lorraine (nee: Hartz). Loving and devoted father of Brian (Elizabeth), Keith (AnnMarie), Julia (Daniel) Englander, Mary (Woody) Weldon, Maureen (Jay) Coyle, Robert (Sara) and Morgan. Adored grandfather of twenty-one. Dear brother of Marie Prusak, Anne Mayer, John (Jack) and the late Charles Reardon. Also survived by 17 nieces and nephews. Reposing Saturday and Sunday Macken Mortuary, Rockville Centre Chapel, 52 Clinton Avenue 2-4, 7-9pm. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral, Monday 10am. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, NY. mackenmortuary.com

OLAN--Frances Zeller, died August 6th, 2013. Born February 2nd, 1917. A fiercely independent woman, Frances enjoyed following the stock market, was an avid card player, an exuberant dancer, and a proud and loving parent, grandparent, and great-grandparent. Frances will be greatly missed by her son, Neil Olan, her daughter, Sherry Olan Berner, her granddaughters Brett Iimura, Dru Finley and Erin Finley, and her six great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husband, Phil Olan, who died in 1973. Services will be held at noon on Friday, August 9th, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (at W. 91st St.), in Manhattan.

NEUSTADTER--Shirley, 94, died in her sleep on August 7, 2013. Treasured wife of the late Morton Neustadter. Gentle, warm and literate, she maintained her bright smile and sense of humor even as time gradually dimmed less immutable traits. Survived by her sister Rhoda Storch, her grateful sons Stanley (Judy) and Michael, her daughter Amy (Larry) Spitalny, and affectionate grandchildren Simon, Lydia and Max Spitalny.

McNAMER--Ronald, of New York City and Ft. Lauderdale, FL, passed away peacefully at home in New York on Sunday, August 4, 2013. He is survived by his partner of 35 years Charles Cuomo, a sister Nina Cain and numerous nieces and nephews. Ron was a veteran of the United States Navy and an internationally known jewelry designer for Montreaux, Cartier, Tiffany and Zolotas, private clientele, as well as a costume designer for both the theater and ballet. Friends may call Friday, August 9, 5-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Audubon Society. Memorial Services to be held in New York and Ft. Lauderdale at a later date.

LICHTER--George. We lost our dear friend George Lichter last week. Because of his modesty and lack of self celebration few appreciate how he changed so many lives for the better. He was a bona fide hero in World War II, a highly decorated fighter pilot of extraordinary bravery, devoted to his fellow pilots, many of whom never came home. He was among the handful of founders of the Israeli Air Force, carrying world Jewry on his wings from the devastation of Nazism to that country's pride and excellence. He lived life well. "How are you, George?" His answer always was, "Fantastic!" He was a great friend to all his friends, always a cheerleader, always generous. What he was most proud of, deservedly so, was that he was a fabulous father and grandfather. We are grateful that George Lichter showed up on our doorstep 63 years ago and became part of our lives. We will miss him always. Elaine and Alan London

LEWIS--Richard. The Board of Directors and Membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and current President, Richard Lewis. He succumbed only after a long and courageous struggle. His leadership and friendship will be missed by all. Our deepest sympathies are extended to the bereaved family. Glen Head Country Club

LEWIS--Richard B.,on August 7, 2013. Beloved husband of Lenore Strauss Lewis. Cherished father of Stephanie, Jonathan and Julie Lewis. Adored Pops of Maya Strauss Lewis. LANE--Linda. Beautiful Linda we will miss you. Our heartfelt sympathy to Jules and Family. With Love, Skip and Maxine.

LANE--Linda. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Linda Lane. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband Jules, and their family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary

HUBSCHER--Stephen. The Kaplan and Hut families extend their condolences to the family of Stephen Hubscher. He was a gentle wise man. Husband of Dena, father of Sofia Hubscher and Philippa Hubscher Kaplan. Adoring grandfather of Emily and Michael Kaplan and Margarit and Rina Wallach.

HUBSCHER--Stephen, on August 7 at age 80. Devoted husband of Dena for 51 years, loving father of Sofia (Adam), Philippa (Dan). Adored "PopPop" of Emily, Michael, Rina, Margalit. Beloved brother of Myrna (Marvin). Inspired thousands of students during 38 years teaching at New Ro High School. Inspired his family with his love and devotion. Always in our hearts.

FREEDMAN--Esther, age 91 of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida passed away Thursday, August 8, 2013. Cornell University, BA and Columbia University, MSW. She is predeceased by her husband Warren Freedman. Esther is survived by her children, daughters, Debby (Michael) Stiebel and Miriam (Richard Carmen) Freedman-Carmen; son, Dr. Douglas (Dr. Sharon Haas) Freedman. Nine Grandchildren, four great-grandchildren. Graveside Services will be held Sunday, August 11, 2013 at 12:45pm at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, New York. Memorial Contributions may be offered to the Susan G. Komen fight against breast cancer www.komen.org
DORSKIND--Bruce. You will always be in my heart. Send Mom my love. Love, Dad

Grandmother to Jake, Kate, Annika, Carly, Charlie and Camillo. Sister to James M. Ashley IV and Susan Ashley Coss. Always in our hearts. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his children, Harold (Pat), Terri (Henry), and John (Diane); grandchildren; and great-grandchildren. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Visiting Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm, Harden Funeral Home in Bayside, NY. Burial Sat. 10am All Saints Cemetery in Great Neck. Donations in her memory to Little Shelter Animal Rescue, Huntington, NY.

WILLINGER--Kate (also known as Katherine), 94, of New York City, died on August 8, 2013. She was born in The Bronx, NYC, on July 12, 1919. She served in World War II as a pilot with the Women Airforce Service Pilots for which she received the Congressional Gold Medal in 2010. She ran a successful business in NYC from 1946-1970 manufacturing individual record jackets and was the only woman executive in the industry. In retirement she made furniture and stained glass and enjoyed New York's shows, concerts and museums. She was predeceased by her parents, Max and Minnie (Weinstein) Willinger, brother Henry Willinger and sister Miriam Epstein (Julius). She is survived by her long-term partner and friend Theresa Falgiatore, nephews Allan Willinger (Jo Schlesinger), Richard Willinger and Leonard Epstein (Jan), nieces Judith Willinger (Robert Luke) and Dr. Adele Strominger (Norman), and sister-in-law Miriam Willinger. A graveside funeral service will be held at Beth David Cemetery, 300 Elmont Road, Elmont, New York, at 2pm on August 11, 2013. Services handled by O'Brien Sheipe Funeral Home, Elmont, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the WASP Endowment/TWU Foundation, Texas Woman's University, PO Box 425528, 304 Administration Dr., Denton, TX 76204.

WARGO--Michael J.,Chief Exploration Scientist for NASA's Human Exploration and Operations Mission, died unexpectedly on August 4 at his home in Alexandria, VA. He was 61 years old. Dr. Wargo was the son of Margaret and John J. Wargo of Clairton, PA, both deceased, who themselves were the children of Slovak immigrants. Michael was a leading contributor to NASA's human lunar and planetary exploration program. As a scientific member of many lunar missions, including the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter and the LCROSS satellite, Dr. Wargo helped map resources for human missions to the moon and participated in the discovery of ice in the shadows of lunar craters. In a nearly two-decade career at NASA, he received numerous awards including NASA's Exceptional Service Medal and seven group achievement awards. He was a member of the team planning the next robotic mission to Mars in 2020 and worked gathering crucial scientific information needed to allow humans to be sent safely to the moon, Mars and near-Earth asteroids. Much of his work has helped develop a "roadmap" for human and robotic space exploration for the next two decades. Dr. Wargo graduated from M.I.T., with an SB degree in Earth and Planetary Science and received a Doctorate in Materials Science in 1982. At MIT, he was recognized with the John Wulff Award for Excellence in Teaching and the Hugh Hampton Young Memorial Fund Prize for exhibiting leadership and creativity while maintaining exceptionally broad and interdisciplinary interests. He began his career at NASA by turning a fledgling microgravity research division into a worldclass program. NASA drew on Dr. Wargo's ability to explain complex scientific findings in straightforward terms as a spokesman at agency press conferences. NASA is asking the International Astronomical Union to name a crater on the moon in his honor "so his name will be forever enshrined in the heavens." His colleagues and his friends remember him as inspirational, full of passion and energy, with a booming voice and a great heart. He is survived by his wife, Adele Morrissette of New York, NY, and brothers John, David and Robert, all of whom graduated from M.I.T. Visitation will be held on Sunday afternoon August 11, at Everly-Wheatley Funeral Home and funeral services will be held on Monday August 12 at 12:30pm at Blessed Sacrament Catholic Church, both in Alexandria VA. Gifts may be made to MIT in memory of Michael Wargo for the Department of Materials Science Endowed Fellowship Fund by contacting Bonny Kellerman, bonnyk@mit.edu or at 617-253-9722.

STRAUSS--Dr. Carl. We will miss our amazing polymath- a brilliant and compassionate family physician for over 50 years. RESNIK--Regina. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Regina Resnik, a treasured star and much-admired colleague whose career with the company was notable not only for the distinctive artistry of her performances, but for its breadth and longevity. Ms. Resnik sang 328 Met performances in an astonishing 39 roles between 1944 and 1983. She began her career in soprano roles such as Leonora in Il Trovatore, which she sang for her Met debut, and later transitioned to the mezzo-soprano and contralto roles in which she would have her greatest triumphs. Two milestones in her wide-ranging Met career were her performances as Ellen Orford in the 1948 company premiere of Britten's Peter Grimes and as the Old Baroness in the 1958 world premiere of Barber's Vanessa. Her roles with the company also included both Chrysothemis and Klytaemnestra in Elektra, the title character in Carmen, Dame Quickly in Falstaff, the Marquise de Berkenfield in La Fille du Regiment, and the Countess in The Queen of Spades. We offer our sincerest condolences to her family, and to her many friends and admirers around the world. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

MOUTOUSSIS--George, MD, a prominent and widely respected internist with over four decades of experience specializing in Geriatric Medicine and Nephrology, died on August 7th in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 65. His death was sudden and caused by cancer. Born in Athens, Greece, on March 13th, 1948, to Gen. Panagiotis and Angeliki Moutoussis (born Spyridonos), Dr. Moutoussis went on to attend the prestigious Medical School of Athens from which he graduated in 1972. A fellowship at New York's Mount Sinai Hospital then brought him to the United States where he would meet Catherine to whom he was happily married in 1979. The practice statement of his Manhattan office best captured Dr. Moutoussis's approach to his profession. It read, "To practice medicine in the old traditional way when the doctor was not a provider and the patient was not a client." His daughters, Natalie and Maryangela described their father as, "an honorable man who taught us the importance of living an ethical and morally correct life and provided us with the perfect example." Dr. Moutoussis was a member of the American College of Physicians, the American Society of Nephrology and the Hellenic Medical Society of New York. Dr. Moutoussis is survived by his wife of 33 years, Catherine, his daughters, Maryangela and Natalie, his sister, Lena Koukoumeli, his niece, Gelina Koukoumeli, and his nephews, John Koukoumeli and Leonardos Seidas. Friends may call Sunday August 11th from 2:00 5:00pm and 7:00 9:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. Funeral Service will be held on Monday August 12th at 10:00am at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity. Memorial donations can be made to The Hellenic Medical Society of New York (718)398-2440 and the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity (212)288-3215.

McLAUGHLIN--Judge Joseph. Judge Joseph M. McLaughlin, of Jamaica Estates, NY, on August 8, 2013. Beloved husband to Frances E. Lynch, devoted father to Mary Jo Clines, Joseph, Matthew and Andrew, grandfather to Joseph, Terence and Kira Clines, Kate, Patrick, Emmett, Paul, Joseph, Elizabeth, Aidan, Nolan, Eva and Jillian McLaughlin. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he received an A.B. from Fordham College in 1954, and was a Captain in the United States Army Corps of Engineers from 1955 to 1957. He then received a LL.B. from Fordham University School of Law in 1959, and an LL.M. from New York University School of Law in 1964. He was in private practice of law in New York City from 1959 to 1961. He worked as a law professor at Fordham University School of Law in Manhattan from 1961 to 1971. In 1971, McLaughlin became Dean of Fordham Law School, a position he held for ten years. He served as Chairman of the New York Law Revision Commission from 1975 to 1982. In 1981, he was nominated by President Ronald Reagan to the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York. In 1990, President George H. W. Bush nominated Judge McLaughlin to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. He served in this capacity until 2013. In addition to serving as a Judge, he was an adjunct Professor of Law at St. John's University School of Law and Fordham University School of Law. His publications include numerous works on the law of evidence and civil procedure. Friends may call at Frank. E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st on Saturday and Sunday from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9pm. The funeral will be held at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 10am on Monday. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Judge McLaughlin's name to Ozanam Hall, 42-41 201st Street, Bayside, NY 11361.

EGER--Edith "Bubs" Seclow, died August 9, 2013 of cancer at her home in Morristown, NJ. Born into a family of freethinking secular Jews in 1919, she embraced "feminist" principals long before the word was invented. She was an unabashed and unapologetic liberal who supported civil and human rights. Her moral compass always pointed true North. Though always refined, she had big opinions and a small ego. She did not suffer fools and endeavored to be informed and learn until the end. She loved her New York Times and New Yorker. Surviving are her sons, Richard and Jeffrey Eger, brother Richard "Dick" Seclow, grandchildren Erik, Asa and Jayna, great-grandson Niko, niece and nephew Theresa and Tom Seclow and all their spouses, extended family and friends. In lieu of flowers, tax-deductible contributions may be sent to the Morris Country Park Commission, P.O. Box 1295, Morristown, NJ 07962 to support the Marvin and Edith Eger Fern Garden at the Frelinghuysen Arboretum. Services will be private.

LANE--Linda. On August 8, 2013, in New York City, at the age of 73. Beloved wife of Jules Lane. Loving mommy of Lisa and Marc Friedman, Julie and Eric Yamin, Stacey and Brooks Kaufman, and Jason and Emily Lane. Adoring grandma of Alex, Madison, Samantha, Jack, Kate, Matthew, Gabrielle, Dylan, Jordyn, Devin, Drayer and baby Stokely. CONKLIN--David A.,of Naples, FL (formerly of Oldwick, NJ) died Thursday, July 25, 2013 at the age of 82. He was a graduate of NYU/Polytechnic in '52 and '59 with degrees in Chemical Engineering. In 1952 he joined Merck & Co., Inc. where he worked for 43 years. From 1955 1957, David served with the Dept. of Biological Research at Walter Reed Army Institute of Research. He returned to Merck & Co., Inc., and rose through the ranks of management becoming the first President of Merck Chemical Manufacturing Division. To end his career he became Senior Vice President of Science and Technology. David served as Chairman of the National Coalition for Advanced Manufacturing (NACFAM) and Chairman of Capital Improvements Campaign for the Puerto Rican Family Institute. Other memberships included Polytechnic University, Panlabs International, and the National Action Committee for Minorities in Engineering (NACME). He is survived by his wife, Ruth, his daughters Dana (Marco) Conklin-Malusa and Diana (Joseph) Lapierre, step children Christopher (Kristen) Haussman and Audrey(Matthew) Largen and 10 grandchildren. He was preceded in death by a daughter, Dale Durney. A memorial service will be held October 12, 2013, at 11:00am at Zion Lutheran Church, 56 Old Turnpike Rd., in Oldwick, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Support Network, 660 Tamiami Trail N, Suite 21, Naples, FL 34102 or to Zion Lutheran Church, 56 Old Turnpike Rd. Oldwick, NJ 08858 Online condolences and signing of the guest book may be entered at www.fullerfuneralhome.com. Fuller Funeral Home Naples, FL -239-592-1611

SCHWARZ--Richard . June 10, 1939 - August 9,2008 You live here in my chest and everywhere I journey. Deeply loved and missed; but anywhere I sit is a mountaintop and what used to be pain is a lovely bench where we can rest under the sun. Larry Wender

WINDHAGER--Helga A.,MD, (nee Rapant) of Tenafly, New Jersey passed away peacefully on August 7, 2013 after a long illness. Born 1928 in Vienna, Austria, she earned her medical doctorate in 1954 at the University of Vienna before emigrating to the USA where she married Erich E. Windhager, MD, in 1956. She retired in 1989 as Director of Laboratories at Jersey City Medical Center and as Associate Clinical Professor of the Medical College of New Jersey. Subsequently, Helga was an active volunteer in the arts. She is survived by her husband of 57 years, her two daughters Evelyn Swanson and Karen Siletzky, their husbands Bart and Paul, and five grandchildren, Jennifer, Eric, Schuyler, Maximilian and Spencer. Private funeral services were held on Sunday, August 11 in Tenafly.

WHALEY--Barton, PhD, 85, on 3 August 2013 in Pacific Grove, CA. Born in San Francisco on 26 May 1928, a pioneer in the field of military deception. Survived by his wife Susan Stratton Aykroyd, and stepsons David and Jim Woodle. He will be sorely missed and never forgotten. Any donations on his behalf may be made to the Special Operations Warrior Foundation at specialops.org.

WARGO--Michael J.,Chief Exploration Scientist for NASA's Human Exploration and Operations Mission, died unexpectedly on August 4 at his home in Alexandria, VA. He was 61 years old. Dr. Wargo was the son of Margaret and John J. Wargo of Clairton, PA, both deceased, who themselves were the children of Slovak immigrants. Michael was a leading contributor to NASA's human lunar and planetary exploration program. As a scientific member of many lunar missions, including the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter and the LCROSS satellite, Dr. Wargo helped map resources for human missions to the moon and participated in the discovery of ice in the shadows of lunar craters. In a nearly two-decade career at NASA, he received numerous awards including NASA's Exceptional Service Medal and seven group achievement awards. He was a member of the team planning the next robotic mission to Mars in 2020 and worked gathering crucial scientific information needed to allow humans to be sent safely to the moon, Mars and near-Earth asteroids. Much of his work has helped develop a "roadmap" for human and robotic space exploration for the next two decades. Dr. Wargo graduated from M.I.T., with an SB degree in Earth and Planetary Science and received a Doctorate in Materials Science in 1982. At MIT, he was recognized with the John Wulff Award for Excellence in Teaching and the Hugh Hampton Young Memorial Fund Prize for exhibiting leadership and creativity while maintaining exceptionally broad and interdisciplinary interests. He began his career at NASA by turning a fledgling microgravity research division into a worldclass program. NASA drew on Dr. Wargo's ability to explain complex scientific findings in straightforward terms as a spokesman at agency press conferences. NASA is asking the International Astronomical Union to name a crater on the moon in his honor "so his name will be forever enshrined in the heavens." His colleagues and his friends remember him as inspirational, full of passion and energy, with a booming voice and a great heart. He is survived by his wife, Adele Morrissette of New York, NY, and brothers John, David and Robert, all of whom graduated from M.I.T. Visitation will be held on Sunday afternoon August 11, at Everly-Wheatley Funeral Home and funeral services will be held on Monday August 12 at 12:30pm at Blessed Sacrament Catholic Church, both in Alexandria VA. Gifts may be made to MIT in memory of Michael Wargo for the Department of Materials Science Endowed Fellowship Fund by contacting Bonny Kellerman, bonnyk@mit.edu or at 617-253-9722.

TRENTHAM--Barbara. August 27, 1944 August 2, 2013. Artist, Barbara Trentham, 68, died August 2, 2013, at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. The cause was complications of leukemia. Barbara was born August 27, 1944, in Brooklyn, NY. She moved to Weston, CT, as a child and graduated from Staples High School in Westport, CT, in 1962. She graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1966 and moved to England that year to study art at the Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Art at the University of Oxford. She married Giles Trentham in 1967. The marriage ended in divorce in 1970. Barbara worked as a model in London during the early 1970s. Her photograph appeared on the cover of the English edition of Vogue Magazine and other magazines numerous times. She also had supporting roles in several movies, including The Possession of Joel Delaney (1972) with Shirley MacLaine, Rollerball (1975), with James Caan, Sky Riders (1976) with James Coburn and Robert Culp, and a made for TV movie, Death Moon (1978). In the mid 1970s she moved to Los Angeles to pursue an acting career. Deciding that she wasn't an actress, Barbara worked in television in Los Angeles as a reporter and a producer of Those Amazing Animals until 1980, when she met and married British comedian and writer John Cleese and moved back to London. That marriage produced a daughter, Camilla Cleese, and ended in divorce in 1990. Shortly before, she had begun to focus again on her lifelong interest, oil painting. In 1993, she moved to Chicago, where she met George Covington, a lawyer. The two were married in 1998 and lived in Lake Bluff, IL. Barbara built an art studio at their home which became a gathering place and a source of inspiration for local artists. She co-founded a local artist organization, Artists on the Bluff. In about 2003 she began spending a substantial part of each year in Jackson Hole, WY, where the western landscape inspired her art. She became active in the Art Association of Jackson Hole and organized and led events at the Association's art fairs. She was represented at various times in Jackson by Center Street Gallery, Lindsay McCandless Contemporary, and Willow Creek Home Furnishings. She is survived by her husband, George Covington, her daughter Camilla Cleese, her brother Robert Schilling, and her nephew Alex Schilling, as well as four step-daughters, Karen Covington, Jean Covington, Sarah Covington, and Cynthia Cleese. A celebration of her life will be held at a time and place to be determined. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to the Art Association of Jackson Hole (Barbara Trentham Fund), PO Box 1248, Jackson, WY 83001. For information, contact Wenban Funeral Home, Lake Forest, IL 847-234-0022 or www.wenbanfh.com.

TREISMAN--Dorothy C. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Adirondack Council are deeply saddened by the passing of Dorothy C. Treisman. She carried on the legacy and tradition of her father, Joseph F. Cullman III, through a commitment to protecting the Adirondack Park and supporting the Adirondack Council's conservation efforts. Her son Joel is continuing that tradition. We extend our condolences to her sons Joel and Jeffrey and the entire family. Ann Carmel, Board Chair, and the Adirondack Council Board of Directors

TREISMAN--Dorothy C. The faculty and staff of the School of Pharmacy are saddened by the passing of our dear friend Dorothy Treisman who, with her family, named The Susan Lehman Cullman Laboratory for Cancer Research in honor of her mother. Barone, Acting Dean and Distinguished Professor, Ernest Mario School of Pharmacy at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey.

STRAUSS--Dr. Carl. We will miss our amazing polymath- a brilliant and compassionate family physician for over 50 years. Loving husband to Shirley Strauss for 67 years and devoted father to Dr. Elton Strauss (Karen) and Bonnie Carroll (Kevin); adored grandfather to Eric (Bridget), Elisa (Marc), Melanie (Peter) and the late K.J. Great-grandfather to Sophie, Margot, Ryan and Gavin. In 1993, Dr. Carl, who delivered generations of Brooklyn babies, was voted "Man of the Year" in Bensonhurst. He will be missed enormously by so many for whom he was man of the year, every year. Carl, along with his wife Shirley, was a staunch supporter of the East Midwood Jewish Center. The family would appreciate contributions be sent there or Temple Beth EI, Manhattan Beach or Turning Point, Patterson, NJ. Services Sunday 12 Noon at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. www.shermanschapel.com

STERNLIEB--Dr. Peter, a brilliant physician and beloved husband, father and grandfather, died on Saturday, August 3, at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, where he had been an internist on staff for more than 50 years. He was 81. Scuba diving, underwater photography, squash, swimming and jazz music were lifelong passions, but all paled in comparison to the 40-year romance he shared with his beloved wife, Sybil Sternlieb, to whom he wrote love poems every week. A consummate family doctor, he bestowed loving attention on family, friends and patients whose lives were forever touched and who will treasure him always. Dr. Peter Sternlieb is survived by his loving wife, Sybil Sternlieb, a Senior VP at Merrill Lynch. He also leaves two daughters, Susan (Edward) Novick and Debra Morris (Holly Haygood); two sons, David (Barbara) Rosenberg and Michael Sternlieb; and four grandchildren, Myles and Olivia Novick, and Jennifer and Daniel Rosenberg (April Branson), who adored and were adored by him. Donations to the Feinstein Institute for Medical Research in honor of Dr. Peter Sternlieb.

SPIEGEL--Aaron. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our beloved member and Honorary Trustee, Aaron Speigel, devoted husband of Helen. We will miss his passion for living and his dedication to family, friends, and shule. Rodeph Sholom was his second home. We send our deepest condolences to his family, all members of our synagogue, Cindy Spiegel, Peter Kupfer, Rachel and Jonathan and Shari Spiegel, Alan Berliner and Eli. May his memory be a blessing. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President

SPIEGEL--Aaron, on August 9, 2013. Beloved husband of Helen. Adoring father of Cindy (Peter) and Shari (Alan). Doting grandfather of Rachel, Jonathan, and Eli. Service 10am Monday at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd Street.

SCHOFER--Marvin Y. Sunday, August 4, 2013. Born on January 26, 1933, in Minneapolis. As a teenager he studied piano with acclaimed pianist Gary Graffman. He attended UVA and received a BA from NYU and an MA from BU. He began his career as a pianist/ stage manager with the NBC Opera and subsequently as a manager for Sarah Caldwell's Opera Company of Boston. He was Director of PR for the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Boston Pops, and Tanglewood. He spent his career representing symphony and opera conductors at CAMI and ICM Artist. He is survived by many loving friends and his husband of 34 years, James D. Rosenthal.

RESNIK--Regina. CUNY TV is deeply saddened by the passing of our friend and colleague, Regina Resnik. Ms. Resnik was indeed a diva, but more than that, Regina was "a woman of valor." We extend our condolences to her son, Michael Philip Davis. Bob Isaacson, CUNY TV

RESNIK--Regina. The board and staff of the Metropolitan Opera Guild and Opera News are saddened by the death of Regina Resnik. A major international artist, Regina served on the board of the Guild since 1986, and was an enthusiastic supporter of all of our programs. Our deepest sympathies go to her brother Jack, her son, Michael, and his partner, Alberto. Winthrop Rutherfurd, Jr., Chairman Richard J. Miller, Jr., President Stewart Pearce, Managing Director

REED--Orrel P.,92, art and architectural historian, died at his Malibu, CA home on May 26, 2013. Mr. Reed was a highly regarded art expert and made major contributions to preserving the legacy of Frank Lloyd Wright. Full obituary online at: legacy.com

REISSMAN--Myron "Mike", died on July 7, 2013. His wife, Dorothy "Tuddy" Reissman, predeceased him in September of 2008, one month short of their 60th anniversary. Mike followed many interests during his 95 years but his life-long passions were music, which he pursued both personally and professionally, and golf. A born salesman, Mike, started his own stereo import and sales business, the Reissman International Corporation and he continued working in sales until the age of 85. Everyone who had the pleasure to know him agreed that you could never meet a more likable guy than Mike Reissman. Mike was a kind, gentle and considerate man, who always had a funny line and friendly word for everyone. Mike passed away peacefully surrounded by his daughter Joan, her fiance Paul, and friends at his bedside. Donations may be made in Myron's memory to the Brooklyn College Alumni Fund.

QUINN--Thomas P.,of East 72 Street in New York City died at home this week. The wake will be at Krtil Funeral Home, 70 St. and 1st Ave, Sunday 5-9pm. The funeral will be at St. John the Martyr Church, 72nd St. between 2nd and 3rd Ave, Rev. Msgr. Charles Quinn, the deceased brother, officiating.

PLOCKI--Ilse Constance, passed away peacefully and surrounded by family in Rockville, MD, on August 3, 2013. She was 85. Ilse was born in Frankfurt, Germany, in 1928 and immigrated to the United States in 1953. She lived most of her life in New York City, where she was Vice President of the fine leather goods retailer Madler. Ilse lived in Florida and Maryland upon retirement, but always considered herself a New Yorker. She is survived by her son Peter, daughter-in-law Merry, and grandchildren Justin and Alexandra, of Silver Spring, MD. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made in Ilse's name to Transitional Housing Corp. at www.thcdc.org. Online condolences may be made at pumphreyfuneralhome.com.

PITNEY--Kathleen. Kathleen Pitney, nee Troast, 89, on August 1 at home in Mendham, NJ. Graduate of Passaic (New Jersey) High School and Smith College, '44. She was the daughter of Paul Troast, Chairman of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority during the time of its construction and Republican gubernatorial candidate in 1953. Kathleen paved the way for women in politics as president of the New Jersey Federation of Republican Women. She was also an influential advocate, giving selflessly of her time to numerous social and educational causes. She served as chairwoman of the New Jersey Comprehensive Planning Council, the Public Health Council, the Disciplinary Review Board of the Supreme Court of New Jersey, the Mendham Township Committee and many other organizations. She was a trustee of Fairleigh Dickinson University and played an instrumental role in the Development Office of Smith College. A respected horticulturalist, she tended and expanded the gardens of Pitney Farm, which are in the archives of the American Gardens at the Smithsonian Institution. She also served on the board of Wave Hill and was the president of the Garden Club of Somerset Hills. She exhibited in the Philadelphia and New York Flower Shows, winning numerous awards, including the prestigious Certificate of Excellence from the National Garden Club of America in recognition of her work in miniatures. Kathleen had a wonderful private life filled with love, family, friends and travel. She and her adoring husband Duncan set the standard for her children and grandchildren whom she embraced with patience and good humor. Kathleen once wrote "It's the things you don't do that you regret, so don't be afraid to try things that will make your life fuller and richer." She leaves behind her brothers John and Arthur Troast, sons Trygve and Erik Sletteland, daughters Sigrid Franzblau, Karen Jackson, Wendy Macbeth, stepsons John and Christopher Pitney, eighteen grandchildren and sixteen great-grandchildren. Her husband Duncan and stepdaughter Jenifer Lyle predeceased her. A remembrance ceremony for Kathleen and Duncan will be held on September 15 at 3:00pm at Pitney Farm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the "Community Foundation of New Jersey, Friends of Pitney Farm Fund", P.O. Box 338 Morristown, NJ 07963, or online at www.cfnj.org. The Fund is a nonprofit organization dedicated to the preservation of Pitney Farm as a cultural hub for Mendham.

OLAN--Frances Zeller, died August 6th, 2013. Born February 2nd, 1917. A fiercely independent woman, Frances enjoyed following the stock market, was an avid card player, an exuberant dancer, and a proud and loving parent, grandparent, and great-grandparent. Frances will be greatly missed by her son, Neil Olan, her daughter, Sherry Olan Berner, her granddaughters Brett Iimura, Dru Finley and Erin Finley, and her six great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husband, Phil Olan, who died in 1973. Services will be held at noon on Friday, August 9th, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (at W. 91st St.), in Manhattan.

MOUTOUSSIS--George, MD, a prominent and widely respected internist with over four decades of experience specializing in Geriatric Medicine and Nephrology, died on August 7th in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 65. His death was sudden and caused by cancer. Born in Athens, Greece, on March 13th, 1948, to Gen. Panagiotis and Angeliki Moutoussis (born Spyridonos), Dr. Moutoussis went on to attend the prestigious Medical School of Athens from which he graduated in 1972. A fellowship at New York's Mount Sinai Hospital then brought him to the United States where he would meet Catherine to whom he was happily married in 1979. The practice statement of his Manhattan office best captured Dr. Moutoussis's approach to his profession. It read, "To practice medicine in the old traditional way when the doctor was not a provider and the patient was not a client." His daughters, Natalie and Maryangela described their father as, "an honorable man who taught us the importance of living an ethical and morally correct life and provided us with the perfect example." Dr. Moutoussis was a member of the American College of Physicians, the American Society of Nephrology and the Hellenic Medical Society of New York. Dr. Moutoussis is survived by his wife of 33 years, Catherine, his daughters, Maryangela and Natalie, his sister, Lena Koukoumeli, his niece, Gelina Koukoumeli, and his nephews, John Koukoumeli and Leonardos Seidas. Friends may call Sunday August 11th from 2:00 5:00pm and 7:00 9:00pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. Funeral Service will be held on Monday August 12th at 10:00am at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity. Memorial donations can be made to The Hellenic Medical Society of New York (718)398-2440 and the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity (212)288-3215.

MOSS--Lloyd. Brooklyn boy, WQXR announcer, author of "Zin! Zin! Zin! A Violin." Lloyd asked that donations be made in his name to: The Innocence Project, 40 Worth Street, Suite 701, New York, NY 10012 www.innocenceproject.org

McLAUGHLIN--Hon. Joseph M. The Fordham Law community is deeply saddened by the death of former Fordham Law Professor and Dean Hon. Joseph M. McLaughlin, Class of 1959. As a dedicated and beloved professor, a sagacious dean, and an accomplished federal judge, he will be remembered at Fordham for his superb classroom teaching skills, his brilliant case analysis, and the lightning humor he displayed throughout his entire career. A prolific writer, he earned a distinguished reputation for his published legal scholarship on the law of evidence and civil procedure. During his ten-year deanship, he made a number of important contributions to the Law School, including transforming the curriculum, building the financial underpinnings of the school, and augmenting the faculty with more women. In 1981, he was nominated by President Ronald Reagan to serve on the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York and was later nominated for elevation to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Until his retirement, he was one of four Fordham Law alumni serving as a federal judge at the U.S. court of appeals level. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Frances, his three sons Andrew, Joseph (Class of 1988), and Matthew (Class of 1994), his daughter Mary Jo, his daughters-in-law, son-in-law, sister Angela, and 13 grandchildren whom he loved dearly. Michael M. Martin, Dean Fordham Law School

McLAUGHLIN--Judge Joseph. Judge Joseph M. McLaughlin, of Jamaica Estates, NY, on August 8, 2013. Beloved husband to Frances E. Lynch, devoted father to Mary Jo Clines, Joseph, Matthew and Andrew, grandfather to Joseph, Terence and Kira Clines, Kate, Patrick, Emmett, Paul, Joseph, Elizabeth, Aidan, Nolan, Eva and Jillian McLaughlin. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he received an A.B. from Fordham College in 1954, and was a Captain in the United States Army Corps of Engineers from 1955 to 1957. He then received a LL.B. from Fordham University School of Law in 1959, and an LL.M. from New York University School of Law in 1964. He was in private practice of law in New York City from 1959 to 1961. He worked as a law professor at Fordham University School of Law in Manhattan from 1961 to 1971. In 1971, McLaughlin became Dean of Fordham Law School, a position he held for ten years. He served as Chairman of the New York Law Revision Commission from 1975 to 1982. In 1981, he was nominated by President Ronald Reagan to the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York. In 1990, President George H. W. Bush nominated Judge McLaughlin to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. He served in this capacity until 2013. In addition to serving as a Judge, he was an adjunct Professor of Law at St. John's University School of Law and Fordham University School of Law. His publications include numerous works on the law of evidence and civil procedure. Friends may call at Frank. E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st on Saturday and Sunday from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9pm. The funeral will be held at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 10am on Monday. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Judge McLaughlin's name to Ozanam Hall, 42-41 201st Street, Bayside, NY 11361.

LICHTER--George. December 14, 1921-August 2, 2013. Aviator, businessman and philanthropist, died in Boulder, Colorado, August 2, two weeks after being diagnosed with leukemia (AML). Born and raised in Brooklyn, New York, George grew up in a Jewish family with very strong extended family ties. In his childhood, airplanes were the new technology and George, from his earliest years, developed a fascination with flying. After Pearl Harbor, he volunteered for service and qualified for the U.S. Army Air Force pilot training course. He finished his training with distinction and became a fighter pilot of Mustangs and Thunderbolts, as well as of other aircraft. He was initially based in Washington, D.C. as part of the air defense of the capital and then in England, from where he flew 88 combat missions over occupied Europe including air support during the Normandy invasion. After World War II, George worked as a civilian flight instructor and private pilot. Outraged by the holocaust, he was deeply moved by the struggle to create an independent Jewish State. Although he was dubious about the survival of tiny Israel against the superiority of the Arabs, he threw in his lot with the nascent Israeli air arm by becoming one of its first and most important flight instructors. From 1948-1950, he lived in Israel and gave "wings" to the first Israeli pilots, who included the commander of the Israel Air Force during the Six Day War and the chief test pilot in the early decades of the state. Other air force friends went on to high positions in government and industry and included Ezer Weizmann, the late Israeli president. From the early '50s through 1990, George was active in the textile field, where he became a success with the development of Berkeley Mills, a wholesaler of drapery fabrics. He and his life-long friend and colleague, Eugene Towbin, of Boca Raton, Florida, built the business in a very focused manner and through strong customer relationships throughout the United States. After selling the business, George retired in 1995 to Boulder, where he enjoyed the company of eleven family members in three generations. He enjoyed listening to music, especially jazz, and could be moved to tears by a beautiful performance. His charities were diverse and included Jewish and Israeli causes, especially those organizations that advocated for peace and compromise. In the week before he died, George said, "I've had a good long run". His biography is entitled "Ups & Downs With No Regrets" and his story will be part of a film documentary, now in development, on Jewish-American air force volunteers in the 1948 War of Independence. His parents, Ben and Bessie Lichter and his youngest brother, Irwin, pre-deceased him. Survivors include his brother, Jules of Orlando, Florida, and his children John, Peggy and Michael, of Boulder. His former wife, Ishka Lichter, and his dear friend, Bonnie Kaye of New York City, also mourn him deeply. George Lichter died quickly, without suffering, at home, surrounded by loving family members. He had a long, wonderful life and a peaceful death.

KOSSEFF--Jerome, W.,PhD, passed away peacefully on August 1, 2013, after a prolonged illness. He was a World War II veteran and a respected psychoanalyst and educator. Jerome served in the Army Air Forces from 1942-46 as Chief Psychologist, 2nd Central Medical Establishment, 5th Air Force; he administered psychological tests to prospective aviation cadets and, after he was sent to the Pacific theater with a P-38 fighter squadron in 1944, evaluated trauma in combat air crews and treated traumatized service members. He completed service as a 1st lieutenant. After earning his PhD in clinical psychology from New York University, he maintained a private psychoanalytic practice in New York City from 1952-2011, retiring at the age of 92. He was 93 when he retired from his position as an adjunct full professor at Teacher's College at Columbia University after a total of 64 years teaching there. He was a lifelong and generous supporter of young professionals entering the field. He was an innovator in the field of group psychotherapy, particularly by integrating object relations theory into the practice of leading groups. In 1971, he organized a trip to London for an exchange of ideas between British and American psychoanalysts and afterwards began teaching courses in object relation theory. In 1973, he took 16 American therapists to Israel to help with bereavement following the Yom Kippur War; he traveled twice more to Israel to teach. He also volunteered his counseling services at Ground Zero to help those affected by the September 11 attacks. He was deeply involved in professional organizations, particularly the American Group Psychotherapy Association and the Eastern Group Psychotherapy Society (EGPS). In 1970, he founded GROUP, the official journal of EGPS, serving as its editor in chief until 1975. Throughout his career, he continued to contribute to professional publications. Jerome was very proud of his family; he is survived by his wife of 43 years, Elaine, three sons, Peter, Andrew and Christopher and their wives Pam, Nancy and Betty, six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for the future. Contributions may be made to The Nature Conservancy.

KNOWLES--Clayton P.,Jr., 72, a New York entertainment lawyer whose clients included the actress Erin Gray, jazz keyboardist Kim Pensyl, and many 1980s rock groups including Twisted Sister, died on August 5. The cause of death was complications following pneumonia. Clay himself was an accomplished professional musician. Over the years he played guitar and sang at clubs from Greenwich Village to the Upper East Side, and his band played at functions and venues across the city and New Jersey. Clay was a graduate of Montclair High School in Montclair, NJ, Hobart College, Geneva, NY, and New York Law School. He served as a Second Lieutenant in the Army's 1st Air Calvary Division during the Vietnam War, from 1965 to 1966. He was awarded the Bronze Star and Air Medal. Clay always said that his guitar saved his life in Vietnam. While playing for a group of officers when he first arrived there, he caught the attention of an Army colonel who six months later recruited Clay as a liaison officer. Two weeks after Clay started his new job, 16 members of his platoon were killed in an enemy ambush including the lieutenant who replaced him. The tragedy marked Clay for life. Clay was the son of the late Clayton P. Knowles, a reporter for The New York Times, and the late Ruth Knowles, a civic activist. He is survived by his wife, Renata Renner Knowles, an industrial minerals consultant, his brother, Jeffrey Knowles, a lawyer in Washington, D.C., and his sister, Laurie Knowles, a lawyer in Santa Fe, NM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Fender Music Foundation, which provides instruments to music education programs. The foundation's website is fendermusicfoundation.org.
KALB--Philip, 89, devoted husband of Alma, father to Sara and Robert (Marianne), poppop to Jake, Ben and Elle, and bibliophile. Contributions in his honor to New York Public Library.

HUNTER--Henry H.,age 91, died peacefully in Connecticut on July 18, 2013. He was a public relations executive and consultant in New York and Connecticut, and a resident of North Palm Beach, Florida. During World War II he served two tours as a marine in the Pacific, including the capture and defense of Guadalcanal and the Philippines. Following the war he graduated with honors from the Journalism School at the University of Missouri. After working in public relations for Ross Roy and Grant Advertising, he joined Olin in New York in 1954 as publicity manager, and became vice president for public relations in 1965. He is survived by his wife Eunice, two children, Henry Hunter Jr. and Alison Potter, three stepchildren and eleven grandchildren. His infectious sense of humor, peerless storytelling ability, and gentlemanly charm will be missed by his loving family and countless friends. Memorial contributions may be made to Lost Tree Charitable Foundation, 11520 Lost Tree Way, North Palm Beach, FL.

GORDON--Harley. David, Philippa, and Neil Gordon are sad to announce that their father Harley, known as Boetie, died quietly and peacefully in his sleep on August 8th, 2013 at the age of 89. Our father's life was one of deep commitment to his high and unwaveringly progressive political and ethical ideals, from his early anti-Apartheid activism to his lifelong professional commitment, as a physician, to the medical care of poor and underserved children in South Africa, Britain, and New York; steadfast dedication to his wife of nearly 70 years, the writer Sheila Gordon, who predeceased him by three months; boundless kindness and generosity to his children, his children-in-law Ken and Esin, and his grandchildren Sophie, Leila, Annie, Jacob, and Eve; and fidelity to a lifetime of close friends. Services will be private, and our father has requested no flowers. The family will be sitting Shiva on Thursday, August 15, from 4:00 to 8:00pm at 295 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201.

EGER--Edith "Bubs" Seclow, died August 9, 2013 of cancer at her home in Morristown, NJ. Born into a family of freethinking secular Jews in 1919, she embraced "feminist" principals long before the word was invented. She was an unabashed and unapologetic liberal who supported civil and human rights. Her moral compass always pointed true North. Though always refined, she had big opinions and a small ego. She did not suffer fools and endeavored to be informed and learn until the end. She loved her New York Times and New Yorker. Surviving are her sons, Richard and Jeffrey Eger, brother Richard "Dick" Seclow, grandchildren Erik, Asa and Jayna, great-grandson Niko, niece and nephew Theresa and Tom Seclow and all their spouses, extended family and friends. In lieu of flowers, tax-deductible contributions may be sent to the Morris Country Park Commission, P.O. Box 1295, Morristown, NJ 07962 to support the Marvin and Edith Eger Fern Garden at the Frelinghuysen Arboretum. Services will be private.

DOUGLAS--Albert R.,served in the US Navy (LtJG) and Harvard class of '42, died on July 27, 2013. He served in World War II, which included piloting torpedo bombers from the escort carrier USS Savo Island. While flying reconnaissance at US landings at Leyte Gulf in the Philippines, he discovered a major Japanese fleet trying to sneak up on the landings. The major U.S. fleet had been lured well to the north to attack the major Japanese ships not realizing that the Japanese carrier planes had all been destroyed. That left the US escort carriers at Leyte to fight off the unexpected Japanese fleet by themselves. It is a dramatic and successful episode in U.S. Naval history. After having discovered the Japanese fleet, Douglas made it back to his carrier with all of his crew. Later at Leyte he was on a mission over Cebu Island when his plane was severely shot up, including its steering control. He was able to nurse the fifty foot plane back to the carrier safely with all three crew members. Douglas said he was most concerned the plane would catch fire. The plane was so badly riddled with bullet holes that it was promptly thrown overboard. For his service he was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal. Douglas was born on September 23, 1920 to Major Richard and Madeleine Dabo Douglas. He graduated from the Kent School in Connecticut in 1938 and from Harvard with a BA degree in 1942. He then enlisted in the Navy and underwent flight training as carrier pilot in Florida, and then on a training deck built for the Navy into Lake Michigan near Chicago. After the war he remained in the Navy for a time, flying virtually every kind of propeller plane in the Navy while ferrying VIP's. After leaving the Navy he worked as a stock broker and investment advisor with E.F. Hutton, among others. He continued this work until his death. Most recently he has been affiliated with A.J. Weed & Co. and R.M Stark & Co. He and his wife Celeste Murray Bartlett Douglas, known to family and friends as Murray, lived in Manhattan with a second home in Old Chatham, New York. They have been married since June 14, 1963. Mrs. Douglas was the chief designer and part owner of the famous fabric and wallpaper house of Brunschwig et Fils. Mr. and Mrs. Douglas were active in The Shaker Museum & Library, where Mrs. Douglas was a long time board member, and the Old Chatham Hunt Club. Mr. Douglas was a sixty-eight year member of the Harvard Club of New York. Albert Douglas is survived by his wife, Murray Douglas, and his step-son Francis Russel Lyons of Seattle, WA. He is also survived by his brother-in-law, Keith Lockhart of San Rafael, California and Mr. Douglas's nephews, Frank Lockhart of Olympia, WA and Douglas Lockhart of Napa, CA. His sister Jean Lockhart, MD died in 2011. A time for family and friends to share together memories of Albert's life will be held August 10, 2013, at 1pm at the Douglas's house, the School House, at the corner of County Route 13 and Ford Rd in Old Chatham, NY. Interment of his ashes will take place at a date still to be determined.

CONKLIN--David A.,of Naples, FL (formerly of Oldwick, NJ) died Thursday, July 25, 2013 at the age of 82. He was a graduate of NYU/Polytechnic in '52 and '59 with degrees in Chemical Engineering. In 1952 he joined Merck & Co., Inc. where he worked for 43 years. From 1955 1957, David served with the Dept. of Biological Research at Walter Reed Army Institute of Research. He returned to Merck & Co., Inc., and rose through the ranks of management becoming the first President of Merck Chemical Manufacturing Division. To end his career he became Senior Vice President of Science and Technology. David served as Chairman of the National Coalition for Advanced Manufacturing (NACFAM) and Chairman of Capital Improvements Campaign for the Puerto Rican Family Institute. Other memberships included Polytechnic University, Panlabs International, and the National Action Committee for Minorities in Engineering (NACME). He is survived by his wife, Ruth, his daughters Dana (Marco) Conklin-Malusa and Diana (Joseph) Lapierre, step children Christopher (Kristen) Haussman and Audrey(Matthew) Largen and 10 grandchildren. He was preceded in death by a daughter, Dale Durney. A memorial service will be held October 12, 2013, at 11:00am at Zion Lutheran Church, 56 Old Turnpike Rd., in Oldwick, NJ. BERTHOLD--Ruth P. 88. Died peacefully on July 26, 2013. Loving wife, mother, grandmother and sister. Daughter of Abraham L. and Hazel Stern Kaufman of Haverstraw, NY. Ruth served honorably as an Army Nurse on the S.S. Hope Hospital ship during WWII. She devoted 38 years to nursing and public health. Ruth retired to her vegetable garden in Old Tappan in 1979 and traveled the world with her husband Arthur, who died in April. Ruth is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, David and Nancy, grandchildren, David, Anna, Michael, Madeline, two sisters-in-law Louise O'Brien and Helen Berthold. Private interment at Hackensack Cemetery, New Jersey.

BERGER--Elizabeth, Elizabeth Berger was a great civic leader and champion of Lower Manhattan. As the President of the Alliance for Downtown New York and President of the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association she helped shape the reimagining and rebuilding of Lower Manhattan after the 9/11 attacks and recently led an effort to assist Lower Manhattan businesses and residents recover from the effects of Superstorm Sandy. She died on August 5th at Bellevue Hospital Center. She turned 53 this past Saturday. Under Ms. Berger's leadership, the Alliance and the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association successfully advocated for full funding and timely completion of the Fulton Street Transit Center, the reconstruction of Fiterman Hall and the enactment of post-9/11 commercial leasing incentives. Rather than focus on the district as the location of a terrible tragedy, Ms. Berger, renowned for her indefatigable energy and exacting intellect, was driven by a vision of Lower Manhattan as a place teeming with vitality and potential and a proving ground for municipal innovation. "Liz Berger's passion, sophistication and drive shaped Lower Manhattan as surely as any skyscraper or bulldozer," said Robert R. Douglass the Chairman of the Alliance for Downtown New York and the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association. "Her strength as an advocate and strategist was only exceeded by her loyalty as a friend and her dedication as a mother and wife. She will be sorely missed." Elizabeth Harrie Berger was born on August 3, 1960 in New York City. Ms. Berger had decades of experience in government, community affairs and strategic planning. Prior to her time with the Alliance she established and built government relations practices at the law firms Lord Day & Lord Barrett Smith and LeBoeuf, Lamb Greene & MacRae and the Law Offices of Claudia Wagner. Ms. Berger is also credited with creating the Department of Government and External Affairs at Lincoln Center. She served as an Assistant Mayoral Representative to the New York City Council during the Koch administration. A graduate of Yale College where she created her own major, The Study of the City, Ms. Berger was also involved with a variety of civic organizations in New York City beyond her professional obligations. She was at various times a board director of The Municipal Art Society, Film Forum, Second Stage Theatre, American Museum of Natural History Planetarium Authority and the New York Building Congress. She was also a mayoral appointee to the board of the Trust for Governors Island. In a statement Mayor Michael Bloomberg said of Ms. Berger "Liz Berger loved our City with passion and gave her great intelligence and inventiveness to New York without reserve. She was more than an advocate for Lower Manhattan, she was a partner in building its future. As new transit hubs, skyscrapers, full access to our waterfront and a fresh vitality emerge downtown, Liz's influences are everywhere to be seen. We shared a vision of Lower Manhattan as a model 21st century business and residential district, and thanks to her tireless work, it's being realized before our eyes. The City mourns the loss of a great civic leader." She is survived by her husband Frederick Kaufman, daughter Phoebe, son Julian, her mother Anita, and brother Gideon. The family will hold a private gathering for immediate family and close friends and a public memorial will be planned for the early fall. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Liz's memory to Film Forum or the Bowery Residents' Committee. For more information contact abreslau@downtownny.com

BASILEVSKY--Nathalie (nee Wrangel), 99, of Cos Cob, CT. Beloved mother of Peter A. Basilevsky and the late Helen A. Basilevsky, grandmother of Alexis P. Basilevsky and Katharine H. Deering and two great-grandchildren. She died peacefully on August 9, 2013. She had a big heart, a sharp intellect and will be missed by all who knew her. Mrs. Basilevsky, born in 1913 in St. Petersburg, Russia, was the last surviving child of Lt. Gen. Baron Peter N. Wrangel and Olga M. Wrangel. She was predeceased by her husband Alexis G. Basilevsky, sister Helene Meyendorff and her brothers Peter and Alexis Wrangel. Baron Wrangel was the last Commander in Chief of the White Army in the Russian Civil War and who, after a long and valiant struggle despite his army being woefully outmanned and undersupplied, engineered the seaborne evacuation of approximately 150,000 soldiers and civilians, including 7,000 children, from the Crimea in November 1920 in the face of overwhelming advancing Bolshevik forces. Funeral Services will be held on Tuesday, August 13, 2013 at St. Mary's Holy Assumption Russian Orthodox Church, 141 Den Road, Stamford, CT at 10:00am followed by burial at the Russian Orthodox Convent of ''Novo-Diveevo'', 100 Smith Road, Nanuet, New York. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to St. Mary's or the Tolstoy Foundation, 104 Lake Road, Valley Cottage, NY 10989.

BARCLAY--Laura (Bilkey). Passed away suddenly on July 3, 2013 at her home in Bovey Tracey, Devon, United Kingdom. Beloved mother of Randell, Brewster and Carey; devoted grandmother of Natsuki, Katherine and Theodore. Predeceased by her husband, George Barclay - the love of her life who led her on an adventure-filled, overseas executive life that included postings in Indonesia, Japan and the United Kingdom, which became their home of over 40 years. Born in New York on October 3, 1932. Graduate of Chapin, Miss Porters's School and Wellesley. Predeceased by her parents Edward Bilkey and Emily Frelinghuysen McFarland; Granddaughter of United States Senator Joseph Frelinghuysen, who served in Congress during the Harding Administration, part of a distinguished American family devoted to public service. "Talk of me as though I was beside you. I loved you so, twas Heaven here with you."

ARRIGHI--Lara Alden, of Bronxville, NY, died on July 31, 2013 at her home in Cotuit, MA after a two-year struggle with angiosarcoma. She was 42. Lara was born on March 17, 1971 in Hinsdale, IL. She graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, and earned a joint B.A. and M.A. in Politics, Economics, Rhetoric, and Law from the University of Chicago, where she won the Mary Jean Mulvaney Scholar-Athlete Award, and an M.B.A. from the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University. After a career in finance, Lara devoted herself to motherhood. Her intellect, disarming sense of humor, and love of play allowed her to effortlessly captivate and engage the creative spirit of her four young children, Luke (7), Frances (5), Mabel (4) and Osborne (2). In addition to her children, Lara is survived by her husband, Dana Arrighi, her parents, Dr. Shakeab and Mrs. Geraldine Alshabkhoun, and her siblings, Tord, Dana, Kris, Natasha and Justin Alden. A memorial mass will be held at the Church of St. Joseph in Bronxville, NY, on August 16, 2013, at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Lara's memory to the Ann and Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago, 225 East Chicago Avenue, Box 4, Chicago, IL 60611 and to Phillips Exeter Academy.
ADLER--Viola. Vi, our beloved friend, bright, great sense of humor. You will always be in our hearts. Annie and Joel

ADLER--Viola. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Viola Adler, and extend sincere condolences to her family. Alan Fischer, President

ADLER--Viola Dudnick. Vi Adler of Sarasota, FL and Greenwich, CT died on August 4 in Greenwich Hospital. Vi was the beautiful, smart, vibrant and beloved wife of John; loving mother of Donna (Ron) Harris of Lake Okoboji, IA, Andy Dudnick of San Francisco, CA, and the late Michael Devon; caring step-mother of Lani Adler and Johnny Adler (Sherri Levine) of New York City; and proud and adored Nana of Josh (Anna) Harris of Chicago, Laura June Dudnick and Bobby Dudnick of San Francisco, Luke Adler Willert and Ryan and Hannah Adler-Levine of New York City. She was the great-grandmother of Cecelia, Oliver and soon-to-be-born namesake Violet Harris. Her older sisters, Natalie Deichmiller and Gloria Levine predeceased her, and Natalie's caring daughter Scotte (Paul) Mason loved her "Auntiola." Viola Hope Schlossberg was born on February 23, 1930. She and John both grew up in New Rochelle, NY and were high school and college sweethearts for five years. Next New Year's Eve would have been the 70th Anniversary of their first date. After attending Syracuse University, Vi married Solis (Sy) Dudnick and raised her children in Highland Park, IL. Vi later graduated from Northeastern Illinois University in Chicago and taught for a while. After Vi and John were both divorced, they finally put it together and shared a joyous 31-year marriage. She was a fine tennis player and was especially fond of theatre, bridge, the outdoors and traveling all over the world, when she wasn't spending time with her extended family. Vi wanted her life to be celebrated with a party. It will be held on Saturday, August 24 at Beach Point Club, 900 Rushmore Avenue, Mamaroneck, NY at 11am with lunch following. Unfortunately, Vi suffered from LAM, a rare degenerative genetic lung disease that affects only women. More fortunately, she was a poster girl for LAM as the oldest known survivor of the 1,000 or so LAM patients in North America. The LAM Foundation's Distinguished Benefactor Award is named after her. If you wish to honor Vi, please do so through the LAM Foundation, 4015 Executive Park Drive, Suite 320, Cincinnati, OH 45241.
