MACHOL--Betty F. Kurzman 12/24/1921 - 8/12/2012 My beloved Betty, a year has come and gone. Absence can not change my love nor time void your constant presence. I spend the day, wake up and end it at night remembering the many loving years we spent together. Erwin

WEINSTEIN--Burton, on August 9, at age 87. Devoted husband, parent, grandparent, brother, World War II veteran, engineer, entrepreneur, pilot, sailor, fisherman, and a man of extraordinary kindness, patience, humility and optimism. Inventor of countless skiing, boating and woodworking devices. Proud member of the City Island and New York Yacht Clubs. Survived by his loving wife of 37 years, Carolyn Weinstein; stepdaughters, Jacquelyn and Gwendolyn Wong; sons-in-law Serge Michaut and Neil Wertheimer; grandchildren Davis and Lucas Wertheimer; brother and sister-in-law Gerald and Alice Weinstein; and many loving nieces and nephews. Funeral at 11am, Tuesday, August 13, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan.

WALCH--Margaret. A life-long New Yorker, Margaret Walch died peacefully in her Manhattan apartment on Saturday, August 10, 2013. In addition to being an adored mother, daughter, grandmother, sister, sister-in-law, mother-in-law, cousin, aunt, niece, and friend, she was the former director of the Color Association of the United States. A memorial for friends and family will take place this week.

SHERR--Daniel Alan, born 1959, remembered as 'the intrepid adventurer.' He died July 27, 2013 at his home in Roxbury New York. He was the beloved husband of Elizabeth Mayhall Sherr and loving son of Anne Nevard Sherr. His father, S. Irving Sherr, predeceased him in 2012. He leaves his brother Robert Sherr, his sister-in-law Deborah and his nephews Bruno and Chris of New Jersey. He loved his many aunts, uncles, and cousins. As an avid open boater, Danny canoed over 100,000 miles of rivers and supported The American Whitewater Association. He documented his experiences through journaling and illustrations. Danny shared the love of golf with his father. He graduated from Emory University and studied urban planning at UT Austin. Danny devoted himself to discovering new music by playing the guitar and archiving garage rock. He was a staunch believer in Israel. Danny was a founding underwriter of WIOX radio station in Roxbury.

RESNIK--Regina. The board and staff of the Metropolitan Opera Guild and Opera News are saddened by the death of Regina Resnik. A major international artist, Regina served on the board of the Guild since 1986, and was an enthusiastic supporter of all of our programs. Our deepest sympathies go to her brother Jack, her son, Michael, and his partner, Alberto. Winthrop Rutherfurd, Jr., Chairman Richard J. Miller, Jr., President Stewart Pearce, Managing Director

MOSER--Belle, 90, died on August 9, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Alexander Moser. A daughter of immigrants to this land, she enriched the lives of her family and friends with the bright colors of her paintings which reflected her love of the natural world and traced a full life, from a childhood in Brooklyn to many summers spent in the Adirondack Mountains. She will always be deeply loved and is survived by sons Nathan, Franklin and Joel, daughters-in-law Rita, Caroline and Wednesday and grandchildren Rachel, Allison, Michelle, Steven, Claire, Julia, Alexandra, Katharine, Eliot and Lyle. Donations in her memory can be made to the 92Y Art School.

McLAUGHLIN--Hon. Joseph M. The Fordham Law community is deeply saddened by the death of former Fordham Law Professor and Dean Hon. Joseph M. McLaughlin, Class of 1959. As a dedicated and beloved professor, a sagacious dean, and an accomplished federal judge, he will be remembered at Fordham for his superb classroom teaching skills, his brilliant case analysis, and the lightning humor he displayed throughout his entire career. A prolific writer, he earned a distinguished reputation for his published legal scholarship on the law of evidence and civil procedure. During his ten-year deanship, he made a number of important contributions to the Law School, including transforming the curriculum, building the financial underpinnings of the school, and augmenting the faculty with more women. In 1981, he was nominated by President Ronald Reagan to serve on the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York and was later nominated for elevation to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Until his retirement, he was one of four Fordham Law alumni serving as a federal judge at the U.S. court of appeals level. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Frances, his three sons Andrew, Joseph (Class of 1988), and Matthew (Class of 1994), his daughter Mary Jo, his daughters-in-law, son-in-law, sister Angela, and 13 grandchildren whom he loved dearly. Michael M. Martin, Dean Fordham Law School

McLAUGHLIN--Judge Joseph. Judge Joseph M. McLaughlin, of Jamaica Estates, NY, on August 8, 2013. Beloved husband to Frances E. Lynch, devoted father to Mary Jo Clines, Joseph, Matthew and Andrew, grandfather to Joseph, Terence and Kira Clines, Kate, Patrick, Emmett, Paul, Joseph, Elizabeth, Aidan, Nolan, Eva and Jillian McLaughlin. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he received an A.B. from Fordham College in 1954, and was a Captain in the United States Army Corps of Engineers from 1955 to 1957. He then received a LL.B. from Fordham University School of Law in 1959, and an LL.M. from New York University School of Law in 1964. He was in private practice of law in New York City from 1959 to 1961. He worked as a law professor at Fordham University School of Law in Manhattan from 1961 to 1971. In 1971, McLaughlin became Dean of Fordham Law School, a position he held for ten years. He served as Chairman of the New York Law Revision Commission from 1975 to 1982. In 1981, he was nominated by President Ronald Reagan to the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York. In 1990, President George H. W. Bush nominated Judge McLaughlin to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. He served in this capacity until 2013. In addition to serving as a Judge, he was an adjunct Professor of Law at St. John's University School of Law and Fordham University School of Law. His publications include numerous works on the law of evidence and civil procedure. Friends may call at Frank. E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st on Saturday and Sunday from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9pm. The funeral will be held at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 10am on Monday. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Judge McLaughlin's name to Ozanam Hall, 42-41 201st Street, Bayside, NY 11361.

LEIGH--Sandy. A gentleman and loving husband. Rest in peace. Martha Schwartz
LEIGH--Sanford. I'll find you in the morning sun; And when the night is new, I'll be looking at the moon, But I'll be seeing you. To Sheppy, my beloved husband. Nothing will ever be the same.

LEIGH--Sanford, our dear Sandy, died Thursday, August 8 to our dismay. The Willinger family will sorely miss him. He remains forever in our hearts, never to be replaced. Aunt Barbara, Uncle Hans, cousins Elise and Gavin.
LEIGH--Sanford. Beloved son for 32 years. Wonderful husband to daughter Karen. We will always miss you. Love, Mom and Sy

LANE--Linda, We are heartbroken by the loss of Linda, our dear friend of over 60 years. Life will never be the same without you. Our deepest sympathy to Jules, and the entire family. With Love, Ellie and Marty

FATES-TESSIER--Margery Gerdes. August 3, 2013 at Greenport, NY. Beloved wife of John S. Tessier, daughter of the late John and Theodora Gerdes of New York, sister of the late Janet G. Short. Children are D. Livingston Miller, Jr. of Greenwich, CT, Alexandra M. Howard of Laurel Hollow, NY, John's Island, FL and Courtlandt G. Miller of Palm Beach, FL. Grandmother of five, great-grandmother of nine. Mrs. FatesTessier graduated from the Chapin School, Vassar College and Yale Law School. She was a member of the NY Bar. Chairman of Radiology Volunteers at Huntington Hospital and a volunteer public defender for the Family Court in Westbury, NY. Former member of the Piping Rock Club, Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club, North Country Garden Club, and Life Member of the Colony Club and Colonial Dames of America. Active member St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY and sang in the church choir, which she and her late husband, Dudley L. Miller, founded in the early 50's. Services at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. on October 26, 3pm. In lieu of flowers, please donate to St. John's Church PO Box 266 Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724.

BASILEVSKY--Nathalie (nee Wrangel), 99, of Cos Cob, CT. Beloved mother of Peter A. Basilevsky and the late Helen A. Basilevsky, grandmother of Alexis P. Basilevsky and Katharine H. Deering and two great-grandchildren. She died peacefully on August 9, 2013. She had a big heart, a sharp intellect and will be missed by all who knew her. Mrs. Basilevsky, born in 1913 in St. Petersburg, Russia, was the last surviving child of Lt. Gen. Baron Peter N. Wrangel and Olga M. Wrangel. She was predeceased by her husband Alexis G. Basilevsky, sister Helene Meyendorff and her brothers Peter and Alexis Wrangel. Baron Wrangel was the last Commander in Chief of the White Army in the Russian Civil War and who, after a long and valiant struggle despite his army being woefully outmanned and undersupplied, engineered the seaborne evacuation of approximately 150,000 soldiers and civilians, including 7,000 children, from the Crimea in November 1920 in the face of overwhelming advancing Bolshevik forces. Funeral Services will be held on Tuesday, August 13, 2013 at St. Mary's Holy Assumption Russian Orthodox Church, 141 Den Road, Stamford, CT at 10:00am followed by burial at the Russian Orthodox Convent of ''Novo-Diveevo'', 100 Smith Road, Nanuet, New York. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to St. Mary's or the Tolstoy Foundation, 104 Lake Road, Valley Cottage, NY 10989.

ARRIGHI--Lara Alden, of Bronxville, NY, died on July 31, 2013 at her home in Cotuit, MA after a two-year struggle with angiosarcoma. She was 42. Lara was born on March 17, 1971 in Hinsdale, IL. She graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, and earned a joint B.A. and M.A. in Politics, Economics, Rhetoric, and Law from the University of Chicago, where she won the Mary Jean Mulvaney Scholar-Athlete Award, and an M.B.A. from the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University. After a career in finance, Lara devoted herself to motherhood. Her intellect, disarming sense of humor, and love of play allowed her to effortlessly captivate and engage the creative spirit of her four young children, Luke (7), Frances (5), Mabel (4) and Osborne (2). In addition to her children, Lara is survived by her husband, Dana Arrighi, her parents, Dr. Shakeab and Mrs. Geraldine Alshabkhoun, and her siblings, Tord, Dana, Kris, Natasha and Justin Alden. A memorial mass will be held at the Church of St. Joseph in Bronxville, NY, on August 16, 2013, at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Lara's memory to the Ann and Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago, 225 East Chicago Avenue, Box 4, Chicago, IL 60611 and to Phillips Exeter Academy.
ADLER--Viola. Vi, our beloved friend, bright, great sense of humor. You will always be in our hearts. Annie and Joel

A bond made up of subprime mortgages was created by Goldman Sachs in 2007 as an investment vehicle. But many of those loans went into default right away and the bond has been toxic ever since. Still, 10 percent of the loans are actually larger than they started out, an indication that the loan is stressed, while the other 90 percent have shrunk as they have been modified and/or paid down.

WEIL--Barbara (Harnett), passed away peacefully on August 11th. Cherished wife of the late Kenneth. Adored mother of Michael and Emily, Marjorie and Kenneth Jahre, Nancy and Dennis Gottfried. STUTZEL--Dr. William M.,on August 11, 2013. Loving husband to the late Carole Knopf and beloved son of the late Louis and Esther. Proud U.S. Army Veteran. Dentist and Professor at NYU Dental School. Funeral service at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 Second Ave. Tuesday, August 13, 10:30am.

STEIN--Sheila Smith, of Bronxville, NY, died August 10, 2013 after a courageous battle with cancer. She was 76 years old. A native Minnesotan and graduate of University of Minnesota, she has lived and served in the Bronxville community for 40 years. Elected Mayor of Bronxville in 1987, she served six terms until 1993. She ran for New York State Assembly on the Republican ticket in 1994. Sheila was a wonderful wife, mother, grandmother and friend. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Martin (Fritz) Stein Jr. and their six children and 14 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, August 15 at 2:00pm at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Maxwell Institute, 92 Yonkers Avenue, Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

RUSSELL--Richard Lee (Dick), aged 83, died August 10, 2013 after a long illness. Husband, father, lawyer and golfer (not necessarily in that order), he was the son of Sol A. Rosenblatt and Elizabeth Block Russell. He is survived by his wife, Diane de Coppet and four children, sons Robert S. Russell and Thomas W. Russell and daughters Tracy R. Evers and Melanie de Coppet. He was preceded in death by daughter Pamela W. McKee. He is also survived by his brother, Robert A. Russell, and three grandchildren, Alexander Duvoisin, Audrey Russell, and Natalie Russell. A lifelong New Yorker, Mr. Russell grew up in Great Neck, New York. A graduate of the University of Colorado at Boulder, he served as a bomber and test pilot in the US Air Force during the Korean War, ending his military career as a Major. After his service, Mr. Russell returned to New York to attend Columbia University Law School. He had a long, varied and distinguished legal career, practicing Family and Trust and Estates law, working as an accomplished litigator, and spending his final decades as a highly distinguished Banking and Securities attorney. A world traveler, Mr. Russell also claimed to have visited every state in the United States. He loved and cared for his family, protected and partnered with his clients, and passionately pursued excellence in golf. Mr. Russell's membership at the Sands Point Golf Club was the longest in that club's history. And while life in New York City let him attain his childhood dream of a concrete front lawn, there was one other place that Mr. Russell liked as much: his second home in Kiawah Island, South Carolina, where he could be challenged by a different, beautiful and difficult golf course every day. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to St. Bernard's School at 4 East 98th Street in New York City. A memorial service will be held in New York during the Fall.

ROSENBERG--Marion, 73, on August 10, 2013. The late Harry's cherished wife, Marisa and Robert's incomparable, irreplaceable mom and David and Laurie's amazing mother-in-law. World's most fantabulous Nana to Hannah, Emma, Harry and Avery. The late Hardie's kid sister and adored aunt of Amy, Damon and Joanna. Instant friend and inspiration to everyone. Service: Tuesday, August 13, 2013, 11:45am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of (fresh) flowers, donations in her memory may be made in honor of Marion Rosenberg to Long Island Jewish Hospital for Oncology Valet Parking.
RESNIK--Regina. We are greatly saddened by the passing of Regina Resnik. She will be sorely missed by us and her many other friends and colleagues at The Mannes Opera. Eugenia and David Ames

RESNIK--Regina. The Hunter College community mourns the loss of a great artist and distinguished alumna. A trustee emerita of the Hunter College Foundation, Regina provided our community with a wealth of insight and support. Her extraordinary life story of public education, hard work and success will continue to serve as an inspiration to the many Hunter College students who follow in her footsteps. Our heartfelt condolences to her son, Michael and her entire family. A memorial will be held at Hunter College in the fall. Jennifer J. Raab, President, Hunter College, Lisa Witten, Chair, Hunter College Foundation

McLAUGHLIN--Hon. Joseph M. On behalf of the Judges, Magistrate Judges and all the Eastern District of New York family, we wish to express our sorrow on the loss of our friend and colleague Judge Joseph M. McLaughlin. We are deeply saddened, and our thoughts go out to his beloved wife Frances and their family. Please accept our sincere condolences.

McLAUGHLIN--Hon. Joseph M. The Fordham Law Alumni Association mourns the death of the Honorable Joseph M. McLaughlin (Class of 1959), gifted professor, brilliant scholar, visionary Dean, and loyal alumnus. Before he ascended to the federal bench where he served with great distinction as a trial and then appeals court judge, he taught and led a generation of Fordham lawyers in whom the laws of evidence and New York practice are engrained. His nimble mind, command of the law, and unmatched wit as a teacher, and his leadership as our Dean, provided the cornerstone on which thousands of us launched and built our careers. He modeled decorum and fairness, and he consistently demonstrated the way humor combined with rapier wit could bring clarity to even the most mundane matters of law. We will long celebrate the contributions of our fellow alumnus as a distinguished jurist and modern-day builder of Fordham Law School. Our deepest sympathies to his wife Frances, daughter Mary Jo, sons Andrew, Joseph (Class of 1988) and Matthew (Class of 1994), and sister Angela. Mark J. Hyland, '80, President Fordham Law Alumni Association

LODGE--Lorraine. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Lorraine Lodge, whose philanthropic family was deeply committed to helping millions of people in need and strengthening the Jewish community. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Lorraine's husband, Steven; sister, Susan Efron; brother-in-law, Paul; and parents, Don and Tosia Gringer, during this difficult time. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO
LANGSTON--DORIS. Died August 5, 2013 in her Bronx home at age 97. For a program with date and time of burial this week please visit http://bit.ly/D--T--L

LAND--Leslie, 66, of Cushing, ME, and Pleasant Valley, NY, died August 10 due to complications from metastatic breast cancer. Champion of country cooking, ambitious gardener, and, in her own words, "the latest in a long line of garden advisers that stretches back, approximately, to Adam, who we can be sure was frequently asked about the niceties of apple culture." In her syndicated "Good Food" column, four books, scores of magazine articles, and 400 Garden Q&A columns for the New York Times, Leslie wrote about food and gardening with wit and authority. She cooked at Chez Panisse in the early 1970s, then decamped for rural Maine where she built a new life as a writer. Leslie published two cookbooks, "Reading Between the Recipes" and "The Modern Country Cook," was an editor at Yankee magazine, and co-wrote "The 3,000 Mile Garden," which became a PBS series. She also edited "1000 Gardening Questions and Answers," based on the New York Times column. Leslie leaves her husband, Bill Bakaitis, daughter Celia, granddaughter Ursula, sister Claudia, brother David, a niece, two nephews, and countless friends she inspired to love gardening, good food, and life.

HERZ--Shirley. Broadway was her life. She lit up every theater she entered with her big smile. Tirelessly devoted to improving the lot of her union sisters and brothers. We will miss you, Shirley. ATPAM
HERZ--Shirley. With deep appreciation for her wisdom, advice and judgment during many years of dedicated service as an officer of the Foundation. The Dorothy Strelsin Foundation

HERZ--Shirley. She helped light up Broadway by her skillful and devoted representation of her many theatrical clients, just as she enriched my life by our mutual friendship and sincere love. I will miss her enormously. Sam Altman

HERZ--Shirley, publicist and human dynamo at age 87. Her radiant smile will be missed by all. HERZ--Shirley. You were my family. You were there for me every step of the way as I was building my theatrical career. You stepped up to the plate so many times for me. And as the four decades followed, we became a team that watched over each other. I will always remember and admire your passion for the theatre, your unselfish love, your amazing loyalty and your integrity. You showed me how to follow through on what was right and never to compromise our standards, no matter what. You were one of the most honorable people I ever had the great fortune of knowing. You will always be alive in my heart and those who knew you will continue to follow your bright star that always watched over us. You gave new meaning to The Best of Times, and were they ever! Jon Wilner
HERZ--Shirley. A dear friend who will be greatly missed and always remembered. Enid and Corinne Nemy

ETTINGER--Dina. The Board of Directors, officers, and staff of American Friends of Tel Aviv University are deeply saddened by the loss of our cherished friend and Board member, Dina Ettinger. The vision and longtime commitment she and her late husband shared -- including the establishment of Ettinger Hall and the Yona and Dina Ettinger Chair in Contemporary History of the Middle East -- helped shape the study of Middle Eastern life and culture at TAU. Her sweetness and warmth will be greatly missed. We extend deepest sympathies to her daughters, Tamar Rudich and Ruth Rifkin, her grandchildren and great grandchildren, and the entire family. COUTURE--Jerold L.,on August 12, 2013. Survived by his wife Susan, children Natasha and Tanya; Peter, David, Richard and Alison; his twin brother Jim, his sister Susan, and 11 grandchildren. Service private.

BROWNSTEIN--Robert, of Stamford, CT and Sarasota, FL died Friday of a heart attack at 88. Loving and devoted husband of Laura and father to David, Peter and Jason. His wit, intelligence and love will be missed.

BARASCH--George, died on August 11, 2013 at the age of 102. He lived a long and illustrious life. After graduating from St. John's University and School of Law, he became involved in the labor movement and was the Founder and President of the Allied Trades Council and Principal Officer of Local 815, International Brotherhood of Teamsters. He created many employee benefit funds including the Union Mutual Pension Plan, the Allied Welfare Health Plan, and the Vacation Fringe Benefit Fund. He founded the Union Mutual Benefit Retiree Association and created the Union Mutual Foundation and the Union Mutual Medical Fund to provide educational and medical benefits for retired union workers. Until the time of his death he remained active as the Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Allied Educational Foundation, a charitable and educational foundation. During his illustrious and productive career, he served as Research Professor of Management at Stevens Institute of Technology, President of the New York Cardiac Center, Labor Consultant to the Queens County District Attorney, Director of the Queens County Crime Prevention Board and Member of the Honor Legion of the New York Police Department. He also served as the editor of the "Unity News" and the "Cardiac Journal." His work in the fields of education and medicine has been recognized with achievement awards from the New York Cardiological Society, Colum- bia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, Accuracy in Media, the Washington Legal Foundation, Stevens Institute of Technology and the Korean Association of New York. He is survived by his loving family: Stephen and Charlene Barasch, Linda and Richard Glazer, Jayne and Bernard Troy as well as four grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. Sally, his loving wife of 67 years, predeceased him. He will be remembered with great fondness by all who had the pleasure of knowing him and will remain in our hearts forever. Services will be held today at Eden Memorial Chapels, 327 Main Street, Fort Lee, NJ 07024 at 12:30pm.

BACHRACH--Ruth. Ruth Bachrach, born July 8, 1918 in Frankfurt, Germany, found a home in New York City after fleeing Nazi Germany during World War II. After marrying Howard H. Bachrach and raising two daughters, she earned a Master's Degree in Sociology from The New School and went on to teach at Brooklyn College and Lehman College. In addition to her passion for learning, she loved music, art, ballet, and theatre which she regularly enjoyed with her many friends and family. She died on August 12, 2013 at the age of 95. She will always be remembered with love and admiration by her two daughters, Judy and Marion; her four grandchildren, Noah and Sam Seifman and Jeremy and Rachel Siegfried; and her two sons-in-law, Richard Seifman and Jonathan Siegfried. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation or other Alzheimer's research. The family will receive friends at 130 East End Avenue on Thursday, August 15, from 5pm to 9pm.

ALAYETO--George I. of Westfield died on Saturday August 10, 2013 surrounded by his loved ones. He is now reunited in heaven with his wife Gloria F. Alayeto, honorary life member of the Westfield Red Cross. Gloria was the love of George's life. Visiting today from 6-9pm at the Dooley Colonial Home, 556 Westfield Ave., Westfield, NJ. Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Wednesday at 11am at Holy Trinity Church, Westfield with Interment following at Fairview Cemetery, Westfield. Born in Cuba, he emigrated to the United States and settled in Westfield in 1961. He was senior Executive Vice President of The Connell Company in Berkley Heights doing international business and trade for 49 years retiring January 2011. Then, He was President and CEO of Alafer LLC. Surviving are his son Dr. Nelson Trujillo of Washington D.C.; six grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren. Memorial contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Westfield Rescue Squad. Please visit www.dooleycolonialfuneralhome for more information.

YAVARKOVSKY--Rose. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of Rose Yavarkovsky, of blessed memory, wife of the late beloved, Solomon Yavarkosky, of blessed memory. Cardozo School of Law, the Wurzweiler School of Social Work and the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. She also was an active leader of the Yeshiva University Women's Organization where she was a member of the Executive Council. May her memory be a source of blessings to all her loved ones. May the entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

STEIN--Sheila Smith, of Bronxville, NY, died August 10, 2013 after a courageous battle with cancer. She was 76 years old. A native Minnesotan and graduate of University of Minnesota, she has lived and served in the Bronxville community for 40 years. Elected Mayor of Bronxville in 1987, she served six terms until 1993. She ran for New York State Assembly on the Republican ticket in 1994. Sheila was a wonderful wife, mother, grandmother and friend. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Martin (Fritz) Stein Jr. and their six children and 14 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, August 15 at 2:00pm at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Maxwell Institute, 92 Yonkers Avenue, Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

STAMBERG--Frank L.,90, of Stamford, CT, died on August 9, 2013, at Stamford Hospital. He was a retired Group Vice President and a member of the Board of Directors of Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc. He maintained residences in Stamford, CT and Palm City, FL. A golf and squash enthusiast, he was a member and Past Governor of the Greenwich Country Club and Harbour Ridge Yacht & Country Club. He and his late wife, Barbara Bushman Stamberg, were married in 1948 and lived in Greenwich until his move to Edgehill in 2000. He is survived by his children Susan S. Schnoor of Hurlock, MD, Frank L. Stamberg Jr. of Riverside, CT, and Barbara S. McCarthy (Bob) of Ridgefield, as well as three grandsons, Justin Lawless of Columbia, MD, and Jack and Paul McCarthy of Ridgefield, CT. His daughter, Amie D. Stamberg, predeceased him. The immediate family will hold a private memorial service. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society in his name by visiting: www.nationalmssociety.org

SARNOFF--Irving, passed away on August 11, 2013. A professor emeritus of Psychology at NYU, Irv was married to his beloved wife Suzanne for 61 years until her death five years ago. He is survived by his son David (Pepper), daughter Sara (Jeffrey Palmer), four grandchildren, and one great-grandson. Graveside funeral August 15 at 2:00pm at the Sandisfield Cemetery on Rte 57 in Sandisfield, MA. Omit flowers.

RUSSELL--Richard, "Dick" 1930-2013, passed away on Saturday, August 10th. Our lawyer, our advisor, our role model, our idol and our friend. A gentleman with steely eyes, fierce determination and an immense love for his family and friends. We miss you already. Diego and Maria Ball, Juan and Florence Ball, Pablo and Cecilia Stalman

RUSSELL--Richard Lee (Dick), aged 83, died August 10, 2013 after a long illness. Husband, father, lawyer and golfer (not necessarily in that order), he was the son of Sol A. Rosenblatt and Elizabeth Block Russell. He is survived by his wife, Diane de Coppet and four children, sons Robert S. Russell and Thomas W. Russell and daughters Tracy R. Evers and Melanie de Coppet. He was preceded in death by daughter Pamela W. McKee. He is also survived by his brother, Robert A. Russell, and three grandchildren, Alexander Duvoisin, Audrey Russell, and Natalie Russell. A lifelong New Yorker, Mr. Russell grew up in Great Neck, New York. A graduate of the University of Colorado at Boulder, he served as a bomber and test pilot in the US Air Force during the Korean War, ending his military career as a Major. After his service, Mr. Russell returned to New York to attend Columbia University Law School. He had a long, varied and distinguished legal career, practicing Family and Trust and Estates law, working as an accomplished litigator, and spending his final decades as a highly distinguished Banking and Securities attorney. A world traveler, Mr. Russell also claimed to have visited every state in the United States. He loved and cared for his family, protected and partnered with his clients, and passionately pursued excellence in golf. Mr. Russell's membership at the Sands Point Golf Club was the longest in that club's history. And while life in New York City let him attain his childhood dream of a concrete front lawn, there was one other place that Mr. Russell liked as much: his second home in Kiawah Island, South Carolina, where he could be challenged by a different, beautiful and difficult golf course every day. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to St. Bernard's School at 4 East 98th Street in New York City. A memorial service will be held in New York during the Fall.
LUCKS--Harvey. Dear Harriet, I am greatly saddened by your loss. You have been the dearest and most wonderful friend to me. I extend my deepest sympathy to you. Elyse.

LUCKS--Harvey Chester. We mourn the passing of this fine man, who embodied empathy, strength and intellect. Howard and Joan Ballon Carla and Mick Gorrell Hilary Ballon and Orin Kramer

LUCKS--Harvey Chester, in New York City on August 12, 2013, age 89. Harvey was the beloved husband of Harriet Ballon and the late Edythe M. Lucks. He was a loving father of Susan and Stuart (Sara), adored grandfather of Philip (Kate), Eva, Daniel and great-grandfather of little Stuart. For over 40 years Harvey was President of Long Island Tinsmith Supply, founded by his father Philip in 1918. He was an inspiration to all employees, loved sailing, history, business strategy, politics and was a legendary storyteller. Harvey graduated Lehigh University in 1947 in Mechanical Engineering. He served in the US Army in the Southern Pacific during WWII. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Lehigh University Scholarship Fund www.mylehigh.edu/makeagift Funeral service on Thursday at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Burial will be private.

LITT--Judith L.,81, of Rye, NY, beloved mother, grandmother and friend, gifted artist, avid bicyclist, traveler, reader and passionate lover of life, passed away on Monday, August 12, 2013 in Cleveland after a courageous battle with ovarian cancer. Mrs. Litt was born in New York, NY, to Milton and Tessie Lasser on May 14, 1932. She was a member of the class of 1950 at Mamaroneck High School, and of the class of 1954 at Skidmore College, where she was a student of Robert Davidson. She married Mark D. Litt, a native of New York City, a longtime partner of the Wall Street firm of Asiel & Co., and member of the New York Stock Exchange, on September 12, 1954. Mr. and Mrs. Litt lived for many years in Larchmont, NY, where they were members of Larchmont Temple and enthusiastic boaters who cruised Long Island Sound and the Hudson River as members of the United States Power Squadron. An award-winning artist who specialized in bronze, marble and wood sculptures of animals and portraits of family members, Mrs. Litt continued her studies at Greenwich House Pottery in New York City and at the Westchester Workshop at the County Center in White Plains with Helen Beling and Ruth Nickerson. She exhibited her work in numerous group exhibitions throughout Westchester, winning many prizes including two Beaux-Arts Awards given by The Women's Clubs of Westchester. She charmed customers at Anderson's Bookshop in Larchmont with a sculpture of Brutus, a cat who used to perch in the store's window and sleep on its computer. Mrs. Litt is survived by her husband, Mark Litt, of Rye; her son, Steven Litt, and daughter-in-law Rosalie Litt and their children, Sarah Joy Litt and Elizabeth Simone Litt, of Shaker Heights, OH; her daugher, Helen R. Litt, of Marina del Rey, CA; and her brother, Howard Lasser, of Virginia; sister-in-law, Ruth Lasser, of Rye and sister-in-law Susan McLeod and her husband, Roderick McLeod, of Toronto, ON. A burial service will be held at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, Thursday, August 15 at 10:30am, with Rabbi Mara Nathan of Larchmont Temple officiating. A memorial service will follow at 12 Noon at The Osborn, 101 Theall Rd., in Rye, NY, where Rabbi Nathan will also officiate. The family of Judith L. Litt requests that any donations in her memory be made to Planned Parenthood Hudson Peconic, Inc., or the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York for community center programs in day care. The family wishes to extend sincere thanks to Dr. Robert Debernardo and the nursing staff of the Cleveland Clinic; to Dr. Elizabeth O'Toole and the nursing staff of Judson Park in Cleveland; to Visiting Angels Living Assistance Services, and to care managers Sarah Parran, of Cleveland, and Miriam Zucker of Westchester County, NY.

LEICHTER--Martin, passed away on August 12 at Robert Wood Johnson Hospital in New Brunswick after a 3-year battle with Myelodysplasia. He was 83. Adored husband to Bernice (nee Steigman), beloved father to Steve (Shari) and Suzanne, loving grandfather to Elizabeth, Jack, and Sarah. Marty was born in Brooklyn on April 21, 1930, and attended James Madison High School. He graduated from New York University in 1951, and went on to serve as an Army Sergeant in the Korean War. After the war, he pursued his love of entertainment, working in an earlier era of New York City television and film production. He was the studio manager at Gold Medal Studios in Astoria, and served as production manager on a wide variety of films, including 'Butterfield 8,' and on television shows such as 'Naked City,' 'Car 54, Where Are You?' and 'Man of the House,' the pilot for 'The Dick Van Dyke Show.' He was introduced to his beloved 'Bunny' at a Columbia Pictures screening of 'The Goddess,' where she worked at the time. He left the industry in 1961 to become a New York City schoolteacher. He taught English and Film for over 25 years at Far Rockaway High School, where he served as Dean of Students, and at Susan Wagner High School. He inspired numerous students to pursue their own careers in the entertainment industry. After his retirement, he continued to share his lifelong passion for film and television, serving as an adjunct Professor of Communications at Mercer County College in New Jersey, and as a Featured Lecturer at the Maltz Jupiter Theatre in Florida. He passed along his love of photography, baseball, film, television, and the ability to tie a perfectly dimpled four-in-hand tie knot to his children and grandchildren. His quiet dignity masked a sly sense of humor, and he will be deeply missed by us all. Funeral services will be held graveside at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing on Wednesday, August 14 at 1:30pm. The family will be sitting shiva at 78 Barkers Point Road in Sands Point on Wednesday, August 14 from 5 to 8pm, and on Thursday, August 15 from 1 to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society (www.lls.org).

FATES-TESSIER--Margery Gerdes. August 3, 2013 at Greenport, NY. Beloved wife of John S. Tessier, daughter of the late John and Theodora Gerdes of New York, sister of the late Janet G. Short. BACHRACH--Ruth. Ruth Bachrach, born July 8, 1918 in Frankfurt, Germany, found a home in New York City after fleeing Nazi Germany during World War II. After marrying Howard H. Bachrach and raising two daughters, she earned a Master's Degree in Sociology from The New School and went on to teach at Brooklyn College and Lehman College. In addition to her passion for learning, she loved music, art, ballet, and theatre which she regularly enjoyed with her many friends and family. She died on August 12, 2013 at the age of 95. She will always be remembered with love and admiration by her two daughters, Judy and Marion; her four grandchildren, Noah and Sam Seifman and Jeremy and Rachel Siegfried; and her two sons-in-law, Richard Seifman and Jonathan Siegfried. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation or other Alzheimer's research. The family will receive friends at 130 East End Avenue on Thursday, August 15, from 5pm to 9pm.

YAVARKOVSKY--Rose, 99, passed away on Monday, August 12. Rose held an honorary doctorates degree from Yeshiva University. She was also a benefactor at Yeshiva University. A founder of the Sy Syms School of Business. She was a member of the board of directors of the Women's Organization of Yeshiva University and was a widely known philanthropist. She is survived by her daughter, Mrs. Rhoda Spiegel and her husband Richard, her son Mr. Ira Yavarkovsky and Jerome Yavarkovsky and her grandchildren Mr. Robert Spiegel and his wife Jill and Jeffrey Spiegel and his wife Meredith and eight great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Today at 1pm at Boulevard Riverside Chapel 1450 Broadway in Hewlett, LI.

WINTERS--Fred, 62, passed away on August 13th at the Weill Cornell Medical Center, after failing to recover from a brain hemorrhage. Mr. Winters was born in Queens on January 6, 1951, and graduated from Skidmore College in 1973. He was a Vice President at the strategic communications firm, George Arzt Communications, Inc., since 2003. Mr. Winters also served as Director of Communications for the Bronx Borough President from 2001 until 2003. Mr. Winters was passionate about hockey and was widely known as a die-hard New York Rangers fan. He is survived by his wife, Karen Crowe and his children Jacob, 18, and Grace, 15, his sister Elizabeth, his brother Douglas, stepbrother Robert, stepsister Ellen, and four nieces and six nephews. His funeral will be held on Friday, August 16, 2013, at 2:30pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to a charity of choice.

UNTERMAN--David, M.D.,Dr. Unterman died at 94 on August 13, 2013. Dr. Unterman was a kind and compassionate doctor who believed in quality of life for his patients. He is survived by his beloved wife, Rosalind, his daughter, Ilene (Rick) and his grandchildren, by the late William Unterman (Janet), Jeremy and Sarah. The funeral is at 1:00pm at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Contributions can be made to the Alzheimer's Association or the American Heart Association.

SPECTER--David Kenneth, The Office of Specter DeSouza Architects, PC, expresses our heartfelt condolences to David's wife Patricia Brown Specter, his sons and family on the loss of our founder and mentor, David Kenneth Specter, AIA. Ronald A. DeSouza, AIA

SPECTER--David Kenneth. David Kenneth Specter, AIA, Architect, 82, of New York City and Sherman, CT, died on August 13, 2013 of congestive heart failure after a short illness, surrounded by his family and according to his specific instructions. He is survived by his beloved wife of 46 years, Patricia Brown, his adored sons, Prof. Matthew Goodrich Specter of New Haven (Marjan Mashhadi), and Evan Ross Specter of Berkeley (Amy) and his grandchildren, Leila Beatrix, Luka Kenneth, and Katherine Patrice. He leaves also his sister, Elinore Tilles (Bud Tilles dec), his nephews Peter Tilles (Leslie) of Princeton, NJ and Daniel Tilles (Ellen) of London, and their children, Amanda, Olivia, and Ella, and a niece, Wendy Tilles (deceased). Brooklyn-born, David attended Brooklyn Tech., Harvard College '52 (Phi Beta Kappa) and The Harvard Graduate School of Design '56. He was awarded Harvard's coveted Sheldon Traveling Fellowship in 1952-3 which formed the basis for his subsequent noted book, "Urban Spaces", a photographically illustrated exploration of spatial phenomena as they relate to urban design. He won the Arnold Brunner Scholarship from the Architectural League of New York. He served two years in the U.S. Army in Munich and worked in Europe. He founded the firm of David Kenneth Specter, AIA, Architects in 1963, presently Specter DeSouza Architects, PC. A classic modernist architect, he was most influenced by the work of Alvar Aalto and was concerned with the issues of urban context and appropriateness. He was best known for the Galleria (1974), one of the first mixed-use buildings in NY (its iconic penthouse was designed for Stewart Mott) and the first USTA National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows (1978), but his favorite projects were private homes. His clients became close friends. He was a gentle gentleman. Adventurous, creative, curious, calm. He was an avid skier, a passionate photographer, a lover of all music (clarinetist in the Harvard Band), and a crack tennis player though he admitted that designing the National Tennis Center did not improve his game. At the time of his passing, he was a member of the Century Association and on the Board of Directors of The New York Landmarks Conservancy and the Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass. He served for 21 years on the Board of the 92nd Street Y. His father was Louis S. Specter, a Brooklyn cardiologist, who worked his way through Columbia playing the piano at the Lower East Side Settlement House, later the Sarnoff Building, for which David later redesigned the facade. His mother, Ina Rous Specter, was an illustrator for Claire McCardell and a prolific painter. His maternal grandfather, Bernard H. Rous, an engineer, held patents in 1915 for machinery to manufacture corrugated boxes and founded the Grand City Box Company in the 1920's, a leader in the industry. Contributions may be sent in his name to The Harvard Graduate School of Design or The New York Landmarks Conservancy. Funeral services private. A memorial will be announced in the Fall.

SIMPKINS--Arthur, 86, died on August 10, 2013, beloved husband of Marcia for 62 years, adored father of Helen Jaffa, Dan (Irene) Simpkins and Nancy Simpkins, cherished grandfather of Scott (Mara) Jaffa, Marc Jaffa, Stephanie Jaffa and Nina Simpkins. Arthur was born in Brooklyn, lived most of his life in Westbury, NY, then retired to Boynton Beach, FL. A WWII veteran, Arthur earned a B.S. EE from CCNY, ran Simpkins Stores for more than 40 years, then studied computer science and taught computer skills classes at Nassau Community College. He was brilliant, funny, creative, industrious, caring and devoted to his family. He will be greatly missed by family and friends.

SARNOFF--Irving, passed away on August 11, 2013. A professor emeritus of Psychology at NYU, Irv was married to his beloved wife Suzanne for 61 years until her death five years ago. He is survived by his son David (Pepper), daughter Sara (Jeffrey Palmer), four grandchildren, and one great-grandson. Graveside funeral August 15 at 2:00pm at the Sandisfield Cemetery on Rte 57 in Sandisfield, MA. Omit flowers.

MORRISSEY--Jane E.,of Bronxville, NY, died peacefully in Dallas, TX on August 10, 2013 of complications following surgery to relieve a blocked artery. She was 76 years old. Born in New York City, Jane graduated from The College of New Rochelle and earned a M.A. from Columbia Teachers College. For 43 years she taught English at Westlake High School in Thornwood, NY inspiring countless students, motivated and reluctant, to achieve excellence in the classroom and in life. She was truly loved and respected by her fellow staff members and friends. Her boundless generosity, kindness and willingness to listen will be sorely missed. Jane was predeceased by her father, Walter J. Rako of Lakeville, CT and mother, Edith M. Rako of Bronxville, NY. She is survived by her brother, John and his companion Judy Holgersen of Bronxville, NY. A private memorial will be held. For more info. contact jpfr@optonline.net. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Pajama Program, 34 E. 39th St, NYC.

LUCKS--Harvey Chester, in New York City on August 12, 2013, age 89. Harvey was the beloved husband of Harriet Ballon and the late Edythe M. Lucks. He was a loving father of Susan and Stuart (Sara), adored grandfather of Philip (Kate), Eva, Daniel and great-grandfather of little Stuart. For over 40 years Harvey was President of Long Island Tinsmith Supply, founded by his father Philip in 1918. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Lehigh University Scholarship Fund http://mylehigh.lehigh.edu/makeagift Funeral service on Thursday at 11:30am at Frank E. LEVINE--Elsie, 92, died August 9, 2013, Columbus, OH; predeceased by husband Mortimer G. Levine. Survived by daughters Peri Wolfman (Charles Gold), Marjorie Levine, and Cathy Levine (Jon Groner). Please visit: epsteinmemorialchapel.com

LEICHTER--Martin, passed away on August 12 at Robert Wood Johnson Hospital in New Brunswick after a 3-year battle with Myelodysplasia. He was 83. Adored husband to Bernice (nee Steigman), beloved father to Steve (Shari) and Suzanne, loving grandfather to Elizabeth, Jack, and Sarah. Marty was born in Brooklyn on April 21, 1930, and attended James Madison High School. He graduated from New York University in 1951, and went on to serve as an Army Sergeant in the Korean War. After the war, he pursued his love of entertainment, working in an earlier era of New York City television and film production. He was the studio manager at Gold Medal Studios in Astoria, and served as production manager on a wide variety of films, including 'Butterfield 8,' and on television shows such as 'Naked City,' 'Car 54, Where Are You?' and 'Man of the House,' the pilot for 'The Dick Van Dyke Show.' He was introduced to his beloved 'Bunny' at a Columbia Pictures screening of 'The Goddess,' where she worked at the time. He left the industry in 1961 to become a New York City schoolteacher. He taught English and Film for over 25 years at Far Rockaway High School, where he served as Dean of Students, and at Susan Wagner High School. He inspired numerous students to pursue their own careers in the entertainment industry. After his retirement, he continued to share his lifelong passion for film and television, serving as an adjunct Professor of Communications at Mercer County College in New Jersey, and as a Featured Lecturer at the Maltz Jupiter Theatre in Florida. He passed along his love of photography, baseball, film, television, and the ability to tie a perfectly dimpled four-in-hand tie knot to his children and grandchildren. His quiet dignity masked a sly sense of humor, and he will be deeply missed by us all. Funeral services will be held graveside at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing on Wednesday, August 14 at 1:30pm. The family will be sitting shiva at 78 Barkers Point Road in Sands Point on Wednesday, August 14 from 5 to 8pm, and on Thursday, August 15 from 1 to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society (www.lls.org).

KRAUSE--Ruth Agert, formerly of Jericho, NY, passed away on August 12, 2013 at the age of 90. KOLKER--Kenneth. Born in Brooklyn, New York August 24, 1923. Ken attended the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School, Harvard Business School and the London School of Economics. During World War Two Ken served as a Lieutenant in the Navy on the Destroyer Escort Albert E. Harris in the Pacific. After the war he joined the training squad program at Abraham and Straus and became Executive Vice-President of Merchandising. During that period he mentored many of today's top retail executives. Ken later joined May Department Stores as President of May Merchandising and Chairman of May Department Stores International. He loved the Arts, Jazz, Sports and the beaches in Fire Island, Ponte Vedre and Southampton. He had a keen interest in politics and policy both National and International and would love to engage in spirited discussions always with a depth of knowledge on the specific topic. Ken just made you feel good to be with him and a great friend to all! He was above all a kind, caring, generous and humble man. Ken will be missed by all! Services will be Friday August 16th at 11:00am at Frank E. Campbell 81 Street and Madison Avenue. Donations can be made to the 92nd Street Y' Jazz Program.

GARFINKEL--Jack, 95, August 14, 2013. Predeceased by his beloved wife Lillian of 55 years. Devoted father of Barbara (Vernon) and Richard. Loving brother to Sidney. His joy of living and loving ways will be missed by all. Retired professional basketball player and teacher. Visiting 5-8pm Thursday. Services 11:30am Friday at IJ Morris, Brooklyn.

GADDIPATI--Sreedhar (Sree), MD The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and the New York Presbyterian (NYP) Sloane Hospital for Women mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our dear friend and revered colleague, Dr. Sree Gaddipati. During his final hours he was surrounded by his loving wife, Paulina, his brother, his parents, and many members of our Sloane family. A truly gifted and devoted physician, Dr. Gaddipati was beloved by all of his patients for his compassion and extraordinary skill in managing complicated pregnancies. He was also a cherished and respected teacher. Many medical students and residents decided to pursue a career in Maternal Fetal Medicine because of his mentorship. He inspired many with his brilliance, humility, compassion and humanism. His loss to our institution and department is immeasurable. We are heartbroken for his family and extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Paulina, their two young children, Matthew and Grace, his parents and brother. We have created the "Dr. Sree Gaddipati Fund" to continue his legacy and to honor his contribution to patient care and medical education. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Dr. Gaddipati can be made to, Columbia University OB/GYN - Dr. Sree Gaddipati Fund. 622 West 168th Street, Suite 1628, New York, NY 10032. Attn: Carolyn Hoare. Mary E. D'Alton, MD, Director, Obstetric and Gynecological Services, NewYork - Presbyterian Hospital, Sloane Hospital for Women; Chair, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons

GABEL--Harold, MD. 90, of Oakhurst, NJ, died on August 12. He was born in NYC on March 9, 1923, to Morris and Esther Gabel; was the brother of Richard; husband of the late Adelaide "Addie" Gabel, 89; father of seven and grandfather of 15. He graduated from Stuyvesant High, Columbia College, and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. He was predeceased days ago by his beloved Addie.

FLOOD--James, J.,55, of Manhattan, NY, died Friday, August 9, 2013. Predeceased by his parents, Jim was the devoted only child of James J. and Doris (nee Baker) Flood. Survivors include his maternal aunt, Audrey (Peter) Hickey (nee Baker), his paternal aunt, Sally (the late Robert) Flood and cousins Johanna Kagel, Tara, Catherine and (the late Denise) Hickey, Robert, Stephen, Thomas and John Flood. Jim was a 1979 magna cum laude graduate of Fordham University and earned his MBA from Manhattan College in 1985. He began his career at the CBS Broadcast Group, answering viewer questions about news programming, leaving for the opportunity to work at the New York City Mayor's Office of Operations. He became a manager for the New York City Department of Homeless Services, which led to a position as the Director of Human Resources for Common Ground in 2000, a nonprofit social services organization in New York City whose goal is to create high-quality permanent and transitional housing for the homeless. Jim was born and raised in the Bronx, was devoted to his faith, and was a member of the Church of St. Raymond and St. John the Evangelist. Jim was a Manhattan resident for over 30 years. The wake will be at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave., Manhattan, NY on Friday August 16th from 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm. BRANDT--Coleman. Coleman "Mort" Brandt, 77, of New York City, NY, the beloved husband of Grace for almost 54 years passed away on August 6, 2013. His life had a far-reaching impact on his family members, friends, and co-workers. Coleman was born in 1936 in Brooklyn, NY to Sol and Tillie Brandt. He received his B.S. from Philadelphia Textile Institute in Philadelphia, PA and a M.B.A. from Harvard University in Cambridge, MA. He went on to a career in financial services at multiple firms on Wall Street before founding his own firm, Ark Asset Management in 1989. He served in the U.S. Air Force, was a member of Mensa and a fan of Monty Python, Steve Jobs and Andy Borowitz. A lover of theater, the arts, reading, coffee, cookbooks, wine and cheese, Coleman appreciated stimulating conversation, clever wordplay and good company. He was the patriarch, confidant and moral compass to his immediate and extended family. He leaves his sons David and Leland, daughters-in-law Kelley and Lynne, five cherished grandchildren, Alexandra, Noah, Chaim, Sofie and Eli, much-loved sisters Lila Kirschner and Rita Berger, and numerous nieces and nephews that he adored. Those who knew and loved him will feel his impact and loss for eternity. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, August 18th at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY, with Rabbi Seth Bernstein officiating. Internment will follow with a graveside service at the Union Field Cemetery of Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 8211 Cypress Avenue, Ridgewood, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in Coleman's memory may be made to the following organizations: Prep For Prep and Thirteen.org. Friends and colleagues are invited to send stories, anecdotes or other remembrances to (lborder@comcast.net). Services entrusted to Riverside Memorial Chapel, for more information or directions, please visit (riversidememorialchapel.com)/ or 212-362-6600

COHN--Donald J. Aged 83, died suddenly on August 13, 2013. Loving husband of Eva Brunner Cohn, devoted father of Charles (and Christine), Theodore, Alexandra and Ralph (and Barbara), doting grandfather of Benjamin and David. A graduate of Columbia Grammar School; a three-letter football player, scholar at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, and a founder of the Hillel Society at Princeton University; an Editor of the Yale Law Journal, he served as a Lieutenant in the US Coast Guard during the Korean War. He was appointed Administrative Assistant US Attorney for the Southern District of New York, and became a Senior Partner and Head of the Litigation Department at the law firm of Webster & Sheffield. A public-spirited neighbor, he served for many years on the Board of the Riverdale Neighborhood House, UJA, Friends of the Hebrew University, Riverdale Country School, President of the Riverdale Nature Preservancy, pro bono attorney for the Children's Aid Society and the Natural Resources Defense Council. He touched many lives around the world and was loved for his wise counsel and warm personality. He was an avid fisherman who spent many happy hours on the waters off the family home in Amityville, L.I. Funeral services will be held at the Conservative Synagogue of Riverdale on Friday at 11am. 475 W. 250th Street at Henry Hudson Parkway. He will be greatly missed and fondly remembered.

Mr. Winters was passionate about hockey and was widely known as a die-hard New York Rangers fan. He is survived by his wife, Karen Crowe and his children Jacob, 18, and Grace, 15, his sister Elizabeth, his brother Douglas, stepbrother Robert, stepsister Ellen, and four nieces and six nephews. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to a charity of choice.

SPECTER--David Kenneth. David Kenneth Specter, AIA, Architect, 82, of New York City and Sherman, CT, died on August 13, 2013 of congestive heart failure after a short illness, surrounded by his family and according to his specific instructions. He is survived by his beloved wife of 46 years, Patricia Brown, his adored sons, Prof. Matthew Goodrich Specter of New Haven (Marjan Mashhadi), and Evan Ross Specter of Berkeley (Amy) and his grandchildren, Leila Beatrix, Luka Kenneth, and Katherine Patrice. He leaves also his sister, Elinore Tilles (Bud Tilles dec), his nephews Peter Tilles (Leslie) of Princeton, NJ and Daniel Tilles (Ellen) of London, and their children, Amanda, Olivia, and Ella, and a niece, Wendy Tilles (deceased). Brooklyn-born, David attended Brooklyn Tech., Harvard College '52 (Phi Beta Kappa) and The Harvard Graduate School of Design '56. He was awarded Harvard's coveted Sheldon Traveling Fellowship in 1952-3 which formed the basis for his subsequent noted book, "Urban Spaces", a photographically illustrated exploration of spatial phenomena as they relate to urban design. He won the Arnold Brunner Scholarship from the Architectural League of New York. He served two years in the U.S. Army in Munich and worked in Europe. He founded the firm of David Kenneth Specter, AIA, Architects in 1963, presently Specter DeSouza Architects, PC. A classic modernist architect, he was most influenced by the work of Alvar Aalto and was concerned with the issues of urban context and appropriateness. He was best known for the Galleria (1974), one of the first mixed-use buildings in NY (its iconic penthouse was designed for Stewart Mott) and the first USTA National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows (1978), but his favorite projects were private homes. His clients became close friends. He was a gentle gentleman. Adventurous, creative, curious, calm. He was an avid skier, a passionate photographer, a lover of all music (clarinetist in the Harvard Band), and a crack tennis player though he admitted that designing the National Tennis Center did not improve his game. At the time of his passing, he was a member of the Century Association and on the Board of Directors of The New York Landmarks Conservancy and the Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass. He served for 21 years on the Board of the 92nd Street Y. His father was Louis S. Specter, a Brooklyn cardiologist, who worked his way through Columbia playing the piano at the Lower East Side Settlement House, later the Sarnoff Building, for which David later redesigned the facade. His mother, Ina Rous Specter, was an illustrator for Claire McCardell and a prolific painter. His maternal grandfather, Bernard H. Rous, an engineer, held patents in 1915 for machinery to manufacture corrugated boxes and founded the Grand City Box Company in the 1920's, a leader in the industry. Contributions may be sent in his name to The Harvard Graduate School of Design or The New York Landmarks Conservancy. Funeral services private. A memorial will be announced in the Fall.

A celebration of his life will be on Sunday, August 18th 11am at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

SCHORR--Jerome ("Jerry"), a wonderful husband, father and grandfather to Marcia ("Marcie"), David and Maxwell. Jerry excelled in the group insurance business for many years. He loved his work and cared very much about his clients. He was a voracious reader and especially loved history. Jerry was fascinated by etymology and the flexibility of the English language. He disliked incompetence and called this "The age of inferior alternatives." Jerry had a great zest for life and will be sorely missed.

RIVKIN--Betty Ann, Of Garden City, NY was born with a smile and it never left her face. On August 15, 2013, Betty passed away from cancer in her 85th year. Survived by her adoring husband Leonard Rivkin. She is also survived by her loving children Douglas Friedman and Robert Friedman as well as her daughter-in-law Linda Friedman and granddaughters Rachel Friedman and Jesse Friedman. Her step- children Janet Zuckerman, John Rivkin and their spouses Joe Zuckerman and Nancy Rivkin cherished her company as did their children Scott Zuckerman, Matthew Zuckerman, Diana Rivkin, Michael Rivkin and Erica Rivkin. Betty had a world of adoring friends and she made the world smile. She was loved and will be missed by many. Funeral services will be private. Shiva at home, Monday, 4pm-8pm.

McCARTHY--Catherine A. (Sugrue), 96, of River Edge, NJ passed away on August 14th. Catherine graduated from Cathedral High School and, at age 65, received a B.S. from William Paterson College. Beloved wife of the late Edward Francis McCarthy. Devoted mother of Edward, James, John, Thomas, Timothy and Joseph. Family will receive friends at Beaugard Funeral Home, River Edge NJ on Friday, August 16th from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Peter the Apostle Church, River Edge, NJ at 10:00am on Saturday, August 17th.

LEVY--Alice, age 102. April 18, 1911 - August 13, 2013. Died, at home, after a recent illness. She leaves her loving family; son Harold Levy, daughter-in-law Pat, grandchildren Hannah and Noah, sister, Edith and sister-in-law Eva. Her good nature serves as an inspiration to all. Funeral to be private. Donations may be made to Luxembourg Income Survey c/o the CUNY Graduate Center Foundation, 365 Fifth Ave., Suite 8204, New York, NY 10016.

KRAUSE--Ruth Agert, formerly of Jericho, NY, passed away on August 12, 2013 at the age of 90. Cherished wife of the late Alfred, adored mother of Martin (Maddie), Michele (Philippe) and Loren (Peter). Beloved grandmother of Adam, Benjamin, Samuel, Alexandra, Andrew and Michael. She was an extraordinary woman who lived each day with great courage, compassion, intelligence and beauty. She was loved and adored by all who knew her. Ruthie, you will forever be in our hearts. Services will be held on Friday, August 16th at 11am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury, NY 11797.
KOLKER--Kenneth. Friends are Forever. Forever our Friend. Gilda and Henry Meg and Hank

KOLKER--Kenneth. Born in Brooklyn, New York August 24, 1923. Ken attended the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School, Harvard Business School and the London School of Economics. During World War Two Ken served as a Lieutenant in the Navy on the Destroyer Escort Albert E. Harris in the Pacific. After the war he joined the training squad program at Abraham and Straus and became Executive Vice-President of Merchandising. During that period he mentored many of today's top retail executives. Ken later joined May Department Stores as President of May Merchandising and Chairman of May Department Stores International. He loved the Arts, Jazz, Sports and the beaches in Fire Island, Ponte Vedre and Southampton. He had a keen interest in politics and policy both National and International and would love to engage in spirited discussions always with a depth of knowledge on the specific topic. Ken just made you feel good to be with him and a great friend to all! He was above all a kind, caring, generous and humble man. Ken will be missed by all! Services will be Friday August 16th at 11:00am at Frank E. Campbell 81 Street and Madison Avenue. Donations can be made to the 92nd Street Y' Jazz Program.

GADDIPATI--Sreedhar (Sree), MD The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and the New York Presbyterian (NYP) Sloane Hospital for Women mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our dear friend and revered colleague, Dr. Sree Gaddipati. During his final hours he was surrounded by his loving wife, Paulina, his brother, his parents, and many members of our Sloane family. A truly gifted and devoted physician, Dr. Gaddipati was beloved by all of his patients for his compassion and extraordinary skill in managing complicated pregnancies. He was also a cherished and respected teacher. Many medical students and residents decided to pursue a career in Maternal Fetal Medicine because of his mentorship. He inspired many with his brilliance, humility, compassion and humanism. His loss to our institution and department is immeasurable. We are heartbroken for his family and extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Paulina, their two young children, Matthew and Grace, his parents and brother. We have created the "Dr. Sree Gaddipati Fund" to continue his legacy and to honor his contribution to patient care and medical education. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Dr. Gaddipati can be made to, Columbia University OB/GYN - Dr. Sree Gaddipati Fund. 622 West 168th Street, Suite 1628, New York, NY 10032. Attn: Carolyn Hoare. Mary E. D'Alton, MD, Director, Obstetric and Gynecological Services, NewYork - Presbyterian Hospital, Sloane Hospital for Women; Chair, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons

FLOOD--James, J.,55, of Manhattan, NY, died Friday, August 9, 2013. Predeceased by his parents, Jim was the devoted only child of James J. and Doris (nee Baker) Flood. Survivors include his maternal aunt, Audrey (Peter) Hickey (nee Baker), his paternal aunt, Sally (the late Robert) Flood and cousins Johanna Kagel, Tara, Catherine and (the late Denise) Hickey, Robert, Stephen, Thomas and John Flood. Jim was a 1979 magna cum laude graduate of Fordham University and earned his MBA from Manhattan College in 1985. He began his career at the CBS Broadcast Group, answering viewer questions about news programming, leaving for the opportunity to work at the New York City Mayor's Office of Operations. He became a manager for the New York City Department of Homeless Services, which led to a position as the Director of Human Resources for Common Ground in 2000, a nonprofit social services organization in New York City whose goal is to create high-quality permanent and transitional housing for the homeless. Jim was born and raised in the Bronx, was devoted to his faith, and was a member of the Church of St. Raymond and St. John the Evangelist. Jim was a Manhattan resident for over 30 years. The wake will be at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave., Manhattan, NY on Friday August 16th from 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm. Mass of Christian burial 10am on Saturday August 17th at St. John the Evangelist, 348 East 55th St., Manhattan, NY. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery following the mass, 2600 Lafayette Avenue, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

COUTURE--Jerold L. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are saddened by the loss of Jerold Couture, trustee of The Frederick Loewe Foundation. Supporters of The Frederick Loewe Theater Program at Hebrew University, Jere and The Frederick Loewe Foundation enhanced the well-being of Israel by fostering the arts. We extend our sympathies to Jere's family and to Emily and Dara Altman. American Friends of The Hebrew University Daniel I. Schlessinger, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

COHN--Donald J. Aged 83, died suddenly on August 13, 2013. Loving husband of Eva Brunner Cohn, devoted father of Charles (and Christine), Theodore, Alexandra and Ralph (and Barbara), doting grandfather of Benjamin and David. A graduate of Columbia Grammar School; a three-letter football player, scholar at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, and a founder of the Hillel Society at Princeton University; an Editor of the Yale Law Journal, he served as a Lieutenant in the US Coast Guard during the Korean War. He was appointed Administrative Assistant US Attorney for the Southern District of New York, and became a Senior Partner and Head of the Litigation Department at the law firm of Webster & Sheffield. A public-spirited neighbor, he served for many years on the Board of the Riverdale Neighborhood House, UJA, Friends of the Hebrew University, Riverdale Country School, President of the Riverdale Nature Preservancy, pro bono attorney for the Children's Aid Society and the Natural Resources Defense Council. He touched many lives around the world and was loved for his wise counsel and warm personality. He was an avid fisherman who spent many happy hours on the waters off the family home in Amityville, L.I. Funeral services will be held at the Conservative Synagogue of Riverdale on Friday at 11am. 475 W. 250th Street at Henry Hudson Parkway. He will be greatly missed and fondly remembered.

BRANDT--Coleman. Coleman "Mort" Brandt, 77, of New York City, NY, the beloved husband of Grace for almost 54 years passed away on August 6, 2013. His life had a far-reaching impact on his family members, friends, and co-workers. Coleman was born in 1936 in Brooklyn, NY to Sol and Tillie Brandt. He received his B.S. from Philadelphia Textile Institute in Philadelphia, PA and a M.B.A. from Harvard University in Cambridge, MA. He went on to a career in financial services at multiple firms on Wall Street before founding his own firm, Ark Asset Management in 1989. He served in the U.S. Air Force, was a member of Mensa and a fan of Monty Python, Steve Jobs and Andy Borowitz. A lover of theater, the arts, reading, coffee, cookbooks, wine and cheese, Coleman appreciated stimulating conversation, clever wordplay and good company. He was the patriarch, confidant and moral compass to his immediate and extended family. He leaves his sons David and Leland, daughters-in-law Kelley and Lynne, five cherished grandchildren, Alexandra, Noah, Chaim, Sofie and Eli, much-loved sisters Lila Kirschner and Rita Berger, and numerous nieces and nephews that he adored. Those who knew and loved him will feel his impact and loss for eternity. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, August 18th at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY, with Rabbi Seth Bernstein officiating. Internment will follow with a graveside service at the Union Field Cemetery of Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 8211 Cypress Avenue, Ridgewood, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in Coleman's memory may be made to the following organizations: Prep For Prep and Thirteen.org. Friends and colleagues are invited to send stories, anecdotes or other remembrances to (lborder@comcast.net). Services entrusted to Riverside Memorial Chapel, for more information or directions, please visit (riversidememorialchapel.com)/ or 212-362-6600

ASCOLI--Joseph, M.D.,died on August 11, 2013, at the age of 85 years. Dr. Ascoli was born March 1928, in Andretta, Italy; he is survived by his son Paul, wife Jennifer, and three grandchildren; his daughter Ellen Pashiardis, husband Haris, four grandchildren, and former wife Nancy Parady. He completed his education at the University of Naples, Italy with a degree in medicine. He was a Diplomat in Surgery, had a private practice for thirty years in the Bronx, NY and was an attending Surgeon at Harlem Hospital, New York City. He will be missed and remembered as a skilled Physician, Humanitarian, and loving father and grandfather.

PILCER--Benjamin, of Hallandale and Aventura, FL. Born Lodz, Poland February 20, 1919. He spent WWII in the Lodz Ghetto, then Auschwitz. He met his wife, Leonia (Gradon) in a displaced persons camp in Landsberg, Germany. They came to the US in the 1950's and lived in the boroughs of Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens. Benjamin leaves behind his loving wife of 68 years, Leonia; his children Sonia, Samuel and Mitchell; their spouses Morton Makler, Grace Pilcer and Suzy Pilcer; and his grandchildren Julia Pilcer, Jacob Makler and Hannah, Natan, Ishai and Ruth Pilcer. He led a full and interesting life as a real estate entrepreneur and private investor, which he continued to do until shortly before his death. Services will be at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NY, NY on Sunday August 18th at 1pm. Donations to Friends of the Israel Defense Forces www.fidf.org

LODGE--Lorraine, aged 52 of New York City and Telluride, passed away on August 8th to BRCA related ovarian cancer. She is survived by her beloved husband Steve, parents Don and Tosia Gringer, sisters Susan Efron and Lydia Schinasi, and their families. Lorraine went to Northwestern University and received an MBA from Wharton, and spent her career at investment banks in New York and London, and most recently, at a financial training company. Her kindness, intelligence, and sense of humor will be deeply missed by all. Donations may be made in Lorraine's memory to: Ovarian Cancer Research Fund (ocrf.org) or Calvary Hospital (calvaryhospital.org)

Our sweet nana, beautiful loving mother and mother-in-law to Jacqueline, Darius and Jill, devoted grandmother to Sasha, Maxwell, Ella and Beau has left us with the traditions and tools to continue life in a joyful and enriching way. ADLER--Michael. The Board of Overseers of Columbia Business School expresses deep sorrow at the passing of Michael Adler, Professor Emeritus of Business at Columbia Business School. He had a profound influence on international financial markets and his work continues to be cited today. Columbia Business School extends its profound sympathy to the Adler family. Glenn Hubbard, Dean, Columbia Business School
