VISELTEAR--Nedwyn, 1936 -2013, was born in the Bronx to what would now be considered a dysfunctional family. He found solace in a neighborhood filled with zany and irreverent characters. It was there in the verbally aggressive language of the street that he honed his timing and emerged with a sharp wit and fall-down funny sense of humor. Possessing a high IQ and a reputation as a wordsmith, he established himself in the ad business, as an award winning writer, a creative director, a partner in his own agency and having his exploits chronicled by his friend, advertising guru, Jerry Della Femina. He loved jazz and had an extensive record collection. He was the personification of "the man about town" for his time. Attractive, charming, well read, impeccably dressed, with a groovy pad on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and the best stereo system that anyone had ever heard. He was married briefly and had no children. Despite his troubles, he always managed to live life on his terms. He leaves a brother, a sister-in-law and a whole lot of family and friends who loved him. He will forever be too hip for the room. He was the best Ned we knew.

VACANTE--Gino. Died peacefully on May 10, 2013 in Montreal, Canada at the age of 73. Survived by his wife Sheila (nee McGahan) and his children Steven (Kathleen) and Jeffery (Tammy). Loving grandfather to Kieran, Ryan, and Ashley. He will be deeply missed.

TREISMAN--Dorothy C.The Joseph and Joan Cullman Conservation Foundation and the Joseph and Joan Cullman Foundation for the Arts mourn the loss of Dorothy Cullman Treisman, President of both foundations and daughter of Joseph F. Cullman, 3rd. Dorothy contributed a unique blend of passion, insight, and personal warmth to each board discussion and decision. Her commitment to furthering the missions of both foundations inspired all around her. Under Dorothy's visionary leadership, the Cullman Conservation Foundation consistently and significantly supported innovative solutions to the challenges of protecting natural habitats and wildlife in the Adirondack Mountains, throughout the US, and internationally. Dorothy was especially proud of the expansion of the breadth of programs and initiatives supported by Cullman Foundation for the Arts. With her guidance, the foundation extended its grant making beyond an initial base of larger NYC arts organizations to include a variety of younger cutting edge visual and performing arts organizations in and outside the city. We are privileged to have worked with Dorothy on all of these exciting projects. We express our condolences to her sons, Joel and Jeffrey Treisman, and to their families. Michael Cardozo Secretary and Treasurer

TANNEHILL--Frances. Broadway actress and lifelong New Yorker, died on August 5th in Manhattan. She was 90. Known for her stunning looks as well as her talents as a dramatic and comedic actress, Ms. Tannehill started her Broadway career at age 8 in the play "Purity". She attended Professional Children's School in Manhattan, which enabled her to perform and keep up with her studies while touring. Ms. Tannehill was cast in Cole Porter's 1938 Broadway musical "Leave it to Me", starring Mary Martin, Sophie Tucker and Gene Kelly. In 1940, she appeared on Broadway in "Keep off the Grass", choreographed by George Balanchine and starring Jimmy Durante, Ray Bolger, and Jane Froman. Ms. Tannehill joined the Broadway cast of "Othello" in 1943, starring Paul Robeson, Uta Hagen and Jose Ferrer. At age 19, Ms. Tannehill met actor Alexander Clark during the Broadway revival of "Counsellor-at-Law", starring Paul Muni. They married in 1945 and honeymooned in Europe on a six month tour with the USO. They remained married for fifty years until Alec Clark's death in 1995. In 1952, the acting couple was hired for a year-long national tour of "Call Me Madam" starring Elaine Stritch. Ms. Tannehill also performed with Helen Hayes, Dame Flora Robson, Sarah Churchill, Jessica Tandy, Lillian Gish and Michael Redgrave. TV and radio performances included episodes on The Alcoa Hour, Kraft Television Theatre and Theatre Guild on the Air. Ms. Tannehill was the 3rd generation performer from an American theatrical family dating back to the 1850s. Her father, Frank Tannehill Jr. was an actor, playwright and lyricist. Her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Tannehill performed throughout the U.S. In 1857, they were part of the ensemble company at Philadelphia's Arch Street Theatre. John Wilkes Booth joined the company that year. For over 25 years, Ms. Tannehill created and performed one woman shows recounting her own theatrical experiences and those of other notable people in the arts. Since 1995, she was President of Twelfth Night Club, Inc.; the oldest extant club for women of the theatre in the U.S. She will be remembered with love and admiration for her bright mind, her vibrant charm, her beautiful voice and wonderful theatre recollections. She is survived by her daughter Nicole Clark, of Manhattan. Memorial contributions may be made to The Actor's Fund.

STEPPACHER--John A.,Falmouth, Maine passed away August 11. Survived by his wife of 65 years, Joan (Pendleton), and children Brian Steppacher, Jill and Rob DeWitt, all of Maine and Lee Steppacher and Dan Shepard of Massachusetts. Worked for Cone Mills Inc., and then as President of International Sales for Crompton Co., selling textiles worldwide. A memorial service in Castine, Maine is planned. Full obituary at www.athutchins.com.

SPECTER--David Kenneth. David Kenneth Specter, AIA, Architect, 82, of New York City and Sherman, CT, died on August 13, 2013 of congestive heart failure after a short illness, surrounded by his family and according to his specific instructions. He is survived by his beloved wife of 46 years, Patricia Brown, his adored sons, Prof. Matthew Goodrich Specter of New Haven (Marjan Mashhadi), and Evan Ross Specter of Berkeley (Amy) and his grandchildren, Leila Beatrix, Luka Kenneth, and Katherine Patrice. He leaves also his sister, Elinore Tilles (Bud Tilles dec), his nephews Peter Tilles (Leslie) of Princeton, NJ and Daniel Tilles (Ellen) of London, and their children, Amanda, Olivia, and Ella, and a niece, Wendy Tilles (deceased). Brooklyn-born, David attended Brooklyn Tech., Harvard College '52 (Phi Beta Kappa) and The Harvard Graduate School of Design '56. He was awarded Harvard's coveted Sheldon Traveling Fellowship in 1952-3 which formed the basis for his subsequent noted book, "Urban Spaces", a photographically illustrated exploration of spatial phenomena as they relate to urban design. He won the Arnold Brunner Scholarship from the Architectural League of New York. He served two years in the U.S. Army in Munich and worked in Europe. He founded the firm of David Kenneth Specter, AIA, Architects in 1963, presently Specter DeSouza Architects, PC. A classic modernist architect, he was most influenced by the work of Alvar Aalto and was concerned with the issues of urban context and appropriateness. He was best known for the Galleria (1974), one of the first mixed-use buildings in NY (its iconic penthouse was designed for Stewart Mott) and the first USTA National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows (1978), but his favorite projects were private homes. His clients became close friends. He was a gentle gentleman. Adventurous, creative, curious, calm. He was an avid skier, a passionate photographer, a lover of all music (clarinetist in the Harvard Band), and a crack tennis player though he admitted that designing the National Tennis Center did not improve his game. At the time of his passing, he was a member of the Century Association and on the Board of Directors of The New York Landmarks Conservancy and the Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass. He served for 21 years on the Board of the 92nd Street Y. His father was Louis S. Specter, a Brooklyn cardiologist, who worked his way through Columbia playing the piano at the Lower East Side Settlement House, later the Sarnoff Building, for which David later redesigned the facade. His mother, Ina Rous Specter, was an illustrator for Claire McCardell and a prolific painter. His maternal grandfather, Bernard H. Rous, an engineer, held patents in 1915 for machinery to manufacture corrugated boxes and founded the Grand City Box Company in the 1920's, a leader in the industry. Contributions may be sent in his name to The Harvard Graduate School of Design or The New York Landmarks Conservancy. Funeral services private. A memorial will be announced in the Fall.

SINDEL--Roberta (nee Ellen), of New York and Boynton Beach, Florida, passed away peacefully on Friday evening, August 16. She was surrounded by her devoted husband of 56 years, Brian, and her loving daughters, Shari Turner, Jane and Patricia. Born in Brooklyn on August 26, 1933, she was the proud grandmother of Sam and Jonathan Turner, Gabi and Michael Sindel Dymant, and mother-in-law of Stewart Turner. Funeral services will be held at the Community Synagogue of Sands Point on Monday, August 19 at noon.

SCHWARTZ--Madelyn E. In loving memory of Madelyn E. Schwartz, 90, who passed away on August 9, 2013 in Saddle River, NJ. Devoted wife, mother to Andrew and Carol, beloved grandmother of Brian, Daniel, Emily, Josh and Isabelle. A graduate of Bank Street College, she worked in Projects Head Start and Follow Through. A talented artist, she was married for 58 years to artist and educator Fred R. Schwartz.

SHERR--Daniel Alan, born 1959, remembered as 'the intrepid adventurer.' He died July 27, 2013 at his home in Roxbury New York. He was the beloved husband of Elizabeth Mayhall Sherr and loving son of Anne Nevard Sherr. His father, S. Irving Sherr, predeceased him in 2012. He leaves his brother Robert Sherr, his sister-in-law Deborah and his nephews Bruno and Chris of New Jersey. He loved his many aunts, uncles, and cousins. As an avid open boater, Danny canoed over 100,000 miles of rivers and supported The American Whitewater Association. He documented his experiences through journaling and illustrations. Danny shared the love of golf with his father. He graduated from Emory University and studied urban planning at UT Austin. Danny devoted himself to discovering new music by playing the guitar and archiving garage rock. He was a staunch believer in Israel. Danny was a founding underwriter of WIOX radio station in Roxbury.

RIVKIN--Betty Ann, Of Garden City, NY was born with a smile and it never left her face. On August 15, 2013, Betty passed away from cancer in her 85th year. Survived by her adoring husband Leonard Rivkin. She is also survived by her loving children Douglas Friedman and Robert Friedman as well as her daughter-in-law Linda Friedman and granddaughters Rachel Friedman and Jesse Friedman. Her step- children Janet Zuckerman, John Rivkin and their spouses Joe Zuckerman and Nancy Rivkin cherished her company as did their children Scott Zuckerman, Matthew Zuckerman, Diana Rivkin, Michael Rivkin and Erica Rivkin. Betty had a world of adoring friends and she made the world smile. She was loved and will be missed by many. Funeral services will be private. Shiva at home, Monday, 4pm-8pm.

REYNOLDS--Kathleen A.,on August 13, 2013 at age 73. Beloved sister of C. Scott Reynolds. Loving Aunt of Peter A., Carrie A. and Jessica M. Reynolds. Adored Great Aunt of Ethan M., and Isabella A. Reynolds. Also survived by Christi Reynolds, Anne, Bud and Katy Schad. Retired Assistant Commissioner for Special Projects, City of New York Real Estate. A celebration of her life will be held Saturday, September 7, 2013 11am-2pm with service to start at 1pm at Andrett Funeral Home 353 2nd Ave, NYC. Contributions in her memory may be made to any animal or environmental charity of your choice.

REICH--Peter, M.D.,82, of Cambridge, MA and Long Lake, NY, died August 11, 2013 of complications of AML. The son of Eleanor Brussell and Carl Reich, MD, he was born in New York City. He attended City and Country School, Horace Mann Lincoln High School and graduated from Harvard College in 1952. He went to Harvard Medical School, did a medical internship at Brigham and Women's Hospital and residency in psychiatry at the Boston Psychopathic Hospital. Dr. Reich was head of the Division of Psychiatry at Brigham and Women's Hospital and was a Professor of Psychiatry at Harvard Medical School. Subsequently he served as the head of the Mental Health Service in the Medical Department at MIT. He is survived by his wife, Lee C. Reich, brother, daughter, son and daughter-in-law and four grandchildren. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held in the fall. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Adirondack Council, P.O. Box D-2, Elizabethtown, NY 12932.

PILCER--Benjamin, of Hallandale and Aventura, FL. Born Lodz, Poland February 20, 1919. He spent WWII in the Lodz Ghetto, then Auschwitz. He met his wife, Leonia (Gradon) in a displaced persons camp in Landsberg, Germany. They came to the US in the 1950's and lived in the boroughs of Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens. Benjamin leaves behind his loving wife of 68 years, Leonia; his children Sonia, Samuel and Mitchell; their spouses Morton Makler, Grace Pilcer and Suzy Pilcer; and his grandchildren Julia Pilcer, Jacob Makler and Hannah, Natan, Ishai and Ruth Pilcer. He led a full and interesting life as a real estate entrepreneur and private investor, which he continued to do until shortly before his death. Services will be at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NY, NY on Sunday August 18th at 1pm. Donations to Friends of the Israel Defense Forces www.fidf.org

MONTGOMERY--Rodman III, beloved son of the late Rodman Montgomery Jr. and N. Caves Howard, died on August 12th in Tennessee. Survived by two sisters; Jennifer and Phoebe, five nephews, one great-nephew and two great-nieces.

MARKS--Joyce, 86, of 205 3rd Ave.,beloved wife of Mike, died on Saturday, August 17. Born in London on January 14, 1927. Came to the United States as a war bride in March of 1946. Worked many years as a school secretary in Staten Island and Manhattan. Surviving, besides her husband, are a brother, John Lewis, a nephew, Liam, and a niece, Patsy, all of Ireland. Joyce's son, Paul Merrill, died in 1969.

MAIER--Pauline. The Trustees and Staff of the New-York Historical Society mourn the loss of historian Pauline Maier, brilliant scholar, gifted writer and treasured advisor to our exhibitions program and Graduate Institute for Constitutional History. Our hearts go out to Pauline's family. Roger Hertog, Chairman Pam B. Schafler, Chair Elect Louise Mirrer, President & CEO
MacDONALD--Robert. Succumbed to cancer at 73. Former executive with Foote, Cone and Belding and BBDO. A true New Yorker, loved and sorely missed.

LYTTON--Sidney. It is with great sadness that we have learned of the recent passing of our beloved colleague and Life Member, Dr. Sidney M. Lytton. Ian Buckingham, President New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute

LODGE--Lorraine, aged 52 of New York City and Telluride, passed away on August 8th to BRCA related ovarian cancer. She is survived by her beloved husband Steve, parents Don and Tosia Gringer, sisters Susan Efron and Lydia Schinasi, and their families. Lorraine went to Northwestern University and received an MBA from Wharton, and spent her career at investment banks in New York and London, and most recently, at a financial training company. Her kindness, intelligence, and sense of humor will be deeply missed by all. Donations may be made in Lorraine's memory to: Ovarian Cancer Research Fund (ocrf.org) or Calvary Hospital (calvaryhospital.org)

LEVINE--Elsie, 92, died August 9, 2013, Columbus, OH; predeceased by husband Mortimer G. Levine. Survived by daughters Peri Wolfman (Charles Gold), Marjorie Levine, and Cathy Levine (Jon Groner). Please visit: epsteinmemorialchapel.com
KOLKER--Kenneth. Friends are Forever. Forever our Friend. Gilda and Henry Meg and Hank

LAND--Leslie, 66, of Cushing, ME, and Pleasant Valley, NY, died August 10 due to complications from metastatic breast cancer. Champion of country cooking, ambitious gardener, and, in her own words, "the latest in a long line of garden advisers that stretches back, approximately, to Adam, who we can be sure was frequently asked about the niceties of apple culture." In her syndicated "Good Food" column, four books, scores of magazine articles, and 400 Garden Q&A columns for the New York Times, Leslie wrote about food and gardening with wit and authority. She cooked at Chez Panisse in the early 1970s, then decamped for rural Maine where she built a new life as a writer. Leslie published two cookbooks, "Reading Between the Recipes" and "The Modern Country Cook," was an editor at Yankee magazine, and co-wrote "The 3,000 Mile Garden," which became a PBS series. She also edited "1000 Gardening Questions and Answers," based on the New York Times column. Leslie leaves her husband, Bill Bakaitis, daughter Celia, granddaughter Ursula, sister Claudia, brother David, a niece, two nephews, and countless friends she inspired to love gardening, good food, and life.

KOLKER--Kenneth. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn with heavy hearts the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, Kenneth Kolker. He had a deep love of music and generously shared this love with many in our community. Our hearts and prayers are with Ken's friends and family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Stuart J. Ellman, President Thomas S. Kaplan, Chairman

KNOX--Cornelius Van Santvoord, 92, formerly of Darien, CT, passed away July 8 in Shelburne, VT. After 40 years in broadcasting, he retired as CBS Radio's Vice President of Affiliate Relations. He lived every day to the fullest; he bought new skis at 91. His wife, Nancy Cronyn Knox, passed away in 2010. He is survived by his sister, his four children, six grandchildren and a great-grandchild. We'll celebrate his life 3pm, Friday, August 23, Darien Community Association, 274 Middlesex Rd., Darien.

HULTGREN--J. Leonard.,81, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, passed away on August 5, 2013. A United States. Navy Veteran and graduate of Fordham University, his career involved market research, marketing and ultimately being a founding partner of the advertising agency Scali, McCabe, Sloves. Beloved husband of Patricia (McCormack) Hultgren; special brother to Lisa Pheney; loving brother-in-law, uncle, cousin and good friend to many. At Leonards' request, there will be no services. For those who wish to do so, please consider a contribution in his memory to a charity of your choice. Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, family owned and operated. www.taylormodeen.com.
HERZ--Shirley. A theater loving original. You reached out to me with friendship and warmth that has truly enriched my life. I will remember you forever with the deepest affection. Sandra Powers

GADDIPATI--Sreedhar (Sree), MD The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and the New York Presbyterian (NYP) Sloane Hospital for Women mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our dear friend and revered colleague, Dr. Sree Gaddipati. During his final hours he was surrounded by his loving wife, Paulina, his brother, his parents, and many members of our Sloane family. A truly gifted and devoted physician, Dr. Gaddipati was beloved by all of his patients for his compassion and extraordinary skill in managing complicated pregnancies. He was also a cherished and respected teacher. Many medical students and residents decided to pursue a career in Maternal Fetal Medicine because of his mentorship. He inspired many with his brilliance, humility, compassion and humanism. His loss to our institution and department is immeasurable. We are heartbroken for his family and extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Paulina, their two young children, Matthew and Grace, his parents and brother. We have created the "Dr. Sree Gaddipati Fund" to continue his legacy and to honor his contribution to patient care and medical education. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Dr. Gaddipati can be made to, Columbia University OB/GYN - Dr. Sree Gaddipati Fund. 622 West 168th Street, Suite 1628, New York, NY 10032. Attn: Carolyn Hoare. Mary E. D'Alton, MD, Director, Obstetric and Gynecological Services, NewYork - Presbyterian Hospital, Sloane Hospital for Women; Chair, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons

GABEL--Harold, MD. 90, of Oakhurst, NJ, died on August 12. He was born in NYC on March 9, 1923, to Morris and Esther Gabel; was the brother of Richard; husband of the late Adelaide "Addie" Gabel, 89; father of seven and grandfather of 15. He graduated from Stuyvesant High, Columbia College, and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. He was predeceased days ago by his beloved Addie.

FORTUNE--James Malcolm, 85, an artist whose work reflected the natural world and the imaginary world, died on August 12th of heart failure in Boston, MA. Jim's work has been exhibited in museums and galleries throughout the country. Jim was born on October 23, 1927 in Philadelphia, PA to Ruth H. Krodell of New York City and James S. Fortune of Wexford, Ireland. During WWII he enlisted in the United States Coast Guard and served in Greenland. In 1949 he married Genevieve M. Baker and they had five children. Jim graduated as Valedictorian of his class in 1966 from Plymouth State College with a Bachelor's degree in Art Education. In 1969 he received a Master of Fine Arts degree in Painting from Assumption College in Worcester, MA. He met his wife Peggy (Marguerite A. Houseworth) while they were both students in the Masters of Art Education program at the Massachusetts College of Art in Boston. In 1984, Jim retired as Associate Professor of Art Emeritus from Plymouth State College in Plymouth, New Hampshire (now Plymouth State University). While at Plymouth, he was a Fulbright Exchange Professor at the Watford School in England. In addition to his wife Peggy of 36 years, Jim's surviving family members include his sister Eileen Fortune Crawford and husband Owen of Winter Park, FL, his son Jay Fortune of Farmington, NH, his daughter Joanne B. Fortune of Greenfield, MA, his son Robert D. Fortune and wife Nancy of Seattle, WA, his son Timothy P. Fortune and wife Sharon of Lincolnville, ME. His son John W. (Jack) Fortune predeceased him. His grandchildren are Janet M. Fortune of North Brookfield, MA, Caleb James Delisle of Greenfield, MA, and Nick Fortune and wife Melissa of Washington, ME, and step-grandson Logan Sampson of Lincolnville, ME. He leaves his cousin Florence Parker of Southampton, NJ, nieces, nephew, friends, and family. There will be a ceremony to celebrate his life on Saturday, August 24 at 11am in Heritage Commons on the Plymouth State University campus in Plymouth, NH. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Jim's memory may be made to the Plymouth State University Art Department Endowment Fund or to the Lamson Library Book Acquisition Fund, PSU, 17 High Street, Plymouth, NH 03264, or to a charity of one's choice.

DIERDORFF--John A.,of Manhattan and Rhinecliff, known as Jack to his many friends and his colleagues in journalism, passed away peacefully on August 8 at the Baptist Home in Rhinebeck after a long illness. He was 85. Jack's journalism career spanned more than seven decades, beginning with a mimeographed weekly newspaper that he started and ran for four years in grade school in Portland, OR, and ending with the online edition of Business Week in the early days of the Internet. Upon graduation from Yale in 1949, he returned to Portland as a reporter, and later Assistant Editor, of The Oregonian newspaper. He joined Business Week in 1956 and was Managing Editor at the time of his retirement in 1993. He then served as a consultant for 15 years, helping the magazine develop its online strategy. Jack was a lover of music, particularly jazz, classical music and opera, and served on the Board of Directors of the Bard Music Festival. He was an avid hiker, covering most of the northern Appalachian Trail. His lifelong love of trains prompted many rail excursions in North America, Europe and Asia. Jack's friend and partner of over 40 years, Alonzo Smith Jr., died in 2011. He is survived by his beloved brother David Dierdorff and sister-in-law Madeleine Lefebvre, of Juneau, AK. Jack headed the Coffee House club in New York City for many years. A memorial celebrating his life will be held there on the evening of October 2. For information, please e-mail: JackMemorialNYC@gmail.com

DESPARD--Clement Lyndon, 84, of Stonington, CT and New York died August 5, 2013. He possessed a mischievous sense of humor and a kind and creative spirit. Mr. Despard grew up in Rumson, NJ and New York and was a graduate of Harvard College. He was an officer in the army during the Korean War and pursued a career in business before becoming an artist. His whimsical, inventive work was represented by Gallery Henoch in New York, and exhibited throughout the New London area. Mr. Despard was predeceased by his wife Lucy Edwards. He leaves two daughters, Alice and Jessie, by his first wife, Caroline Scott, and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11am on August 31 at Calvary Church, 26 Church St., Stonington, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Stonington Community Center.

CASEY--E. Paul, 83, of Marblehead, MA, Hobe Sound, FL and formerly of Grosse Point, MI, died at his home in Marblehead on August 16. Mr. Casey attended the Fessenden School and graduated from Phillips-Exeter Academy in 1948. He received a B.A. from Yale University in 1952 and received a M.B.A with distinction from Harvard Business School in 1955. Mr. Casey started his career managing his family's business, Davidson Rubber Co., Inc. In 1965, Davidson was sold to McCord Corporation, and he succeeded as President of McCord the following year. Upon the merger of McCord and Ex-Cell-O Corp. in 1978, he became President and COO, and in 1981 he became CEO of Ex-Cell-O. Textron acquired Ex-Cell-O in 1986, and he became Vice Chairman of Textron. He resigned in 1987, and in 1988 founded Metapoint Partners, a private equity firm, and was Chairman Emeritus at Metapoint. In addition to serving on the boards of directors of Metapoint portfolio companies, he was also a member of the Chief Executives Organization, the Society of Automotive Engineers, and the Harvard Business School Club of Florida, President of Hobe Sound Community Chest, and Senior Warden at Christ Memorial Chapel. He served as a Director at numerous companies, including Wyman-Gordon, Comerica, Paladin Brands, Durcon Incorporated, Saint-Gobain Abrasives, Inc., and Hood Enterprises. Paul was a seasoned and successful yachtsman, racing and cruising on a wide variety of sailing vessels, especially his beloved sloop "Manticore." He served as Commodore of the Eastern Yacht Club, helping to guide the club through the modernization of many key areas, including admissions and club governance. He was also a member of the New York Yacht Club, Jupiter Island Club, Hobe Sound Yacht Club, Detroit Athletic Club, Grosse Pointe Club, Yondotega Club and the Question Club. Throughout his life, he donated his time and resources to numerous charities. His philanthropy extended from large health care institutions, such as Henry Ford Hospital and Lahey Clinic, to smaller civic organizations helping people in need, as well as many educational institutions. Paul is survived by his wife, Mary Ann (Bickford) Casey, and his five daughters, Patricia Shepherd, of Gloucester, MA, Tyler Casey, of Hull, MA, Jennifer Casey, of Marblehead, MA, Sheila McManus, of Brunswick, ME and Gina Pettengill, of Topsfield, MA. He was predeceased by his first wife of 46 years and childhood sweetheart, Patricia "Dinky" Pinkham Casey, who died in 1996. He also leaves behind four stepchildren; Pamela Patton, Ted Patton, Dick Patton, and Jennifer Rabley, and, as "Papa Paul", 24 grandchildren. Paul also leaves an enduring legacy for helping, learning from and caring for family and friends. He recognized the existential need to reach out to people of all ages. In concluding his 1998 memoir he said, "with the help of others, I have found fulfillment and joy." A memorial service will be held at St. Michael's Church in Marblehead on Friday, August 23rd at 11:00 am. In lieu of flowers, gifts can be made to Christ Memorial Chapel, 52 South Beach Road, Hobe Sound, FL 33455, or the Hobe Sound Community Chest, P.O. Box 511, Hobe Sound, FL 33475. For on line guest book or additional information please call 978-744-0497 / visit (MurphyFuneralHome.com).

BRANDT--Coleman. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Coleman Brandt, husband of Grace. Coleman's longstanding dedication and generosity has helped millions of people in need. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his children, David and Leland; daughters-in-law, Kelley and Lynne; grandchildren; and his entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

BIKOFF--Susan Kafoyat. Susan Kafoyat Bikoff, 75, on August 15, 2013, of Bal Harbor, Southampton and Manhattan. Our sweet nana, beautiful loving mother and mother-in-law to Jacqueline, Darius and Jill, devoted grandmother to Sasha, Maxwell, Ella and Beau has left us with the traditions and tools to continue life in a joyful and enriching way. From nana's upbringing in Teheran, Iran to her new life in America at an early age, she inspired all with her natural grace and elegance. She made certain that her children traveled to understand their roots and the importance of family and love. Nana touched the lives of all who met her and people gravitated to her wit and charm. Funeral service at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St., on Monday, 10am.

BOROS--Jerome S. Jerome S. Boros, the longtime village justice of Sands Point, New York, and a lawyer, died on August 15th at his home after a long illness. He was 87. Judge Boros had a long and prominent career as an attorney specializing in communications law, and at the time of his death was also Senior Vice President and General Counsel of Lotus Communications. He was also associated with the law firm of Jaspan Schlesinger in Garden City, Long Island. Prior to that, Judge Boros was a partner in the law firm of Fly Schuebruk, Gaguine, and Boros, and later associated with the law firm of Bryan Cave. He was a member of the Harmonie Club in New York. A man of diminutive bearing, Judge Boros was known as a commanding litigator who frequently wore a cowboy hat to and from the courtroom. He served as Sands Point Village Justice for more then 20 years. He was a graduate of Syracuse University and received law degrees from Syracuse and Yale. He is survived by his wife, Elayne Boros; three stepchildren, Richard Levine, Jill Levine, and Ronald Levine, and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, August 20th, at 11am, at the Community Synagogue, 160 Middle Neck Road, Port Washington, NY.

BERNSTEIN--Donna, The Alliance for Downtown New York mourns the passing of Donna J. Bernstein on August 12th. Loving wife of the Alliance's acting President and COO William Bernstein and devoted mother of Adam, an Information Associate at the Alliance. She was 62 at the time of her passing. The dedication and support that animated their family life inspired us all. Donations can be made in Donna's name to the National Kidney Foundation.

BARBATELLI--Ettore. Ettore Barbatelli, 89, was born to eternal life on July 15, 2013 surrounded by his children at his home in Mequon, WI. Born and raised in New Haven, CT, he attended Yale University, graduating in 1947 with his '45W class, earning a BS in Mechanical Engineering. A former resident of Morristown, NJ and resident of Palm Beach, FL, he spent summers in Wisconsin. He is survived by his four children, seven grandchildren and nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his wife of 62 years, Lovedy, who died in 2010. Barb, as he was known, had a long and distinquished business career. He and Lovedy founded Valuation Research Corporation in Milwaukee, WI in 1975 and he was President or Chairman for 21 years. Prior to that, he was employed by American Appraisal Company from 1947 until 1974, becoming President and CEO. Barb served on numerous corporate, professional and civic boards including Johnson Controls, Inc., Simplicity Manufacturing, Inc, National Association of Accountants (Chairman-1971)(now Institute of Management Accounting), William E. Simon School of Business at University of Rochester, and his Class of 1945 at Yale. Barb continued his Board leadership with the Florida Science Museum and the Norton Gallery of Fine Arts in Palm Beach Florida, leading its' expansion and building drives. Barb met Lovedy at a WWII USO dance. Following his return from a 40-month tour in the Asiatic Pacific theatre with the US Army Corps. of Engineers, they married in 1948, primarily living in New Jersey where they developed many life-long friends. Business advancement relocated them and their four children to Milwaukee in 1964, becoming active in the business and cultural communities there. Later and in retirement they resided in Gulfstream and Palm Beach, FL and travelled worldwide, in later years especially enjoying the Fall months in Tuscany and Umbria, with special visits to see relatives in his parents' native town. Barb leaves behind a devoted family who appreciate the loving wisdom, experiences, and strong values their parents shared with them. Likewise, many friends and colleagues share respect and admiration for rising from humble beginnings through hard work, intelligence, steadfast discipline, and friendship. Services and burial will be at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in 7845 N River Road, River Hills, WI 53217 on September 7 at 10:30am, in lieu of a planned 90th birthday celebration. Gifts in lieu of flowers to St. Christopher's, where he worshipped and served for 50 years, are preferred. Feerick Funeral Home, Milwaukee, Wisconsin. (414)962-8383.

ASCOLI--Joseph, M.D.,died on August 11, 2013, at the age of 85 years. Dr. Ascoli was born March 1928, in Andretta, Italy; he is survived by his son Paul, wife Jennifer, and three grandchildren; his daughter Ellen Pashiardis, husband Haris, four grandchildren, and former wife Nancy Parady. He completed his education at the University of Naples, Italy with a degree in medicine. He was a Diplomat in Surgery, had a private practice for thirty years in the Bronx, NY and was an attending Surgeon at Harlem Hospital, New York City. He will be missed and remembered as a skilled Physician, Humanitarian, and loving father and grandfather.

ANESHANSLEY--James T.,age 78, passed peacefully at home in Germantown, NY on August 11, 2013. Beloved husband of Julia, for 40 years, loving father of Jill, Jessica and Ethan. Devoted and cherished grandfather of Erik, Spencer, Emma, Harrison and Charlotte; also surviving are his loving sisters Pat, Gerry and Nancy and his two sons-in-law Eric and Tony. Jim leaves many friends whom he loved and was loved by. Jim, you are an inspiration and we will forever love you. You will never be forgotten.

ADLER--Michael. The Board of Overseers of Columbia Business School expresses deep sorrow at the passing of Michael Adler, Professor Emeritus of Business at Columbia Business School. For more than forty years, Professor Adler taught thousands of students in corporate and international finance. He had a profound influence on international financial markets and his work continues to be cited today. Columbia Business School extends its profound sympathy to the Adler family. Glenn Hubbard, Dean, Columbia Business School

DIMSTON--Blanche. To see the world in a grain of sand, and heaven in a wildflower, hold infinity in the palm of your hand and eternity in an hour. We miss you.
ARKIN--Albert J. April 17, 1909 to August 19, 1985. Dad - Thinking Of You. With Love, Joan

WEIL--Peter H.,79, died August 17, 2013, in Lafayette, CO. Son of Henrietta and Frank L. Weil. Survived by wife, Helen, two children, three grandsons and two brothers. Graduate of Horace Mann School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. Practiced law in New York for more than 35 years, first at his father's firm, Weil, Gotshal & Manges and then at Kaye Scholer where he was a partner, head of the firm's banking division and its leading authority on asset based lending. Retired to Colorado to enjoy the mountains. Loved classical music and was active with CU College of Music and with Colorado Music Festival; was himself a very accomplished pianist. Memorial contributions may be made to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

VACANTE--Gino. Died peacefully on May 10, 2013 in Montreal, Canada at the age of 73. Survived by his wife Sheila (nee McGahan) and his children Steven (Kathleen) and Jeffery (Tammy). Loving grandfather to Kieran, Ryan, and Ashley. He will be deeply missed.

SINDEL--Roberta (nee Ellen), of New York and Boynton Beach, Florida, passed away peacefully on Friday evening, August 16. She was surrounded by her devoted husband of 56 years, Brian, and her loving daughters, Shari Turner, Jane and Patricia. Born in Brooklyn on August 26, 1933, she was the proud grandmother of Sam and Jonathan Turner, Gabi and Michael Sindel Dymant, and mother-in-law of Stewart Turner. Funeral services will be held at the Community Synagogue of Sands Point on Monday, August 19 at noon.

SHAPIRO--Irving M.,died on August 18, 2013 after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Marilyn Goldberg and the late Ruby Shapiro. Loving father of Anne and Louise. Devoted grandfather of Rachael, Rebeka, Sam, Ruth, Danielle, Julia and Andrew. Lifelong Brooklynite. He will be missed by so many. Services today at 12 Noon at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

SANTLOFER--Joy.Unexpectedly on August 16th, 2013. Beloved wife of Jonathan, Mother of Doria, sister of Kathy. Friend to many, respected food writer and historian. Family and friends will gather at the Santlofer home on Wednesday, August 21st 4-6pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Meals on Wheels.

DIERDORFF--John A.,of Manhattan and Rhinecliff, known as Jack to his many friends and his colleagues in journalism, passed away peacefully on August 8 at the Baptist Home in Rhinebeck after a long illness. He was 85. Jack's journalism career spanned more than seven decades, beginning with a mimeographed weekly newspaper that he started and ran for four years in grade school in Portland, OR, and ending with the online edition of Business Week in the early days of the Internet. Upon graduation from Yale in 1949, he returned to Portland as a reporter, and later Assistant Editor, of The Oregonian newspaper. He joined Business Week in 1956 and was Managing Editor at the time of his retirement in 1993. He then served as a consultant for 15 years, helping the magazine develop its online strategy. Jack was a lover of music, particularly jazz, classical music and opera, and served on the Board of Directors of the Bard Music Festival. He was an avid hiker, covering most of the northern Appalachian Trail. His lifelong love of trains prompted many rail excursions in North America, Europe and Asia. Jack's friend and partner of over 40 years, Alonzo Smith Jr., died in 2011. He is survived by his beloved brother David Dierdorff and sister-in-law Madeleine Lefebvre, of Juneau, AK. Jack headed the Coffee House club in New York City for many years. A memorial celebrating his life will be held there on the evening of October 2. For information, please e-mail: JackMemorialNYC@gmail.com

KNOX--Cornelius Van Santvoord, 92, formerly of Darien, CT, passed away July 8 in Shelburne, VT. After 40 years in broadcasting, he retired as CBS Radio's Vice President of Affiliate Relations. He lived every day to the fullest; he bought new skis at 91. His wife, Nancy Cronyn Knox, passed away in 2010. He is survived by his sister, his four children, six grandchildren and a great-grandchild. We'll celebrate his life 3pm, Friday, August 23, Darien Community Association, 274 Middlesex Rd., Darien.

BURSTEIN--Irving, 86, of Riverdale, NY and Coconut Creek, FL died Saturday August 17, of cardiac arrest. Loving husband of Claire for 63 years. Beloved father of Larry, Paula, and Diane. Adored grandfather of Bari, Erin, Walter, Grace and Luke and loving father-in-law to Nancy, Lenny, and John. A lifelong New Yorker and graduate of George Washington High School, he served in World War II aboard the air craft carrier USS Antietam, and was called up again during the Korean War. Irv was a weekend fisherman, a member of the Fort George Robins football team, a storyteller. He retired after a life's work in the cigar business from Altadis (Consolidated Cigar Corporation) and as an active member of Teamsters Local 805. He was kind, generous, and not only believed that everyone deserved a chance to lead their best life, but was there for those who needed a helping hand. He was part of the greatest generation, and generously showed us how to aspire to greatness ourselves. He set the bar high. Services, Monday August 19 at 11:30am. Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 West 76th Street New York, NY 10023.

BOROS--Jerome S. Jerome S. Boros, the longtime village justice of Sands Point, New York, and a lawyer, died on August 15th at his home after a long illness. He was 87. Judge Boros had a long and prominent career as an attorney specializing in communications law, and at the time of his death was also Senior Vice President and General Counsel of Lotus Communications. He was also associated with the law firm of Jaspan Schlesinger in Garden City, Long Island. Prior to that, Judge Boros was a partner in the law firm of Fly Schuebruk, Gaguine, and Boros, and later associated with the law firm of Bryan Cave. He was a member of the Harmonie Club in New York. A man of diminutive bearing, Judge Boros was known as a commanding litigator who frequently wore a cowboy hat to and from the courtroom. He served as Sands Point Village Justice for more then 20 years. He was a graduate of Syracuse University and received law degrees from Syracuse and Yale. He is survived by his wife, Elayne Boros; three stepchildren, Richard Levine, Jill Levine, and Ronald Levine, and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, August 20th, at 11am, at the Community Synagogue, 160 Middle Neck Road, Port Washington, NY.

BIKOFF--Susan Kafoyat, The Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art express with great sadness the passing of Susan Kafoyat Bikoff beloved mother of Board member Darius Bikoff. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to Darius and Jill, their children Ella and Beau, his sister Jacqueline and the entire Bikoff family. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. BIKOFF--Susan Kafoyat. Susan Kafoyat Bikoff, 75, on August 15, 2013, of Bal Harbor, Southampton and Manhattan. Our sweet nana, beautiful loving mother and mother-in-law to Jacqueline, Darius and Jill, devoted grandmother to Sasha, Maxwell, Ella and Beau has left us with the traditions and tools to continue life in a joyful and enriching way. From nana's upbringing in Teheran, Iran to her new life in America at an early age, she inspired all with her natural grace and elegance. She made certain that her children traveled to understand their roots and the importance of family and love. Nana touched the lives of all who met her and people gravitated to her wit and charm. Funeral service at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St., on Monday, 10am.
BAUM--Nicole (nee Hirsch), on August 16, 2013. Beloved wife of Henry M. Baum. Cherished mother and grandmother. Deeply loved, she will be forever in our hearts.

WEIL--Peter H.,79, died August 17, 2013, in Lafayette, CO. Son of Henrietta and Frank L. Weil. Survived by wife, Helen, two children, three grandsons and two brothers. Graduate of Horace Mann School, Princeton University, and Harvard Law School. Practiced law in New York for more than 35 years, first at his father's firm, Weil, Gotshal & Manges and then at Kaye Scholer where he was a partner, head of the firm's banking division and its leading authority on asset based lending. Retired to Colorado to enjoy the mountains. Loved classical music and was active with CU College of Music and with Colorado Music Festival; was himself a very accomplished pianist. Memorial contributions may be made to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

TRACHTMAN--Gilbert, died August 18, 2013, one day short of 87, after a lengthy struggle with kidney disease. Loving and beloved husband of the late Joan Polan Trachtman, father of Jeffrey and Joshua, father-in-law of Sonya Yerid, grandfather of Anna, Jordan, Benjamin, and Matthew. Founder and Director of the NYU School Psychology Programs 1963-86 and a leader, innovator, and reformer in school psychology for 50 years; teacher, mentor, consultant, author, troublemaker, civil libertarian, Pharmacist's Mate U.S. Navy, and frustrated New York Giants center fielder. Services Thursday, August 22, 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In Gil's spirit, guests are invited to dress comfortably. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Gilbert M. Trachtman Fund of the NYCLU Foundation, bit.ly/GMTfund, or a charity of choice.

TEMPLE--Philip T.,80, on August 16, 2013 in Riverdale, NY. A lifelong New Yorker, Phil was a graduate of Dewitt Clinton High School, the City College of New York and Columbia University Law School, '57. As an attorney for over 50 years, he developed a national reputation as an expert in Charitable Gift Planning at Prerau and Teitell, later joining McCarthy Fingar in White Plains. Phil loved the arts, especially the musical theater. He embraced quips, the Mets, and all things New York. He is survived by his three children Adam, Pam and Eric and four grandchildren. Service Friday August 23, 2013, 1:30pm at The Riverside, 76 St at Amsterdam Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers, please remember Phil by making a contribution to the UJA Federation.

SCHWARTZMAN--Dr. Isidore, a resident of Chelsea for over 60 years, died of heart failure on August 14th, 2013 at the age of 92. He retired 23 years ago, after practicing dentistry in the neighborhood for over 42 years. Like his late wife Jacqueline, a well-known local political activist who founded the Chelsea Independent Democrat, Isidore also got involved in the community. He was particularly proud of having planted the very first tree in Chelsea in 1959. A graduate of CCNY in 1939, he was a WWII veteran and after his retirement, he became a founding member of QUEST, the CCNY Adult Learning Community, where he began writing. Later, at the age of 88, he also started to paint and his unique impressionist style earned him the nickname of the "Grandpa Moses" of 22nd Street. To celebrate his 90th birthday, Dr. Schwartzman's first book, "Struts & Frets," a collection of his stories, photographs and water colors, was published by his children, Leslie (Hoban) Blake, Stephen Short, Cheryl Bulbach and Wayne Blackmon, all of whom survive him. Donations in his memory may be made to the NYPL, the ADL and/or Quest/CCNY.

MURRAY--Albert. Jazz at Lincoln Center mourns the passing of our friend Albert Murray, one of America's great cultural thinkers and one of our original champions. Albert's conceptions are the intellectual foundation of our institution. He spoke eloquently on the significance of American vernacular to the fine art of jazz. Deeply philosophical about jazz's rightful place in the pantheon of Western arts, Albert was an engaged listener to jazz of all styles, and had a profound belief in the transformative power of the music. Our friend will be missed, and his contributions will increase in significance as time goes on. Robert Appel, Chairman and Wynton Marsalis, Managing & Artistic Director

MASTER--Edith Louise, daughter of Dr. Arthur M. Master and Hilda Altschul Master of New York City, died August 18, 2013 at the age of 80. Edith was a champion equestrian and a member of four U.S. Olympic teams. When she won the bronze medal in team dressage at the 1976 Olympic Games in Montreal, Edith became the second-oldest United States woman to win an Olympic medal in any sport. She is survived by her sister, Camilla M. Rosenfeld, her brother-in-law Isadore Rosenfeld, her niece, Hildi Rosenfeld Silbert, and her three nephews, Arthur Rosenfeld, Stephen Rosenfeld and Herbert Rosenfeld. Services are private.

LIEBERMAN--Bruce S.,of Livingston, NJ, on Monday, August 19, 2013, beloved husband of Stacey; devoted father of Alex Stephen and Sydney Hannah; loving son of Lenore and Martin; cherished brother of Denise Wanda Lieberman; fond uncle of Brian Joshua Mendel and Melanie Sarah Mendel; adored grandson of Thelma Berman; dear son-in-law of Karen and Howard Whitman. Funeral service Wednesday, August 21, at 11am in the Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzma Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ.

KUTLER--Sidney I.,97, of Hewlett Harbor, NY and Boca Raton, FL passed away on August 18, 2013. He will be deeply missed because "everyone loves Sid." Sidney is survived by his wife Evelyn, daughters Nita, Honey, Teresa and Maryann, five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Graveside Service: Wednesday, 11am, Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

KLEIN--David Bertram. April 20, 1925 - August 18, 2013. Son of Julius and Blondine. Brother of the late Jerome. Father of Lorinda, Warren and Mary Lou. Pre-deceased by wife, Ruth. Survived by former wife, Vera. Veteran, WWII - ASTRAP. Graduate of NYU and Columbia. Engineer, Hospital Administrator, native New Yorker, American. Funeral Tuesday, August 20, 2013 at 11am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

HOLLANDER--John. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our distinguished colleague. A poet and critic of unparalleled range and brilliance, he worked for decades to expand the possibilities of the imagination. His work has changed and exhilarated us.

HOLLANDER--John. The trustees and staff of The Library of America are saddened by the death of John Hollander, eminent poet, esteemed editor, and dear friend. We send sincere sympathies to his wife Natalie and daughters Elizabeth and Martha. D. Ronald Daniel, Chairman Cheryl Hurley, President

HELFANT--David, 84, of Queens, New York, widower of Mickee, beloved father of Mindy A. Helfant-Ross (Daniel) brother to Sidney Helfant (Rosalie) and uncle to Adam (Sheila) and Robert (Nogah) Helfant, has passed away peacefully in his home. His funeral will be at Star of David Chapel on Thursday, August 22 at 10am with interment to immediately follow at New Montefiore Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family wishes donations be made in his memory to Fisher House. For more information: jewish-funeral-home.com

GERSTNER--Louis V.,III, passed away on August 14, 2013 at the age of 41 after a choking incident while dining in a restaurant. Beloved father of Grace and Olivia, he was the President of the Gerstner Family Foundation. A graduate of St. Paul's School, Princeton University and Columbia Business School, he dedicated much of his adult life to providing educational opportunities to underprivileged children. In addition to his children, he is survived by his sister, Dr. Elizabeth Gerstner and his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis V. Gerstner, Jr.

DeCHILLO--Douglas, on August 18th, 2013, at age 55, from complications of multiple myeloma. Beloved son of the late Michael and Patricia (nee Fischetti) and brother of Robert, Thomas, Neal, Frank, Bruce and the late Michael. Also survived by his loving sisters-in-law and nine adoring nieces and nephews. Visiting Tuesday, 7-9pm and Wednesday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at the Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home, 255 9th Street, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass Thursday 10am, St. Saviour Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Donations may be made in Douglas' name to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation at themmrf.org.

COLTON--William Kingsley, 89, of Hanover, NH died peacefully on August 18th with his wife of 62 years, Amanda (nee Eggert) by his side. In addition to his wife, he leaves behind three children, Peter B. (Laura) of Burnsville, MN, Catherine C. Drake (Jonathan) of St. Davids, PA, and Anne Colton Sapp (Daniel) of Mill Valley, CA and eight grandchildren. He was predeceased by his brothers the Reverend Harold Bradford Colton and Michael Olcott Colton. Known as Kingsley, he attended McBurney School in New York City and worked as a child model and radio actor to support his family during the Depression, appearing regularly on such shows as "My Son and I" and "Let's Pretend." In Orson Welles' and John Houseman's 1938 production of "A Christmas Carol" on The Campbell Playhouse, Kingsley played the role of Tiny Tim, and in Welles' Mercury Theater production of "Oliver Twist" he played the role of Oliver. After serving in the Army he entered Columbia University on the GI Bill, receiving his BA and later an MA in American History. He spent his adult career at Young & Rubicam holding various administrative positions and was named a vice president. He and his family resided in Lloyd Harbor, Long Island before he retired with his wife to Kendal at Hanover in 1991. A Burial Mass will be held at 10am on Friday, August 23rd at St. Denis Church, in Hanover, NH. No memorials please.

BROOKS--Rachel Edell, died peacefully at her home at the age of 100 years and three months. She is predeceased by her loving husband George and survived by Robert and Stuart her devoted sons and her daughter-in-law Brenda.

BENJAMIN--Samuel Henry, passed away peacefully at his home on August 18th. He was the beloved husband of Joy DeVries Benjamin for 62 years, devoted father of Lisa Benjamin-Dancy, Mark Harris Benjamin, Susan Frances Benjamin, and adoring grandfather of Hannah Miriam Dancy, father-in-law of Joel Prihoda, brother of the late Martin Benjamin and survived by his sister Ruth and numerous nieces and nephews. He was a loving, gentle, sweet natured and honorable man who will be forever missed but always present in our hearts. Services will be Today, August 20th at 1pm at the Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore, 1001 Plandome Rd., Manhasset, NY 11030.

TRACHTMAN--Gilbert, died August 18, 2013, one day short of 87, after a lengthy struggle with kidney disease. Loving and beloved husband of the late Joan Polan Trachtman, father of Jeffrey and Joshua, father-in-law of Sonya Yerid, grandfather of Anna, Jordan, Benjamin, and Matthew. Founder and Director of the NYU School Psychology Programs 1963-86 and a leader, innovator, and reformer in school psychology for 50 years; teacher, mentor, consultant, author, troublemaker, civil libertarian, Pharmacist's Mate U.S. Navy, and frustrated New York Giants center fielder. Services Thursday, August 22, 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In Gil's spirit, guests are invited to dress comfortably. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Gilbert M. Trachtman Fund of the NYCLU Foundation, bit.ly/GMTfund, or a charity of choice.

TEMPLE--Philip T.,80, on August 16, 2013 in Riverdale, NY. A lifelong New Yorker, Phil was a graduate of Dewitt Clinton High School, the City College of New York and Columbia University Law School, '57. As an attorney for over 50 years, he developed a national reputation as an expert in Charitable Gift Planning at Prerau and Teitell, later joining McCarthy Fingar in White Plains. Phil loved the arts, especially the musical theater. He embraced quips, the Mets, and all things New York. He is survived by his three children Adam, Pam and Eric and four grandchildren. Service Friday August 23, 2013, 1:30pm at The Riverside, 76 St at Amsterdam Ave., NYC. In lieu of flowers, please remember Phil by making a contribution to the UJA Federation.

SULLIVAN--Kenneth W.,Sr., 58, formerly of Mountainside, NJ, New York City, and Manasquan, passed away on Monday, August 19, 2013 surrounded by his loving friends and family. He is survived by his wife, Linda Greenberg, son, Ken, daughter, Katie and five brothers and sisters. For complete obituary information please go to: neary-quinnfuneralhome.com

ROTHWELL--Alexander Falcon, Of Westport, CT, and Remsenburg, NY, treasured son of Susan and Jim Rothwell and adored brother of Zachary, died unexpectedly on August 12, 2013, at the age of 13. Joyous, singular soul, fearless explorer, adventurous spirit, fiery and sensitive, impulsive tinkerer, brilliant mathematician, science Olympian, voracious fantasy reader, Clash of Clans addict, ocean lover, prodigious builder of all things, and reluctant paddle board champion, Alex's blazing smile lit the way. His death devastates those he touched, yet our hearts overflow with the utmost pride in his life -- in his intelligence, his wit, his energy, his beauty, and his unwavering faith in his ideas. Alex's family and friends invite you to join them in celebrating Alex's life at the Unitarian Church in Westport, CT, on Saturday, August 24th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, if you would like to make a small donation in Alex's honor please consider Oceana, a cause that Alex cared about: https://act.oceana.org/ donate/d-donate.

McMANUS--James T. Jr.,57, died peacefully on August 13, 2013. A Brooklyn Heights resident for 33 years, Jim was born in Albany, NY and graduated from Vincentian Institute, Hamilton College, and Rutgers University's MBA Program. A 22 year employee of the New York Times, Jim was a Digital Inventory Manager. Jim was predeceased by his Dad, James T. McManus, Sr. and is survived by his mother, Beatrice and his sisters Ellen Laurencin, Mary McManus, and Bridget Honeycutt, and their beloved families. An inveterate traveler, fluent in four languages, Jim was dryly funny, an avid reader, a music lover, a loyal son, brother and friend. He will be deeply missed and forever remembered.

LAPORTE--John Henry Jr.,"Jack", on August 12, 2013 John H. "Jack" Laporte, Jr., 68, passed away peacefully surrounded by family at his home in Ruxton, MD. Jack was the beloved husband of Andrea Berry Laporte, devoted father of Christopher Palmer Laporte and his wife Jennifer and Timothy Marshall Laporte, loving grandfather of Christopher Palmer Laporte, Jr. and Isabel Margaret Laporte, and dear brother of Jill Laporte Sklarz. Jack was preceded in death by his parents, John Sr. and Donna Bailey Laporte. A loyal employee of T Rowe Price for more than 35 years, Jack managed the firm's New Horizons Fund with great success from 1987 to 2010. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 28, 2013 at 1pm at Old St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 233 Charles St., Baltimore, MD 21225. Memorial donations, in lieu of flowers, may be made to The SEED School of Maryland c/o Maria Darby 200 Font Hill Ave., Baltimore, MD 21223, The Walters Art Museum c/o Julia Keller, 600 N. Charles St., Baltimore, MD 21201, or The John H Laporte Class of '67 Memorial Fund at Princeton University, P.O. Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08543-5357.

LANDAU--Noemi, 91 years old, of Jackson Heights, NY, passed away August 11, 2013. Services were held on August 20. Donations in her memory may be made to Selfhelp Community Services at: www.selfhelp.net.
KUTLER--Sidney. We mourn our esteemed member's passing and send heartfelt sympathy to his family. Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre

HOLLANDER--John. The Saul Steinberg Foundation acknowledges with sorrow the death of John Hollander, who served on the board at the behest of the artist and was the foundation's first president. Sheila Schwartz, Executive Director; Prudence Crowther, Ian Frazier, Jeffrey Hoffeld, Megan Fox Kelly

HESS--Linda A.,on August 20, 2013, of Port Washington. Beloved wife of Stephen. Loving mother of Brian (Cristina) Hess and Suzanne (Michael) Fanous. Cherished grandmother of Casey, Carly and Chloe. Devoted sister of William (Cathy) McCarthy and Thomas (Lisa) McCarthy. Visitation will be on Wednesday 7-9pm and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30am, St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington with interment to follow at Nassau Knolls Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to NSUH-Healthcare Foundation, North Shore LIJ Lung Cancer Program, 125 Community Dr., Great Neck, NY, 11021 Attn: Christina Bishop-Feeney.

HELFANT--David, 84, of Queens, New York, widower of Mickee, beloved father of Mindy A. Helfant-Ross (Daniel) brother to Sidney Helfant (Rosalie) and uncle to Adam (Sheila) and Robert (Nogah) Helfant, has passed away peacefully in his home. His funeral will be at Star of David Chapel on Thursday, August 22 at 10am with interment to immediately follow at New Montefiore Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family wishes donations be made in his memory to Fisher House. For more information: jewish-funeral-home.com

GREENE--George, 91 years old, died August 19, 2013. Beloved husband of Sonya. Very devoted father of David, Jeffrey, Leslie and Jessica. Cherished grandfather of eleven. Dear brother of Judith Gran. He was a wonderful, generous person who was loved by all who knew him. Services: Wednesday, August 21, 2013 at 11am at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

DeCHILLO--Douglas, on August 18th, 2013, at age 55, from complications of multiple myeloma. Beloved son of the late Michael and Patricia (nee Fischetti) and brother of Robert, Thomas, Neal, Frank, Bruce and the late Michael. Also survived by his loving sisters-in-law and nine adoring nieces and nephews. Visiting Tuesday, 7-9pm and Wednesday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at the Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home, 255 9th Street, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass Thursday 10am, St. Saviour Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Donations may be made in Douglas' name to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation at themmrf.org.
BECK--Barbara. We will surely miss you. Love, the Nusims

BASKIN--Alex. In loving memory of Dr. Alex Baskin, 85, formerly of Jersey City, New Jersey, who passed away on August 17, 2013 in Birmingham, Alabama. Devoted father to Amy and Julie (Paul), beloved grandfather to Clare, Rachael, David, and Harlan, and loving brother to Arnold. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he was predeceased by his older brother, Sam, and parents, Benjamin and Rose. Graveside service at 10:30am Friday, August 23rd at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

BARTOSIK--Edward. National Council of Jewish Women New York Section mourns the passing of our visionary colleague and friend, Ed Bartosik. Ed's enthusiasm for the arts was an inspiration for all. He will be fondly remembered and missed. Sincerest condolences to Jacqui, Zachariah and Ellesse, and his many friends. Paula A. TRAUT--Charron Follett. Accomplished actress of stage, film and television, passed away on Saturday, August 17, 2013, in Hinsdale, IL. Charron was born in 1933 in River Forest, Ill., to Robert and Glenna Follett. She took the stage at age five in the title role of Heidi at Chicago's Civic Theatre in 1938, beginning a remarkable acting career that spanned seven decades. Through her teenage years, Charron worked professionally in radio and television in Chicago before moving to New York in the 1950's to perform on stage and in a series of dramatic roles for broadcast television. A protege of Helen Hayes, and Lillian and Dorothy Gish, Charron shared the stage and screen with these and other noted actors, including Claude Rains, Jessica Tandy, and Hume Cronyn. In 1956, Charron married Richard "Dick" Traut of Oak Park, a lieutenant in the U.S. Army at the time. Later Dick joined the Follett family business and the couple moved to Hinsdale to raise their family. Charron continued to pursue acting at the Theatre of Western Springs (TWS), performing for over 45 years in 34 plays and over 300 performances between 1962 and 2009. In 2004, she was named Active Laureate at TWS, where she remained a devoted member until her death. Charron attended Oak Park and River Forest High School, and studied acting at Northwestern University. She received a scholarship to the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London, where she earned a degree. Charron also earned a degree from the University of London. While in England pursuing her studies, she was presented to Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace in 1953. Charron F. Traut is survived by her husband, Dick, her children, Christopher D. (Lee) Traut and Sabrina T. (Patrick) Usher, her grandchildren, Benjamin and Catherine Traut, Alexandra, Samantha, James and Christopher Usher, her sister Dona (Paul Richard "Dick") Litzsinger, as well as many nieces and nephews. Charron is preceded in death by her daughter, Victoria Ann Traut, and her sister, Michelle "Shelley" F. (Robert) Iverson. Visitation is scheduled for Thursday, August 22nd, from 4:00 to 8:00pm at Adolf Funeral Home, 7000 S. Madison Street, Willowbrook. Family and friends will meet on Friday, August 23rd, at 10:30am for Mass at Notre Dame Catholic Church, 64 Norfolk Avenue, Clarendon Hills. Services will conclude at the church. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Foundation of the Theater of Western Springs 4384 Hampton Avenue, Western Springs, IL 60558 would be appreciated. Service information: 630-325-2300 or www.adolfservices.com.

SPECTER--David Kenneth. The Trustees and Staff of The Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass mourn the loss of our Board President and send our sincere condolences to his wife Patricia Brown Specter, his sons and their families. As a trustee from 1999 and Board President from 2008, David guided the Neustadt Collection with loyalty and enthusiasm. His warmth and wise counsel will be greatly missed.

ROTHWELL--Alexander Falcon, Of Westport, CT, and Remsenburg, NY, treasured son of Susan and Jim Rothwell and adored brother of Zachary, died unexpectedly on August 12, 2013, at the age of 13. Joyous, singular soul, fearless explorer, adventurous spirit, fiery and sensitive, impulsive tinkerer, brilliant mathematician, science Olympian, voracious fantasy reader, Clash of Clans addict, ocean lover, prodigious builder of all things, and reluctant paddle board champion, Alex's blazing smile lit the way. His death devastates those he touched, yet our hearts overflow with the utmost pride in his life -- in his intelligence, his wit, his energy, his beauty, and his unwavering faith in his ideas. Alex's family and friends invite you to join them in celebrating Alex's life at the Unitarian Church in Westport, CT, on Saturday, August 24th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, if you would like to make a small donation in Alex's honor please consider Oceana, a cause that Alex cared about: https://act.oceana.org/ donate/d-donate.

McCULLOUGH--James J.,Jr. Coney Island Pioneering Family. Jim, 84, of Massapequa, NY, passed away August 19, peacefully at home. Loving husband to the late Lois, son of the late James & Helen. Cherished by daughters Carol, Mary & Anthony Meluso, Lois & Tim Goulis, Nancy and five grandchildren. Jimmy spent his life as the owner of an amusement park in Coney Island. WIRTH--Russell D. L. Jr.,83 years old, died peacefully August 9th in Peoria, AZ. Russell D. L. Wirth Jr. was born to Russell D. L. Wirth and Mary McMahon Wirth in Milwaukee, WI on June 30, 1930. He earned a BA summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa, from Yale University in 1951 and an MBA with honors from Johns Hopkins University in 1954. In 1958, Russell married Alice Guion Ardrey of Dallas, TX. The couple divorced in 1971. Russell's business career included: Underwriter, Blyth & Co., 1954-59; Latin Am. Loan Officer, US Dev. Loan Fund, 1960-61; EVP, Int'l Invest Co., 1962-64; Invest Officer, Chase Int'l Co., 1965-67; President, Puerto Rican Financial Group, 1968-92; Co-founder, Hemisphere Oil Co., 1978-1993; Founder, Wirth and Co. Invest Bankers, 1989- Russell's military career included: 2nd Lieutenant, US Marine Corps Reserve, Korea, 1951-53: Decorated Silver Star, Bronze Star, Purple Heart, UN Korean War medal with three stars, Presidential unit citation; Major, US Army Special Forces, 1977-84. Russell's athletic achievements include: 2x All-Am, US Triathlon; 4x FL State champ, Sprint Triathlon; Member U.S. National Triathlon Team. He is survived by his son Russell D.L. Wirth III, his daughter Mary Elizabeth Wirth, his sister Mary Rogers Littell and his brother Harry McMahon Wirth.

SHORIN--Edward. Long Island University mourns the loss of Edward Shorin, University trustee and chancellor of LIU Brentwood and LIU Riverhead. A champion of lifelong learning and a generous benefactor of the University's scholarship programs and Hutton House Lectures, Mr. Shorin helped change the face of continuing education on Long Island and empowered countless students to pursue their dreams. His wisdom, creativity and commitment to our students knew no bounds, and his legacy will live on in those whose lives he touched. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Kimberly R. Cline President, LIU Edward Travaglianti Chairman, Board of Trustees, LIU

ROTHWELL--Alexander Falcon, Of Westport, CT, and Remsenburg, NY, treasured son of Susan and Jim Rothwell and adored brother of Zachary, died unexpectedly on August 12, 2013, at the age of 13. Joyous, singular soul, fearless explorer, adventurous spirit, fiery and sensitive, impulsive tinkerer, brilliant mathematician, science Olympian, voracious fantasy reader, Clash of Clans addict, ocean lover, prodigious builder of all things, and reluctant paddle board champion, Alex's blazing smile lit the way. His death devastates those he touched, yet our hearts overflow with the utmost pride in his life -- in his intelligence, his wit, his energy, his beauty, and his unwavering faith in his ideas. Alex's family and friends invite you to join them in celebrating Alex's life at the Unitarian Church in Westport, CT, on Saturday, August 24th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, if you would like to make a small donation in Alex's honor please consider Oceana, a cause that Alex cared about: https://act.oceana.org/ donate/d-donate.

GATES--John Sanford, age 95, of Lake Forest, Illinois passed away on August 20, 2013. Born in Billings Montana, he was the son of Everett C. Gates and Edith H. Gates. In life, he was surrounded by the joy of his family and his ever loving wife of 62 years, Christine S. Gates. John was a graduate of Montana State University. He served our country in World War II as a United States Army Colonel in various campaigns throughout Burma and China - including the opening of the Burma Road. He then went onto The Wharton School of Business at The University of Pennsylvania, where he met his future wife Christine. He spent his career in the investment world, where he held senior management positions at Allied Chemical, Marsh and McClennan and Smith Barney, from which he retired at age 88. His primary philanthropic interests were in education. He and his wife established The Gates Center for Leadership and Personal Growth at Lake Forest College. He is survived by his son John S. Gates, Jr. (Weezie), Susan Gates Cooper (Bill), Sarah Gates Colley (Bryan) and his grandchildren: John S. Gates III, Edward H. Gates, Thomas J. Gates, Ellen M. Cooper, Kaitlin L. Cooper, Christine L. Colley and Benjamin G. Colley. A memorial service will be held at 11am, on Saturday, August 24th at The Church of The Holy Spirit, 400 E. Westminster, Lake Forest, Illinois. In lieu of flowers, donations would be gratefully accepted by The Gates Center for Leadership and Personal Growth at Lake Forest College, 555 N. Sheridan Road, Lake Forest, Illinois 60045.

EISENBERG--Martin E. Beloved father to Jewlia and Samuel, husband to Rhonda, friend to many. Community organizer, teacher, and fierce advocate for racial and economic justice. Sociology Professor, Queens College; Assistant Director, United Community Centers; Director, Camp Hurley. He will be sorely missed. Memorial Sunday, August 25, 1:00pm, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

DAYTON--Mary Lee Lowe, community leader, philanthropist, and supporter of women's issues, died peacefully at her home in Wayzata, MN on August 21, 2013. She was predeceased by her husband of fifty-four years, Wallace C. Dayton, who died in 2002. Born in Marshall, Missouri, on May 12, 1925, she was the daughter of Braddie Douglass Lowe and the Reverend Arnold Hilmer Lowe. She attended John Borroughs School in St. Louis, and graduated from Northrop Collegiate School in Minneapolis in 1943 and from Vassar College in 1946. Always active in community affairs, she held leadership positions in many organizations in the Twin Cities and elsewhere. She served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Macalester College, The Minneapolis Foundation, The Minneapolis YWCA, and Planned Parenthood of Minnesota, and was a founder of the Minnesota Women's Fund, now the Women's Foundation of Minnesota. She also served as a Board member of the Breck School, the Mississippi River Fund, the Ripley Memorial Foundation, the Sister Kenny Foundation, the Greater Twin Cities United Way, the University of Minnesota Arboretum Foundation, Vassar College, Westminster Presbyterian Church, and other organizations. In addition, after her husband's death, she remained committed to the environmental organizations that he had led and supported, including The Nature Conservancy and the National Audubon Society, and others. She is survived by her four daughters, Sally D. Clement (Stephen) of New York City, Katherine D. Nielsen (Stuart) and Ellen D. Grace, both of Minneapolis, and Elizabeth D. Dovydenas (Jonas) of Lenox, MA, and nine grandchildren: Theodore and Winston Clement; John and Elena Dovydenas; Olivia Nielsen; Samuel Richardson; and Matthew, Katherine, and Rosamond Sturgis. The family wishes to thank Becky Fredericks and her staff for their caring service. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in her name to any of the above organizations, or the charity of the donor's choice. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 7 at 3 pm at Westminster Presbyterian Church, 1200 Marquette Avenue South, Minneapolis.

CLARK--John Stephen, of Bronxville, NY passed away suddenly on August 21, 2013. He is survived by his beloved wife of 52 years, Mary Caroline (Leary). Loving father of John Stephen, Jr. (Heidi), Danny, Margie (Stephen Finn) and Jennifer (Tim McGrath). Devoted grandfather of John III and David Clark, Kevin, Michael, Charlie and Carrie Finn, Tim, Caroline, Sean and Brendan McGrath. Dear brother of Anne Prout and the late Joseph P. Clark. Also surviving are several nieces and nephews. Born January 4, 1929 in Queens Village, NY, John graduated from Georgetown University (BA), Columbia Law School (JD) and Columbia University (MA in European Studies, 2001). He Served in Korea (1952-53) as a 1st Lieutenant, US Air Force and as an Assistant US Attorney (SDNY). John was a senior partner of Abeles, Clark, Osterberg and Prager, specializing in copyright and entertainment litigation representing many clients including the rock and roll band AC/DC. He was Counsel to the New York State Racing Commission, a member of the Planning Board of the City of Yonkers and Director of the Puccini Foundation. He was a Knight of Malta and Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. He was a former member of the of Directors of the Georgetown University Alumni Association, a Trustee of St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, a tutor at St. Ignatius Middle School and mediator for the US District Court (SDNY). Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street, Bronxville, NY, between the hours of 4 to 7pm Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, Aug. 26 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Archdiocese of New York Inner City Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Avenue, NY, NY 10022.

BOISI--James O.,Passed away August 21, 2013 at his home surrounded by three generations of his family. This quintessential New Yorker was born in 1919 on the Lower East Side, and educated in the New York public school system attending Stuyvesant High School, Brooklyn College and Fordham Law School. His first position was at the law firm of Amend & Amend where he gravitated to the practice of real estate law, ultimately representing clients such as the legendary William Zeckendorf, Sr. in many real estate dealings. In 1956 he was then offered a position as real estate attorney for the New York Central Railroad eventually becoming Vice President of Real Estate. During his tenure he made a profound impact on the New York City skyline by transforming the residential corridor of Park Avenue above Grand Central Station into high-rise office towers by arranging ground leases with developers on property owned by the railroad. He was visionary in his use of utilizing the concept of "air rights" to increase the buildable area of buildings in NYC. In 1964, Thomas Gates recruited Mr. Boisi to Morgan Guaranty Trust Company to head a newly formed Real Estate ultimately being promoted to Executive Vice President of Corporate Finance in 1970 and then to Executive Vice President of the parent company J.P. Morgan & Co. in 1972. He headed Strategic Planning for the Bank creating an Investment Banking Group and Merger department. In 1978 Mr. Boisi was then elected Vice Chairman of the Board and Director and a member of the Corporate Office where he served until his retirement in 1984. Boisi was a staunch advocate for New York working closely with then Governor Hugh Carey establishing International Banking Facilities to lure offshore banking business back to the United States. He also helped secure financing for the transit system of NYC and was a lead banker in providing support for the Municipal Assistance Corporation (MAC) which brought NYC out of bankruptcy in 1975. Upon his mandatory retirement from the bank, Harry Helmsley persuaded him to join Helmsley Enterprises as Executive Vice President where he served from 1984 through 1987. Mr. Boisi was then asked by The British Coal Board to become Chairman of its US property subsidiary, Pan American Properties, serving from 1987 through 1990. In 1991 he set about establishing the Mentoring Partnership of Long Island. Mr. Boisi chaired the Leadership Council until 1996 and served as Co-Chair from 1996 - 2000. He has served on several Boards of Directors over his career including Cities Service Co., Denny's, J.P. Morgan & Co., Boy Scouts of America, the Real Estate Board of New York, and Mentoring Partnership of Long Island. For 51 Years of his impressive business career Mr. Boisi also taught real estate at Pace University in the evenings becoming Co-Chairman of the Department and finally a Trustee Emeritus of the University. Mr. Boisi was a devout Catholic serving as an active parishioner of St. Mary's Church and lector for Sunday Mass. He was also a Knight of Malta. Mr. Boisi is survived by his loving wife of 68 years Edith Mae Mullen, six children James, Geoffrey (Rene Isacco), Jeanne (Robert) Sheehy, Mark (Barbara Gallagher), Patricia (John) Sheehy, Eileen (William) Dobbs, 19 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A wake will be held at Beney Funeral Home, Syosset, NY on August 23rd from 2-5pm and 7-9pm and a Funeral Mass will be held on August 24th, 10am at St. Mary's Church, Roslyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mentoring Partnership of Long Island.
