SHEPARD--Martin Elliot. 5/20/48-8/24/73 Forty years ago today, Marty passed away. Bright and talented, there was so much promise ahead in his life. His kidneys were transplanted into others. A success at the time and of some consolation. He'll always be loved and missed. Wendy, Lora and Irving
LANGERMAN--Bea, Redhead. How lucky we were to be touched by you. Never will you be forgotten. Love always, Herb and Brian

SHEIMAN--Louis, MD, July 6, 1921 - August 22, 2013, 92, died of Parkinson's disease surrounded by his family. He maintained a private practice in hematology/oncology in New York City and was loved by his patients. He was an attending physician at Montefiore Hospital and on the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He became the medical director of the Health Insurance Plan of New York. He graduated with honors from DeWitt Clinton, Phi Beta Kappa from NYU, and received his medical degree from NYU School of Medicine. He carried himself with modesty, compassion and humor. He will be remembered for his intellect, wit and sound advice. Most important in his life was his family. He married Jean (Fink) in 1951. He was the adored father of Dr. Robert Sheiman and Nina Sheiman Goldweit, and admiring father-in-law of Sara Sheiman and Dr. Richard Goldweit. He was the cherished grandfather of Jennie (William) Sheiman Katz, Dr. Daniel Goldweit, Dara Sheiman, and Alana Goldweit, and the proud great-grandfather of Ezra Katz. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Englewood Hospital and Medical Center, Englewood, NJ. Services will be held 11:45am Sunday August 25, 2013 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City.

SHABER--Sandra. Exceptional woman who worked hard, played hard, had it all. 60-year love affair with husband Gary; caring and nurturing mother to Ruth and Steven; inspirational role model to granddaughters Hannah, Maddy and Allison; faithful sister to Allan and Gary. Born 1935, Toledo, Ohio, to Eve and David Cohen; died August 9, near her grand, historic home in Society Hill, Philadelphia. Sandra was all about balance world traveler who never forgot her Midwest roots; career achiever who put family first; politically engaged liberal, compassionate but tough-minded; fierce competitor and constructive collaborator; pioneering feminist who made a fashion statement; acquisitive intellectual who devoured spy novels; discerning gourmand with a taste for Philly cheesesteaks. Ohio State BA and MFA; Penn PhD in international relations. Superstar econometric consultant, go-to authority on consumer economics, regularly quoted and interviewed in the business press and media Wall Street Journal, NPR, CNN, PBS NewsHour. Retired in 1999 to travel extensively, pursue cultural interests, read voraciously, support good causes and actively participate in the Foreign Policy Research Institute. Sandra will be remembered by her adoring family, loyal friends and esteemed colleagues with great love, admiration and respect. Donations in her name will be welcomed by the Free Library of Philadelphia.

SCHUPF--Jana Beller, 103, at home. Daughter of Simon and Rose Beller, born in Poland and raised in Vienna. Married Jacques Schupf and together raised four children: Lucienne, John, Gabrielle and Nicole. Nine grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. Studied philology at the University of Vienna. Settled in America in 1938, and always lived in New York. She was a great hostess with an impeccable sense of style and a biting sense of humor. Loved art, Mahler, and nature, especially mountains. An avid sportswoman and a great reader who had a firm belief in the value of Latin. She will be missed by all who knew her. Funeral services at Riverside Chapel, Sunday August 25 at 11.15am.

ROSENWALD--James B. Jr.,"Jimmy", 82, of Ossining, NY, passed away on August 20, 2013. Beloved husband to wife, Mimi, devoted father of Jamie (Laura), Jill (Lawrence McRae), Cynthia Coudert (Brian Morris), Sandra Graham (Todd), cherished grandfather of Jocelyn, Benno, Hailey, Thea, Bennett, Caroline and Loch, dear brother of Pat Heller. Everybody loved Jimmy. Funeral Services to be held at The University Club of New York, 1 West 54th St., New York, NY, Wednesday August 28 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Teatown Lake Reservation (teatown.org) or Cancer Research Institute (cancerresearch.org).
NOCERA--David. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of David Nocera, associated with The New York Times from April 1, 1958 until retiring on January 1, 1993.

KAPLAN--Leo, on August 21, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Loving father of Susie, Alan and the late Roberta. Adoring grandfather of Jackie, Zak, Keith, Jake and Jarrett. Services: Monday, 2pm, Sharon Gardens Cemetery, 273 Lakeview Ave., Valhalla, NY.

GOODMAN--Bernice "Bunny" Wedeen. Born August 2, 1920 in Manhattan to Sylvia and William Wedeen, died at home in Riverdale on August 22, 2013. Bunny attended NYU, became a licensed real estate broker and a noted interior designer. Predeceased by the love of her life, her husband of 69 years, Dr. David Goodman and her devoted daughter Sally Fran (at age 33) in 1982. She is survived by her loving son, Thomas and her treasured grandson Tristan and many adoring nieces and nephews. Her beauty, quick wit and her gift for telling a great story or joke endeared her to many friends who will miss her forever. Rest in peace our dear "Bunny."

FISHBEIN--Zenon. Manhattan School of Music is deeply saddened by the passing of Zenon Fishbein, an alumnus and distinguished member of the College and Precollege piano faculties since 1961. His artistry, intellect and compassion have had an enormous impact on generations of pianists. As a colleague and friend he will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his three sons, Elliot, Eric and Loren, and five grandchildren. Peter G. Robbins, Chairman, Board of Trustees James Gandre, President

EISENBERG--Martin E. Beloved father to Jewlia and Samuel, husband to Rhonda, friend to many. Community organizer, teacher, and fierce advocate for racial and economic justice. Sociology Professor, Queens College; Assistant Director, United Community Centers; Director, Camp Hurley. He will be sorely missed. Memorial Sunday, August 25, 1:00pm, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

CANDIOTTI--Dr. Alan, 66, of Bernardsville, New Jersey, died suddenly on August 19, 2013. Alan was the interim Dean of Drew University's College of Liberal Arts in Madison, NJ and a valued member of the University's Faculty and Administration since 1980. He was a celebrated teacher, department head and administrator as well as a leader in the Governor's school for New Jersey high school students. He was a devoted son, the family historian, an active member of Congregation B'nai Israel in Basking Ridge, NJ and a lifelong Yankees fan. Alan is survived by many cousins, colleagues, students and friends. He will be sorely missed and remembered fondly. A memorial service is being planned on the Drew campus for the fall. Memorial contributions in honor of Alan may be made to Drew University.

BOISI--James O. The Officers and Directors of the Realty Foundation of New York are saddened at the loss of James Boisi. Remembered with great fondness, James was a legend in the industry, paving the way for the next generation of real estate professionals. With his knowledge and expertise, mentoring all through the real estate maze. Our heartfelt condolences to Mark Boisi, Vice President and good friend of the foundation and to the entire Boisi family. Jerry L. Cohen, Chairman H. Dale Hemmerdinger, President Officers and Directors

BARKLE--Richard N.,formerly of Water Mill, NY, passed away on August 7, 2013 in San Francisco, CA. During his many years at Pan Am Airlines, he was responsible for accompanying VIP's and dignitaries from around the world. With his warmth and good nature many became life long friends. He is survived by his nieces, Prisca Geeslin and Claire Betar, and his nephews, Joel Bakos, Richard Bakos and James Page. A graveside service will be held in Seaside, CA at 1pm on Monday, August 26th.

A six-member military jury declined to allow Staff Sgt. Robert Bales any chance at freedom after he slaughtered 16 Afghan civilians inside their homes.
After years of delays and stagnating fund-raising, New York’s Museum for African Art is assuming a new identity.
Joseph Bottum, in an essay in Commonweal magazine, writes about his change of heart on the issue, citing the “natural law” theology of Thomas Aquinas.
A military jury convicted Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, an Army psychiatrist, on all counts in the 2009 shooting rampage at Fort Hood in which 13 people were killed and 32 wounded or shot at.
Is it time to take a running back, or a wide receiver? Jason and Justin Sablich answer such questions as readers prepare for their fantasy football drafts.
The mysterious pitch was supposed to arrive in the United States in 2007 with the Japanese pitcher, though it may have never surfaced.
The New York City Independent Budget Office released findings on the prison population.
Over 12,000 people were held in New York City jails last year, according to the Independent Budget Office, with the city spending more per inmate than any other state or city.
Building a better mousetrap may be the easy part. After that comes patent, production and marketing, and missteps along the way can be costly.
A relatively small number of demonstrators were so cowed by the violence of the recent crackdown that they took steps to avoid even the smallest confrontation.
For Daniel R. Smith, 81, who attended the March on Washington in 1963, the country has a ways to go in realizing the dream of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
With the next estimated tax payment around the corner, here are some tips to avoid overpaying.
Help to Buy, in which the government either offers interest-free credit or guarantees part of the property loan, has come under criticism from those who say it could create a real estate bubble.
Read The New York Times’s original coverage of the March on Washington and its implications in August 1963, headlined “200,000 March for Civil Rights in Orderly Washington Rally.”
Scott M. Stringer took over management of a Manhattan bar called Simon Sez in the fall of 1990, but it closed after a dispute with the landlord.
The blasts outside two Sunni mosques in Tripoli killed dozens of people and reinforced fears that the Middle East could be plunging into unbridled Sunni vs. Shiite warfare.
Microsoft got a lift after its chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, said he would retire within the year.
Steven A. Ballmer’s departure paves the way for a generational change at Microsoft and gives it an opportunity to adapt to a world dominated by technologies that have eluded its influence.
A dissenting judge said the main defendant’s conviction should be reversed because he was entrapped in a plot to shoot missiles at military planes and blow up synagogues.
ESPN had been working with PBS on a film about head injuries in the National Football League, whose games are shown on the sports network and represent a cherished source of revenue.
Moscow said it was now up to the opposition to guarantee safe access for United Nations investigators to examine the site of a suspected chemical weapons attack near Damascus.
Xu Zhiyong was detained last month, and prosecutors formally approved his arrest Thursday in a case that has prompted protests in China and criticism from the United States.
Officials from both sides agreed to revive an emotionally charged program in which relatives separated by the Korean border will meet for the first time since the Korean War.
The military said it bombed “a terrorist site” early Friday, a response to four rockets that were fired into Israel the previous day.
Prosecutors at the trial of Bo Xilai, the disgraced Communist Party official, asserted on Friday that he knew about a French villa bought for his family by a tycoon.
The greatest botanical artist of this century quietly works by hand at her home in the south of France.
A dual review of what’s new: Tom Dixon and Brian Eno weigh in on skin care, fleece shorts and the documentary “Muscle Shoals.”

CARTER--David. The Carter boys remember their father every day and particularly on this, his 100th birthday. In the spirit of the season of new year and atonement, Danny says he's sorry he nearly burned down the house in 1957, Donny says he's sorry he spilled a bottle of ink all over the new upstairs carpet in 1957, and Larry says he's sorry you couldn't see him parachuting out of a plane at 72 years old in 2013. Keep Mom laughing in heaven and thanks for giving us all a wonderful life. Donny, Danny & Larry

WEIL--Peter H.,79, died August 17, 2013. Kaye Scholer remembers its friend and colleague as a brilliant mind, a leader in commercial lending, a man of unimpeachable integrity, and author of the first comprehensive treatise on asset-based finance, which is still in use today. Integral member of our firm's banking and finance practice for more than 33 years. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife, Helen, their children and the entire family.

TURNER--Lottie "Dolly", of Southbury, CT, peacefully completed her journey of 91 years surrounded by the family and friends in her home, this evening, August 22, 2013. She will be joining her adoring husband of 50 years, which she has long awaited. Dolly was a wonderfully kind and giving person and truly touched everyone that knew her. She was an extremely accomplished fashion designer with an extraordinary eye for color and style, which awarded her a scholarship to the Fashion Institute of Rhode Island in 1945. Among her many other talents included her love for gardening and cooking. But her greatest achievement was the positive attitude and persistence the she brought to every challenge that she confronted. She has a tremendous love for her son Charles, daughter Nancy and her partner, grandchildren, Natasha, Piers, and William, and nephews Bob Ayrsman and Willard Norton and niece Nancy Norton. Dolly was very fortunate to have the Shay family as lifelong friends and two very special caregivers, Marge Wargo and Ava Cardinal who enriched her life every day. Dolly will be terribly missed by all. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, August 27th at 4pm at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 294 Main St. South, Woodbury, CT. Burial will be private. The Southbury Funeral Home of Munson-Lovetere, 235 Main St. North, Southbury, CT is in charge of services. Online condolences may be made through: www.munsonloveterefuneral home.com.

WALKER--George R.,died August 22, 2013 at 89. Yale '45, Harvard Business School '48. Member of The University Club since '47. Worked for Esso/Exxon in various senior positions in Coral Gables, Lima, Bogota, Paris, London and New York. A loyal company man. Predeceased by wife, Patricia. Survived by his two sisters, Ruth Walker, PHD and Frances Dwyer; his children, Malcolm, Nicholas and Georgina, six grandchildren and a niece and nephew.

TODA--Tamotsu. Japanese fashion designer whose vision was the "Elegance and Spirit of Understatement" died August 17, 2013 at the age of 68. He was born in Saitama, Japan on July 29, 1945 and graduated from Kuwazawa Design School in Tokyo. He fell in love with New York while attending the Fashion Institute of Technology. Winner of several awards, his elegant and minimalist designs were well loved by a wide range of women, including First Lady Hilary Clinton. After retirement, he enjoyed painting and travelling. He will be greatly missed by his older brother Isao Toda, sister-in-law, niece and nephew and countless friends. A memorial service is planned for the fall.

SHORIN--Edward, age 86, died August 19, 2013 at his home in Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of the late Genevieve with whom he shared much love, life and laughter for 56 years. Devoted father of Richard (Andrea) and James (Michelle); loving grandfather of six grandchildren. He graduated from Bucknell University, served in the U.S. Navy, and was an executive of Topps Chewing Gum. A trustee of Long Island University, Mr. Shorin received an honorary doctorate degree from the university in 1999. His second career at LIU brought him much enjoyment, intellectual stimulation and treasured friendships. He died as he lived to the last moment with wisdom, humor, compassion and grace. Memorial Service Monday, August 26th, 10am at Hillwood Commons, C.W. Post campus, LIU. Interment at Nassau Knolls Cemetery. Family and friends may visit to celebrate his life at his residence on Monday and Tuesday, 6-9pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to Edward and Genevieve Shorin Scholarship Fund at LIU.

SHEIMAN--Louis, MD, July 6, 1921 - August 22, 2013, 92, died of Parkinson's disease surrounded by his family. He maintained a private practice in hematology/oncology in New York City and was loved by his patients. He was an attending physician at Montefiore Hospital and on the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He became the medical director of the Health Insurance Plan of New York. He graduated with honors from DeWitt Clinton, Phi Beta Kappa from NYU, and received his medical degree from NYU School of Medicine. He carried himself with modesty, compassion and humor. He will be remembered for his intellect, wit and sound advice. Most important in his life was his family. He married Jean (Fink) in 1951. He was the adored father of Dr. Robert Sheiman and Nina Sheiman Goldweit, and admiring father-in-law of Sara Sheiman and Dr. Richard Goldweit. He was the cherished grandfather of Jennie (William) Sheiman Katz, Dr. Daniel Goldweit, Dara Sheiman, and Alana Goldweit, and the proud great-grandfather of Ezra Katz. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Englewood Hospital and Medical Center, Englewood, NJ. Services will be held 11:45am Sunday August 25, 2013 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City.

SHAFEY--Dr. Sherif. Miami neurologist, passed away Sunday, August 18, 2013, at the age of 80. Dr. Shafey was born in Cairo, Egypt in 1932, graduated from Cairo University Faculty of Medicine in 1955, Magna Cum Laude, and completed residency training in orthopedic surgery in 1959. That year, Dr. Shafey emigrated to the United States and completed residency training in neurology at Grasslands Hospital, Westchester Medical Center, NY Medical College and Kings County Hospital, Downstate Medical Center, New York University in New York. In 1963, he was appointed chief resident in neurology at Jackson Memorial Hospital and Dr. Shafey served as assistant professor at University of Miami School of Medicine from 1966-1969. From 1965 to January of 1969, he served as Coordinator of the Training and Teaching Program in the Department of Neurology at the University of Miami School of Medicine. In June of 1967, Dr. Shafey was granted US citizenship by a Congressional Act, in the 90th Congress, in recognition of his numerous scientific publications and National Institutes of Health-funded research on cerebrovascular disease, especially the impact of smoking and artificial birth control on risk of stroke in young women from 1964 thru 1966. Dr. Shafey established his Miami private practice in neurology in 1969 and served ten years as Mercy Hospital's Chief of the Division of Neurology, in the Department of Internal Medicine. With a visionary approach to patient care, Dr. Shafey served as a clinical investigator introducing 2' 3'-dideoxyinosine (ddi) treatment for patients with HIV/AIDS, Levodopa therapy for Parkinson's patients, the first one in Florida and one of the earliest in the Northeastern US and Valproic Acid therapy to prevent seizures, the first in the State of Florida, as well as Tacrine HCI (Cognex) for the treatment of Alzheimer's Disease. He helped build a dedicated invasive neuroradiology procedures suite at Mercy Hospital and, with a grant from the James Colt Foundation, Dr. Shafey created the first dedicated neurological intensive care unit in Florida. In 1975, Dr. Shafey developed the first computerized axial tomography (CAT) scanner unit in Miami. He served as the Medical Director of the CAT Scanner from 1975 thru 1987. Over 46 years in private practice, Dr. Shafey served thousands of Miamians and patients from around the world. Dr. Shafey was a Diplomate of the American Board of Neurology, A Fellow of the American College of Physicians and a member of the American Academy of Neurology, as well as a Fellow of the American Heart Association, Cerebrovascular Disease Sections (Strokes). Dr. Shafey was also a member of the Dade County Medical Association, Florida Medical Association, the Florida Society of Neurology, and the Southern Clinical Neurological Society. Dr. Shafey is survived by his wife, Mary; two sons Omar and Joseph; and two grandchildren, Sarah and Suzanna. In lieu of flowers, the Shafey family requests donation to Camillus House. Private graveside services were held.

SHABER--Sandra. Exceptional woman who worked hard, played hard, had it all. 60-year love affair with husband Gary; caring and nurturing mother to Ruth and Steven; inspirational role model to granddaughters Hannah, Maddy and Allison; faithful sister to Allan and Gary. Born 1935, Toledo, Ohio, to Eve and David Cohen; died August 9, near her grand, historic home in Society Hill, Philadelphia. Sandra was all about balance world traveler who never forgot her Midwest roots; career achiever who put family first; politically engaged liberal, compassionate but tough-minded; fierce competitor and constructive collaborator; pioneering feminist who made a fashion statement; acquisitive intellectual who devoured spy novels; discerning gourmand with a taste for Philly cheesesteaks. Ohio State BA and MFA; Penn PhD in international relations. Superstar econometric consultant, go-to authority on consumer economics, regularly quoted and interviewed in the business press and media Wall Street Journal, NPR, CNN, PBS NewsHour. Retired in 1999 to travel extensively, pursue cultural interests, read voraciously, support good causes and actively participate in the Foreign Policy Research Institute. Sandra will be remembered by her adoring family, loyal friends and esteemed colleagues with great love, admiration and respect. Donations in her name will be welcomed by the Free Library of Philadelphia.

ROTHWELL--Alexander Falcon, Of Westport, CT, and Remsenburg, NY, treasured son of Susan and Jim Rothwell and adored brother of Zachary, died unexpectedly on August 12, 2013, at the age of 13. Joyous, singular soul, fearless explorer, adventurous spirit, fiery and sensitive, impulsive tinkerer, brilliant mathematician, science Olympian, voracious fantasy reader, Clash of Clans addict, ocean lover, prodigious builder of all things, and reluctant paddle board champion, Alex's blazing smile lit the way. His death devastates those he touched, yet our hearts overflow with the utmost pride in his life -- in his intelligence, his wit, his energy, his beauty, and his unwavering faith in his ideas. In lieu of flowers, if you would like to make a small donation in Alex's honor please consider Oceana, a cause that Alex cared about: https://act.oceana.org/ donate/d-donate.

PINDYCK-STEINER--Johanna, died August 18th, 2013. Brilliant physician and beloved wife of Phillip, mother of Deborah, grandmother of Megan and Michele, sister of Frank and Bruce. She will be deeply missed and forever remembered.

ROSENWALD--James B. Jr.,"Jimmy", 82, of Ossining, NY, passed away on August 20, 2013. Beloved husband to wife, Mimi, devoted father of Jamie (Laura), Jill (Lawrence McRae), Cynthia Coudert (Brian Morris), Sandra Graham (Todd), cherished grandfather of Jocelyn, Benno, Hailey, Thea, Bennett, Caroline and Loch, dear brother of Pat Heller. Everybody loved Jimmy. Funeral Services to be held at The University Club of New York, 1 West 54th St., New York, NY, Wednesday August 28 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Teatown Lake Reservation (teatown.org) or Cancer Research Institute (cancerresearch.org).

NASH--Crosby, of Washington, D.C.,passed away peacefully on July 31, 2013 at the age of 82. Born in Brooklyn, Mr. Nash is survived by his wife, Hawsie Crisfield Nash, four children; Page Englehart of Connecticut, Grayson Nash of the United Kingdom, Wylie Holzach of Hawaii and Elliott (Sarah) Moore of New Hampshire, a dozen grandchildren and his sister, Susan of California. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to www.populationeducation.org. A private ceremony will be held at a later date.

McCULLOUGH--James J.,Jr. Coney Island Pioneering Family. Jim, 84, of Massapequa, NY, passed away August 19, peacefully at home. Loving husband to the late Lois, son of the late James & Helen. Cherished by daughters Carol, Mary & Anthony Meluso, Lois & Tim Goulis, Nancy and five grandchildren. Jimmy spent his life as the owner of an amusement park in Coney Island. He also traveled on the State Fair circuits. He proudly owned the B&B Carousell that was sold to the city of N.Y., recently renovated & reopened in Coney Island. He was a hard working man with a humble demeanor. A true gentle giant, he is irreplaceable in our hearts & will be greatly missed by all who had the pleasure of his acquaintance. Arrangements entrusted to William E. Law Funeral Home, Massapequa, NY. 516-541-8070

MA--Tung Kwong-Kwong. Well-known Chinese-American pianist, Tung Kwong-Kwong, (Mrs. Kwong Kwong Ma) died Monday, August 5, 2013 in a suburb of Philadelphia. Born in Shanghai, China, she was first taught piano by her mother, ZY Wong, and studied with Maestro Paci in Shanghai before coming to the United States in 1946. She became one of Arthur Fiedler's favorite soloists with the Boston Pops. Tung Kwong Kwong was one of the last students of the famous pianist, Artur Schnabel, studied with Karl Ulrich Schnabel and Leonard Shure. She performed all five piano concerti of Beethoven and the two by Brahms with the Seventh Army Symphony Orchestra in Germany which was conducted by her brother Maestro Ling Tung in the 1950's. Later, Tung Kwong Kwong with her husband Ma Si-Hon recorded and toured together throughout Western Europe, North America, and the Far East under Columbia Artists Management. They appeared at the Salzburg and Dartington Festivals and were resident artists at the Marlboro Music Festival. They also founded the Si-Yo Music Society, which presented annual series of chamber music concerts in New York City between 1971 and 2004 in support of the Chinese community. In addition to her many duo and ensemble performances, Tung Kwong-Kwong appeared regularly in New York, performing at Town Hall, Lincoln Center, Merkin Hall, and later in a solo recital in Carnegie Hall. Through her long career, starting as a teenager in Shanghai, Tung Kwong Kwong remained a remarkable and influential teacher to many gifted young players. Tung Kwong Kwong is beloved by her late husband Si-Hon Ma of 50 years and her family and friends.

MARMOR-MOSKOWITZ--Margot. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of Mrs. Margot Marmor-Moskowitz, who lived in Alexandria, Virginia and Los Altos, California where she was a respected member of the Jewish Community and an active leader in Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her beloved sister, Mrs. Lotte Bravmann, a YU Benefactor with her husband Ludwig Bravmann, Vice Chairman of the Yeshiva University Board of Trustees, a member of: the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary Board of Trustees, the Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies, the Yeshiva University Museum, and to her daughters, Michelle (and Dr. Michael) Greenfield and Mrs. Jacqueline Richeson, and her grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

MARMOR-MOSKOWITZ--Margot. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Margot Marmor- Moskowitz, beloved sister of Lotte Bravmann and sister-in-law of Ludwig. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lotte, Ludwig, and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

MARDIN--Latife. Latife Mardin, 89, author and playwright, passed away on August 19 in New York City. Ms. Mardin was born in Istanbul, Turkey, attended the English High School for Girls and the American College in Istanbul. After graduation, she worked as assistant director on various independent Turkish films and as a simultaneous translator at the ILO (Institute for Labor). She came to the United States in 1958 with her husband, aspiring musician/arranger Arif Mardin, settling first in Boston and then in New York, where she worked at the United Nations, also completing her first book, Of Emeralds and Kings, a romance/spy novel set in post WWII Istanbul. Her play, The "A" Word, set in 1968, about an unwanted teenage pregnancy, examined the moral and social hypocrisy surrounding abortion in the pre Roe v. Wade era and stimulated a lively dialog in the press and social media. A quartet about the later years of the Ottoman Empire, including East is East and West is West, evolved into An Ottoman Saga, which was published in Turkey in 2009. Energetic, brilliant, compassionate and generous, she was at the center of the Turkish community in both her adopted country and in Turkey, and was the proclaimed wind beneath the wings of her late husband, Arif Mardin, whose many production credits included the song of the same name. She is survived by children Nazan Joffre, Joe Mardin and Julie Mardin, son-in-law Hugues Joffre and granddaughter Lara Agar Stoby. Her remains will be interred at the Karacaahmet Cemetery in the Uskudar district of Istanbul.

LYNCH--Robert J.,Jr. On the morning of Wednesday, August 21, after a nearly three year battle with pancreatic cancer, Robert John Lynch Jr. (Bob) died at the age of 64 in his Westport home under the light of a full moon. Born in Boston, Massachusetts to the late Robert and Doris Lynch, Bob remained a passionate Red Sox fan all of his life. He will be missed dearly by his beautiful and loving wife of 37 years, Maureen, their son Bob, who lives in Spain with his fiance, Tory, their daughter Kelly Houff, who lives in Virginia with her husband, Jeff, and their three year-old-son, Liam, to whom he was affectionately known as "Papi". He was a selfless family man who always put his loved ones before himself. Bob was the oldest of six children and is survived by his siblings, Jane Shilalie and her husband Bob, Kathy Meinelt and her husband Terry, Steve Lynch and his wife Barbara, Mary Jo Sharkey and her husband Jim, and John Lynch and his wife Mimi, all of the greater Boston area. He was "Uncle Bob" to 21 nieces and nephews, who all laughed at his jokes, despite hearing the same ones over and over. Bob worked in Finance for over 35 years, notably at Citibank, US Trust, and Barclays, finally retiring, for the third time, just four months before he was diagnosed with cancer. He was the mentor and friend to countless colleagues throughout the years and always set an example of hard work, fairness, and integrity. Bob was a human encyclopedia of sports trivia, lover of nature, and the rare combination of both a Republican and Francophile. His determination to fight off his disease inspired everyone around him and he is the unofficial World Record holder for the most pull-ups ever done by a man in his 60's after 58 chemotherapy treatments. A memorial service will be held at Assumption Church, 98 Riverside Avenue in Westport, CT on Wednesday, August 28 at 11:00am. The family will receive visitors at Norwalk's Hoyt-Cognetta Funeral Home, 5 East Wall Street, on Tuesday, August 27 from 4-8pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the 100 for Bob charity drive at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute. His page can be found at together4cures.org and then searching for Robert Lynch. Please visit: norwalkfh.com for more information and to send a condolence to the Lynch family.

KRONHOLTZ--Jane, Died quietly August 14, 2013, ending a rich, adventurous life of civic engagement, joyful travel and wide friendship. Friends will toast her in September in New York City. Write ForJaneK@Outlook.com

KAPLAN--Leo, on August 21, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Loving father of Susie, Alan and the late Roberta. Adoring grandfather of Jackie, Zak, Keith, Jake and Jarrett. Services: Monday, 2pm, Sharon Gardens Cemetery, 273 Lakeview Ave., Valhalla, NY.

HULSHIZER--Pamela C.,69, died peacefully at her home in Short Hills, NJ on August 18, 2013. She was comforted by her beloved son, Hunter. His expressions of love and gratitude provided her safe passage. Daughter of Robert Cushing and Dorothy Hedges Cushing, sister to Cheryl Campbell and Candy Cushing. Pam attended Kent Place School and Connecticut College, class of 1966. She married Henry Hulshizer in 1971. Pam worked at both Citibank and American Express before devoting herself to the care of her family and community activities, most extensively a member of the Short Hills Garden Club where she served for many years as the Chairman of the Millburn-Short Hills Community Garden. She was also a life-long member of the Short Hills Club. Pam is survived by her son, Hunter and Hank's daughter, Lisa from his previous marriage and her daughters, Serena and Melissa. Pam and Hank's daughter Brooke passed away in 1980. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to either The Millburn-Short Hills Community Garden (checks should be made out to Short Hills Garden Club sent to P.O. Box 182, Short Hills, NJ 07078- Pamela Hulshizer/Community Garden in the memo line). Or the Millburn-Short Hills Volunteer First Aid Squad (checks made payable to MSHVFAS, P.O. Box 226 Millburn, NJ 07041-Pamela Hulshizer in the memo line). A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 14, 2013 at 4pm at Christ Church, 66 Highland Ave., Short Hills, NJ 07078. For further information, or to send the family a condolence, please visit: bradleyfuneralhomes.com.

KAHN--Donald Paul, age 88, passed away on August 10, 2013 in Salzburg, Austria. Born in New York City in 1925, he was the son of Stanley Kahn and Janet Annenberg and elder brother to Gilbert Kahn. He was educated at Peddie, MIT, Columbia, and Wharton. At various times maintaining homes in Washington, D.C., Miami, London and Salzburg, Mr. Kahn's enthusiasm for the cultural life of those cities made him a loyal patron, most especially of the visual and performing arts. In England he was awarded an OBE for his service to the nation. In Salzburg he supported many architectural restorations, including the opera house Haus Fur Mozart. He supported the Salzburg Music Festival, sponsoring productions, publications, and public lectures, and was a founding member of numerous international patron groups supporting the festival. In Salzburg, he received many awards, including Goldenes Ehrenzeichen des Landes Salzburg, and was made Honorary Senator of the University. He is survived by his beloved wife Jeanne Combs Kahn; five children, Donald Kahn, Jr., Douglas Kahn, Alexandra Kahn Graubert (John), Julie Kahn Brown, and Stephen Kahn (Sara); and grandchildren Thomas Bender, Sophia Carter-Kahn, Isabel Carter-Kahn, Samuel Brown, Jr., and Christina Graubert. In addition he is survived by his first wife, Marion Crombie. He was well loved for his quick wit and generous spirit. A memorial to celebrate his life will take place in Salzburg in August 2014, on a date to be confirmed.
HECK--Susan, 71, passed on August 17th. A funeral mass will be held in her memory at 1pm, September 7th, All Saints Church, Pasadena, CA.

GRAF--Frederick W.,September 29, 1919 - August 3, 2013. Father of David F. Graf, MD, passed August 3, 2013 in the presence of his family at the age of 93. He worked at Lehmann and Graf Welding-Machine Shop from an early age and became its President and Chairman of the Board until his retirement in 1977. He survived a three day typhoon with winds exceeding 180 MPH. Many servicemen were killed by this storm. Fred was a member of Syracuse Turners, F&M Salt Springs Lodge #

GOODMAN--Bernice "Bunny" Wedeen. Born August 2, 1920 in Manhattan to Sylvia and William Wedeen, died at home in Riverdale on August 22, 2013. Bunny attended NYU, became a licensed real estate broker and a noted interior designer. Predeceased by the love of her life, her husband of 69 years, Dr. David Goodman and her devoted daughter Sally Fran (at age 33) in 1982. She is survived by her loving son, Thomas and her treasured grandson Tristan and many adoring nieces and nephews. Her beauty, quick wit and her gift for telling a great story or joke endeared her to many friends who will miss her forever. Rest in peace our dear "Bunny."

GOLDNER--Fred H. 86, Professor Emeritus of Sociology at Queens College, CUNY, died August 19th after a three-year tourist visit to cancer country without a return visa. Born in New Haven, CT, he had a long and varied career, going back and forth between academia and the public and private corporate world, which included serving both as Chief of Staff of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and as an Executive Consultant with an emergent HMO- Sanus- and its national successor NYLCare. His most notable scholarly contributions included: the development of the concept of Pronoia (the delusional opposite of Paranoia); the delineation of power relations within organizations; pointing out the necessity of following the flow of money through an organization in order to understand organizational processes; calling attention to managerial demotion; developing the concept of organizational cynical knowledge; studying the effects of belief systems within organizations; identifying correlations between managerial perspectives and future success or failure; discerning, by the analysis of survey data, the startling differences between the belief systems of older and younger priests in the late '60s. He served in the U.S. Navy 1944-46 and taught at Columbia Graduate School of Business 1964-70. He was an active member of the American Association of Public Opinion Research (AAPOR), honored twice as nominee for president and serving on the Council and as Conference Chair in 1981. He started competitive swimming for the first time at 75 and placed in the top 10 nationally 76 times. During the last decade, he was an advisor to the Board of the Lay Center of Foyer Unitas in Rome. He leaves his brother Merwin; his daughter Saren; his son Paul; June, his ex-wife but present companion; and Joseph Lynaugh, his intellectual colleague and close friend of 45 yrs. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Friends of the Lay Center, C/O 3900 Cathedral Ave. NW, Apt 202A, Washington, D.C. 20016.

GIBSON--Herbert Hall, 91, a sustainable agriculture pioneer and retired organic farmer, died Tuesday, August 20, at his beloved Ryder Farm in Brewster, NY. Born November 8, 1921, in Lee County, VA, he was the third son of Herbert Hall Gibson and Julia Click Gibson and grew up in Kilmarnock, VA, where he was a high school pitcher and valedictorian who enjoyed nature. A dreamer and visionary by nature, he believed that America's suburbs and urban areas could be enriched by growing organic produce, and he adapted agricultural implements to help people grow vegetables in beds between sod strips to minimize the need to weed. From 1977 to 2010, he was a pioneer in the New York organic food movement, helped save the 125-acre family farm in Brewster and was one of the first farmers to bring organic produce to Union Square's Green Market. He was predeceased by his wife, Katharine Ryder Gibson, and is survived by a brother, Robert N. Gibson of Newport News, VA; three children: Robert Ryder Gibson of Charlottesville, VA; Anne Virginia Gibson Tausch of Arlington; and Henry Hall Gibson of Amherst, MA; and six grandchildren: Helen Gibson Mikac of Furth, Germany; Sally Logan Gibson of Washington, D.C.; Stella Ryder Gibson of Charlottesville; Julia Dorothy Gibson of Portland, OR; Rose Katharine Gibson of Amherst; and Alec Ryder Tausch of Arlington. A memorial service is planned for 12 noon on September 1 at Ryder Farm.
GERSTNER--Louis V. III. We extend our deepest condolences to the family of Louis V. Gerstner III, our friend and longtime champion. The TEAK Fellowship

GERSTNER--Louis V.,III, passed away on August 14, 2013 at the age of 41 after a choking incident while dining in a restaurant. Beloved father of Grace and Olivia, he was the President of the Gerstner Family Foundation. A graduate of St. Paul's School, Princeton University and Columbia Business School, he dedicated much of his adult life to providing educational opportunities to underprivileged children. In addition to his children, he is survived by his sister, Dr. Elizabeth Gerstner and his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis V. Gerstner, Jr.

GELFAND--Seymour, March 9th, 1927 - August 20th, 2013. Beloved husband for 63 years of Susan. Loving father of Jamie and Rebecca, Bill, Diana and Yossi. Cherished uncle, adoring grandfather of six. Graduate of NY Law School class of 1950. He had a successful law practice for over sixty years. We will love and miss him forever.

GATTON--Henry Howard Jr.,"Honesty is the Best Policy", age 89, passed away peacefully at home with family on Sunday, August 18th 2013, in Wellington, FL where he lived with his daughter Meryl and granddaughter Cassandra. Born April 21, 1924 to Henry and Grace Gatton in Brooklyn, NY. He attended Cooper Union in 1946, where he met his wife Charlotte H. Gatton who passed on September 21, 1976. A member of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and Electrican and Supervisor at the NYCHA for 33 years. Henry was passionate about the study of history and politics and delighted in sharing his views with others. He credited acupuncture for his health and longevity and admired the teachings of Albert Ellis and Brian Weiss. He leaves behind many loving friends from residences in Florida, New York and Oregon. He was a unique and passionate soul, who was well loved and will be deeply missed. Three daughters, Susan (deceased), Karen , Meryl and one son and his wife, Keith and Karuna, two grandchildren; Jesse and Cassandra Dalla Riva.

FREEMAN--John Palmer Jr.,former government bond trader and retired Chairman of the Board of Aubrey G. Lanston and Company, age 85, of Port Washington, on August 21, 2013. Beloved husband of Patricia. Loving father of John Christopher (Francine), Jeffrey Palmer, and Shannon Duffy (Robert). Adored grandfather of John Palmer, William, Hailey, Logan, and Sadie. Dear brother of Jeanne. The funeral is private.

DORSEY--Lula C. Life-long civil rights activist, educator, writer, mother and grandmother, L.C. Dorsey died in her home in Jackson, MS on August 21. She was 74 and will be remembered by many as one who never stopped helping people whether they were death row prisoners or impoverished black families in the Mississippi Delta, where she was born.

DAYTON--Mary Lee Lowe, Community leader, philanthropist, and supporter of women's issues, died peacefully at her home in Wayzata, MN on August 21, 2013. She was predeceased by her husband of fifty-four years, Wallace C. Dayton, who died in 2002. Born in Marshall, Missouri, on May 12, 1925, she was the daughter of Braddie Douglass Lowe and the Reverend Arnold Hilmar Lowe. She attended John Borroughs School in St. Louis, and graduated from Northrop Collegiate School in Minneapolis in 1943 and from Vassar College in 1946. Always active in community affairs, she held leadership positions in many organizations in the Twin Cities and elsewhere. She served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Macalester College, The Minneapolis Foundation, The Minneapolis YWCA, and Planned Parenthood of Minnesota, and was a founder of the Minnesota Women's Fund, now the Women's Foundation of Minnesota. She also served as a Board member of the Breck School, the Mississippi River Fund, the Ripley Memorial Foundation, the Sister Kenny Foundation, the Greater Twin Cities United Way, the University of Minnesota Arboretum Foundation, Vassar College, Westminster Presbyterian Church, and other organizations. In addition, after her husband's death, she remained committed to the environmental organizations that he had led and supported, including The Nature Conservancy and the National Audubon Society, and others. She is survived by her four daughters, Sally D. Clement (Stephen) of New York City, Katherine D. Nielsen (Stuart) and Ellen D. Grace, both of Minneapolis, and Elizabeth D. Dovydenas (Jonas) of Lenox, MA, and nine grandchildren: Theodore and Winston Clement; John and Elena Dovydenas; Olivia Nielsen; Samuel Richardson; and Matthew, Katherine, and Rosamond Sturgis. The family wishes to thank Becky Fredericks and her staff for their caring service. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in her name to any of the above organizations, or the charity of the donor's choice. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 7 at 3 pm at Westminster Presbyterian Church, 1200 Marquette Avenue South, Minneapolis.

CLARK--John Stephen, of Bronxville, NY passed away suddenly on August 21, 2013. He is survived by his beloved wife of 52 years, Mary Caroline (Leary). Loving father of John Stephen, Jr. (Heidi), Danny, Margie (Stephen Finn) and Jennifer (Tim McGrath). Devoted grandfather of John III and David Clark, Kevin, Michael, Charlie and Carrie Finn, Tim, Caroline, Sean and Brendan McGrath. Dear brother of Anne Prout and the late Joseph P. Clark. Also surviving are several nieces and nephews. Born January 4, 1929 in Queens Village, NY, John graduated from Georgetown University (BA), Columbia Law School (JD) and Columbia University (MA in European Studies, 2001). He Served in Korea (1952-53) as a 1st Lieutenant, US Air Force and as an Assistant US Attorney (SDNY). John was a senior partner of Abeles, Clark, Osterberg and Prager, specializing in copyright and entertainment litigation representing many clients including the rock and roll band AC/DC. He was Counsel to the New York State Racing Commission, a member of the Planning Board of the City of Yonkers and Director of the Puccini Foundation. He was a Knight of Malta and Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. He was a former member of the of Directors of the Georgetown University Alumni Association, a Trustee of St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, a tutor at St. Ignatius Middle School and mediator for the US District Court (SDNY). Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street, Bronxville, NY, between the hours of 4 to 7pm Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, Aug. 26 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Archdiocese of New York Inner City Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Avenue, NY, NY 10022.

BURNS--Red. The entire Sexton family mourns the loss of our brilliant friend and neighbor, Red Burns. We admired her for her genius and vision and achievements, but loved her for her unique brand of self-confidence, humor, and sass. She lit up the world; we live now in a dimmer, colder place. We grieve with her family, loved ones, friends, and they are in our prayers. John, Lisa, Jed, Danielle and Katie Sexton

BURNS--Red. The Tisch School of the Arts is heartbroken over the death of the incandescent and amazing Red Burns. Innovator, visionary, truth-teller, cherished colleague, and revered teacher - Red brought high standards, brilliance, humor, perseverance, and a sharp eye for great ideas to her four decades at Tisch, and through ITP made Tisch a beacon on the digital landscape. The hallways and classrooms will seem a little dimmer without her presence. She was one-of-a-kind, and will be missed terribly. We offer our deepest condolences to her family, loved ones, friends, and many, many admirers. Mary Schmidt Campbell, Dean, NYU's Tisch School of the Arts

BROWN--Sarah Lynn, died unexpectedly on August 17, 2013. She will be remembered with love by her family: Sarah M. Brown, Ivan E. Brown, Donna Seelig, Laura Chappell-Brown and her many friends. Our lives were enhanced by her thoughtfulness, generosity, and grace. Her smile warmed our hearts. Her conversation and wit enlivened our minds. She sought challenge in her professional life, most recently as a founder and Partner of Oceanic Partners which focused on connecting international hospitals to North American health care payers. From 2008 to 2012 she was a Senior Vice President of ICC Lowe where she provided best practices consulting for drug commercialization. Sarah Lynn was a graduate of The Spence School -1991 and The University of Texas-1995. She loved movies, ballet, opera, and travel. She read widely and could always recommend a good book based upon her own classification system: airplane books or everything else. A Memorial Service to remember Sarah Lynn will be held in Brooklyn Heights in mid October. Gifts in memory of Sarah Lynn may be made to: The Brown Ledge Foundation, 25 Wilson St., Burlington, VT 05401.

BRONNER--Frederick Van Voorhees. 1925-2013, died August 23, 2013 in Jupiter, Florida. He was preceded in death by his wife, Judith. He is survived by his son, Geoffrey; and his sister, Louise Trafalet.
BRODIE--Jerry (Jake), 91, passed away August 22. Beloved husband of Gloria. Loving father of Stephen and Nancy. Dearest grandfather.

BRANDT--Carl D.,on August 13. Longtime resident of Rhinebeck, NY, distinguished literary agent for over 50 years. Beloved friend, colleague, and mentor to numerous accomplished authors, Carl remained to the end a true gentleman and will be greatly missed. He is survived by children Diana, Colin and Cameron, their spouses, eight grandchildren, wife Clare, and co-workers at Brandt & Hochman Literary Agents.

BOURONCLE--Dr. Bertha (Pereny). Passed away surrounded by friends and family last Friday August 16th after receiving the last rites. Bertha was born in Peru in 1919. Her parents were the Harvard-educated Dr. Luis H. Bouroncle and Carmela Bouroncle Gonzalez-Quint. She was the fourth of five children, Luis, Consuelo, Maruja and Antonio. She is survived by Consuelo. Bertha spent most of her life and career as a Professor of Medicine at The Ohio State University (OSU). Before moving to Columbus, she graduated at the top of her class from the San Marcos Medical School in Peru. Bertha became a world-renowned medical researcher, a beloved teacher to thousands of medical students, having been named Professor of the Year multiple times and the first woman chief resident and the first female full professor of Medicine in Ohio. Her biggest accomplishment as a researcher was the identification of a formerly fatal type of leukemia, now mostly treatable thanks to her lifetime efforts and the efforts of her disciples that are continuing her dream of finding a cure to all cancers. Dr. Bouroncle was instrumental in the creation of The Ohio State University, Arthur G. James Cancer Hospital and Richard J. Solove Research Institute, affectionately known as "The James." Today thousands and possibly tens of thousands of cancer survivors are able to share their lives with their beloved ones thanks to the discoveries from the research led by Dr. Bouroncle. In addition to her research, she also was the ultimate patient advocate and a consummate teacher. Upon her retirement in 1989, OSU created the so-called "Bertha Bouroncle Day" to honor bright students and young researchers in medicine. Dr. Bouroncle has given back to the community in her lifetime by creating the Bertha Bouroncle and Andrew Pereny Chair of Medicine to fund in perpetuity an endowed professorship in Medicine at the Ohio State University College of Medicine. Bertha was a supporter of the Columbus Symphony, the Columbus Zoo and Aquarium, and also loved the ballet and the arts. Bertha was preceded in death by her husband, the industrialist Andrew Pereny. Andrew passed away in 1983. Bertha is the most beloved icon of the entire Bouroncle family and an icon at OSU, as her entire family as well as countless colleagues and patients at the Ohio State University can attest. Bertha is survived by 11 nieces and nephews, 27 grand-nieces and nephews and 16 great grand-nieces and nephews, and by Burke Showe and his children and grandchildren, her "Columbus family." Those wishing to honor Bertha's memory can send funds to the Bertha Bouroncle Fund at The Ohio State University, 660 Ackerman Road Room 651, PO Box 183112, Columbus, Ohio 43218 to the attention: Steve Chaykowski, Stephen.Chaykowski@osumc.edu or call 614-293-3745. To share memories or condolences, visit shoedinger.com.

BOISI--James O. The Officers and Directors of the Realty Foundation of New York are saddened at the loss of James Boisi. Remembered with great fondness, James was a legend in the industry, paving the way for the next generation of real estate professionals. With his knowledge and expertise, mentoring all through the real estate maze. Our heartfelt condolences to Mark Boisi, Vice President and good friend of the foundation and to the entire Boisi family. Jerry L. Cohen, Chairman H. Dale Hemmerdinger, President Officers and Directors

BERNSTEIN--Sid. More than a brilliant and renowned impresario, Sid was a staggeringly loving and caring human being. Indeed, he was the embodiment of those Beatles lyrics "All You Need is Love" and will be sorely missed. My deepest sympathy to Geri and the family. Brian Madden

BOISI--James O.,Passed away August 21, 2013 at his home surrounded by three generations of his family. This quintessential New Yorker was born in 1919 on the Lower East Side, and educated in the New York public school system attending Stuyvesant High School, Brooklyn College and Fordham Law School. His first position was at the law firm of Amend & Amend where he gravitated to the practice of real estate law, ultimately representing clients such as the legendary William Zeckendorf, Sr. in many real estate dealings. In 1956 he was then offered a position as real estate attorney for the New York Central Railroad eventually becoming Vice President of Real Estate. During his tenure he made a profound impact on the New York City skyline by transforming the residential corridor of Park Avenue above Grand Central Station into high-rise office towers by arranging ground leases with developers on property owned by the railroad. He was visionary in his use of utilizing the concept of "air rights" to increase the buildable area of buildings in NYC. In 1964, Thomas Gates recruited Mr. Boisi to Morgan Guaranty Trust Company to head a newly formed Real Estate ultimately being promoted to Executive Vice President of Corporate Finance in 1970 and then to Executive Vice President of the parent company J.P. Morgan & Co. in 1972. He headed Strategic Planning for the Bank creating an Investment Banking Group and Merger department. In 1978 Mr. Boisi was then elected Vice Chairman of the Board and Director and a member of the Corporate Office where he served until his retirement in 1984. Boisi was a staunch advocate for New York working closely with then Governor Hugh Carey establishing International Banking Facilities to lure offshore banking business back to the United States. He also helped secure financing for the transit system of NYC and was a lead banker in providing support for the Municipal Assistance Corporation (MAC) which brought NYC out of bankruptcy in 1975. Upon his mandatory retirement from the bank, Harry Helmsley persuaded him to join Helmsley Enterprises as Executive Vice President where he served from 1984 through 1987. Mr. Boisi was then asked by The British Coal Board to become Chairman of its US property subsidiary, Pan American Properties, serving from 1987 through 1990. In 1991 he set about establishing the Mentoring Partnership of Long Island. Mr. Boisi chaired the Leadership Council until 1996 and served as Co-Chair from 1996 - 2000. He has served on several Boards of Directors over his career including Cities Service Co., Denny's, J.P. Morgan & Co., Boy Scouts of America, the Real Estate Board of New York, and Mentoring Partnership of Long Island. For 51 Years of his impressive business career Mr. Boisi also taught real estate at Pace University in the evenings becoming Co-Chairman of the Department and finally a Trustee Emeritus of the University. Mr. Boisi was a devout Catholic serving as an active parishioner of St. Mary's Church and lector for Sunday Mass. He was also a Knight of Malta. Mr. Boisi is survived by his loving wife of 68 years Edith Mae Mullen, six children James, Geoffrey (Rene Isacco), Jeanne (Robert) Sheehy, Mark (Barbara Gallagher), Patricia (John) Sheehy, Eileen (William) Dobbs, 19 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mentoring Partnership of Long Island.
BERKE--Dorothy. Beloved grandmother to Jori, Lani and Tara; great-grandmother to Shane and Connor. Rest In Peace.

BERKE--Dorothy. In dedication to our "Mom," who has passed on in grace, and is now resting in peace. Thank you for the love, strength, beauty and courage you have given us. You are an important part of harmony of this universe of life. May your soul rest in Peace and Love. We will miss you in sight, but hear you always. Carole, Peter and Thai Chi

BARRY--Anne Morse, died peacefully at home on August 19, 2013, after 20 months of valiantly living with heart failure and kidney failure. Raised in Exeter, New Hampshire, she attended the Baldwin School and Radcliffe College, where she received her BA cum laude in 1962. Her first fulltime job was as secretary/assistant to Norman Mailer. She became a free-lance writer, whose work appeared In Esquire, Village Voice, Mademoiselle, and Cosmopolitan. She wrote a memoir, Bellevue is a State of Mind, and ghost-wrote The Mayor's Man, by Barry Gottehrer. She taught non-fiction writing at The New School for over 20 years. In the '90s she shifted her emphasis to quiltmaking and used those techniques to create fabric art: www.annebarryartist.com. At various times she belonged to American Society of Journalists and Authors, Empire Quilters, Jersey City Quilters, Textile Study Group, NYC-Radcliffe '62, and Van Vorst Park Association. She met David Greenwood in 1990 and moved to Jersey City; they married in 1991. She is survived by her husband, her sister Emily Lovering (Graham Walker), her brother Kit Barry, nephews Daniel Lovering and Matthew Lovering (Sylvia Balding), her stepchildren Daniel Greenwood (Carol Salem), Jimmy Greenwood, and Julie Greenwood, and her stepgrandchildren Gabe, Sheva, and Yoni. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 21: details at: www.caringbridge.org/visit/ annebarry Donations in her honor may be made to American Jewish World Service.

BARKLE--Richard N.,formerly of Water Mill, NY, passed away on August 7, 2013 in San Francisco, CA. During his many years at Pan Am Airlines, he was responsible for accompanying VIP's and dignitaries from around the world. With his warmth and good nature many became life long friends. He is survived by his nieces, Prisca Geeslin and Claire Betar, and his nephews, Joel Bakos, Richard Bakos and James Page. A graveside service will be held in Seaside, CA at 1pm on Monday, August 26th.

ANTONAKOS--Stephen, 86, died suddenly August 17th, interrupting a life in art active since the 1950s. Known for his abstract, spatial work with neon from 1960 to the present, Antonakos defined his work as "real things in real spaces" -- avoiding representation, illusion, symbolism. The activation of the space occupied by both the art and the viewer, and the crucial architectural placement of forms, were defining characteristics of decades of work that redefined neon as capable of great formal subtlety and, often, spiritual power. His complete and incomplete neon circles and squares and their spatial relationships to their sites connect his work with Minimalism, but Antonakos's distinctive lightness allows a certain openness in interpretation. Even with the large Public Works he said he hoped to reach the inner person. In addition to the neon work, there are Artist's Books, reliefs, collages, prints, and an enormous history of drawings on paper and vellum -- often folded, cut, layered, or crumpled. Recent series of cut or crumpled gold leaf sheets continued his investigation into questions of light. Since the 1960s he has exhibited in New York and across the US and in Europe in hundreds of shows. Among the outstanding exhibitions were "Ten Outdoor Neons, Fort Worth," 1974; Documenta 6, 1977; "Chapel of the Saints," 1993, Rhodes; Venice Biennale, 1997; Marzona Collection, Hamburger Bahnhof; 2001-2002; A Retrospective, 2007-8, Athens, org. by the J.F. Costopoulos Foundation; and "The Search," 2011, Elefsina. Shows in 2013 include paper work at The Drawing Room, East Hampton; the early "Pillows" at Lori Bookstein Fine Art, Chelsea; the 1965 "Hanging Neon" in "Dynamo" at the Grand Palais; and "4 Directions" at the Konrad Fischer Galerie, Berlin. Over 50 Public Works have been installed in such cities as Athens, Bari, Dijon, Frankfurt, Los Angeles, New York, Odessa, Tel Aviv, Tokyo, and Seattle. Antonakos's work is represented in numerous private and public collections, including The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney Museum of American Art, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, the National Gallery in D.C., and the National Museums of Contemporary Art in Athens and Salonica. Major publications include Irving Sandler's 1997 monograph and the catalog for the Athens Retrospective, with essays by Martin Filler, Eleftherios Ikonomou, Katerina Koskina, Daniel Marzona, and Brian O'Doherty. In 2011 he received Lifetime Achievement Awards from the National Academy of Art and Museum, and from the Greek American Foundation. A modest man of great gentleness and sensitivity, he made bold, original investigations into the open experience of form, color, and light in space. Antonakos was born November 1, 1926 in the small Greek village of Agios Nikolaos, Laconia. He often mentioned remembering the sunrises there. He came to New York at the age of 4 with his parents Thomas and Evangelia (Gregory), his brothers Bill, Peter, and Tony, and his sister Kanella. He grew up in Bay Ridge and served in the Philippines in WWII. He is survived by his wife Naomi Spector, his children Stephen B Antonakos, a musician, and Evangelia Mary Spector Antonakos, a mathematician, and many loving relatives and friends. We will miss his energy and his warmth. Viewings at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., Thursday August 29 from 5 to 9pm and Friday August 30 from 2 to 5pm. Funeral at St. John the Baptist Greek Orthodox Church, 143 East 17th St., Saturday August 31 at 10am.

AUSTIN--Charles V.,born on January 15, 1954 in New York. He passed away suddenly on August 22, 2013 at Stamford Hospital. Charles attended Xaverian High School and Saint Francis College in Brooklyn. During his banking career he worked at Irving Trust Company, The Bank of New York, and most recently at BNY Mellon. His career spanned over 30 years in financial services and technology. He is survived by his parents Charles and Eileen Austin of Plymouth, Massachusetts. He also leaves his sister Eileen Perrone, husband David, nieces Olivia and Emily, his sister Rose Austin, husband James Bullock and nephews Austin and Owen. He was predeceased by his brother Matthew. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday, August 26th at 10am at The Basilica of Saint John the Evangelist, in Stamford, CT. His family will receive friends on Sunday, August 25th from 4 to 6pm at Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home at 2900 Summer Street in Stamford. To leave an online condolence please visit www.leopgallagherstam ford.com

ABELOW--Herb. The board and staff of the Mahaiwe Performing Arts Center mourn the passing of our caring and dedicated treasurer. Our hearts go out to his entire family. Lola Jaffe, Founder Maggie Buchwald, Chair Beryl Jolly, Executive Director

ABELOW--Herbert Bruce, born December 23, 1933 in Brooklyn, New York to Irving and Aida (Sokol), passed away from pancreatic cancer on August 23, 2013 in New York City. After a long and successful career in finance, he relocated to Berkshire County, Massachusetts, where he gave freely of his boundless energy, serving as chairman of the local school district, treasurer of the historical society and village association in New Marlborough, and board member of the Mahaiwe Theater. He also served on the boards of the Rumsey Hall School, the Lenox Library and the Edith Wharton Restoration. He was a supporter of the Muscular Dystrophy Association and the National Association for Learning Disabilities, and a long-time member of the Wyantenuck Golf Club. Together with beloved wife and girlfriend Betsy, he raised llamas, pygmy goats, and other exotic animals at the aptly-named Random Farm. He delighted in welcoming people with disabilities, schoolchildren, and other visitors to the farm. He drove for Meals-On-Wheels and was never happier than when launching fleets of model rockets or giving tractor rides to delight younger guests. His kindnesses to others were legion, and often performed in secret. Few who met him were not richer for the experience. He attended Stuyvesant High School and graduated Wharton School. A career on Wall Street led to senior positions at Morgan Stanley and First Boston before co-founding Abelow-Ihasz. He is survived by his beloved and loving wife Betsy Ross Colhoun; his four children: Bradley, Lisa Hedley, Justin and Hawley; eleven grandchildren: Sarah, Hannah, and Daniel Abelow; Powell, Nicholas, LilyClaire, and Iris Hedley; Campbell and Libby Abelow; Kasper Schmiedl; and, Everett Dalrymple; daughters-in-law Carolyn Murray and Sallie Judd Abelow; sons-in-law Tom Hedley and Phil Schmiedl; brother Richard and sister-in-law Betty Abelow; and step-daughter Kyle Utter.
