SUSSMAN--Ruth Levine. Today, and every day, we miss you and love you. Becky, Jane, and David

CARTER--David. The Carter boys remember their father every day and particularly on this, his 100th birthday. In the spirit of the season of new year and atonement, Danny says he's sorry he nearly burned down the house in 1957, Donny says he's sorry he spilled a bottle of ink all over the new upstairs carpet in 1957, and Larry says he's sorry you couldn't see him parachuting out of a plane at 72 years old in 2013. Keep Mom laughing in heaven and thanks for giving us all a wonderful life. Donny, Danny & Larry

WILKIE--Margot Loines Morrow, of New York and Martha's Vineyard, died peacefully August 21. She was predeceased by her son Stephen Morrow and her stepdaughter Edith Wilkie, and survived by her daughters Faith Morrow Williams of Washington, DC, and Constance Morrow Fulenwider of Weston, MA, eight grandchildren, ten great-grandchildren, and three stepchildren, Rennie Lieber, Neil Wilkie, and Peter Wilkie.

TODA--Tamotsu. Japanese fashion designer whose vision was the "Elegance and Spirit of Understatement" died August 17, 2013 at the age of 68. He was born in Saitama, Japan on July 29, 1945 and graduated from Kuwazawa Design School in Tokyo. He fell in love with New York while attending the Fashion Institute of Technology. Winner of several awards, his elegant and minimalist designs were well loved by a wide range of women, including First Lady Hilary Clinton. After retirement, he enjoyed painting and travelling. He will be greatly missed by his older brother Isao Toda, sister-in-law, niece and nephew and countless friends. A memorial service is planned for the fall.

SIMSTEIN--Rose S.,101, died peacefully at her home in New York City, Sunday, August 25, 2013. She was the beloved wife of the late Dr. Irving Simstein and devoted mother of the late Dr. Lee Simstein. A woman of grace, charm and wit, she is survived by her daughter-in-law Beverly, granddaughters Jessica Robb, Julie Tillman and Dr. Rebecca Simstein Ginsburg, and seven great-grandchildren. She will be mourned by her many devoted nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held at The Plaza Memorial Chapel, Tuesday at noon.

SIEBERT--Muriel, A groundbreaking, trail blazing "Grand Dame" who did everything her way. A most special friend. Thank you for the memories- we had fun. May you always have Ketel One on the rocks waiting for you wherever you go. Love, Lynda and Richard

SHORIN--Edward, age 86, died August 19, 2013 at his home in Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of the late Genevieve with whom he shared much love, life and laughter for 56 years. Devoted father of Richard (Andrea) and James (Michelle); loving grandfather of six grandchildren. He graduated from Bucknell University, served in the U.S. Navy, and was an executive of Topps Chewing Gum. A trustee of Long Island University, Mr. Shorin received an honorary doctorate degree from the university in 1999. His second career at LIU brought him much enjoyment, intellectual stimulation and treasured friendships. He died as he lived to the last moment with wisdom, humor, compassion and grace. Memorial Service Monday, August 26th, 10am at Hillwood Commons, C.W. Post campus, LIU. Interment at Nassau Knolls Cemetery. Family and friends may visit to celebrate his life at his residence on Monday and Tuesday, 6-9pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to Edward and Genevieve Shorin Scholarship Fund at LIU.

RASMUSSEN--Waldo. In loving memory of Waldo Rasmussen who died on August 15, 2013 after a long illness. Waldo was born in Tekoa, Washington in 1928 and raised in Portland, Oregon where he later graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Reed College. After initially working at the Portland Art Museum, he moved to New York where he began his career at the Museum of Modern Art. For many years, Waldo was the Director of the International Program, responsible for the installation of circulating exhibitions to a wide international range of countries. His final project for the museum was an extensive survey exhibition "Latin American Artists of the Twentieth Century". He was deeply committed to exposing this artwork to a wider public. In addition to fine art, Waldo had a life-long love of classical music, dance, theater and film. He was pre-deceased by his beloved daughter Lisa and is survived by his life companion and spouse John Dowling of New York City, a son M.D. Rasmussen and three grandchildren. A previous marriage to Geraldine Rasmussen ended in divorce. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on September 24th at 5:00pm.

KRONHOLTZ--Jane, Died quietly August 14, 2013, ending a rich, adventurous life of civic engagement, joyful travel and wide friendship. Friends will toast her in September in New York City. Write ForJaneK@Outlook.com

KEYES--Joan Ross (nee Rafter), author of educational materials and teacher in the Port Washington Public Schools, age 89, of Sands Point, on August 23, 2013. Beloved wife of the late William. Loving mother of William, Peter, Dion, and Kenzie. Adored grandmother of eight grandchildren and great-grandmother of four great-grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10am at Our Lady of Fatima RC Church, 6 Cottonwood Rd., Port Washington. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

KAUSHIK--Helena, RN, Died at home on Saturday, August 24, 2013. She was born in Detroit, MI on July 22, 1944. Helena was the inspiration for a college for women founded in her name. Donations can be made to Helena Kaushik Education Foundation, P.O. Box 234, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510. www.helenakaushik.org.

GOLDNER--Fred H. 86, Professor Emeritus of Sociology at Queens College, CUNY, died August 19th after a three-year tourist visit to cancer country without a return visa. Born in New Haven, CT, he had a long and varied career, going back and forth between academia and the public and private corporate world, which included serving both as Chief of Staff of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and as an Executive Consultant with an emergent HMO- Sanus- and its national successor NYLCare. His most notable scholarly contributions included: the development of the concept of Pronoia (the delusional opposite of Paranoia); the delineation of power relations within organizations; pointing out the necessity of following the flow of money through an organization in order to understand organizational processes; calling attention to managerial demotion; developing the concept of organizational cynical knowledge; studying the effects of belief systems within organizations; identifying correlations between managerial perspectives and future success or failure; discerning, by the analysis of survey data, the startling differences between the belief systems of older and younger priests in the late '60s. He served in the U.S. Navy 1944-46 and taught at Columbia Graduate School of Business 1964-70. He was an active member of the American Association of Public Opinion Research (AAPOR), honored twice as nominee for president and serving on the Council and as Conference Chair in 1981. He started competitive swimming for the first time at 75 and placed in the top 10 nationally 76 times. During the last decade, he was an advisor to the Board of the Lay Center of Foyer Unitas in Rome. He leaves his brother Merwin; his daughter Saren; his son Paul; June, his ex-wife but present companion; and Joseph Lynaugh, his intellectual colleague and close friend of 45 yrs. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Friends of the Lay Center, C/O 3900 Cathedral Ave. NW, Apt 202A, Washington, D.C. 20016.

FISCH--Richard L.,83, of Chappaqua, NY and Marthas Vineyard, died peacefully at home on Friday, August 23, following a long illness. Born on September 27, 1929 in Far Rockaway to Abraham and Alice Fisch (Silver), he was raised on the upper West Side and received his education in New York: at Hunter Model School, Stuyvesant High School, Syracuse University and New York Law. A veteran of the Korean War, he practiced law in Manhattan for over 50 years, at first in his father Abraham's field of the law of admiralty and then primarily in the field of matrimonial law, which he loved. He was an active and dedicated member of the Chappaqua Volunteer Ambulance Corps and the Chappaqua Fire Department for over 25 years. He received the Royal Order of the North Star from the King of Sweden in recognition of his endeavor to restore the old Swedish cemetery on the island of St. Barts. A passionate surfcaster on Fire Island and on Marthas Vineyard, he also ran a bar/restaurant and disco in Ocean Beach in the 60's. A true New Yorker he was an ardent Giants fan and season ticket holder since 1956. Modest about his accomplishments and generous with his time he will especially be remembered for his fabulous jokes and joke telling skills. Most important in his life was his family. He was the loving and beloved husband of Ebba (Dahlin) for 45 years and a loving father to his children John (Mary Ann Hynes), Tony (Malka), Peter (deceased) and Viktoria (Colby Goodrich); the adored and loving grandfather of Matthew, Michael, Abraham, Desiree, Aidan and Luke as well as the beloved brother of Stephen (deceased), Genivieve Hewitt and Nancy Fish (Scott Perry). A memorial service will be held on Friday August 30, at 10:00am, at Beecher Flooks Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY 10570. Enterrement will follow at Fair ridge Cemetery on Quaker Road in Chappaqua. In lieu of flowers, please donate to Chappaqua Volunteer Ambulance Corps or the Chappaqua Fire Department.

FERENZ--Mary Posch. Mary Posch Ferenz, passed away on Monday, August 12, 2013, at the age of 83 at the Sunrise at Fox Hill Assisted Living Community in Bethesda, MD. She was born on March 2, 1930, in New York City, the daughter of the late Anton and Pauline Posch of Slovakia. She is preceded in death by her beloved husband of 58 years, Joseph Andrew Ferenz, her parents, her sisters Theresa Hromada and Anne Robinson, and her grandson Mark Ferenz. She is survived by her two daughters, Anne Ferenz and Jean-Marie Fernandez; one son, Peter Ferenz; one brother, Anthony Posch; eight grandchildren, Sofia Fernandez, Alexander Fernandez, Alina Fernandez, Elizabeth Wallace, Paula Fisher, Helen Ferenz, Margaret Ferenz, and Andrew Ferenz; and five great- grandchildren. Mary met and married the love of her life, the "boy next door", Joseph Andrew Ferenz on November 15, 1952, and embarked upon 58 years of a wonderful life marked by deep love, family, and extensive travel. Always by her husband's side and following his work overseas, she lived many years in The Netherlands, Iran, Canada, Great Britain, and spent many months in Saudi Arabia and Egypt. Mary and her husband retired to Charlottesville, Virginia, and enjoyed time together with friends and watching her husband play golf. Mary loved reading with a passion, classical music, and absolutely anything British. She adored her grandchildren, and spent her final years helping with homework, attending recitals, and watching her favorite tv shows in their company. A funeral mass will be conducted 11am Thursday, August 29, 2013, at Our Lady of Mercy Catholic Church in Potomac, MD. Interment services will follow at Park Lawn Memorial Park in Rockville, MD. The family will receive friends and family immediately following the interment at the home of Jean-Marie and Raul Fernandez. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of Washington at 924 G St. NW, Washington, D.C. 20001. (202) 772-4394 www.catholiccharitiesdc.org

COHEN--Sylvia Steinberg, widow of Dr. E. Malcolm Cohen, died August 23, at age 91. Her funeral service was held. Her loving nieces and nephews will be privately celebrating her life. Our profound gratitude to Carol Samuels for her years of kind, dedicated and extraordinary service.

BURNS--Red, The Tisch School of the Arts is heartbroken over the death of the incandescent and amazing Red Burns. Innovator, visionary, truth-teller, cherished colleague, and revered teacher - Red brought high standards, brilliance, humor, perseverance, and a sharp eye for great ideas to her four decades at Tisch, and through ITP made Tisch a beacon on the digital landscape. The hallways and classrooms will seem a little dimmer without her presence. She was one-of-a-kind, and will be missed terribly. Red's legacy will continue through a scholarship fund established in her name at www.itp.nyu.edu/redburnsfund We offer our deepest condolences to her family, loved ones, friends, and many, many admirers. Mary Schmidt Campbell, Dean, NYU's Tisch School of the Arts

BURNS--Red, on August 23, 2013, at her home in New York City. Survived by her children Michael, Barbara, Catherine and her grandchildren Daisy, Sally and Olive. She is predeceased by her daughter Wendy. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Red Burns Scholarship Fund: itp.nyu.edu/redburnsfund/
BRODIE--Jerry (Jake), 91, passed away August 22. Beloved husband of Gloria. Loving father of Stephen and Nancy. Dearest grandfather.

BRANDT--Carl D.,on August 13. Longtime resident of Rhinebeck, NY, distinguished literary agent for over 50 years. Beloved friend, colleague, and mentor to numerous accomplished authors, Carl remained to the end a true gentleman and will be greatly missed. He is survived by children Diana, Colin and Cameron, their spouses, eight grandchildren, wife Clare, and co-workers at Brandt & Hochman Literary Agents.

BERKE--Dorothy, on August 23, 2013. Beloved mother of Carole and Peter Meltzer. Devoted grandmother of Jori Wolfe, Lani Rager and Tara Meltzer, and loving great-grandmother of Shane and Connor Wolfe. Funeral service Tuesday 11:30am at Fank E. Campbells: 1076 Madison Avenue and 81st Street. Interment to follow at Montefiore Cemetery.

ANTONAKOS--Stephen, 86, died suddenly August 17th, interrupting a life in art active since the 1950s. Known for his abstract, spatial work with neon from 1960 to the present, Antonakos defined his work as "real things in real spaces" -- avoiding representation, illusion, symbolism. The activation of the space occupied by both the art and the viewer, and the crucial architectural placement of forms, were defining characteristics of decades of work that redefined neon as capable of great formal subtlety and, often, spiritual power. His complete and incomplete neon circles and squares and their spatial relationships to their sites connect his work with Minimalism, but Antonakos's distinctive lightness allows a certain openness in interpretation. Even with the large Public Works he said he hoped to reach the inner person. In addition to the neon work, there are Artist's Books, reliefs, collages, prints, and an enormous history of drawings on paper and vellum -- often folded, cut, layered, or crumpled. Recent series of cut or crumpled gold leaf sheets continued his investigation into questions of light. Since the 1960s he has exhibited in New York and across the US and in Europe in hundreds of shows. Among the outstanding exhibitions were "Ten Outdoor Neons, Fort Worth," 1974; Documenta 6, 1977; "Chapel of the Saints," 1993, Rhodes; Venice Biennale, 1997; Marzona Collection, Hamburger Bahnhof; 2001-2002; A Retrospective, 2007-8, Athens, org. by the J.F. Costopoulos Foundation; and "The Search," 2011, Elefsina. Shows in 2013 include paper work at The Drawing Room, East Hampton; the early "Pillows" at Lori Bookstein Fine Art, Chelsea; the 1965 "Hanging Neon" in "Dynamo" at the Grand Palais; and "4 Directions" at the Konrad Fischer Galerie, Berlin. Over 50 Public Works have been installed in such cities as Athens, Bari, Dijon, Frankfurt, Los Angeles, New York, Odessa, Tel Aviv, Tokyo, and Seattle. Antonakos's work is represented in numerous private and public collections, including The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney Museum of American Art, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, the National Gallery in D.C., and the National Museums of Contemporary Art in Athens and Salonica. Major publications include Irving Sandler's 1997 monograph and the catalog for the Athens Retrospective, with essays by Martin Filler, Eleftherios Ikonomou, Katerina Koskina, Daniel Marzona, and Brian O'Doherty. In 2011 he received Lifetime Achievement Awards from the National Academy of Art and Museum, and from the Greek American Foundation. A modest man of great gentleness and sensitivity, he made bold, original investigations into the open experience of form, color, and light in space. Antonakos was born November 1, 1926 in the small Greek village of Agios Nikolaos, Laconia. He often mentioned remembering the sunrises there. He came to New York at the age of 4 with his parents Thomas and Evangelia (Gregory), his brothers Bill, Peter, and Tony, and his sister Kanella. He grew up in Bay Ridge and served in the Philippines in WWII. He is survived by his wife Naomi Spector, his children Stephen B Antonakos, a musician, and Evangelia Mary Spector Antonakos, a mathematician, and many loving relatives and friends. We will miss his energy and his warmth. Viewings at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., Thursday August 29 from 5 to 9pm and Friday August 30 from 2 to 5pm. Funeral at St. John the Baptist Greek Orthodox Church, 143 East 17th St., Saturday August 31 at 10am.

SIEBERT--Muriel F. "Mickie." Siebert Financial Corp. and Muriel Siebert & Co., Inc., are saddened to announce the death of their Founder, Chairwoman and Chief Executive Officer, Muriel F. "Mickie" Siebert. Ms. Siebert, 84, died of complications from cancer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering in Manhattan on August 24. Known as the "First Woman of Finance," among her many achievements, Ms. Siebert was the first woman to own a seat on the New York Stock Exchange and the first to head one of its member firms, Muriel Siebert & Co., Inc. Ms. Siebert was also a pioneer in the discount brokerage field, transforming her firm into a discount brokerage in 1975 on the first day NYSE members were allowed to negotiate commissions. In 1977, she put her firm in a blind trust to serve as New York State's first woman Superintendent of Banking for five years. Through the Muriel F. Siebert Foundation, Ms. Siebert developed the "Siebert Personal Finance Program: Taking Control of Your Financial Future," a financial literacy program which has improved the lives of innumerable middle and high school students and adults by teaching them essential skills. She was the recipient of numerous awards and honors throughout her life, served on many prestigious boards of directors and was an active member of many non-profit, civic and women's organizations. Services will be held at 11am on Tuesday, August 27, 2013, at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Ave., between 54th and 55th Streets, New York, NY 10022. Contributions may be made to the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons, The Muriel F. Siebert Foundation or a charity of your choice.
SIEBERT--Muriel. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Muriel Siebert Bernstein. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family.

SIEBERT--Muriel, The Women's Forum of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our founding member and past president Muriel Siebert. The Founder and President of the discount brokerage firm that bears her name, Mickie was known as the "First Woman of Finance" for nearly 50 years. She was the first woman member of the New York Stock Exchange, the first woman to head one of its member firms and the first woman Superintendent of Banks for New York State. A true pioneer for women, Mickie made headlines when she shattered "male only" barriers at the NYSE by starting, owning and operating her own member firm- then trading as no woman had done before her, on the exchange floor. Mickie's passion to improve the financial literacy of young adults became a reality in 2004 when she originated a curriculum to teach personal finance to high school students. The Personal Finance Program: Taking Control of Your Financial Future is currently being used by numerous high schools to provide students with the fundamentals of personal finance. A true legend of the Women's Forum of New York, Mickie will be greatly missed. Doris P. Meister President Rita B. Crotty Executive Director

SIEBERT--Muriel. Guild Hall of East Hampton mourns the passing of Muriel "Mickie" Siebert, a beloved Board member, who served as our Treasurer and Finance Committee Chair. She will be missed. Martin Cohen, Chair Mickey Straus, Honorary Chair Ruth Appelhof, Executive Director

SIEBERT--Muriel, A groundbreaking, trail blazing "Grand Dame" who did everything her way. A most special friend. Thank you for the memories- we had fun. May you always have Ketel One on the rocks waiting for you wherever you go. Love, Lynda and Richard

SIEBERT--Muriel. Mickey was singular. We appreciated her trailblazing and paving the way for the newly launched Financial Literacy Project at Teachers College. She was an encouraging voice for us. SIEBERT--Muriel. The board and staff of New York Legal Assistance Group mourn the passing of our supporter and partner, Muriel Siebert. Abby Milstein, Chair Yisroel Schulman, President

You are witty, spirited, so much fun - ready to break into song and dance at any moment! Caring, compassionate, so actively striving to help others. What a rare combo. PERLMAN--Doris B.,(nee Feder). Beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandma, aunt and friend. Her life was a blessing. Services today.

PAKTER--Selma Mednikov Dies at 97. Mrs. Pakter, a concert pianist and composer, was an honors graduate of the Juilliard School of Music where she received her B.M. and M.M. She studied with Carl Friedberg and upon graduation was appointed professor of Advanced Musical Theory. She also taught privately and was awarded the top prize for excellence by the National Guild of Piano Teachers. Mrs. Pakter concertized nationally and internationally, developing a series of Didactic Concerts and the innovative 1-2-3-4 Series. She held the distinction of being a Steinway Artist. Mrs. Pakter was born on July 25, 1916, in Kansas City, MO and died in her Manhattan home, Tuesday, August 20, 2013. She was 97. She leaves her children Sheila, Walter (died 2002), David, Laura, Leone and Robert, their spouses, many grandchildren and great- grandchildren. Her husband Paul died in 1993. She was a beautiful person. A viewing will be held on Wednesday, August 28, at the Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 2pm. No flowers please.

NUNEZ--Eladio Alvarez. His passing on August 19, 2013, at age 85 is deeply mourned by his colleagues in the Department of Pathology and Cell Biology at Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons. Ed made a deep impression, both on fellow faculty members and on the many students of medicine and dentistry that were fortunate to have had Ed as a teacher. He was renowned for the booming optimism that allowed him to overcome the adversity that filled his early life. Ed was born in Spain in 1928 to parents on the losing side of the Spanish Civil War. That drove him first to a refugee camp in France and then, at the age of eight, to foster parents in New York. His education in NYC public schools had to be managed in English, which he rapidly acquired. After serving in the US Army during the Korean War, Ed earned a bachelor's degree from St. Johns University and a PhD from NYU. He began his career at Cornell Medical School but soon moved to Columbia University, where he served as a professor from 1975 to 2009. Ed made major contributions to knowledge of the cellular biology of thyroid parafollicular cells with the support of a Career Development Award and subsequent research grants from the National Institutes of Health. Ed will be remembered fondly as an indefatigable and enthusiastic director of courses in both medical and dental curricula. We extend our sympathy to Ed's wife, Selina; his two sons, Robert and Richard (a P&S graduate); his daughter, Terra; and his three grandchildren. Michael Gershon, MD Chairman Emeritus, Anatomy and Cell Biology Letty Moss-Salentijn, DDS, PhD Vice Dean for Academic Affairs, College of Dental Medicine Michael Shelanski, MD, PhD Chairman, Pathology and Cell Biology Columbia University

NOVEMBERBarbara L.,on August 26. The most lovely wife, mother, grandmother, and teacher will be missed by everyone she touched. Services will be held Sunday, September 8th at 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LOW--Mickey, on August 25th, 2013. Beloved husband of Linda. Devoted father of Sheri, Jeffrey, Sean (Cate), Nicole (John), Adam (Elizabeth), Justine and the late Brian. Cherished Grandfather of Jordan, Joshua, Lucas, Taylor, Blake, Mira, Liev, Genevieve, Ari, Kaylin, Skylar, Dylan and Alexander. Loving brother of JoAnne (Malcolm). Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering or Take the Lead.

KRY--Stig A.,Stig A. Kry, 84, passed away August 24, 2013, peacefully at his Manhattan home, surrounded by family. Born January 18, 1929, in Aplared, Sweden, Mr. Kry emigrated to the United States after receiving an engineering degree from NKI Skolan, Stockholm. He joined KSA, a management consulting company, in 1958, and was there for more than 40 years, including serving as chairman of the board. He served on various corporate boards including Dominion Textiles, NPD, Oshkosh B'Gosh, and Paul Harris Retail. He also served on the board of the School of Human Sciences at Auburn University. Mr. Kry was a man of integrity and kindness. Fluent in three languages, he was a true intellectual, and he possessed a keen sense of humor. He loved the outdoors, tennis, world travel and reading. Mr. Kry will be greatly missed by his wife, Rebecca, and his children, Lisa Levenson and Lars Kry, his stepchildren, Anne Rochell Konigsmark and Carlton Rochell, nine grandchildren, and his sisters, Brita Josefsson and Siv Martinsson. A memorial service will be held on September 7 at 4:30pm at Church of Sweden, 5 East 48th St., New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Church of Sweden.
KRAUS--Stephen. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Stephen Kraus, associated with The New York Times from September 1, 1960 until retiring on January 1, 1993.
KOVAL--Dr. Raymond P. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

HEALY--James D.,on August 23, 2013 after a long illness. Retired New York State Banking Department, HSBC (Marine Midland) Bank. Predeceased by parents, Anna and Morgan and brother Morgan. Survived by sister Grace Healy, sister-in-law Greta Healy nieces Lorilee Crafa and Marylee Hoge and their spouses and children. Proud graduate of St. Francis College and member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick and the Knights of Columbus. He loved his church, family, country, Ireland and New York City. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave., NYC, Wednesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 11am at Epiphany Church.

FRIEND--Solomon H. of Boca Raton, FL, 90 years. Brilliant lawyer, humorous, and loving father and friend, died on August 26, 2013. He was married to Channa for 64 years, and leaves his beloved children Debbie, Sheara, Lisa, David; cherished grandfather of Benjamin, Noah, Daniel, Giulia, Sophie and Eliza. Services Wednesday, 11:30am at Temple Emanuel, 160 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY. Mr. Friend was Justice of Kings Point, NY, North Hills, NY, President, Nassau County Magistrates Association, Legal Counsel UAHC and Jewish advocate.

FERENZ--Mary Posch. Mary Posch Ferenz, passed away on Monday, August 12, 2013, at the age of 83 at the Sunrise at Fox Hill Assisted Living Community in Bethesda, MD. She was born on March 2, 1930, in New York City, the daughter of the late Anton and Pauline Posch of Slovakia. She is preceded in death by her beloved husband of 58 years, Joseph Andrew Ferenz, her parents, her sisters Theresa Hromada and Anne Robinson, and her grandson Mark Ferenz. She is survived by her two daughters, Anne Ferenz and Jean-Marie Fernandez; one son, Peter Ferenz; one brother, Anthony Posch; eight grandchildren, Sofia Fernandez, Alexander Fernandez, Alina Fernandez, Elizabeth Wallace, Paula Fisher, Helen Ferenz, Margaret Ferenz, and Andrew Ferenz; and five great- grandchildren. Mary met and married the love of her life, the "boy next door", Joseph Andrew Ferenz on November 15, 1952, and embarked upon 58 years of a wonderful life marked by deep love, family, and extensive travel. Always by her husband's side and following his work overseas, she lived many years in The Netherlands, Iran, Canada, Great Britain, and spent many months in Saudi Arabia and Egypt. Mary and her husband retired to Charlottesville, Virginia, and enjoyed time together with friends and watching her husband play golf. Mary loved reading with a passion, classical music, and absolutely anything British. She adored her grandchildren, and spent her final years helping with homework, attending recitals, and watching her favorite tv shows in their company. A funeral mass will be conducted 11am Thursday, August 29, 2013, at Our Lady of Mercy Catholic Church in Potomac, MD. Interment services will follow at Park Lawn Memorial Park in Rockville, MD. The family will receive friends and family immediately following the interment at the home of Jean-Marie and Raul Fernandez. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of Washington at 924 G St. NW, Washington, D.C. 20001. (202) 772-4394 www.catholiccharitiesdc.org

FAUROT--Charles Henry, of Midlothian, VA, born October 3, 1935, founder of Old Blue Records and beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, teacher, coach, and friend, died on Sunday, August 25, 2013, from complications of pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his wife, children, and his beloved family. A memorial service will be held 11am, Saturday at the Huguenot Chapel of Woody Funeral Home, 1020 Huguenot Road, Midlothian. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Operation Walk Virginia, c/o Inova Mount Vernon Hospital Unit 4A, 2501 Parkers Lane, Alexandria, VA 22306.

COLFELT--Jean Beggs, 97, of Gladwyne, PA, died peacefully Saturday, August 24, 2013. Born at home on Berkeley Road, Merion, PA, in 1916, Jean Todd Beggs was daughter to Hilda Farr and Robert A. Beggs Jr., he being a businessman and alumnus of University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School and Penn Law. The youngest of three sisters, Jean and her siblings shared a joyful childhood together, made memorable by time spent with adoring grandparents on both sides, including the Hon. John R. Farr, Speaker of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives and later a United States Congressman from the Pennsylvania's 10th District. Jean recalled, as an independent young woman, driving her Model "A" Ford down Montgomery Avenue to Miss Wright's School in Bryn Mawr, and then navigating further the long route to brand new Bennington College, where she was in the pioneering Class of 1937. In 1939, she was married to Herbert P. Colfelt Jr., of New York and Haverford, an aeronautical engineer with Piasecki/BoeingVertol. The couple had met at a dance, when Mr. Colfelt was a student at The Haverford School. They would settle in central Philadelphia's English Village near Rittenhouse Square, where for over 65 years, Mrs. Colfelt lived, and thrived on life in the City. From Philadelphia Orchestra matinees and New Year's concerts, to marriage and raising a son within steps of science and art museums, to purposeful errands at Wanamaker's or Stawbridge's, she gave up the car and took pride in walking everywhere she went. A devoted mother herself, Jean cared for her mother through multiple sclerosis and then for husband Herbert during cancer, until his death in 1987. Mrs. Colfelt spent her later years in happy enjoyment at Waverly Heights, in Gladwyne. Predeceased by sisters Louise Beggs Stern, an actress, and Bette Beggs Ashford, a painter. Jean Beggs Colfelt is survived in her immediate family by a son Todd (Gail) and grandson Craig (Michael Andrews). In lieu of flowers, charitable contributions in Jean's memory can be made to Bennington College, Office of External Relations, One College Drive, Bennington, VT 05201 (www.bennington.edu/Alumni/ Support/WaysGive.aspx), or to the Waverly Heights Employee Appreciation Fund, c/o David Farling, 1400 Waverly Rd., Gladwyne, PA 19035. Graveside service on Tuesday, August 27, 1pm, West Laurel Hill Cemetery, 225 Belmont Ave., Bala Cynwyd, PA. Services by Bringhurst Funeral Home, Inc. www.forever-care.com

SIEBERT--Muriel, What do we think of when we think of you dear Mickie? We think of someone who is not only incredibly smart and brilliant and a true legend - but someone with a heart of gold. You are witty, spirited, so much fun - ready to break into song and dance at any moment! Caring, compassionate, so actively striving to help others. What a rare combo. ROBINSON--Ruth B.M.,88. Born in Wellington, New Zealand, daughter of Sir A.C. Turnbull, wartime administrator of the Pacific island of Samoa, and Dorothy Moncrieff Turnbull. During WWII, met and married a U.S. navy pilot, Lieut. Cmdr. Richard W. Robinson, commander of a squadron of Hellcat fighters on Samoa. After he was shot down during the battle of Okinawa, she remained in the U.S., graduating from the University of South Carolina. In 1957, she was hired by The New York Times, rising from secretary to reporter to editor in the Style section. An avid mountain climber and skier, many of her articles involved travel and the outdoors. Her grace, wit and companionship will be missed. Donations are being accepted by the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference, www.nynjtc.org.

ROAMAN--Eileen. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of Eileen Roaman, beloved daughter of our dear friend Carol Roaman and the late Martin Roaman. An esteemed member of the Einstein community and a longtime supporter of biomedical research, Carol is president of our Women's Division and serves on the College's Board of Overseers. Our hearts go out to Carol, her son Bradford Roaman and his children Oliver and Reese, and the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

ROAMAN--Eileen. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to her mother Carol, her brother Bradford and family. Eileen was loved by all who knew her and will surely be missed. Trudy and Marvin Schlachter

ROAMAN--Eileen. Died peacefully Monday afternoon surrounded by family and friends. Loving daughter of Carol Roaman and the late Martin Roaman, adoring sister of Bradford Roaman and cherished Aunt of Oliver and Reese Roaman. Funeral service Thursday at 11:00am. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons.

PAKTER--Selma Mednikov Dies at 97. Mrs. Pakter, a concert pianist and composer, was an honors graduate of the Juilliard School of Music where she received her B.M. and M.M. She studied with Carl Friedberg and upon graduation was appointed professor of Advanced Musical Theory. She also taught privately and was awarded the top prize for excellence by the National Guild of Piano Teachers. Mrs. Pakter concertized nationally and internationally, developing a series of Didactic Concerts and the innovative 1-2-3-4 Series. She held the distinction of being a Steinway Artist. Mrs. Pakter was born on July 25, 1916, in Kansas City, MO and died in her Manhattan home, Tuesday, August 20, 2013. She was 97. She leaves her children Sheila, Walter (died 2002), David, Laura, Leone and Robert, their spouses, many grandchildren and great- grandchildren. Her husband Paul died in 1993. She was a beautiful person. A viewing will be held on Wednesday, August 28, at the Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 2pm. No flowers please.

NAWY--Victoria, nee Rashti, passed away peacefully at her home in Forest Hills, NY on August 20, 2013 at the age of 104. She joins her husband Carl, and son Harold. She is survived by her children, Joe and Joyce; grandchildren Scott A, Jesse, Jena, Scott G, and Marc; 8 great-grandchildren, and many adoring nephews and nieces. Vicky was an inspiration, always inquisitive and youthful, and she lit up our lives with her smile, wit, and grace. Mom, Our Hearts are Full of Your Love, and Your Light.

LOW--Mickey, on August 25th, 2013. Beloved husband of Linda. Devoted father of Sheri, Jeffrey, Sean (Cate), Nicole (John), Adam (Elizabeth), Justine and the late Brian. Cherished Grandfather of Jordan, Joshua, Lucas, Taylor, Blake, Mira, Liev, Genevieve, Ari, Kaylin, Skylar, Dylan and Alexander. Loving brother of JoAnne (Malcolm). He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Services Wednesday August 28th, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering or Take the Lead.

HEALY--James D.,on August 23, 2013 after a long illness. Retired New York State Banking Department, HSBC (Marine Midland) Bank. Predeceased by parents, Anna and Morgan and brother Morgan. Survived by sister Grace Healy, sister-in-law Greta Healy nieces Lorilee Crafa and Marylee Hoge and their spouses and children. Proud graduate of St. Francis College and member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick and the Knights of Columbus. He loved his church, family, country, Ireland and New York City. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave., NYC, Wednesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 11am at Epiphany Church.

GROSSER--Andrew. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of one of our youngest members. Minna Brown, Board Chair

COOPER--Karen K. died on August 22, 2013, after a year-long struggle with cancer. At the time of her passing, she had been President for the last six years of the architectural firm of Cooper, Robertson & Partners, where she had worked since its inception in 1979. In that capacity, as well as in her personal life she bore the following traits, recognized by all who knew her: intelligent and uncommonly mature, strategic and decisive, self-reliant and self-aware, high spirited and high minded, candid and generous, passionate and compellingly feminine. Karen reached out to numerous professional, civic and charitable groups and served as a Board Member of The Arts Horizons organization. She graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree from the State University of New York. She is survived by her sister, Kathleen Krauze, her partner, Adam Medici, by her dogs, PeeWee, Zanzibar and Lassy and by a banquet of friends who love her deeply and remain blessed by her radiance. Donations in her name may be made to: the George Jackson Academy, 104 St. Marks Place, New York, NY 10009. gjacademy.org or PetResQ, Inc., 24 West Railroad Avenue, Tenafly, NJ 07670. petresqinc.org.

ROAMAN--Eileen. Died peacefully Monday afternoon surrounded by family and friends. Loving daughter of Carol Roaman and the late Martin Roaman, adoring sister of Bradford Roaman and cherished Aunt of Oliver and Reese Roaman. Funeral service Thursday at 11:00am. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons.

RASMUSSEN--Waldo. The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art is deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Waldo Rasmussen, the former longtime Director of The Museum of Modern Art's International Program, on August 15 after a long illness. Waldo was an unflagging ambassador for the Museum, passionate about sharing its treasures with a large international public. His legacy will be warmly remembered by Council members and professional colleagues at MoMA and throughout the world. Waldo was predeceased by his beloved daughter Lisa. He is survived by his life companion and spouse John Dowling, his son M.D. Rasmussen, and three grandchildren. His previous marriage to Geraldine Rasmussen ended in divorce. Agnes Gund, Chairman Sharon Percy Rockefeller, President Joann K. Phillips, Jeanne C. Thayer, Jo Carole Lauder, Presidents Emeritae The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

LOWE--Hannah (Esh). August 26, 2013, Predeceased by husband Bertram S. Lowe (1985). Survived by children David (Anne), Susan (John Beekman), Daniel (Marcia), six grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. Private burial.

LOVEJOY--Paul Robert, 58, of Wakefield, Rhode Island and Chicago died suddenly on August 26th after a brief illness. A lawyer, most recently with Kirkland & Ellis and previously as General Counsel of United Airlines, Paul relished the practice of corporate law. His long, distinguished career included partnerships with the firms Squire, Sanders and Weil, Gotshal and Manges, and nine years as Assistant General Counsel of Texaco. Paul served many non-profits as a board member and volunteer, including his college, New England College, where he graduated summa cum laude in 1977, and his law school, Case Western Reserve University, where he earned the distinction of Order of the Coif and served as an editor of the law review. He is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Susan Seyfarth Lovejoy, his daughter, Kate Lovejoy Anderson (Peter), two sisters, Maryann Lovejoy Alfano, and Linda Lovejoy Jukes and seven nieces and nephews. Paul was predeceased by his parents, Jean and V. Paul Lovejoy of Mentor, Ohio. A private celebration of Paul's life will be held over the weekend. Donations in his name can be made to South Kingstown Land Trust, Wakefield, RI.

LIPPMANN--Robert L.,on August 26. Husband of the late Rosalie Thalheimer Lippmann. Father of Pamela Lippmann Roth (Matthew) and Valerie Lippmann Doran (Daniel); devoted grandfather of Stacey and Scott Roth; brother of John. He spent his career as a trimmings buyer for such noted designers as Pauline Trigere and Blassport. An active Mason for more than 40 years, he was also the last original member of the Board of Directors of his co-op, having served for more than 50 years. Services Sunday, September 1, 10:00am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to Masonic Brotherhood Fund, 71 W. 23rd St., New York, NY 10010.

KLEINBERG--Luise. We note with sorrow the passing of our member, Luise Kleinberg, and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

KLEINBERG--Luise, on August 27th, 2013. Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Andrew and his wife Lakshmi and Jeanine and her husband Jack. Cherished grandmother of Cecilia, Jake, Annika and Liliana. Devoted sister of Howard and the late Leonard. An extraordinary woman, totally devoted to a wide circle of family and friends who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Friday August 30th, 2013 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Bottomless Closet 1510 Penn Plaza, level B Suite 40 New York, NY 10001.

EZRINE--Ivan Allan. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Ivan Allan Ezrine and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

EZRINE--Ivan Allan. On August 27, 2013. Beloved husband of Lucille V. Corrier. Devoted father of Jonathan, James, and Elizabeth Poguntke. He is also survived by four grandchildren. Cherished brother of Rhoda Ganz, Aivin Ezrin and Martin M. Ezrin. Graveside Service today at 1pm at Mt. Ararat Cemetery. Contributions may be made in Ivan's memory to Central Syngogue.

COOPER--Karen K. died on August 22, 2013, after a year-long struggle with cancer. At the time of her passing, she had been President for the last six years of the architectural firm of Cooper, Robertson & Partners, where she had worked since its inception in 1979. In that capacity, as well as in her personal life she bore the following traits, recognized by all who knew her: intelligent and uncommonly mature, strategic and decisive, self-reliant and self-aware, high spirited and high minded, candid and generous, passionate and compellingly feminine. Karen reached out to numerous professional, civic and charitable groups and served as a Board Member of The Arts Horizons organization. She graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree from the State University of New York. She is survived by her sister, Kathleen Krauze, her partner, Adam Medici, by her dogs, PeeWee, Zanzibar and Lassy and by a banquet of friends who love her deeply and remain blessed by her radiance. Donations in her name may be made to: the George Jackson Academy, 104 St. Marks Place, New York, NY 10009. gjacademy.org or PetResQ, Inc., 24 West Railroad Avenue, Tenafly, NJ 07670. petresqinc.org.

BILLY--William M. July 2, 1958 - August 30, 1993 20 years ago my dear friend died. 20 years without his wonderfully unique perspective on life; his very opinionated opinions on art, design, food, music, dance, theater, science, and any other aspect of the human condition you wanted to discuss; his ridiculous love of the ridiculous; his brutal honesty in calling out the phony and the false, never cruelly but not necessarily without a bite; 20 years without his happy, restless creativity that ranged from the highly profound to the highly questionable; and 20 years without his love, support, and friendship which he always gave so honestly, lovingly, and generously. Among his friends he is spoken of often and always with a smile. Sometimes I hesitate to think of what might have been but I know that it would have been wonderful. Bill McIntosh

SCHULTZ--Irene Z. (87), of Floral Park (formerly Rockville Centre) died at home on her birthday, August 28. 20l3. Cherished wife of the late Morton Schultz and beloved companion of the late Martin Kamisher, dear sister of Janet Segal, and devoted mother of Ann William (Doug) and Ami Belsky (Mark). RUSSELL--Irwin. Prominent entertainment attorney Irwin Russell died August 24 of Leukemia at the age of 87. Russell was central to a wide range of landmark entertainment industry deals and represented Jim Henson in the deal that brought the Muppets to Sesame Street. Other clients included legendary comedienne and actress Carol Burnett, children's author Theodore Geisel (aka, Dr. Seuss), actor Robert Preston, and Christina Crawford. Russell's longtime client and associate, Michael Eisner, former CEO and Chairman of The Walt Disney Company and founder of The Tornante Company, said, "Irwin Russell was a brilliant lawyer, an insightful executive, an eloquent writer and, in all things, a true gentleman. He represented me for 40 years, including my tenures at ABC, Paramount, Disney and, until the day he died, at Tornante. He was able to write and get all parties to agree to a one-page deal, something unheard of in American business. Ethics, doing it right and being fair were embedded in his DNA. This is a deep loss for all of us." Russell is a graduate of Townsend-Harris High School in Queens, and interrupted his undergraduate education at the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce to serve in the U.S. Army Air Corps during World War II, returning to get his B.S. from Wharton in 1947 and his J.D. from Harvard Law School in 1949. Russell is survived by his wife, Suzanne. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Irwin E. Russell J.D. '49 Financial Aid Fund at Harvard Law School. A memorial service is being planned for September
ROAMAN--Eileen. Carol - my thoughts are with you always. Brian

MEADE--Judith. Passed away August 24 after a brief and brave battle with cancer. Loving wife to William Meade and mother to Henry and Patrick, Judy was a true New Yorker from her birth in Sunnyside, Queens to her last home on the Upper West Side. A graduate of the University of Georgia, she returned to Manhattan and had a long career in publishing including Bon Appetit and Seventeen magazines and the Scholastic Co. After the birth of her twin sons, she became a freelance copywriter, working for New York magazine, Patch, and Aravind Eye Foundation, as well as directing marketing communications for her husband's entertainment production company. She also developed Charlie B, a children's multimedia education package. Whether it was her flair for decorating or her inventive gourmet menus, Judy will be remembered as a warm hostess with an open door policy for all. She knew no strangers. Judy enjoyed the arts, film, music, and was an excellent Scrabble player with a spirited sense of humor. She loved traveling with her family and was active in supporting her children's schools. In addition to her husband and children, she leaves four siblings: Linda, Ken, Lynn Ann and Patricia, and a wide circle of friends. She is predeceased by her parents and a brother. Services will be held at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Ave., on Saturday, August 31 at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Gilda's Club of New York.

MacWHORTER--R. Bruce 83, slipped peacefully into another world on August 26, 2013, surrounded by his family. Born in Philadelphia, PA, Bruce grew up in Washington, DC. He received his BA degree in American History from Oberlin College in Ohio, and his J.D. degree from the University of Virginia Law School. Bruce joined the New York law firm of Shearman and Sterling in 1956, was elected to the partnership of the firm in 1965, and retired after 35 years of distinguished service. He was the leader of the firm's first antitrust stand-alone practice group for 20 years, during which time the group earned a reputation as one of the most respected antitrust practices in the United States. Bruce was a long time resident of Maplewood, NJ where he and his loving wife raised their family of three daughters and multiple golden retrievers. Bruce and his wife moved to WindsorMeade in Williamsburg, VA in 2007. Bruce was preceded in death by his father and mother George Merritt and Marion Ritchie MacWhorter, and his brother George M. Mac-Whorter. Bruce is lovingly remembered by his wife Althea Davis MacWhorter, his daughters Susan, Nancy and Marjorie, sons-in-law Steve, Eric and Carl, and six grandchildren, Julian, Duncan, Drew, Will, Grayson and Elizabeth. He is remembered for his modest disposition, his sense of humor in stressful times, and as a gentleman lawyer of Wall Street. Most of all he is remembered as a loving and loyal husband and father, and the best granddaddy a grandchild could have. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to Saint Jude's Children's Research Hospital, Smile Train, or a charity of choice.

LISANBY--Charles Alvin Jr.,passed away peacefully in the presence of his family in Los Angeles, California, on August 23, 2013, at the age of 89. Mr. Lisanby had a seven decade career in the arts and entertainment industry, marked by 16 Emmy Nominations and three Wins for Baryshnikov on Broadway, Ben Franklin, The Ambassador - mini series, and (Barry) Manilow: Big Fun on Swing Street. Born in Princeton, KY, Mr. Lisanby arrived in New York City at the age of 16 to pursue art studies and an apprenticeship with the legendary Broadway and Film Art Director, Cecil Beaton. Following a stint in the Army, he landed a position at CBS and later at ABC as their first Art Director. He worked on many variety shows including the Garry Moore Show, where Carol Burnett, among others got their start. In fact, it was Charles who recommended Ms. Burnett to Moore's producer, Bob Banner. Bob Banner, hired Charles for many variety shows, for Alan King, Paul Lynde, Bob Hope, Kathy Lee Gifford, Barry Manilow, Barbra Streisand, Carol Burnett and Julie Andrews, Mikhail Baryshnikov, and Diana Ross. Twelve of his musical specials won Emmys for best Variety Show. He did multiple Motion Picture Academy Awards Shows, the Grammys, and the first MTV Awards shows. Commercial producers also reached out to Mr. Lisanby to design, the CLIO award winning original, Merrill Lynch "bull" commercials, and seven Dr. Pepper commercials and the Panasonic "hands" commercials. He was the designer of Radio City's Christmas Show from '78 thru '95 and the full run of their Easter show during that period. His one act play adaptation of "Christmas Carol" ran for seven years at Radio City. Commencing in 1980, he was the designer of the Crystal Cathedral's Christmas and Easter Productions for their entire run. Mr. Lisanby wrote an original musical entitled, "Family Tree", which became the basis for the musical, "Children of Eden" with lyrics and music by Stephen Schwartz. He also wrote the title and dialogue for Andy Warhol's, "25 Cats Name Sam & One Blue Pussy," which earned both of them their first copyrighted work. Charles has been honored by the Art Directors Guild at the Museum of Television and Radio, the Television Academy with his election to their Hall of Fame as the first in his peer group, Production Designers/ Art Directors and a display of a major body of his designs at the Los Angeles Main Public Library in Getty Hall. Mr. Lisanby is survived by his nieces, Dr. Sarah Hollingsworth Lisanby of Durham, NC, Mrs. Elizabeth Ann Lisanby Bianchi of Huntsville, AL; his sister-in-law, Mrs. Gladys Elnora Kemp Lisanby of Princeton, KY; and his partner Mr. Richard Bostard. He is preceded in death by his brother, Rear Admiral James Walker Lisanby, USN Ret, and his parents Rebecca Hollingsworth Lisanby and Charles Alvin Lisanby, Sr. Funeral services will be held at 3pm on Sunday, September 1st, at Morgan's Funeral Home at 301 W Washington St Princeton, KY 42445 Princeton, KY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Charles Lisanby Center Checks should be made to: JMU Foundation -- Charles Lisanby Center, Mailing address: James Madison University, Advancement Gifts and Records, MSC 3603, 220 University Blvd., Harrisonburg VA 22807.

LIPPMANN--Robert L.,on August 26. Husband of the late Rosalie Thalheimer Lippmann. He spent his career as a trimmings buyer for such noted designers as Pauline Trigere and Blassport. An active Mason for more than 40 years, he was also the last original member of the Board of Directors of his co-op, having served for more than 50 years. Services Sunday, September 1, 10:00am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to Masonic Brotherhood Fund, 71 W. 23rd St., New York, NY 10010.

KLEINBERG--Luise, on August 27th, 2013. Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Andrew and his wife Lakshmi and Jeanine and her husband Jack. GURFEIN--Leonard M.,beloved husband of Penny, devoted father of Lois, Daniel and Gregory, adored grandfather of Kate, Brian, Laura, Eric, Allegra, and Ty, and a longtime diamond dealer, died on August 28th. DIOTALLEVI--Filippo, passed away at the age of 80, on August 22, 2013, and was laid to rest on August 23, 2013, in his beloved birthplace Cartoceto, Italy. Filippo was a Korean War Veteran and after the War went to work for the Wildenstein & Co. Art Gallery in Manhattan, NY. Surrounded by the art he admired, his work became his passion. Filippo went on to become the Vice President of Sales until he retired in 2005. He is survived by his wife, Adriena, his daughters Simonetta, Rita, Francesca, and his grandchildren Philip and Elena Lund.

COHEN--Dr. Harry Bruce,Passed away at the age of 75 in his home in Laguna Beach, CA, on August 21, 2013 after a prolonged battle with multiple myeloma. Retired since 2011, Dr. Cohen was a graduate of Brandeis University, and received his Ph.D. in psychology from McGill University in 1963. Until 1972 he was engaged in research at Stanford University with William Dement and the Stanford University sleep research lab. He joined the faculty of the University of California at Irvine in 1972, teaching in the medical school there for a number of years. A lifelong aficionado of wine, food, music, classic cars and a good cigar, the last decades of his professional life were spent working as a director for the County of Orange Mental Health Services. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Adrienne M. Cohen; his younger son Sascha B. Cohen; his elder son Jonathan R. Cohen and his wife Lidija Cohen; two grandchildren Alexandra and Gabriella; and his siblings Vicki Orchier of Irvington, NY and Irwin J. Cohen of Carmel, IN.
BRIMBERG--Arthur, MD,Partners in the practice of Radiology and in life. Our thoughts are with Marilyn, Julie and Davis and their families. Lois and Steve Robinson

BRIMBERG--Arthur David, MD, 76, Passed away from leukemia on August 28th. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Loving father of Julie (Spencer) and Davis. Dearest "Poppy" of Oscar and Daisy. His intellect, wit, vitality and kindness are cherished and will be kept in our hearts always. Funeral services to be held at the Shulman Chapel in the Woods at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains NY on Friday, August 30th at 12 noon.

BRESSLER--Harold, died August 28th at the age of 91. He was happily married for 60 years to Evelyn, who passed away eight years ago. Levy Place, Box 1430, NY, NY 10029.

BOYD--Allen Richards (Dick). 80, of Sarasota, FL, died on August 22. He was the son of John Ritchie and Mary Juliet Williams Boyd of Mt. Kisco, NY. He graduated from Princeton in 1955, served as Naval Intelligence Officer until 1959, and received his MA in Advanced International Studies from Johns Hopkins in 1960. His calm demeanor, determined optimism, and wry sense of humor will be missed. He is survived by his wife, Candace; his children from his first marriage, Scott, Chris, Stephanie, Rebecca, Robert, and Peter; a sister, Juliet Patterson; a brother, Edgar (Bill) Boyd; and thirteen grandchildren.

BLATZ--Linda Jeanne, of NYC and Glen Head passed away peacefully on August 29, 2013. Beloved daughter of the late Jeanne and William Blatz. Adored sister of Susan and Edward (Anne Marie) Blatz. Devoted aunt of Elizabeth, Jessica and Edward Blatz, Jr. Regional Sales Manager for National Business Furniture. Graduate of the University of Maryland. Long time member of the Junior League of NYC, Cosmopolitan Club, National Arts Club and the Brookville Reformed Church. Linda will be remembered for her grace and elegance. She was an active volunteer who was dedicated to improving the lives of others. Linda will be deeply missed but always present on our hearts. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Junior League, 130 East 80th St., NY 10075 would be greatly appreciated.

ASHE--James J. Jr.,1931-2013 of Greenwich, CT, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his family. Jim was formerly from Garden City, NY and Savannah, GA. He leaves his beloved wife, Dorothy, of 54 years, his adored son, Richard and wife, Maria, along with his daughter, Marybeth and husband, Peter Wise. He was the proud grandfather of Amanda, Peter, Darby, Whitney and Phoebe. Jim was a long-time member of the Cherry Valley Club in Garden City, NY and a board member of the Landings Club in Savannah, GA. Jim was a graduate of Bishop Loughlin High School, Queens College and received his MBA from NYU. He retired in 1985 from U.S. News and World Report as Vice President of Marketing. A private Memorial Service will be held at a later date to honor James. To leave an online condolence please visit: (leopgallaghergreenwich.com)

GIFFORD--Gertrude, 96, of Chapel Hill, North Carolina, died peacefully on August 28, 2013 after an extraordinarily full life. Gert married William Gifford in 1944. She was the mother of Betsy Gross (married to David Gross) and Bill Gifford (married to Jodi Turner), and the grandmother of Robbie Gross, Traci Gifford and Lucy Gifford. Born in San Francisco, Gert was a 1938 graduate of Stanford University. She met her husband on the golf course at Pebble Beach; they spent their married life on Long Island. Gert was a five-time champion golfer at North Shore Country Club, an artist, and an avid bridge player. She loved theater, the opera and traveling the world with her husband. She will be greatly missed.

BLATZ--Linda Jeanne, of NYC and Glen Head passed away peacefully on August 29, 2013. Beloved daughter of the late Jeanne and William Blatz. Adored sister of Susan and Edward (Anne Marie) Blatz. Devoted aunt of Elizabeth, Jessica and Edward Blatz, Jr. Regional Sales Manager for National Business Furniture. Graduate of the University of Maryland. Long time member of the Junior League of NYC, Cosmopolitan Club, National Arts Club and the Brookville Reformed Church. Linda will be remembered for her grace and elegance. She was an active volunteer who was dedicated to improving the lives of others. Linda will be deeply missed but always present on our hearts. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Junior League, 130 East 80th St., NY 10075 would be greatly appreciated.

BEAL--Jack, a leader of the New York Realist movement, died peacefully August 29, 2013 in Oneonta, NY. He is survived by his wife, artist Sondra Freckelton. We who loved him, will miss his wit, intelligence, generosity and larger-than-life persona. Here's to you, Jack. Love from your friends.

WEISS--Doris T. 10/16/30 - 8/30/03. 10 years, dearly beloved, sadly remembered, always in my heart. "For you have sailed beyond the sunset." Bernie
