VARADI--Marilyn. Loved, missed and remembered always. Chick and VOICE

BILLY--William M. July 2, 1958 - August 30, 1993 20 years ago my dear friend died. 20 years without his wonderfully unique perspective on life; his very opinionated opinions on art, design, food, music, dance, theater, science, and any other aspect of the human condition you wanted to discuss; his ridiculous love of the ridiculous; his brutal honesty in calling out the phony and the false, never cruelly but not necessarily without a bite; 20 years without his happy, restless creativity that ranged from the highly profound to the highly questionable; and 20 years without his love, support, and friendship which he always gave so honestly, lovingly, and generously. Among his friends he is spoken of often and always with a smile. Sometimes I hesitate to think of what might have been but I know that it would have been wonderful. Bill McIntosh

WITCHEL--Alice Dinah Brown, 76, died in her home in New York City on August 23, 2013 after battling cancer. Born October 9, 1936 in Scofield Barracks, Honolulu, Dinah, daughter of Lt. Col. John M. and Alice W. Brown, lived in Germany, Puerto Rico, and Baltimore before settling in NYC. She graduated from Glen Burnie High School and later received her BA from the University of Maryland, then an MA from Columbia University's Teachers College. Dinah wrote for The New York Times and the Baltimore Sun. She went on to work as an executive editor for Ski Magazine, Skiing Magazine and Snow Country. She co-authored "Ski Woman's Way," with Elissa Slanger. She also wrote and edited for Kirkus Reviews and Environmental Nutrition. Dinah is survived by her devoted husband Lawrence Witchel, two children, John and Elisabeth Witchel, and four grandchildren. Generous, wise and full of humour, she will be remembered with love.

JOSLIN--Raymond E. A memorial service to remember and celebrate the life of Raymond E. Joslin will be held on Friday, September 20 at 2pm at Christ Church in Greenwich, CT (254 East Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT 06830, Phone: 203-869-6600, christchurchgreenwich.org). Joslin, former president and group head of Hearst Entertainment & Syndication and senior vice president and member of the board of directors of Hearst Corporation, passed away August 2. He was 76. Joslin was a cable television pioneer, a U.S. media ambassador and a corporate entrepreneur, having carved successful careers in both the cable television systems and cable programming industries. For more than 35 years, he built a career with a vision for growth, an eye for quality and a commitment to corporate excellence. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the The Joslin Family Scholarship Fund, Trinity College, Attention: Amy Brough (300 Summit St., Hartford, CT 06106, 860-297-5315, amy.brough@trincoll.edu).

WILKIE--Margot Loines Morrow, of New York and Martha's Vineyard, died peacefully August 21. She was predeceased by her son Stephen Morrow and her stepdaughter Edith Wilkie, and survived by her daughters Faith Morrow Williams of Washington, DC, and Constance Morrow Fulenwider of Weston, MA, eight grandchildren, ten great-grandchildren, and three stepchildren, Rennie Lieber, Neil Wilkie, and Peter Wilkie.

WHELAN--Elisabeth V. (Liz), on August 30, 2013 after a long illness. Child of the 1960's Village, she loved horseback riding and sculpting, and was an artist of immense talent. She will be missed by her mother Roberta, her life partner Cid, sisters Wendy and Jane, brother-in-law Jim, niece Kathleen, step-mother Margaret, and many friends. A memorial service will be planned for a later date.

TOUHEY--Carl E. A lifelong Albany businessman, passed away on August 25th 2013 at the remarkable age of 95. Born in 1917 to Winifred and Charles Touhey, he was a graduate of the Albany Academy and Princeton University (1939). He ran a stunning race for Mayor of Albany in 1973 almost defeating the notorious Albany democratic machine. He was the President of Orange Motor Company, which was founded by his father, Charles, on Friday the 13th 1916. Carl always chuckled at that date, adding, "And we're still standing, still strong!" For over 75 years his various businesses provided employment for hundreds of Albany area families. A passionate philanthropist, he felt the responsibility to give back to his community. When asking others to do the same, he had an interesting strategy. He would say "How can I get big bucks from this guy? First I need to set the tone by stepping up myself." And he did. Some of his favorite organizations were more traditional ones such as Albany Medical Center, The College of Saint Rose, and Saratoga Performing Arts Center. But he also cared about smaller organizations like Capital Region Sponsor a Scholar and the 15 Love Youth Program both of which directly serve families in the community. He will be greatly missed by his wife, Nancy, and his children, Charles, John, Lila Marie, Virginia, their spouses, as well as the mother of his children, Lila L. Touhey, and seven grandchildren and great grandchildren. Predeceased by his sister, Alice, and his brother, Frank, Carl was a surrogate father to their children as well as Nancy's many children and grandchildren. Contributions may be made to Capital Region Sponsor a Scholar Albany, NY or The Achievement Center for Children and Families, Delray Beach, FL.
TOMASEK--Virginia. Beloved wife of Paul Levy. Survived by sons Josh, Dan and Jeremiah, cousins Sunny and Ginger and her many friends the world over.

SUGRUE--Dennis. The principals and employees of Ellington Management Group mourn the passing of our dear partner and friend, Dennis Sugrue. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Donna; to his daughter Molly; to his son Timothy; and to the entire Sugrue family. His long and courageous battle with brain cancer was an inspiration to us all. He will be profoundly missed.

STERN--Richard M. Richard M. Stern.,of Piermont, NY, died on August 28th, 2013 at the age of 91 after losing a two-year battle with prostate cancer. Dick Stern grew up in New Rochelle, NY, and graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, majoring in industrial engineering. He was a World War II veteran who served in the 3519th Ordnance Medium Maintenance Company, involved in the repair and rearming of frontline troops including efforts during the Battle of the Bulge. After the War, Dick worked alongside his father and two of his brothers in the company that became the Stern Dental Corporation, for which he served in a variety of positions including President. Dick Stern was a very sweet man who was devoted to his family. He was also deeply involved in philanthropy, always interested in providing support and resources for the most needy around the world. He was a world traveler, visiting every continent except Antarctica. He is survived by his wife, Charlene, his brother Thomas E., and his four children, Richard (Lauren) Stern, Alice (Brian Gilbane) Stern, David (Elizabeth Shore) Stern, and Jonathan (Janine) Stern, two stepsons Doug (Amy) Ikelheimer and Bruce (Jo) Ikelheimer, and nine grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Dorothy. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Donations may be made to the Prostate Cancer Foundation.

SEAGRAVE--Norman P.,a decorated World War II veteran and aviation lawyer who set national swimming records into his 90s, died August 24 in Santa Fe, NM. He was 97. He was the loving husband of Mary (Ryan), who died in March, and the adored and adoring father of four daughters. Warm-hearted, civic-minded, witty and exuberant, he lived a full and fascinating life. As a young Army officer commanding American and British troops in North Africa, he received both the Bronze Star and membership in the Order of the British Empire, and eventually rose to the rank of lieutenant colonel. As international law counsel for Pan American World Airways, he negotiated the first flights between New York and Moscow at the height of the Cold War. A lifelong Democrat, he served six terms on the Board of Selectmen for the town of Darien, CT. Born January 31, 1916, in Uxbridge, MA, he graduated in 1937 from Bowdoin College, earned his law degree from Harvard Law School in 1940. After the war, he joined the State Department, where he met and married his wife. They lived in Washington and Montreal before he was named civil air attache to the U.S. embassy in Rome. They moved to Darien in 1954 when he joined Pan Am, then moved to Brunswick, Maine after his retirement. He was member of the Council on Foreign Relations and taught international law at Franklin Pierce Law Center. A U.S. Masters swimmer, he was on three relay teams that set All-American records, most recently when he was 92. Mr. Seagrave is survived by his daughters and their husbands: Anne and Reese Fullerton of Santa Fe, NM, Molly and Walter Channing of Bridgehampton, NY, Jane Seagrave and John Kennedy of Martha's Vineyard, MA, Martha Seagrave and Kurt Kaffenberger of Burlington, VT; and 10 grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for Friday, October 4 at 2:30pm at the First Parish Church in Brunswick, Maine. Memorial donations may be made to the Norman P. Seagrave Scholarship Fund, c/o Peter G. Collias, P.O. Box 2519, Fall River, MA 02722.

SCHULTZ--Irene Z. (87), of Floral Park (formerly Rockville Centre) died at home on her birthday, August 28. 20l3. Cherished wife of the late Morton Schultz and beloved companion of the late Martin Kamisher, dear sister of Janet Segal, and devoted mother of Ann William (Doug) and Ami Belsky (Mark). Loving grandmother of Kenny (Stephanie), Leah (Timothy), Gabriel (Katie) Jeffrey (Vanessa), Hannah (Julianne), and great-grandchildren Ainsley and Eli, dear friend of Wally Capasso. Funeral services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck, NY on Sunday, September 1 at lpm.

SCHNEIDER--Berenice, of Cincinnati, OH, formerly of White Plains, NY, passed away August 28, 2013. Graduate of White Plains High School (1935) and Connecticut College for Women (1939). Beloved wife of the late Dr. Meyer R. Schneider, devoted mother of David (Diane) Schneider, Daniel Schneider and Judith Schneider, dear sister of the late Charles Hecht, Ruth Toby and Rose Altman, loving grandmother of Nicholas (Candice), Anna, Claire and Joel, great-grandmother of Cassandra and Noah. Services are being held on September 1, 2013, at Weil Funeral Home in Cincinnati.

RUSSELL--Irwin. Prominent entertainment attorney Irwin Russell died August 24 of Leukemia at the age of 87. Russell was central to a wide range of landmark entertainment industry deals and represented Jim Henson in the deal that brought the Muppets to Sesame Street. Other clients included legendary comedienne and actress Carol Burnett, children's author Theodore Geisel (aka, Dr. Seuss), actor Robert Preston, and Christina Crawford. Russell's longtime client and associate, Michael Eisner, former CEO and Chairman of The Walt Disney Company and founder of The Tornante Company, said, "Irwin Russell was a brilliant lawyer, an insightful executive, an eloquent writer and, in all things, a true gentleman. He represented me for 40 years, including my tenures at ABC, Paramount, Disney and, until the day he died, at Tornante. He was able to write and get all parties to agree to a one-page deal, something unheard of in American business. Ethics, doing it right and being fair were embedded in his DNA. This is a deep loss for all of us." Russell is a graduate of Townsend-Harris High School in Queens, and interrupted his undergraduate education at the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce to serve in the U.S. Army Air Corps during World War II, returning to get his B.S. from Wharton in 1947 and his J.D. from Harvard Law School in 1949. Russell is survived by his wife, Suzanne. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Irwin E. Russell J.D. '49 Financial Aid Fund at Harvard Law School. A memorial service is being planned for September

ROZYCKI--Danuta Lola, M.D.,a pioneer as one of the first female Ear, Nose and Throat Surgeons in the United States, and a Holocaust survivor, died on August 7, 2013 at Montefiore Medical Center. The cause of death was stroke. Dr. Rozycki was born May 30, 1932 in Maniewicz, Poland. Her family survived the Holocaust by fleeing to the forests of Southeast Poland with the help of a Righteous Gentile and later joining the Partisans. As an eight year old, Dr. Rozycki became a Partisan scout because she quickly learned to read the forest. Small and swift, she was able to quietly look for enemies and find her way back to the camp to report. Family members have been decorated by the Russian government for taking part in acts of sabotage against the Nazis in Poland. After the war, Dr. Rozycki remained in Poland, and obtained her medical degree. While in medical school, she met and married her husband of 57 years, Dr. Ludwik Rozycki. In 1957, the Rozyckis emigrated to Israel where their two daughters were born. Dr. Rozycki completed a second medical residency at Beilinson Hospital in Petach Tikva. Her patients at Beilinson included Golda Meir and David Ben Gurion. In 1966, the Rozycki family emigrated to the New York area where Dr. Rozycki completed her third medical residency at NYU Medical Center. In 1968, she affiliated with Albert Einstein College of Medicine, where she taught Ear, Nose and Throat Surgery. In addition to ENT, Dr. Rozycki specialized in Head and Neck Surgery. She later rose to the position of Director of the Department of ENT Surgery at Montefiore Hospital, at the West Campus of Albert Einstein. There she became Professor of ENT and Associate Professor of Pediatrics. Dr. Rozycki pioneered a number of surgical techniques, including treatment for sleep apnea, and collaborative work with the Department of Neurosurgery in surgical treatment of Pituitary Gland Disease. She retired in 1993. Two things meant more to Dr. Rozycki than anything else -- the welfare of her patients and the welfare of her family. Dr. Rozycki is survived by her husband, Dr. Ludwik Rozycki of Hartsdale and Rancho Mirage, California, her daughters, Sarit Rozycki (Robert Cromwell) and Avital Soldatenko (Gregory), both of Scarsdale, her sister, Helen Eichenwald, of Basel, Switzerland, her brother, Moshe Brat, of Tel Aviv, Israel, and three grandchildren. Her body was interred in Israel, where the family sat Shiva. A public memorial service will be held at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale on September 10, 2013 at 10am. Memorial contributions may be sent to American Friends of Magen David Adom.

ROSE--Robert Hoggan, surrounded by friends and family, died August 28, 2013 from complications related to the treatment for a rare T-cell lymphoma, which he confronted with courage and dignity. Bob was born February 24, 1946, to Frederick E. Rose and Leah Hoggan Rose in Salt Lake City, Utah. He obtained a Bachelors of Science from the University of Utah in 1971. He was an active member and alumnus of Kappa Sigma, Delta-Sigma Chapter. After graduating college, Bob entered the financial services industry, where he worked for 45 years, spending the last 39 years at Morgan Stanley and its predecessor firms, including Dean Witter Reynolds. He was a member of the Chairman's Club for 23 consecutive years and cultivated deep and long-lasting relationships throughout every level of the firm. He was the consummate professional and a willing mentor to so many throughout his career. As Bob's long-time friend and colleague, Phillip J. Purcell, former Chairman and CEO of Morgan Stanley stated, "Bob was one of the most talented and admired financial advisors in the industry. He was respected and beloved by his clients and colleagues." Bob took great pleasure in his work and happily spent his last day alive at his office. In addition to his professional achievements, Bob was an active and generous member of the community. He served on the National Advisory Councils of the University of Utah and David Eccles School of Business and Boards of Directors for Ballet West, The Children's Center, Holy Cross Hospital (Chair), the Morgan Stanley PAC, Museum of Fine Arts, Prevent Blindness of Utah (Chair), Red Butte Garden (Chair), Ronald McDonald House Charities, Salt Lake Acting Company, Salt Lake Honorary Colonels, Utah Symphony, and University of Utah President's Club (Chair). He was a member of the Alta Club and Salt Lake Country Club. He was also a long-time friend and supporter of the Crimson Club Scholarship Program. Another close and long-time friend, Dr. Chris Hill, Athletic Director of the University of Utah said of Bob, "His passion for the University was made clear by his genuine and energetic involvement in so many aspects of the institution he loved. The University is a better place because of Bob." Bob was a loyal friend, sage counselor, and gracious gentleman. He was an engaging, witty, and well-dressed socialite with an uncanny ability to recall names and facts, recount entertaining anecdotes, and offer insightful analyses on a wide range of subjects. As such, he was often the life of any event he attended. He loved good dinners with good friends. Bob was a passionate skier and, on winter weekends, could almost always be found catching the first chairlift at Deer Valley (where he maintained a perfect season-pass record) and, apres ski, holding court at Stein Eriksen Lodge. He also enjoyed golfing with his friends and picked the perfect moment for his first (and only) hole-in-one The Bear's Club in Jupiter, Florida. His early and continuing love of cars (Porsches, in particular) is legendary. He lived life with no regrets. Bob was preceded in death by his parents and his sister, Julianne, who died at birth. He is survived by his brother, Rick (Linda) Rose; his nieces, Allyson (Daron) Cameron and Meredith (Scott) Palfreyman; his grandnieces and grandnephews, Ben, Nick, and Hannah Cameron and Sam and Jack Palfreyman, whom Bob treated as his own children; his "stepson," Christopher M. (Alexandra) Von Maack; his grandchildren, Charles Robert and Juliet Lee Von Maack; and his dear friends, who are too numerous to name here. Bob's friends and family thank the many experienced, diligent, and caring medical professionals at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, Huntsman Cancer Institute, LDS Hospital, Mayo Clinic, Utah Cancer Specialists, and University of Utah who counseled and treated Bob. A celebration of Bob's life will be held September 6, 2013, beginning at 4:00pm, at the Rose Garden at Red Butte Garden in Salt Lake. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution in Bob's name to the American Cancer Society's Salt Lake Hope Lodge Capital Campaign, 941 E. 3300 S. #

ROAMAN--Eileen. The employees and partners at Adams & Co Real Estate note with sadness the passing of our investor and friend, Eileen Roaman. She was a lovely, warm, and vibrant woman, who handled all of the troubles that life threw at her the last few years with dignity and strength. May her memory be a blessing.

ROAMAN--Eileen. Susan L. Solomon and The New York Stem Cell Foundation extend deepest condolences to our long time friend Carol Roaman and her family on the loss of Eileen Roaman, her beloved daughter. We send our sincere sympathies to Carol and her entire family on their tragic loss.
ROAMAN--Eileen. Carol - my thoughts are with you always. Brian

RASMUSSEN--Waldo. The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art is deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Waldo Rasmussen, the former longtime Director of The Museum of Modern Art's International Program, on August 15 after a long illness. Waldo was an unflagging ambassador for the Museum, passionate about sharing its treasures with a large international public. His legacy will be warmly remembered by Council members and professional colleagues at MoMA and throughout the world. Waldo was predeceased by his beloved daughter Lisa. He is survived by his life companion and spouse John Dowling, his son M.D. Rasmussen, and three grandchildren. His previous marriage to Geraldine Rasmussen ended in divorce. Agnes Gund, Chairman Sharon Percy Rockefeller, President Joann K. Phillips, Jeanne C. Thayer, Jo Carole Lauder, Presidents Emeritae The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

RAPPE--Lillian Moira, 90, a Writer Who Fought For NYC Dog Laws, passed away August 27 in Succasunna, NJ. Services: September 3 from 4pm to 9pm at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. (21st St), NYC 10010. Mass: September 4, at 10am Our Lady of Good Counsel, 230 E 90th St., NYC, 10128. Burial: Calverton National Cemetery.

PRAY--Malcolm Sheldon Jr.,of Greenwich, Connecticut, passed away August 25, 2013 after complications following a stroke. Born in New York City, he was the son of Malcolm Sheldon Pray, Sr. and Frances Parker Pray and brother of Sandra Pray Culbert. The Pray family moved to Greenwich in 1939 where Malcolm lived for the remainder of his life. Malcolm was a graduate of Brunswick School and the University of Virginia. Malcolm owned the largest complex of automobile dealerships in the Town of Greenwich, which he built from 1955 until 1999. He was devoted to his employees and customers, and his concentration on customer service earned the Pray Automobile Corporation organization a national reputation for excellence of which he was very proud. In 1999, he sold his business so he could create the Pray Achievement Center where he has inspired many young people to make goals and reach for them. He used his extensive collection of exotic vintage cars to incentivize young people with a desire to be successful. Since it opened in 2001, over eight thousand visitors have heard Mr. Pray's message of encouragement and learned the steps necessary to be successful in the world of business today. Malcolm has received many youth organization, civic and charitable awards for his continued efforts with local charities throughout his lifetime. The Greenwich Boy Scouts, Boys and Girls Club, Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich, Greenwich Red Cross, USO of Metropolitan New York, and the Greenwich Chamber of Commerce are among the recipients of his energy and contributions. For over forty years he worked enthusiastically with local and national Republican Party candidates and was awarded the Prescott Bush Award from the Connecticut Republicans in 1998. He was a proud American and a true patriot. He chaired two National Dealer Councils (Volkswagen and Porsche-Audi) in addition to an automobile trade association of imported car dealers in the United States, the Connecticut Volkswagen Dealers and Connecticut Automotive Trades Association. He is survived by his wife, Natalie, daughters Sabrina Forsythe and her daughters, Courtney and Nicole Fischer, Melanie (Lilly) Pray and her daughter Portia Pray of Boulder, Colorado, Justina Pray and her daughter Natasha and son Parker Grayson, and Malcolm's sister Sandra Pray Culbert. Malcolm was pre-deceased by his son, Malcolm Sheldon Pray, III who died in 1986. Malcolm's wish was that his greatest legacy would be the Pray Achievement Center, in Banksville, New York, and he made plans to endow the Center for the future. In lieu of flowers, we ask that contributions be made to the Pray Family Foundation, which will operate the Achievement Center, so that we may continue the Malcolm Pray mission of inspiring young minds. There will be a Memorial Service on Saturday, September 21st at 11am at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, followed by a reception to celebrate Malcolm's life.
NOVEMBERBarbara L.,on August 26. Services will be held Sunday September 8th at 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

NAWY--Victoria, nee Rashti, passed away peacefully at her home in Forest Hills, NY on August 20, 2013 at the age of 104. She joins her husband Carl, and son Harold. She is survived by her children, Joe and Joyce; grandchildren Scott A, Jesse, Jena, Scott G, and Marc; 8 great-grandchildren, and many adoring nephews and nieces. Vicky was an inspiration, always inquisitive and youthful, and she lit up our lives with her smile, wit, and grace. Mom, Our Hearts are Full of Your Love, and Your Light.
MOLLICA--Ann. August 11, 1930, died August 24, 2013. She was the beloved wife of Frank and mother to Georgina. Viewing, Tues, Ballard-Durand in White Plains Services, 10am Wed at I.H.M.

MITCHELL--Sally Justine, of Beaufort, SC passed August 25th. She was born July 2, 1929 in New York City, daughter of Henry Coggeshall Howells and Lilly Ward Ruperti. Sally graduated from the Chapin School then Bryn Mawr College in 1951. She married the late S. Alexander Mitchell in 1965 and resided in Locust Valley, NY later moving to South Carolina. Mrs. Mitchell was the original owner of Loafers Bakery in Locust Valley, NY. She will be remembered for her generosity of heart, sharing of knowledge and especially feisty spirit. She is survived by her nieces and nephews Henry Howells IV, Kathryn Howells M.D., Julie Avelon, William Howells, five step children, Stephen, Diana, Jennifer, Robert, and Laura Mitchell, 12 great nieces and nephews, and eight step grandchildren.

MELNIK--Bertha, died on August 25, 2013. Faculty Emeritus-Music, The Juilliard. Born May 11, 1914 in Hartford, CT to Eli and Ruth (Dosowitz) Melnik. Studied piano with Alexander Siloti (a renowned student of Franz Liszt) and with Robert Casadesus at Fontainebleau, France. Juilliard Graduate 1939 PNO. BA from Fordham University, 1972. A member of the Philharmonic Piano Quartet. Recorded on Columbia Records. Conductor/pianist for the original New York Production of "Jacques Brel ..." Rehearsal pianist and assistant conductor at New York City Opera. Accompanied many solo artists including Flamenco dancer Jose Greco, cellist Bernard Greenhouse and violinist Dorothy Minty. Taught piano at both the Juilliard and Manhattan Schools of Music. Member of the Juilliard Opera Training Dept. 1958-2008. Former students include Ms. Renee Fleming, Ms. Audra McDonald, Mr. John Aler, Ms. Faith Esham and Sir Willard White. Gifts in Bertha's memory may be made to: The Juilliard School, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY 10023; or visit: www.Juilliard.edu/giving.

MacWHORTER--R. Bruce 83, slipped peacefully into another world on August 26, 2013, surrounded by his family. Born in Philadelphia, PA, Bruce grew up in Washington, DC. He received his BA degree in American History from Oberlin College in Ohio, and his J.D. degree from the University of Virginia Law School. Bruce joined the New York law firm of Shearman and Sterling in 1956, was elected to the partnership of the firm in 1965, and retired after 35 years of distinguished service. He was the leader of the firm's first antitrust stand-alone practice group for 20 years, during which time the group earned a reputation as one of the most respected antitrust practices in the United States. Bruce was a long time resident of Maplewood, NJ where he and his loving wife raised their family of three daughters and multiple golden retrievers. Bruce and his wife moved to WindsorMeade in Williamsburg, VA in 2007. Bruce was preceded in death by his father and mother George Merritt and Marion Ritchie MacWhorter, and his brother George M. Mac-Whorter. Bruce is lovingly remembered by his wife Althea Davis MacWhorter, his daughters Susan, Nancy and Marjorie, sons-in-law Steve, Eric and Carl, and six grandchildren, Julian, Duncan, Drew, Will, Grayson and Elizabeth. He is remembered for his modest disposition, his sense of humor in stressful times, and as a gentleman lawyer of Wall Street. Most of all he is remembered as a loving and loyal husband and father, and the best granddaddy a grandchild could have. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to Saint Jude's Children's Research Hospital, Smile Train, or a charity of choice.

LOVEJOY--Paul Robert, 58, of Wakefield, Rhode Island and Chicago died suddenly on August 26th after a brief illness. A lawyer, most recently with Kirkland & Ellis and previously as General Counsel of United Airlines, Paul relished the practice of corporate law. His long, distinguished career included partnerships with the firms Squire, Sanders and Weil, Gotshal and Manges, and nine years as Assistant General Counsel of Texaco. Paul served many non-profits as a board member and volunteer, including his college, New England College, where he graduated summa cum laude in 1977, and his law school, Case Western Reserve University, where he earned the distinction of Order of the Coif and served as an editor of the law review. He is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Susan Seyfarth Lovejoy, his daughter, Kate Lovejoy Anderson (Peter), two sisters, Maryann Lovejoy Alfano, and Linda Lovejoy Jukes and seven nieces and nephews. Paul was predeceased by his parents, Jean and V. Paul Lovejoy of Mentor, Ohio. A private celebration of Paul's life will be held over the weekend. Donations in his name can be made to South Kingstown Land Trust, Wakefield, RI.

LEE--May "Peter" Foote (nee Strangfeld), of Manchester, VT, formerly of Englewood NJ, Cornwall, CT and Dorset VT, died on August 19, 2013 in Bennington VT. She was in succession the wife and subsequent widow of Charles C. Foote, MD, of New York City, Earl G. Holmes, and James W. Lee. She is survived by daughters Katharine (C. Brown) Lingamfelter of Stuart, FL, Janet Stones of Bethel, CT, and Cynthia Foote (Ward Hinkle) of Orchard Park, NY, eight grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, and one brother, John (Jane) Strangfeld of Chatham, NJ. See notice at Legacy.com.

LAWSON--Trina Richner. In loving memory of Trina who passed away on August 27, 2013 after a three year battle with cancer. She was born in 1944 to George and Bee (Young) Richner in Baltimore, Maryland. During her childhood she moved 17 times with her parents settling in Richmond, VA for her longest stay and attended Thomas Jefferson High School. She went to Vassar College and graduated cum laude majoring in History. Upon graduation Trina moved to New York City and started the first of her three careers at Young & Rubicam Advertising firm. She changed to BBD&O where she was Director of Corporate Communications. She moved to Ready Communications and ended her advertising career at Ebasco Services. She then switched to executive recruiting and worked at Search Associates with her father, the owner. For twelve years they worked together finding recruits for executive positions until George's retirement when they closed the firm. Trina was not happy in retirement so, on a lark, she responded to an advertisement for holiday sales help at Tiffany & Company where she spent two exciting months. Management asked her to stay on with the Schlumberger Collection, a position she gladly accepted, soon becoming the manager. Eight years later Trina was offered a buy-out package and started her second retirement. Ninety days later, Tiffany asked her to come back part time to work as a Client Development Professional where she worked until very recently. Trina leaves her husband, Ted, whom she married in 1974 after a whirlwind five week courtship. Trina and Ted were always inseparable and a perfect match for each other. Trina was a member of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church for over 40 years where she was married to Ted Lawson and was active and an officer. In recent years she and Ted changed to the Marble Collegiate Church. Trina always was a snappy dresser and her interests were people, politics, the arts and traveling. She was a people person and always at her best when interacting with others. Trina will be sorely missed by all those who had the pleasure of her acquaintance. She is survived by her husband, Ted, a sister-in-law, a number of cousins, and a niece and nephew. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Vassar College would be most appreciated. A celebration of her life will be held at the Marble Collegiate Church located at One West 29th Street (Fifth Avenue) on Sunday, September 29 at 2:30pm.

KRUBINER--Marilyn Judith, 86. Beloved wife for 69 years of Sheldon, who passed away in June. Devoted mother of Patrice, Michael (Casey), and Jane (Michael), grandmother and great-grandmother. Born in the Bronx- lead a charmed life of NYC culture surrounded by an extended loving family, both of which sustained her throughout her lifetime. After raising her children, she worked in fashion design, was a lifelong member of NCJW, an avid reader, enjoyed travel, film, boating, and summer days at the beach with grandchildren. We will forever cherish the memory of her beauty, spirit, strength, and endless devotion to her children.

KARELSEN--Frank E. III (born February 24, 1927 - died August 27, 2013) was a fourth generation New Yorker who graduated from The Ethical Culture and Fieldston School, Columbia University and Yale Law School. A retired senior partner of the law firm of Kurzman, Karelsen and Frank, he was a beloved and devoted husband of Ursula Steiner Karelsen-who died in 2007-father, grandfather, uncle, and friend. He adored the law, Sinatra, Ellington, Armstrong, Durante, "Singin' in the Rain", baseball, politics, the theater and chocolate milkshakes. He is survived by his son Franklin, his two daughters, Juliet and Eva, and his five grandchildren. Contributions in his memory should be made to the Ramapo Anchorage Camp for Children or the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, organizations to which he dedicated his energies and care.

JONAS--Manfred. April 9, 1927-August 25, 2013. The John Bigelo Professor of History Emeritus at Union College, Schenectady, NY specializing in US diplomatic and 20th century political history; also of Laguna Woods, CA. Loved and loving husband to Nancy (Greene) for 61 years. Devoted father to Andrew, Katie, Emily and Matthew, and grandfather of eight. "Our love goes with you as your love stays with us."

HAUPTFUHRER--Robert P. Robert P. Hauptfuhrer, 81, beloved husband of Barbara, and father of Brenda Helber of Devon, PA, Bruce of Wayne, PA and Bryan (Linda) of Radnor, PA and grandchildren Andrew, Nicholas and Kristin Helber, and Amanda Hauptfuhrer, died on the 11th of August at Bryn Mawr Hospital, Bryn Mawr, PA from complications of a subdural hematoma. Born on December 31st, l931, Bob graduated from The William Penn Charter School, as valedictorian, in 1949 and in 1988 was honored with the Alumni Award of Merit. He and his brother George established a Hauptfuhrer Scholars' Fund which brought a young Palestinian student to PC for a year to foster interfaith and intercultural understanding. Bob matriculated at Princeton University where he was in Naval ROTC. He received his degree summa cum laude in Public Affairs from The Woodrow Wilson School in 1953 and subsequently established a research thesis scholarship in the Woodrow Wilson School. He was also elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Bob graduated from Naval Officer's Candidate School in Bayonne, New Jersey and then was commissioned in the U.S. Navy; serving as a Supply Officer on the SS Henrico, an attack transport in the western Pacific. Immediately after serving for two years, he went on to Harvard Business School where he graduated with Distinction, and as a Baker Scholar in 1957. In 1963, he married Barbara Ellen Dunlop. Bob joined Sun Oil Company in the summer of 1957, commencing a long career there progressing thru various managerial positions, culminating in his election as President, Chief Operating Officer and Director in January 1987. In November 1988, Sun split the enterprise into two separate companies. Bob was elected the first Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Sun Exploration and Production Company based in Dallas, Texas - later renamed Oryx Energy Company. He retired in 1994. Mr. Hauptfuhrer was active in industry affairs as a Director of The National Association of Manufacturers, a Director of both The American Petroleum Institute and The Independent Petroleum Association of America, and as Chairman of The Natural Gas Supply Association. He served on the corporate boards of Quaker Chemical Corporation, Totem Resources Corporation, Additech, Inc., and Puralube, Inc., and as an independent trustee of 1838 Investment Advisors Funds. In addition to his corporate career, Bob's life was enriched by serving the community in which he lived. While in Dallas, Bob was a board member of the Dallas Citizens Council, The Dallas Symphony Association, The Greater Dallas United Way and The North Texas Educational Television Corporation. Bob was also heavily involved in the civic life of Philadelphia and its suburbs. At various times, he served as a Trustee of The Lankenau Hospital, and The Curtis Institute of Music. He was on the board of The Camp Branch of the YMCA, The Executive Service Corps of the Delaware Valley, The Free Library of Philadelphia Foundation, and The Barra Foundation. He was chair of The Baldwin School Board, Vice-chair of The Trustees of the First Presbyterian Church of Ardmore, and Chair of The University of Pennsylvania Cancer Center Board of Advisors. For a number of years, he co-chaired The Individual Gifts Committee of the Southeastern Pennsylvania United Way with his wife, Barbara. He served his Princeton alma mater as Class Treasurer and Class President, a governor of The Princeton Club of Philadelphia, and as a Charter Trustee of The University, finishing his term as Vice Chair of the Executive Committee. He also served as President of The Harvard Business School Club of Philadelphia. Bob was a member of The Merion Cricket Club, The Philadelphia Country Club and The Johns Island Club in Vero Beach, Florida and previously The Racauet Club, Pine Valley Golf Club, The Union League of Philadelphia and The Skytop Club. At John's Island, he served at one time as vice president of the John's Island Foundation, was on the Forum Committee and was a member of the Johns Island Singers. Bob enjoyed traveling and took his family to many interesting places, often to ski both in the USA and abroad. Sports were a big part of his life football and basketball in high school and college, as well as squash, paddle and golf in later years. Over the years, Bob and Barbara enjoyed catching up with friends from Penn Charter, Princeton and Harvard Business School at major and mini reunions. Recently, Bob celebrated two major milestones; his 50th wedding anniversary in May, and in June, his 60th reunion at Princeton. A Celebration of Life will be held at The Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, 625 Montgomery Avenue, Bryn Mawr, PA, on September 7th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, you may make a contribution to Princeton University, Robert Hauptfuhrer '53 Memorial Fund, Princeton University; Alumni and Donor Records, Attn: Helen Hardy P.O. Box 5357 Princeton, NJ 08540; The Heart Center at Lankenau Hospital, 100 East Lancaster Avenue, Wynnewood, PA., 19096; Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, 625 Montgomery Avenue, Bryn Mawr, PA, 19010; The William Penn Charter School, 300 School House Lane, Philadelphia, PA, 19144 or a charity of your choice.

Son, Jeffrey (Sandra), daughters Randy (Phil), Jinny (Glenn), grandchildren Rachel, Jaime, Lee. Sister Shirley. WWII Navy Radioman. BS/MBA NYU. GRAY--Diane Regina, born April 20, 1946 died peacefully in her sleep on August 25, 2013. Mass at Mary Manning Walsh Home, September 5th at 11am.

GOLDSTEIN--Donald E.,PhD, died August 26, 2013. Adored husband of Arline, cherished father of Lorry (Fred), the late Randy, Robyn (Christian) and son Jody. Loving brother of Linda and the late Robert. Admired educator and business entrepreneur.

GANELES--Joyce K.,Plainview, NY and Delray Beach, FL August 28. Wife of Ron for 58 years, mother of Jeff (Lori Berman) and Eric (Marla Platt) and grandmother of four. Bright and beautiful, she will be missed by family and friends.

FOLLERT--Robert Philip, passed away Saturday, August 24. He was born in Collinsville, CT, where forests and rivers sparked a lifelong passion for fly fishing and shooting. Bob attended Loomis and Yale. He built a successful career in investment marketing that spanned six decades. He was a member of The Leash (where he served on the Board of Governors), The Long Island Wyandanch Club and Squadron A. Bob is survived by wife Patricia, sons Robert Jeffrey (Karen), Howard Vincent II (Frances) and five grandchildren. Bob will be remembered for the twinkle in his eye, his jokes and shaggy dog stories, his madras jackets and his gentlemanly grace on and off stream. Funeral services are private. Donations in Bob's honor can be made to the John Theurer Cancer Center, 92 Second Street, Hackensack, NJ 07601; Keen Company, 520 8th Avenue, Suite 328, New York, NY 10018; or The Leash, 41 East 63rd Street, New York, NY 10065.

FLAKS--Stephen R. During the 1970s, on the nightly news in New York City, an elderly African-American grandmother spoke through tears about her lack of money to pay her bills, such as rent, heating and other apartment fees. If she could not pay her bills, then she would probably die on the streets with her personal effects because her distant family did not have enough money to help her. A couple of hours later a mysterious venture capitalist drove up to the grandmother's small apartment in Harlem and handed her a check. He did this anonymously. This anonymous charitable donor had the name of Steve Flaks. He was a venture capitalist, family man, arts patron, world traveler, philanthropist, and cinema producer. He carved out his own American Dream, while always holding on to his integrity. Stephen Robert Flaks, Venture Capitalist and Renaissance man, age 72, resident of Scottsdale, AZ, died peacefully on August 30th at the Mayo Clinic in Phoenix. Steve, one of three children, was born in New York City, on January 1, 1941. He grew up in the shadows of Yankee Stadium in the Bronx. But like his dad Jack before him, he was a New York Giants baseball team supporter when they still played at the Polo Grounds. Steve Flaks was an outstanding student, graduating with a B.A. from CCNY Baruch College in 1961. Harvard offered him a scholarship to its Business School, but Steve decided to work for Dreyfus Investments. He then began his ascent on Wall Street, even setting up his own successful brokerage firm. He later managed a successful private biotech hedge fund and fulfilled his film production aspirations, producing two films. While earning profits on his stock holdings, his favorite beneficiaries represented educational access, women's rights, animal rights and the environment. He especially supported arts organizations and fine arts in the Scottsdale region. His activities did not however end with philanthropy. Always fascinated by history and culture, Steve and his wife Beverly visited many of the world's continents. They toured on African safaris, trekked through China and India, and travelled by boat through the Amazon in Brazil. He was also a passionate New York Giants football fan, attending two of their recent Super Bowls. Most importantly, Steve Flaks was a dedicated family man. He was very happily married to his wife Beverly for 46 years. They birthed two sons, James and David, and they have two beloved dogs, Luni and Luna. Two sisters, Betty and Vicki, and daughter-in-law Jen, married to David, survive him. His family plans to continue his philanthropic work, carrying on his vision to help the less fortunate.

FLAKS--Felice. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of Mrs. Felice Flaks, the beloved wife of the late Julius Zizmor and her second husband, the late Norbert Flaks. She was the cherished mother of Dr. Jonathan Zizmor, an alumnus of the Marsha Stern Yeshiva University High School for Boys and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, who with his wife, Alexandra, is a Yeshiva University Benefactor, and he serves on the Yeshiva College Board of Overseers. Mrs. Felice Zizmor was a revered active member of the Jewish Center in NYC. She was a writer, publisher of the Judaica Art Journal and a lecturer at the Isabel Friedman Camp. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Dr. Jonathan Zizmor, her grandchildren: Jordana Zizmor, Geraldine Mittler and Adam Zizmor, and to her great-grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

FIXELL--Lester, 94, of East Meadow, NY on Thursday, August 29. Beloved husband of Audrey, father of Douglas (Maria) Fixell, Daniel (Robin) Fixell, Ginny (Gary) Penzell and Andrea (Hector) Fixell Ramos. Adoring grandfather of Ethan, Joshua, Andrew, Alexandra, Jacob, Sam and Matteo. Services Sunday, September 1 at 3pm, Gutterman's, Woodbury, LI.

FINKELSTEIN--Nina, died peacefully in her sleep on August 26th at the age of 86 in New York, her beloved city. Nina was the dearly beloved wife of the late Bill Finkelstein. She was the beloved mother of Jane Finkelstein of Rhode island and Emily Kravinsky of Philadelphia, the dearly loved grandmother of Josh, Sarah, Lev and Eli, the beloved sister of Michael Sachs and the late David Sachs. Nina was deeply loved by numerous friends, cousins, nieces and nephews to whom she was endlessly loyal and supportive. Nina was born in Cleveland, Ohio in 1927 as Nina Rose Sachs, daughter of Alfred Henry (Alter Chaim) and Estelle Dolcort Sachs. Nina moved with her family to New York at age 20 after attending college at Case Western Reserve. She completed her bachelor's degree in New York. In college, she was the National Secretary of the Intercollegiate Zionist Federation of America. In 1953, Nina married the great love and best friend of her life, Bill Finkelstein. Bill died tragically in 1991 of ALS. No relationship could have combined enduring love and friendship more powerfully than Nina and Bill's marriage. Nina worked in several publishing houses as an editor including Dell, Fawcett and Bantam. She was the executive director of World Monuments Fund. She became one of the founding editors of Ms. Magazine in 1971 and was deeply invested in the feminist movement. Following her retirement in 1988, Nina became involved in a myriad of volunteer activities including reading to the blind, teaching English as a second language, GED mentorship for disadvantaged young women and tutoring special needs children in inner city schools. In all of her volunteer jobs, Nina formed deep and personal connections with the people she worked with that always had a quality of deep respect and reciprocity. Nina was deeply committed to a sense of justice and was always there to advocate for people. As an example, she arranged a rent strike in our building in the early 70's and was the first parent to stand up to her children's school in a successful effort to sanction an abusive teacher and to have her removed. She took action. She was fiercely protective. Always attuned to the needs of others, she brought home books for years for her husband and children that perfectly matched their interests of the time. Wonderful books seemed to emerge magically and ceaselessly from her black work bag. Nina was deeply committed to her family and friends. She had a passion for travel. She and her beloved husband Bill spent 25 consecutive summers in Venice at the Pensione Seguso and later traveled to India and many other European and Asian countries. Nina had boundless intellectual curiosity and adored reading. She was always immersed in a book and frequently consulted with her friend Chris Lenahan, the manager of the Corner Bookstore, about contemporary literature. Nina was passionate about New York and also deeply loved the small seaside town of PointLookout where she and our family spent many blissfully happy summers. In latter years, she became increasingly disabled by arthritis and poor mobility following a stroke. In spite of her pain and ongoing, profound grief for her late husband, Bill, she persevered with remarkably heroic courage, taking classes at Hunter College and traveling until she was no longer able to continue due to poor mobility. She read endlessly and saw numerous movies, plays, opera and ballet. She was an avid and highly skilled bridge player, winning a number of tournaments which she was always quite modest about. During her last hospitalization following a fall, her friends organized a bridge game in a hall at Mt. Sinai. In her last weeks, she had a characteristically warm and enlivening dinner party at her home with several beloved friends. Nina deeply loved and always felt a great interest in her four grandchildren. When she was unable to continue to travel to Philadelphia to visit them, she maintained contact by telephone. When the children were young, she arranged memorable vacations for them and also always strove to find them toys and books that she knew they loved just as she had done for her children. Nina was overcome with happiness to be able to participate in the Bar Mitzvah of her youngest grandchild, Eli, this past December. Nina will always be remembered by those who knew her best for a spirit of commitment to the people she loved and to the causes she felt deeply about. She had more earnestness and courage than anyone I have ever known. She was always there to provide support and was very quiet about her own struggles and pain. We will love her and yearn for her forever and feel endlessly grateful for her unfailing, quiet generosity, loyalty and presence. If only there were more time to give back more in return.

FEINSTEIN--Leona. My mother, best friend and inspiration. Mama, everything I am comes from your love and strength. Dmmhhpp3, that's you, me and Blakie. Forever and ever embedded in my heart and soul. Mom, you were "my Lil" and I was "your Becky."

FEINSTEIN--Leona, 84, died July 12, 2013. Beloved wife to Zach (dancing together right now in heaven). Adored mother of Rande and Steven. Mother-in-law to Jill. Nana Lee to Michael, Sammy, Blakie, Charlotte, Zachary and William. A woman who had so much life and energy and a cup way past half full. Donations for "IPF" 212-731-7427.

DIOTALLEVI--Filippo, passed away at the age of 80, on August 22, 2013, and was laid to rest on August 23, 2013, in his beloved birthplace Cartoceto, Italy. Filippo was a Korean War Veteran and after the War went to work for the Wildenstein & Co. Art Gallery in Manhattan, NY. Surrounded by the art he admired, his work became his passion. Filippo went on to become the Vice President of Sales until he retired in 2005. He is survived by his wife, Adriena, his daughters Simonetta, Rita, Francesca, and his grandchildren Philip and Elena Lund.

DELHAISE--Michel G.,age 58, originally of Belguim, died at his home in Ct of cancer. He was co-owner of Jordan Delhaise Gallery. Michel is survived by two brothers and several nieces and nephews in Brussels, and by his partner of 30 years in the US, George E. Jordan. He will be best remembered for his warmth, compassion, thoughtfulness and generosity. Interment will be private.

DAYTON--Mary Lee Lowe, Community leader, philanthropist, and supporter of women's issues, died peacefully at her home in Wayzata, MN on August 21, 2013. She was predeceased by her husband of fifty-four years, Wallace C. Dayton, who died in 2002. Born in Marshall, Missouri, on May 12, 1925, she was the daughter of Braddie Douglass Lowe and the Reverend Arnold Hilmar Lowe. She attended John Borroughs School in St. Louis, and graduated from Northrop Collegiate School in Minneapolis in 1943 and from Vassar College in 1946. Always active in community affairs, she held leadership positions in many organizations in the Twin Cities and elsewhere. She served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Macalester College, The Minneapolis Foundation, The Minneapolis YWCA, and Planned Parenthood of Minnesota, and was a founder of the Minnesota Women's Fund, now the Women's Foundation of Minnesota. She also served as a Board member of the Breck School, the Mississippi River Fund, the Ripley Memorial Foundation, the Sister Kenny Foundation, the Greater Twin Cities United Way, the University of Minnesota Arboretum Foundation, Vassar College, Westminster Presbyterian Church, and other organizations. In addition, after her husband's death, she remained committed to the environmental organizations that he had led and supported, including The Nature Conservancy and the National Audubon Society, and others. She is survived by her four daughters, Sally D. Clement (Stephen) of New York City, Katherine D. Nielsen (Stuart) and Ellen D. Grace, both of Minneapolis, and Elizabeth D. Dovydenas (Jonas) of Lenox, MA, and nine grandchildren: Theodore and Winston Clement; John and Elena Dovydenas; Olivia Nielsen; Samuel Richardson; and Matthew, Katherine, and Rosamond Sturgis. The family wishes to thank Becky Frederick and her staff for their caring service. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in her name to any of the above organizations, or the charity of the donor's choice. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 7 at 3 pm at Westminster Presbyterian Church, 1200 Marquette Avenue South, Minneapolis.

DANZIG--Myrna, born May 14, 1935, died peacefully in her home on August 22, 2013 surrounded by loving family and friends. Mother of Gabriel, Henry and Nachum. Sister of Harland and Barbara. Loving grandmother of 13. Proud feminist, Buddhist, Professor Emeritus Montclair State. Opera, film and book lover. She loved to laugh. We will miss her dearly. Memorial service at SGI NY Culture Center, 7 E. 15th St. on Saturday, September 14 at 4pm.

CASSIDY--Martin Joseph. Stage and film actor, Los Angeles, August 26, age 75. A Manhattan Yorkville native, moving to Los Angeles diversified his stage career to many TV and feature film roles. Survived by wife, Alice.

BROWN--Abraham. Beloved husband of the late Yetta Brown, father of Marsha Brown and the late Stanley Brown, uncle and great- uncle to numerous nieces, nephews and grandnieces and -nephews, died peacefully on Wednesday, August 28, 2013, at the age of 92 from Alzheimer's disease. Abe fought in the 106th Division in the army during WWII, rising to the rank of staff sergeant. After the war, he became an upholsterer, and attended City College for nine years at night for his BA, which he completed Cum Laude. He continued in graduate school for another five years, completing his MA in 1960. He became an inspired, inspiring and beloved teacher, who touched the lives of hundreds of students. He left teaching to become the manager of Rochdale Village, rising to the challenges of what was then the largest non-profit housing development in the world. He went on to become the manager of the Rochdale Center of the then Jamaica Medical Group. To do a more professional job, he went back to graduate school, and in 1976, was awarded a second Master's Degree, in Public Administration, in the field of Health Planning, Policy and Administration. He continued advancing in his career, becoming the administrator of the Jamaica Medical Group, then overseeing the merger of three groups into the LaGuardia Medical Group, of which he was the top administrator until his retirement in 1991. The funeral was held on Friday, August 30, 2013. Shiva will be at home: 68-24 Utopia Pkwy., Fresh Meadows, Queens, (718) 463-5164, until Wednesday, September 4th.
BRIMBERG--Arthur, MD,Partners in the practice of Radiology and in life. Our thoughts are with Marilyn, Julie and Davis and their families. Lois and Steve Robinson

BRADY--Charles. Germany's last news correspondent, Charles "Chuck" Brady, died August 12, 2013 in Fort Walton Beach, FL. Born December, 1928 in Sioux City, IA, schooled in both Iowa and Germany. His two great loves were Berlin and writing. The reunification of Germany reduced the original eighteen foreign correspondents and by 1990 Brady was the only one left. He had two books published but felt his most important and lasting writings delt with the Germans that protected the Jews from the Nazi's during WWII.

BEAL--Jack, a leader of the New York Realist movement, died peacefully August 29, 2013 in Oneonta, NY. He is survived by his wife, artist Sondra Freckelton. We who loved him, will miss his wit, intelligence, generosity and larger-than-life persona. Here's to you, Jack. Love from your friends.

BALCOM--Lucille Parsons, 100, of Palm Beach, FL, widow of Ronald Bush Balcom passed away August 29th at her home in Fishers Island, NY. She was born on November 1, 1912 in Montclair, NJ. "Lulu" was the daughter of Jay Lester Parson and Lucille Myers Parsons. She grew up in Orange, NJ and attended Miss Porters School in Farmington, CT. She was married to and divorced from George Vanderbilt. During WWII she did volunteer work with the American Red Cross. In 1950, she and Ronnie Balcom were married in Palm Beach, FL at her home. She was an exceptional golfer and at the age of 16 hit her 1st of "10 holes in one". She was also an excellent skier and she and Ronnie spent much of their time skiing in Vail, CO and Klosters, Switzerland. Her greatest love in life was traveling and there were few places in the world she had not been. Lulu was an extremely talented artist and was well known for her unique, primitive paintings. Most of her original 3-dimensional paintings depict scenes from the Caribbean and New England. She was predeceased by her beloved husband of 44 years and her brother Jay Lester Parsons, Jr. She is survived by her daughter Lucille V. Pate, two grandsons, Phillip V. Brady and Robert M. Balding, and granddaughter Dawn B. Pate. She is also survived by four great-granddaughters Allston Pate, Emerson Pate, Margaret Balding and Sara Balding, all of Georgetown, SC. In addition, she is survived by her sister Emily Parsons Ridgway of Short Hills, NJ and a step-sister Mrs. Horace Bailey. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you donate to the Island Health Project, PO Box 344, Fishers Island, NY 06390.

ASHE--James J. Jr.,1931-2013 of Greenwich, CT, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his family. Jim was formerly from Garden City, NY and Savannah, GA. He leaves his beloved wife, Dorothy, of 54 years, his adored son, Richard and wife, Maria, along with his daughter, Marybeth and husband, Peter Wise. He was the proud grandfather of Amanda, Peter, Darby, Whitney and Phoebe. Jim was a long-time member of the Cherry Valley Club in Garden City, NY and a board member of the Landings Club in Savannah, GA. Jim was a graduate of Bishop Loughlin High School, Queens College and received his MBA from NYU. He retired in 1985 from U.S. News and World Report as Vice President of Marketing. A private Memorial Service will be held at a later date to honor James. To leave an online condolence please visit: (leopgallaghergreenwich.com)

RUBENSOHN--Herbert. 03/28/1916 - 09/02/2012 Remembered with love and humor by his sister, Janet Lieberman, PhD, his children, grandchildren, and great-grandson, and by his devoted caregiver, Vier Rogers.

EGAN--Helen. On Labor Day Weekend, we remember Helen Teresa McNamara Egan, who left us on January 13, 2013, with love and gratitude. She was the beloved wife of the art dealer Charles Egan, founder of the Egan Gallery, who died in 1993; mother of Kevin Egan, of Ventura, CA; and grandmother to Molly, of Brooklyn, NY, and Galen, Liam, and Taig. Born in Pittsburgh on April 26, 1927, she graduated from Carnegie Tech in 1949; moving to New York, she worked in publishing for 50 years, starting at the New American Library and eventually becoming a managing editor at the Viking Press, Warner Books, and the Metropolitan Museum. Wherever she worked, she was known for her professionalism and collegiality, and especially for her energetic mentoring of newcomers to the industry. Like her husband, her greatest memorial is the success of those she helped to get their start: she is forever in our hearts.

WHELAN--Elisabeth V. (Liz), on August 30, 2013 after a long illness. Child of the 1960's Village, she loved horseback riding and sculpting, and was an artist of immense talent. She will be missed by her mother Roberta, her life partner Cid, sisters Wendy and Jane, brother-in-law Jim, niece Kathleen, step-mother Margaret, and many friends. A memorial service will be planned for a later date.

STERN--Richard M. Richard M. Stern.,of Piermont, NY, died on August 28th, 2013 at the age of 91 after losing a two-year battle with prostate cancer. Dick Stern grew up in New Rochelle, NY, and graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, majoring in industrial engineering. He was a World War II veteran who served in the 3519th Ordnance Medium Maintenance Company, involved in the repair and rearming of frontline troops including efforts during the Battle of the Bulge. After the War, Dick worked alongside his father and two of his brothers in the company that became the Stern Dental Corporation, for which he served in a variety of positions including President. Dick Stern was a very sweet man who was devoted to his family. He was also deeply involved in philanthropy, always interested in providing support and resources for the most needy around the world. He was a world traveler, visiting every continent except Antarctica. He is survived by his wife, Charlene, his brother Thomas E., and his four children, Richard (Lauren) Stern, Alice (Brian Gilbane) Stern, David (Elizabeth Shore) Stern, and Jonathan (Janine) Stern, two stepsons Doug (Amy) Ikelheimer and Bruce (Jo) Ikelheimer, and nine grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Dorothy. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. Donations may be made to the Prostate Cancer Foundation.

VON KROEMER--Dorothea (Sellner), on August 19, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Kurt von Kroemer. Loving mother of Michele von Kroemer Hedges. Wonderful mother-in-law of James E. Hedges. Adoring and proud grandmother of Eleanor Hedges. Funeral service on September 3rd at 10am at The Village Lutheran Church in Bronxville, NY.

SCHNEIDER--Berenice, of Cincinnati, OH, formerly of White Plains, NY, passed away August 28, 2013. Graduate of White Plains High School (1935) and Connecticut College for Women (1939). Beloved wife of the late Dr. Meyer R. Schneider, devoted mother of David (Diane) Schneider, Daniel Schneider and Judith Schneider, dear sister of the late Charles Hecht, Ruth Toby and Rose Altman, loving grandmother of Nicholas (Candice), Anna, Claire and Joel, great-grandmother of Cassandra and Noah. Services are being held on September 1, 2013, at Weil Funeral Home in Cincinnati.

ROSENZWEIG--Murray, passed away August 31st at the age of 89. He was a much loved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather and brother. Funeral services will be held at Guttermans Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY on Tuesday, September 3rd at 12pm.
ROAMAN--Eileen. Dearest Carol, I am shocked and saddened. My thoughts are with you and I send you much much love. Susan Rolfe
MOLLICA--Ann. August 11, 1930, died August 24, 2013. She was the beloved wife of Frank and mother to Georgina. Viewing, Tues, Ballard-Durand in White Plains Services, 10am Wed at I.H.M.

FIROUZABADIAN- MOGHTADERI--Ghamar, of Irvington, NY, born in Shiraz, Iran, died peacefully on August 31, 2013, surrounded by her loving children: Bahram (Dr. Manijeh), Dr. Farideh (Dr. Fraydoon) and Farimah (Soroush). Predeceased by her husband Mohammad Sadegh and by sons Daryoush, Homayoon and Mehrdad. Lovingly remembered by friends, family, seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

FEINBERG--Marjorie Lenore, 86, of New York, NY, died peacefully on August 31, 2013. Loving and devoted mother of Beth Feinberg, mother-in-law of Gordon Kaupp, grandmother of Ella and Dylan Kaupp, sister of Dr. Stanley Norton Gershoff, sister-in-law of Dr. Marilyn Crim, and aunt of Carrie Gershoff. She is predeceased by her beloved husband, Dr. Donald Lester Feinberg, and her dear parents, Carrie and Abraham Gershoff. Margie was a graduate of Hunter College and Columbia University Graduate School, and helped many children during her career as a developmental psychologist. She was an actress in her youth and never lost her lifelong love of singing and passion for the theater. Margie will be deeply missed by her family and friends who will forever cherish her warmth, humor, generosity and strength of spirit. Her family also wishes to extend their deep gratitude to Ethel McKoy, Jurdine Jones and Odette Boodoo for the loving care they provided Margie over the last few years. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 3rd at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Margie's name to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital or to a charity of the donor's choice.

COVEY--Roger E. Art Historian, Editor, Author, Translator. Passed away July 30, 2013 at age 58. President of Tang Research Foundation. www.about.me/coveyr. He is survived by children Nicholas and Rachel Covey; mother Cynthia Covey; sister Helen Covey Boone; brother Robert Covey; step-mother Mary Kaye Covey. Preceded in death by his father, Robert E. Covey. Memorials may be made to Tang Research Foundation, Chicago, IL, USA.

BALCOM--Lucille Parsons, 100, of Palm Beach, FL, widow of Ronald Bush Balcom passed away August 29th at her home in Fishers Island, NY. She was born on November 1, 1912 in Montclair, NJ. "Lulu" was the daughter of Jay Lester Parson and Lucille Myers Parsons. She grew up in Orange, NJ and attended Miss Porters School in Farmington, CT. She was married to and divorced from George Vanderbilt. During WWII she did volunteer work with the American Red Cross. In 1950, she and Ronnie Balcom were married in Palm Beach, FL at her home. She was an exceptional golfer and at the age of 16 hit her 1st of "10 holes in one". She was also an excellent skier and she and Ronnie spent much of their time skiing in Vail, CO and Klosters, Switzerland. Her greatest love in life was traveling and there were few places in the world she had not been. Lulu was an extremely talented artist and was well known for her unique, primitive paintings. Most of her original 3-dimensional paintings depict scenes from the Caribbean and New England. She was predeceased by her beloved husband of 44 years and her brother Jay Lester Parsons, Jr. She is survived by her daughter Lucille V. Pate, two grandsons, Phillip V. Brady and Robert M. Balding, and granddaughter Dawn B. Pate. She is also survived by four great-granddaughters Allston Pate, Emerson Pate, Margaret Balding and Sara Balding, all of Georgetown, SC. In addition, she is survived by her sister Emily Parsons Ridgway of Short Hills, NJ and a step-sister Mrs. Horace Bailey. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you donate to the Island Health Project, PO Box 344, Fishers Island, NY 06390.

ALTMAN--Florence Lillie, on September 1, 2013. A loving, caring mother to Scott (Linda), Leslie, Renni (Rick), and grandmother to Carly, Nina, Daniel and Rachel, and wife to Chester. She passed away peacefully at age 88 at her home with her loving family at her side. Funeral service Tuesday, September 3, 1pm at Cedar Park Cemetery Paramus, NY. Donations can be made in her memory to A.H.R.C. Nassau.

WEEKS--Howard Coxe, 89, of Alstead, NH, formerly of Cedarhurst, NY, died on August 27, 2013. A caring, loving father to Gerald Weeks (Nancy), Isabel Weeks and Hannah Fogg (Fred) and grandfather to Amelia Fogg, Kate Fogg, Avery Fogg, Carly Weeks, and Kyle Weeks. He was the son of Isabel Coxe and Louis Seabury Weeks. He loved painting, woodworking, dancing and gardening. He was a true friend to many. A memorial celebration service will be held at 2pm on Thursday, September 5, 2013 at the Third Congregational Church of Alstead, 14 River Street, Alstead, NH.

SHERMAN--Jerome, on September 1, 2013. Predeceased by his wife Jeanette and his sister Edith S. Weinstein. Practicing attorney in New York. Survived by nephew Peter Weinstein and several great-neices and nephews. Services Wednesday, 11:30am, at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ.

ROTHENBERG--Nathaniel. On August 31, 2013. Formerly of East Northport, LI. Beloved husband of the late Judith. Devoted father of Harold, Lawrence and Alan. Loving grandfather of Sarah and Daniel. Services today 1pm at Beth Moses Cemetery.

ORDAN--Doris K. We mourn the passing of one of the most loving and generous spirited people anyone could know. She was full of love for her friends and family, including her grandchildren, for whom her love knew no bounds. Doris was the wife of the late Harry Ordan, and their love affair will continue in a better place. Please send any gifts in her memory to the National Council of Jewish Women (NCJW.org).

GOLDSMITH--Stuart Oliver, 83, "Buddy" to friends and family, on September 2, 2013. Stuart was a graduate of Rutgers University and Harvard Law School and had a career in commercial real estate development. Beloved husband of the late Vivian Goldsmith, he is survived by his children Victoria Goldman, James Goldsmith, William Goldsmith and Elizabeth Goldsmith McGee and his step-children Robyn Zeller, Gary Binstein, Richard Binstein, as well as his loving grandchildren and his sister Rhoda Gruen. Service Tuesday, September 3, 2013, 1:30pm at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam.

MATZA--Hyman Morris, on September 1, 2013. True patriarch, he always stood fast and strong for his family. Last surviving sibling of seven children of Anna Mevorah Matza and Moshe Aaron Matza of Kastoria, Greece. Veteran of WWII he was with the first troops to liberate the Dachau Concentration Camp. Always proud of serving, his uniform held a place of honor in his life. Loving husband of the late Victoria Alevy Matza, father of Andrea Grass (Tony) and Marc (Robin), grandfather of Kimberly, Alexandra, Jacqueline and Cody. He travelled his own path on every road taken... a man of extraordinary strength. Funeral services Tuesday, September 3rd, 1pm, Gutterman's, Jericho Tpke., Woodbury. Interment to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.
GIFFORD--Gertrude. A woman of character and quality, that was our Gert. A treasured friend, she brightened our lives. Deepest sympathies to the family. Helene Herzig and Family

FEINBERG--Marjorie Lenore, 86, of New York, NY, died peacefully on August 31, 2013. Loving and devoted mother of Beth Feinberg, mother-in-law of Gordon Kaupp, grandmother of Ella and Dylan Kaupp, sister of Dr. Stanley Norton Gershoff, sister-in-law of Dr. Marilyn Crim, and aunt of Carrie Gershoff. She is predeceased by her beloved husband, Dr. Donald Lester Feinberg, and her dear parents, Carrie and Abraham Gershoff. Margie was a graduate of Hunter College and Columbia University Graduate School, and helped many children during her career as a developmental psychologist. She was an actress in her youth and never lost her lifelong love of singing and passion for the theater. Margie will be deeply missed by her family and friends who will forever cherish her warmth, humor, generosity and strength of spirit. Her family also wishes to extend their deep gratitude to Ethel McKoy, Jurdine Jones and Odette Boodoo for the loving care they provided Margie over the last few years. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 3rd at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Margie's name to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital or to a charity of the donor's choice.

FEAGESON--Frieda (Yellin), passed away peacefully September 1st at 90. She is survived by her husband, Edward. The Fainberg, Angel, Sarfati and Greenberg families and her many friends will remember her warmth of character, passion for teaching, love of art and music and most of all her commitment to others. Funeral will be Tuesday, September 3rd at 2:15pm at Riverside Memorial-180 West 76th St.

DENIHAN--Irene, of Manhasset, NY died peacefully at her home on August 31, 2013 after suffering a stroke on July 12th. Born on November 15, 1921 to Anna and Stanislaw Spokas, Irene grew up in Philadelphia, PA. Irene was a strong, courageous, thoughtful, caring woman who made the lives of many of those around her that much richer for knowing her. She will be dearly missed. The devoted wife of Benjamin J. Denihan for forty years, who predeceased her in 1986, Irene is the beloved mother of Julianne D. Bresciani, Brooke D. Barrett-Galbraith, Benjamin J. Denihan, Maureen D. Ferrari, Donald G. Denihan and Laurence K. Denihan and nineteen grandchildren: Alessandra Okay, Michelle Collins, John Barrett, Katharine, Tully and Charles Denihan, Christina O'Donovan, Christopher, Michael, and Margaret Ferrari, Donald, Timothy, Devon, and Patrick Denihan, and Correy, Kelsey, Ranait, Riley, and Quentin Denihan and eight great-grandchildren: Finley, Rowan, and Vaughn Collins, Jacqueline and Reese Barrett, William and Juliette Okay, and Benjamin O'Donovan. In addition, Irene is survived by her dear brother, Otto Edmond Spokas of Palonian Springs, Virginia and her stepsister, Helen Raffa of Cuppertino, California. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, New York, Wednesday, September 4th from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10am, Thursday, September 5th at St. Mary's RC Church 1300 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY. A lifelong supporter of Catholic charities, Irene has been a Manhasset resident and active member of St. Mary's Church for over 50 years. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to The Church of Saint Mary, 1300 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York 11030.

DANZIG--Myrna, died peacefully August 22, 2013 with close friends chanting around her. Lesbian feminist who help change America. Friend and mentor to many. We love her and miss her. Memorial service Saturday, September 14, 4pm at SGI NYCC, 7E15 St.
BRENNEMAN--David, died on August 31 after a battle with sarcoma. Survived by wife, three kids, parents and loving family. Visitation September 4, 4-8pm, Cassidy-Flynn, 288 E. Main, Mt. Kisco, NY.

OPPENHEIMER--Judith Jordan. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, friend and teacher, Judith Jordan Oppenheimer, 89, of New York, died peacefully in her sleep at home on September 3, 2013.
