MARTIN--Murray I.,of Long Island, NY, died on Thursday, August 29th at the Long Island Veteran's Home in Stony Brook, NY after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was 92. Born February 18, 1921, he graduated from City College in 1943. He served in the United States Army in the 643rd Tank Destroyer Battalion as a machine gunner, and bazooka operator. He fought his way through Belgium, France and Germany, where he was ultimately captured and placed in a P.O.W. Camp. He escaped his captors after 30 days, and made his way back to the Allied lines. Upon his discharge, he spent his entire career in the corrugated box industry as an owner, executive and salesman. He is survived by his wife of 67 years, Sylvia, also of Stony Brook, NY. Brother George Kowitt of Syracuse, NY. Daughter Lois and husband Peter Kanaris of Hauppauge, NY. Son Eric and wife Liz of Woodbury, NY. Grandchildren Jennifer, Alexander, Chelsea, Jeremy, and great-grandchild Joshua. Interment was in Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

MANSOURI--Lotfi. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Lotfi Mansouri, the energetic leader and influential advocate for opera who served as General Director of the Canadian Opera Company and subsequently of San Francisco Opera. He initiated and championed the use of live surtitles in opera performances, a legacy that lives on in opera houses around the world, transforming the accessibility of the art form. His directing credits include the company premiere of Massenet's "Esclarmonde" at the Met. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

KARELSEN--Frank E. III. The Ethical Culture Fieldston community is profoundly saddened by the loss of our former board chair, whose indomitable spirit inspired those who worked with him. A proud alumnus, Frank was a member of a deeply committed ECF legacy family, which spanned three generations and also included his wife, Ursula, who served on the faculty for 15 years. Our heartfelt condolences to Franklin, Juliet '80, Eva '82, and the entire family. Damian J. Fernandez, Head of School Robert A. Pruzan '81 & Paul T. Schnell '72, Board Co-Chairs

KARELSEN--Frank E.,III. The partners and staff of the former law firm of Kurzman Karelsen & Frank mourn the death of our partner, Frank E. Karelsen, III. Frank was the leader of the firm's cooperative housing legal practice for decades and was responsible for the creation of many of the leading cooperative apartment buildings in New York City. He was a strong supporter of the idea that apartment dwellers in the City should own their own homes. His influence will continue for a long time. Frank was preceded in death by his beloved wife, Ursula. We extend our condolences to Frank's children, Franklin, Juliet and Eva.

HARVEY--Alexander Dr.,noted physics professor dies at 95. Dr. Harvey taught at Queens College for 25 years where he became chairman of the Physics Dept. until his retirement in 1988. He served as an Army Captain during WWII. Dr. Harvey was a visiting scholar at NYU. He continued publishing papers until 2011. He is survived by his wife of 60 years Rhea Harvey, a brother Robert Harvey and nieces Susan Giordano and Mickie Mandel.

GARFUNKEL--Gloria January 29, 1933 - September 3, 2013. At peace after a valiant battle with cancer. Adored mother of Stacey (Rob), Nana of Tucker and Kiki, fun loving aunt, extraordinary friend and party giver. Memorial Celebration to be announced.

GARCIA de OTEYZA--Juan, Aperture Foundation is sad to report the death of Juan Garcia de Oteyza in Mexico City on Monday, August 26. Juan was director of Aperture Foundation from 2008 to 2010. During his tenure he increased Aperture's international presence in Brazil, Mexico, and Spain. He was a superb editor, an excellent diplomat, and a visionary. At the end of his life he was working on a book of the French photographer Bernard Plossu, for publication in English by Aperture/ Fundacion Televisa. Juan had a great career in publishing, in promoting the arts, and in diplomacy. He was director of Editorial Turner Libros in Madrid (2000 to 2004) and later in Mexico City (2004 to 2007). He became Cultural Attache of the Mexican Embassy, serving in Washington from 2007 to 2008, when he joined Aperture as director. In 1985 Juan founded Eridanos Press to publish contemporary literature of non-English writers in English. From 1996 to 2000, he was director of the Mexican Cultural Institute in New York. He worked with the Museum of Modern Art on the first retrospective of Manuel Alvarez Bravo and also organized a tribute to the poet and Nobel Prize winner Octavio Paz at the Metropolitan Museum in New York. His enthusiasm, knowledge, and charisma will be missed by members of his family, friends, and all of us in the Aperture community around the world.

DENIHAN--Irene, of Manhasset, NY died peacefully at her home on August 31, 2013 after suffering a stroke on July 12th. Born on November 15, 1921 to Anna and Stanislaw Spokas, Irene grew up in Philadelphia, PA. Irene was a strong, courageous, thoughtful, caring woman who made the lives of many of those around her that much richer for knowing her. She will be dearly missed. The devoted wife of Benjamin J. Denihan for forty years, who predeceased her in 1986, Irene is the beloved mother of Julianne D. Bresciani, Brooke D. Barrett-Galbraith, Benjamin J. Denihan, Maureen D. Ferrari, Donald G. Denihan and Laurence K. Denihan and nineteen grandchildren: Alessandra Okay, Michelle Collins, John Barrett, Katharine, Tully and Charles Denihan, Christina O'Donovan, Christopher, Michael, and Margaret Ferrari, Donald, Timothy, Devon, and Patrick Denihan, and Correy, Kelsey, Ranait, Riley, and Quentin Denihan and eight great-grandchildren: Finley, Rowan, and Vaughn Collins, Jacqueline and Reese Barrett, William and Juliette Okay, and Benjamin O'Donovan. In addition, Irene is survived by her dear brother, Otto Edmond Spokas of Palonian Springs, Virginia and her stepsister, Helen Raffa of Cuppertino, California. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, New York, Wednesday, September 4th from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10am, Thursday, September 5th at St. Mary's RC Church 1300 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY. A lifelong supporter of Catholic charities, Irene has been a Manhasset resident and active member of St. Mary's Church for over 50 years. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to The Church of Saint Mary, 1300 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York 11030.

CLADIS--George, artist, husband, father, and grandfather died at his home in New Jersey at the age of 90. Born and educated in New York City, He studied with Yasuo Kuniyoshi and Adja Yunkers. Following an outstanding career in aeronautics/aerospace (distinguished fellow, College of Aeronautics) he left the establishment shortly after his twin sons were born to begin a new, true life as an artist in Paris. After Paris, George and his family returned to the United States where he continued his art in Tribeca. His medium was mostly abstract oil on canvas He invented novel techniques often incorporating mixed mediums such as stitching, rope, and wire mesh. George is survived by his wife Patricia, sister Elpis, twin sons (Harrison and Franklyn) and five grandchildren (Hudson, Alethea, William, Catherine, and Mary).

BRENNEMAN--David Cameron, resident of Chappaqua, NY, died on August 31, 2013, after a fierce 16-month-long battle with a rare and aggressive form of sarcoma. He was born April 10, 1976, in Natick, Massachusetts to Ruth and Tom Brenneman. In his short life, David worked hard to realize many dreams. Throughout his academic career, he prided himself on being a true scholar-athlete. In addition to track and soccer, he captained his Natick High School basketball team and continued to run track in college. David earned his BA, summa cum laude, in International Relations and Russian from Colby College and went on to Yale for his Master's in Slavic Studies and to Harvard Law School for his JD. Upon graduation, he started working as an attorney for Davis, Polk & Wardwell in Manhattan. Subsequently, he became Vice President at Banc of America. In 2007, David moved to Morgan Stanley, where he loved working for the past six years, most recently as an Executive Director within MS Equity Risk Management. Throughout his battle with cancer, he felt that Morgan Stanley was a true second home to him. David met his wife, Mina Brenneman, at Yale in 1998, and they marked their 11th wedding anniversary on August 24, 2013, the day David was hospitalized at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. Even in the final days of his life, David continued to be a doting, gentle and incredibly involved father to his three young children: Will, 8, AJ, 6, and Maggie, 3. He was known to family, friends, colleagues and, lately, doctors and nurses at MSKCC, as a true gentleman, one with a dry sense of humor, sharp wit, a passion for fine wines and good thrillers, and a lucid grasp of abstract concepts, be they literary, legal or financial. Born to a family of educators, teaching was in his blood, and he was also highly respected for his negotiation and people skills. In April 2013, David was presented with a Courage Award by the Sarcoma Foundation of America, an organization for which David helped raise hundreds of thousands of dollars for sarcoma research. He lived up to the honor and responsibility of this award to his final breath and never gave up in spirit. Besides his parents, wife, and children, David is survived by his two brothers, two grandparents, two nieces, a nephew, in-laws, numerous aunts, uncles, and cousins. Visitation will be Wednesday, September 4, 4-8pm at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, 288 East Main St., Mt. Kisco, NY. A private cremation will be held on September 5. There will be a memorial celebration of David's life at a later date, details to be announced. In lieu of flowers, it was David's wish that any potential donations be made to The Brenneman Children Fund: www.giveforward.com/ fundraiser/zfm2

WEIL--Marjorie W.,passed away peacefully at her home in Needham, MA on Sunday September 1, 2013. She joins her husband Richard (1977) and daughter Lynne (2005). Born to Richard and Emily Weingart in Atlantic City, NJ on January 14, 1921, she is survived by her daughter Barbara, her son Lonnie and her daughter-in-law Mitzi; grandchildren Sara, Seth, and Jenny; and three great-grandchildren. Marj's home of residence was Wilmington, VT where she lived in her beautiful home on Lake Raponda. She spent the summers in Northeast Harbor, ME on her 47 foot "Egg Harbor" which she loved living on and skippered into her 90's. In lieu of flowers, Marj's wishes are for donations to be made to her favorite charity, National Wildlife Federation (www.nwf.org).

STOTTER--Hannah (Honey),. Beloved wife of the late Willard. Longtime resident of Scarsdale, NY and currently of Delray Beach, FL. She will be missed by her many good friends for her loyalty, elegance and fun personality.

RICH--Sue. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother died at her home on September 4, 2013 at age 94. She had a passion for life and a devotion to family. She clung to life as courageously as she lived it. Her warmth, intellect, humor and caring for others will be deeply missed. She was married to her late husband John for over 50 years and is survived by her three children; Sherry (Bob), Bruce (Melissa), Laurie (Charlie), four grandchildren; Alyssa (Marco), Kara, Megan and Alex, and two great-grandchildren; Caitlyn and Caroline. Funeral services private.

OSBORN--Charles Shove, 84 years old, died on September 2, 2013. Beloved son of Richard Osborn and Eleanor Osborn Bettle. Devoted brother of Richard, Mary and James. Uncle of Frances Buffum, William and Duncan Mackintosh, James and David Osborn and Sarah Gardner. Great-uncle of many great nephews and nieces. Funeral arrangements will be private.

OPPENHEIMER--Judith Jordan. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, friend and teacher, Judith Jordan Oppenheimer, 89, of New York, died peacefully in her sleep at home on September 3, 2013. A writer and lover of language, Judy was a gifted English teacher at Packard Collegiate Institute, Friends Seminary and other schools. She is survived by her husband, Herbert Oppenheimer, daughters and partners Linda, Joep, Alissa, Bettina, Catherine and Garrett, and extra special grand children: Elliott and William. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 17 from 5:00 6:00 pm at Unitarian Church of All Souls at 1157 Lexington Avenue (80th Street). In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Planned Parenthood.

MORLAN--Rev. Lawrence A. Died August 31. Catholic priest, social justice worker and member of Silo Plowshares Movement. Co-founded Casa Romero, a hospitality House in NYC for young men considering the priesthood. Funeral Mass on September 9, at 11am at St. Patricks Church in LaSalle Peru IL. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Catholic Worker House or a local food pantry preferred. Survived by father Loren, sisters Joanne (Michael), Amy, Beth, Meg and brothers Jeff (Karen) and Jay.

Beaser and Dusan Culich. Cherished grandfather of Michael J. Beaser, Andrew D. Beaser, Caroline Culich, Daniel S. Beaser and Jonathan Culich. Loving great-grandfather of Hannah M. Beaser and Nathan J. Beaser. Services private.

MAHONEY--Estelle Shirley-Ann, of Jupiter, FL and a former long time resident of Rye, NY died peacefully on September 3, 2013, with her family at her side. Shirley was born August 2, 1917 to Joseph and Dorothy Velsor of Huntington, NY. She was the beloved wife of the late Walter J. Mahoney, devoted mother of Walter, Jr. (Binx); Jay (Gail); Daniel (Susan); and Kerry Brown (Tom); and mother in law of Barbara Mahoney; loving grandmother of twelve (pre-deceased by grandson, Ryan Mahoney) and proud great-grandmother of fourteen. Shirley is also survived by her dear friend and caretaker of more than 8 years, Anna Mano. A memorial mass to celebrate her life will be held September 28, 2013 at 10am at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY.

HALL--Eleanor Williams, died of a cerebral hemorrhage in Bellevue, WA on June 22, 2013 at the age of 90. Eleanor was born on January 30, 1923 in Boston, MA and graduated from Radcliffe College in 1944. She joined American Express Company in New York in 1951 where she worked until her retirement in 1983. She was one of the Company's first women to attain officer rank and held a number of senior positions, most recently in marketing and public relations with the Company's international banking subsidiary. A woman of elegant appearance, she is widely remembered for her consistently high standards of literary expression, accuracy and style. Memorial contributions may be made to the University of Washington Medical Center, Seattle WA.

GRUFFERMAN--Lillian, passed away in New York City on August 24, 2013. Beloved wife of Mel, daughter of Yetta and Samuel Saltzman and sister of Stanley Saltzman, all of whom passed before her. Loving daughter, Emily Marino and her husband, Joseph; and dear son, Howard Grufferman and his wife, Barbara survives her. Grandmother of Michael Marino and his wife, Erika; and Sarah and Elizabeth Grufferman. Great-grandmother of Max and Teddy Marino. In remembrance of her devotion to family donations can be made to the Association to Benefit Children, Attn: Lillian Grufferman Memorial Fund, 419 E. 86th St., NYC, NY 10028.

GOTTHELF--Philosopher Allan Stanley, died of cancer at age 70 on Friday, August 30th, at his home in Philadelphia, in the company of his dear friend Cassandra Love. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 7, at 10am at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan; burial will be at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, N.Y., at 3pm. Gotthelf is best known for his scholarship on Aristotle and on Ayn Rand, with whom Gotthelf was friends. At the time of his death he was Anthem Foundation Distinguished Fellow in the Rutgers University philosophy department. He is also an emeritus professor of philosophy at The College of New Jersey and a Life Member of Clare Hall, Cambridge University, and between 2003 and 2012 was a visiting professor of the history and philosophy of science at the University of Pittsburgh, where he held an Anthem Fellowship for the Study of Objectivism. David Charles (Oxford University) speaks of Gotthelf's "decisive role in the renaissance of scholarly and philosophical interest in Aristotle's biological writings," and Alan Code (Stanford University) comments that "no scholar has had a deeper and more lasting impact on the scholarly understanding of Aristotle's biological corpus than Allan Gotthelf." Gotthelf made this impact through a series of path-breaking essays now collected in Teleology, First Principles, and Scientific Method in Aristotle's Biology (Oxford University Press, 2012) and through the conferences and workshops he organized. These events formed the basis for two books: Philosophical Issues In Aristotle's Biology (Cambridge University Press, 1987), which Gotthelf co-edited with James G. Lennox (The University of Pittsburgh), and Aristotle on Nature and Living Things (Mathesis, 1985). The latter book, which Gotthelf edited, was in honor of his friend and mentor David Balme (University of London), and after Balme's death in 1989, Gotthelf shepherded several of his projects to publication. In 2004, Gotthelf's "contributions to the study of classical philosophy and science" were celebrated at a conference at the University of Pittsburgh, which led to the volume: Being, Nature, and Life in Aristotle: Essays in Honor of Allan Gotthelf (Cambridge University Press, 2010), edited by Lennox and Robert Bolton (Rutgers University). Gotthelf met Ayn Rand in 1962, in connection with lectures on her philosophy that he attended. Rand took an active interest in philosophy students, and over the next 15 years, he had the opportunity for long philosophical discussions with her. Gotthelf is one of two friends whose expressions of interest Rand said prompted her to write Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology, which has become one of history's best-selling works on epistemology. Gotthelf was an active participant in Rand's famous 1969-71 Workshops on that book, an edited transcript of which now appears as an appendix to the book's second edition (Plume, 1990). Gotthelf was a founding member of the Ayn Rand Society, a group affiliated with the American Philosophical Association, and he held the Society's highest office from 1990 until his death. Since April of 2013, he has shared that office with Gregory Salmieri (Boston University), his former student and frequent collaborator. Gotthelf co-edited (with Lennox), and contributed essays to, the first two volumes of the Society's ongoing Philosophical Studies series, published by the University of Pittsburgh Press. He is the author of On Ayn Rand (Wadsworth, 2000), and is co-editor (with Salmieri) of Ayn Rand: A Companion to Her Works and Thought (Wiley-Blackwell, forthcoming). He is survived by Ronald and Cassandra Love and their sons Zach and Ian Barber--whom Allan regarded as his family--by his many friends and students, and by his sister, Joan Gotthelf Price.

GOLDSMITH--Miriam (Schulman), November 23, 1939 - September 3, 2013. A loving, loved and dedicated wife, married to Stanley J. Goldsmith for 54 years; loving mother of four, Ira, Arthur, Beth and Mark and their spouses, Diane, Lisa, Jon and Joanna and grandmother of Jack and Anne, David and Moshe, Michelle, Sasha, Talia and Jacob, sister to Leonard and Richard. A gifted homemaker, talented cook, sculptor, proficient in a variety of handcrafts including restorer of porcelain objects who saw goodness, beauty and worth in many people before it was politically correct. Services at Sinai Chapel, Horace Harding Blvd, Queens, NY 2:00pm September 6, 2013. Donations in her memory to Ruben Niesvizky, MD, Myeloma Research at Weill Cornell Medical Center or Palliative Care, North Shore University Hospital and Garvies Point Museum & Preserve.

GARFUNKEL--Gloria January 29, 1933 - September 3, 2013. At peace after a valiant battle with cancer. Adored mother of Stacey (Rob), Nana of Tucker and Kiki, fun loving aunt, extraordinary friend and party giver. Memorial Celebration to be announced.

FEAGESON--Frieda (Yellin), passed away peacefully September 1st at 90. She is survived by her husband, Edward. The Fainberg, Angel, Sarfati and Greenberg families and her many friends will remember her warmth of character, passion for teaching, love of art and music and most of all her commitment to others. Funeral will be Tuesday, September 3rd at 2:15pm at Riverside Memorial-180 West 76th St.

CLONEY--Gerard Paul, of Sharon, CT, Paget, Bermuda and New York City, quietly passed away on September 4, 2013. The cause of death was due to complications from MDS and AML. Dr. Cloney was born in New York City on January 27th, 1931. He is survived by his wife Annette deVallieres Frith Cloney, sons Christopher (Kate) and Jean Marc (Hilda) Cloney, daughter Janine Robertson and seven grandchildren. There will be no funeral services. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Gay Mens Health Crisis at 446 West 33rd Street, New York, NY 10001-2601

CHELNIK--Harriette. The Board of Governors and members of Brae Bum Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member, Harriette Chelnik. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her entire family. Len Shendell, President Doug Simon, M.D., Secretary

CHELNIK--Harriette Fieger, Passed away peacefully surrounded by family on September 3, 2013. Born in Brooklyn to Bessie Goodman Fieger and Arthur Fieger. She raised her family in Scarsdale and later lived in New York and Palm Beach. A talented artist, sculptor, interior designer, world traveler and philanthropist. Graduate and trustee of College of New Rochelle. Survived by devoted husband of 67 years, Martin Chelnik, founder of Chelnik Parking. Loving children Roberta (Jerry) Roth, Peter and Marc Chelnik. Beloved "Mimi" of Amy (Jim) Hall, Melissa Jurist and Charlie Chelnik. Special great-grandma of Jordan, Tyler, Brandon, Ella and Ryan. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services Friday September 6th, 1:15pm, Riverside Memorial Chapel. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens. Shiva beginning at 12pm Saturday and Sunday at their apartment. Donations can be made to a favorite charity.
BRENNEMAN--David, died on August 31 after a battle with sarcoma. Survived by wife, three kids, parents and loving family. Visitation September 4, 4-8pm, Cassidy-Flynn, 288 E. Main, Mt. Kisco, NY.

BERRY--John Francis, son of Peter and Anna Berry, loving father and husband, accomplished journalist, editor and author, and lifelong jazz enthusiast, passed away last Thursday evening at his summer home in Madison, CT. His adventurous spirit, curiosity and kind nature will be missed and celebrated by all who knew him. He is survived by his children Annette and Sean; daughter-in-law Erin Berry; son-in-law Daniel Miller and grandchildren Piper Bee Miller and John Berry III. He was predeceased by Nancy Berry, his beloved wife of 43 years. The funeral is Friday, September 6th at 12pm at St. Margaret Church, 24 Academy St, Madison, CT.

GREENWALD--Irwin Daniel. 09/06/1918 - 02/17/2013 This is the first time that your birthday has arrived and we are not all celebrating it together. Know that you are in our hearts and thoughts each and every day. Isla has arrived and she has been named in your honor. We love and miss you terribly. Your devoted wife, Doris Daughter, Ronny, your grandchildren and great-grandchildren

WHALEN--Joseph. NewYork-Presbyterian and Weill Cornell Medical College mourn the passing of Dr. Joseph P. Whalen, former chair of radiology and radiologist-in-chief at NewYork-Presbyterian/ Weill Cornell Medical Center. Under his leadership from 1976 to 1992, the clinical, teaching, and research programs of the radiology department were all greatly strengthened. He was a pioneer in radiology who was instrumental in introducing CT scans and MRI to New York. He also was deeply devoted to education, and augmented residency and fellowship training opportunities. Our deepest condolences go out to his wife, Elizabeth, his children, and his entire family. Dr. Steven J. Corwin, CEO, NY-Presbyterian Hospital Dr. Laurie H. Glimcher, Dean, Weill Cornell Medical College Dr. Robert J. Min, Chairman and Radiologist-in-Chief, NY-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell

TOBIN--Douglas, beloved by generations of students, a dedicated colleague and friend, a proud New Yorker and lifelong Stuyvesant Town resident, master scuba diver, and lover of jazz, will be sorely missed by the Trinity School community, where he remained devoted to sharing his love of Classics for the past 26 years. We share our deepest and most sincere sympathies with Doug's wife, Corinne Giddings, his brother, Ronald Tobin, and his boyhood friends of the lower east side, who have lost a brother. A memorial celebration of Doug Tobin's life and work will be held on Wednesday, September 11th at 6:30pm in the Hawley Chapel of Trinity School, 101 West 91st Street.
SILVER--Irving, 89. Beloved husband of the late May, father, grandfather, uncle. He made everyone he met happier. Service 2pm Sunday, September 8 at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St.

ROSENTHAL--Patricia A. (Leavitt) 84, passed away September 1, 2013 following a brief illness. Daughter of the late Phillip B. and Dorothy W. Leavitt; Wife of the late Edgar Rosenthal; Beloved sister of Peter Leavitt of Newton Centre, MA, and the late Phillip A. Leavitt of Ashland, MA; and a fun-loving sister-in-law, aunt and friend. Retired financial adviser, adventurer and world traveler. Memorial Gathering Tuesday, September 10th, 11am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in Pat's memory to the New York Public Library.

REVER--Pearl, 94, of Lantana, FL, passed peacefully on September 4, 2013. The wife of the late Irwin S. Rever, she was a beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. A Memorial Service will be held in Florida on Sunday at Quattlebaum Funeral Home 561-832-5171.

OSBORN--Charles Shove, 84 years old, died on September 2, 2013. Beloved son of Richard Osborn and Eleanor Osborn Bettle. Devoted brother of Richard, Mary and James. Uncle of Frances Buffum, William and Duncan Mackintosh, James and David Osborn and Sarah Gardner. Great-uncle of many great nephews and nieces. Funeral arrangements will be private.

MORLAN--Rev. Lawrence A. Died August 31. Catholic priest, social justice worker and member of Silo Plowshares Movement. Co-founded Casa Romero, a hospitality House in NYC for young men considering the priesthood. Funeral Mass on September 9, at 11am at St. Patricks Church in LaSalle Peru IL. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Catholic Worker House or a local food pantry preferred. Survived by father Loren, sisters Joanne (Michael), Amy, Beth, Meg and brothers Jeff (Karen) and Jay.

MAZA--Dr. Carmen, of Redding, CT, formerly of NYC, passed away on September 2. She is survived by loving husband Dr. Howard Weiner, beloved children Allan and Tess, and loving mother Rita Maza. Visitation will be Monday, September 9 from 4-8pm at the Kane Funeral Home in Ridgefield, CT. Funeral mass will be at St. Patrick's Catholic Church in West Redding, CT at 11am on September 10. Donations in Carmen's memory may be sent to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation or a college fund for the children through the funeral home.
MARTIN--Robert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert Martin, associated with The New York Times from March 12, 1934 until retiring on May 1, 1978.

MAHONEY--Estelle Shirley-Ann, of Jupiter, FL and a former long time resident of Rye, NY died peacefully on September 3, 2013, with her family at her side. Shirley was born August 2, 1917 to Joseph and Dorothy Velsor of Huntington, NY. She was the beloved wife of the late Walter J. Mahoney, devoted mother of Walter, Jr. (Binx); Jay (Gail); Daniel (Susan); and Kerry Brown (Tom); and mother in law of Barbara Mahoney; loving grandmother of twelve (pre-deceased by grandson, Ryan Mahoney) and proud great-grandmother of fourteen. Shirley is also survived by her dear friend and caretaker of more than 8 years, Anna Mano. A memorial mass to celebrate her life will be held September 28, 2013 at 10am at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY.

KOPLOW--Ellen Barbara (Goodstein), 63 years old, passed from this world on Wednesday afternoon, September 4, 2013 as a result of a brain tumor. A woman whose acts of kindness were experienced in her own community and in many others will be missed terribly by her family and friends. She is survived by her husband, Meyer, sons and daughters, Michael and Tovah Koplow of Potomac, Maryland, Jonathan and Jennifer Koplow of Skokie, Illinois, Aliza Koplow and fiance, Josh Goldberg of New Rochelle, and grandchildren, Joshua, Kira, Allyson, Zachary and Mikayla and her sisters, Sandra Goodstein Rosenblatt, Ricki Goodstein, and her brother, Fred Goodstein all of Philadelphia. Services will be held Sunday, September 8, 2013 at 11am at Young Israel of New Rochelle, 1149 North Avenue, New Rochelle with interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Shiva will be observed at her residence, 56 Lord Kitchener Road, New Rochelle, NY following the interment each day until 10pm through Thursday and Friday until 4. Donations in her memory may be made to Amit, 817 Broadway, NY, NY 10003.

GOLDSMITH--Miriam (Schulman), November 23, 1939 - September 3, 2013. A loving, loved and dedicated wife, married to Stanley J. Goldsmith for 54 years; loving mother of four, Ira, Arthur, Beth and Mark and their spouses, Diane, Lisa, Jon and Joanna and grandmother of Jack and Anne, David and Moshe, Michelle, Sasha, Talia and Jacob, sister to Leonard and Richard. A gifted homemaker, talented cook, sculptor, proficient in a variety of handcrafts including restorer of porcelain objects who saw goodness, beauty and worth in many people before it was politically correct. Services at Sinai Chapel, Horace Harding Blvd, Queens, NY 2:00pm September 6, 2013. Donations in her memory to Ruben Niesvizky, MD, Myeloma Research at Weill Cornell Medical Center or Palliative Care, North Shore University Hospital and Garvies Point Museum & Preserve.

GLASER--Allan, April 25, 1920 - September 2, 2013 in Tucson, AZ. Born in New York City to May and S.J. Glaser, Allan passed peacefully. He attended DeWitt Clinton High School and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. He was a World War II Officer and Veteran. He was an accomplished Furrier, and a past President of the New York Furrier's Guild. He was preceded in death by the love of his life for 60 years, Roberta (Bobbi). He is survived by his two sons, Robert (Laurie) and Adam (Kathi) and his three grandchildren, Melina, Andrew and Steven. He loved his family, sports, the Democratic Party, the Wildcats, the horses and was the best card player anyone ever knew. We will miss him and were blessed to have him in our lives.

FRIEDMAN--Gerson. Age 87. September 4, 2013. Devoted husband of Carol for 64 years, beloved father of Nancy (Jonathan Fink) and Jill, adored grandfather of Evan and Erica. Funeral services will be held 11am Sunday, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., Manhattan. Contributions to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research would be appreciated.

POWELL--Maxwell M. 20 years in the blink of an eye. I hope you're watching. Missing you terribly, now and always, with so much love, Susan.

GOLDBERG--William Eric. Jan. 2, 1971 - Sept. 7, 2000. Billy, it has been 13 years since you left us. You are in our thoughts and hearts every day. You are our angel. Please watch over us! Love, Mom and Heather.
CURCIO--Frank. Daddy, love you and miss you every day. Watch over us. Paola

TOBIN--Douglas, beloved by generations of students, a dedicated colleague and friend, a proud New Yorker and lifelong Stuyvesant Town resident, master scuba diver, and lover of jazz, will be sorely missed by the Trinity School community, where he remained devoted to sharing his love of Classics for the past 26 years. We share our deepest and most sincere sympathies with Doug's wife, Corinne Giddings, his brother, Ronald Tobin, and his boyhood friends of the lower east side, who have lost a brother. A memorial celebration of Doug Tobin's life and work will be held on Wednesday, September 11th at 6:30pm in the Hawley Chapel of Trinity School, 101 West 91st Street.

SILVER--Irving. My wonderful Irving, you became my best friend when I was 10 years old and you were 11 - that was 77 years ago. Every time I fell down, you picked me up, brushed me off, kissed my cheek and sent me on my way - now it's all over. Give my love to the gang and to you my best friend I say - Goodnight sweet prince, good night. Love, Annie Ettinger

ROSENBERG--Sylvia M.,89, passed peacefully at home on September 5, 2013. Loving wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Joan Rosenberg and Wendy Karp. Adored G-ma of Sophie Karp and Evan Katin-Borland, Lily Karp and Adam Wanetik. Cherished mother-in-law of David Wanetik and Harold Karp. Beloved aunt of generations of nieces and nephews. In the 1940s, Sylvia was the first woman to own and operate a medical laboratory in her hometown of Philadelphia. She loved animals, opera (a longtime Patron of the Met), travel (especially to visit friends in Ireland) and getting cabdrivers to tell her their life stories. Although our loss was not unexpected, it is nonetheless profound. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Sunday, September 8th at 10am.

OBERHAUS--Dorothy Huff, renowned scholar, teacher, writer and lecturer died peacefully at home on September 5, 2013. Lover of American literature and especially Emily Dickinson, she devoted a major part of her academic career to analyzing Dickinson's complete works, especially her magnum opus, the Forty Fascicles. Dickinson was the subject of Dr. Oberhaus's Master's thesis, her Ph.D dissertation, and her first book, Emily Dickinson's Fascicles: Method & Meaning, Pennsylvania State Press, 1995. She also wrote dozens of articles and gave numerous lectures on Dickinson throughout the U.S. and Europe. She received her B.A. from Ohio Wesleyan University, her M.A. from Sarah Lawrence College, and her Ph,D from City University of New York Graduate Center. She began her teaching career in 1972 at Mercy College, Dobbs Ferry, NY and later served as Chair of the Mercy College Curriculum Committee and Chair of its English Department Curriculum Committee. Mercy College honored her and her beloved husband, Ed, at the 32nd Annual Mercy College Trustees Dinner this year at the Plaza Hotel in New York City with its Lifetime Achievement Award. She was a founding member of the Cupola Society, an advisory group at the Emily Dickinson Museum in Amherst, MA, and lectured frequently on Dickinson at Amherst events . At the time of her death she was completing her second book on the Dickinson Fascicles. Surviving are her husband, Ed Oberhaus, of Bronxville, NY, her daughter Ann Mackin, her son-in law Timothy Mackin, and her two grandchildren, Kate and Sean Mackin, all of Chagrin Falls, OH. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Bronxville, on Saturday, September 28, at 2pm.

MAYER--Dr. Lloyd, The Jeffrey Modell Foundation mourns the tragic passing of our founding scientific advisor and friend. Dr. Mayer had the unique talent to connect cutting edge research to compassionate clinical care. He was a treasure, a mentor and a giant in his field. The Foundation's Board of Directors expresses our sincerest and heartfelt condolences to Jill, Marisa, Sara, Josh and the entire family. Vicki and Fred Modell Co-Founders Jeffrey Modell Foundation

KOPLOW--Ellen Barbara (Goodstein), 63 years old, passed from this world on Wednesday afternoon, September 4, 2013 as a result of a brain tumor. A woman whose acts of kindness were experienced in her own community and in many others will be missed terribly by her family and friends. She is survived by her husband, Meyer, sons and daughters, Michael and Tovah Koplow of Potomac, Maryland, Jonathan and Jennifer Koplow of Skokie, Illinois, Aliza Koplow and fiance, Josh Goldberg of New Rochelle, and grandchildren, Joshua, Kira, Allyson, Zachary and Mikayla and her sisters, Sandra Goodstein Rosenblatt, Ricki Goodstein, and her brother, Fred Goodstein all of Philadelphia. Services will be held Sunday, September 8, 2013 at 11am at Young Israel of New Rochelle, 1149 North Avenue, New Rochelle with interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Shiva will be observed at her residence, 56 Lord Kitchener Road, New Rochelle, NY following the interment each day until 10pm through Thursday and Friday until 4. Donations in her memory may be made to Amit, 817 Broadway, NY, NY 10003.

JESSUP--Philip Caryl Jr. Born in Utica, NY, August 30, 1926, died in New York City on August 28, 2013. Survived by his loving family, his wife Helen, children Timothy, Nancy, Margaret, step-children Genevieve, Lucinda, Francesca, Alexander, partners Terje, Kathy, Susi, David, Jeff, and grandchildren Andrew, Aliya, Emily, Julia, Phoebe, Toby, Harry, Kalina. Son of jurist and diplomat Philip C. Jessup and educator Lois Jessup. Secretary and General Counsel, International Nickel Company of Canada, 19781984. Secretary-General Counsel, National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., 19842000. An event to celebrate his life will be held in New York at a date to be announced.

GOULD--Kenneth Dean, 65, long time resident of NYC, on August 31, 2013. Former Cantor Temple B'nai Shalom, E. Brunswick, NJ. Brother of Barry M. (JoAnn) Gould. Service 11:45am Friday, Temple B'nai Shalom, E. Brunswick, NJ, under direction of MT. Sinai Memorial Chapels, E. Brunswick, NJ, www.msmc.us. Burial Floral Park Cemetery, So. Brunswick, NJ.

GOODMAN--Lewis S.,of New York City passed away in his home on September 4th, 2013 after a prolonged battle with cancer. He graduated Harvard cum laude in 1964 and worked as a private investment broker for 45 years. Lewis was among the foremost collectors of petrified wood and agates, an interest which he and his wife passionately pursed together. He will be deeply missed by many. Lewis is survived by his wife of 48 years Peggy Goodman, his son Adam Rains Goodman and daughter-in-law Carla Bowman, his daughter Margaret Goodman Ford and son-in-law Scott Oakley Ford, his mother Elaine Correa, and his grandchildren, Ella Jewel Ford, Noah Rains Goodman, Lucas Ryder Ford, and Amelia Rose Goodman.

FEAGESON--Frieda (Yellin), passed away peacefully September 1st at 90. She is survived by her husband, Edward. The Fainberg, Angel, Sarfati and Greenberg families and her many friends will remember her warmth of character, passion for teaching, love of art and music and most of all her commitment to others. Funeral will be Tuesday, September 3rd at 2:15pm at Riverside Memorial-180 West 76th St.

EPSTEIN--Alan. The Board and staff of the Women's Housing & Economic Development Corporation mourn the untimely passing of Alan Epstein, our long-time counsel, champion and friend. Our thoughts and prayers are with Alan's wife Rachel Miller and daughters, Marni and Tessa. Alan's creative can-do lawyering led to the creation of thousands of affordable homes for New Yorkers. Hon. Analisa Torres, U.S. District Court Judge, Southern District of NY, Board Chair Nancy Biberman, President, WHEDco

EPSTEIN--Alan I.,beloved husband of Rachel Miller, adoring father of Marni and Tessa, devoted son of Harold and Sandra Epstein, wonderful brother to Julie Schneider and Marcia Caban and their spouses Steven and Noel, and special uncle to Ian, Carly, Rebecca and Ali. You will be deeply missed and in our hearts forever. "What we do for ourselves dies with us, what we do for another, remains eternal."--Albert Pike

EPSTEIN--Alan I. The partners, associates and staff of Hirschen Singer & Epstein LLP are deeply saddened by the passing of our partner, colleague, mentor and friend, Alan Epstein, on September 4, 2013. Alan's indomitable spirit inspired all who worked with him. His creativity, curiosity for life and passion for creating safe and affordable housing will be missed. Our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Rachel and his adored children, Marni and Tessa, as well as his parents and the rest of his family.

HOCHHAUSER--Joyce Isseks (51/1932 - 9/10/2010) and Marshall (12/18/1924 - 9/25/1982) We live our lives guided by your spirit, generosity and love. We walk in your honored paths and marvel at our good fortune, understanding our time together was too short. Memories of your love, joy and laughter never fade. We will never forget. David, Scott and Beth

KLEIER--Jonathan. Four years has gone by so fast and yet so slowly. So much has happened, the birth of Caroline two years ago, now another little girl coming, the show, the book, all major events that are always short of true happiness because of your absence. We miss you more and more as time passes. You were voted by the Family as the one we would want with us on a desert island.
