Love you, The Family

GORDON--James P. Memorial Service at St. George's by the River in Rumson, NJ on September 15th at 1pm. Donations in memorial designated to his name will be graciously accepted by the Optical Society of America Foundation. http://www.osa.org/en-us/ foundation/
ABRAMSON--Daniel. 4/8/32-9/5/12 Father, USAF Veteran, DDB Mad Man, artist, writer, lover. A true Renaissance man, loved, missed and never forgotten by sons Jonathan, Joel, Joshua, and his friends.

WEIL--Norman Jr.,81 of NYC and East Hampton died on August 4th, 2013. Norman graduated from Scarsdale High in '50 and Harvard in '54. He was a memorable "character", with strong opinions and love of life. He is survived by his loving life partner of 18 years, Lori Carlis, his brother Peter, sister Elsa and their families. He was most proud of his accomplishments and awards working with co-op boards to create a better quality of life. He was a talented photographer and child pianist. He will be remembered for his upbeat positive energy, loyalty and determination, as he strived for perfection. Norman was a "techy" and most enjoyed creating systems and staying in touch with the world. He was a brilliant strategist, and the CEO of a textile company started by his father. A celebration of life will be held at a later date. Contact lcarlis@aol.com.

WEIL--Marjorie W.,passed away peacefully at her home in Needham, MA on Sunday September 1, 2013. She joins her husband Richard (1977) and daughter Lynne (2005). Born to Richard and Emily Weingart in Atlantic City, NJ on January 14, 1921, she is survived by her daughter Barbara, her son Lonnie and her daughter-in-law Mitzi; grandchildren Sara, Seth, and Jenny; and three great-grandchildren. Marj's home of residence was Wilmington, VT where she lived in her beautiful home on Lake Raponda. She spent the summers in Northeast Harbor, ME on her 47 foot "Egg Harbor" which she loved living on and skippered into her 90's. In lieu of flowers, Marj's wishes are for donations to be made to her favorite charity, National Wildlife Federation (www.nwf.org).

SZER--Wlodzimierz, 89, died August 31 in San Diego, CA. Born in Warsaw, Poland, he escaped to Russia when WWII began. An artillery officer, wounded by the Nazis, he became a Colonel in the Polish Army. He left service at 32, earned his PhD in biochemistry at 35, and joined NYU School of Medicine faculty in 1968. He published 160 scientific papers and taught generations of PhD candidates and medical students. An avid chess player and student of history, art and music, he spoke several languages, loved good food, family and friends, delighted in sharing knowledge and jokes. He is survived by Karina Rothzeid, Dr. Ilona Szer, five grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Donations to NYU Medical School are welcome.

SMITH--James E.,accountant and retired executive for ITT Corporation in New York City, passed away September 5 in Westchester, NY. He was 84 years old. Mr. Smith, born in Gallion, Alabama in 1929, raised in Fairfield, AL, graduated from Fairfield Industrial High School in 1946. Upon completion of his military service in the United States Marine Corps he moved to Greater New York in 1948 where he lived for the rest of his life. After receiving a B.S. in Accountancy in 1951 from Long Island University in Brooklyn, he was first employed by S.D. Leidesdorf. His next position was with NOMA Electric Corporation. In 1954 he joined Polarad Electronics Corporation, a high-technology research, development and manufacturing operation working in Contracts Administration and Accounting. In 1964 he moved to ITT Corporation's Defense Operations as a Contracts Manager. In 1972 he accepted a position at ITT World Headquarters in New York City where he held a number of executive positions. His work enabled him to travel to Germany, Spain, Belgium and many other countries, which he enjoyed despite the rigors of business travel. He retired in 1987 after an interesting and rewarding career. Jim was a member of the American Management Association, the National Contract Management Association, former member of the Armed Forces Communication and Electronic Association, and the National Urban League BEEP Project. He was a former Chair and Chief Executive of the Dorie Miller Housing Co-operative in Corona, NY where he raised his family with his wife Alfreda. At various times he was involved in local Democratic clubs in Elmhurst and Corona. His hobbies included league bowling, photography, golfing, and rooting for the New York Mets. Jim was married to Alfreda until her death in 1988. He is survived by his son Philip, daughter Karen, daughter-in-law Lee and son-in-law Jim. He is also survived by sister his Katherine and brothers Theodore, John and Henry, sisters-in-law Hazel and Mollie, as well as many nieces, nephews, cousins and dear friends.

SILVER--Irving. My wonderful Irving, you became my best friend when I was 10 years old and you were 11 - that was 77 years ago. Every time I fell down, you picked me up, brushed me off, kissed my cheek and sent me on my way - now it's all over. Give my love to the gang and to you my best friend I say - Goodnight sweet prince, good night. Love, Annie Ettinger

ROTENBERG--Aubey, 87, years old of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved husband of Menorah, devoted father of Josiah Rotenberg, Ethan Rotenberg, and Elizabeth Rotenberg-Schwartz, father-in-law of Gila Pollack and Michael Rotenberg-Schwartz, loving grandfather of Nitai, Hallel, Honi, Sheer, Shemaiah, Sidonia, Celan, Peret, and Leket, dear brother of Hart Rotenberg, Lailla Rapoport, David Rotenberg, and the late Daniel Rotenberg z"l. Service 12:30pm Sunday at Congregation Beth Sholom, 354 Maitland Avenue, Teaneck, NJ. Memorial contributions should be directed to the Solomon Schechter Day School of Bergen County: Scholarship Fund.

ROSENBERG--Sylvia M.,89, passed peacefully at home on September 5, 2013. Loving wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Joan Rosenberg and Wendy Karp. Adored G-ma of Sophie Karp and Evan Katin-Borland, Lily Karp and Adam Wanetik. Cherished mother-in-law of David Wanetik and Harold Karp. Beloved aunt of generations of nieces and nephews. In the 1940s, Sylvia was the first woman to own and operate a medical laboratory in her hometown of Philadelphia. She loved animals, opera (a longtime Patron of the Met), travel (especially to visit friends in Ireland) and getting cabdrivers to tell her their life stories. Although our loss was not unexpected, it is nonetheless profound. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Sunday, September 8th at 10am.

RICH--Sue. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother died at her home on September 4, 2013 at age 94. She had a passion for life and a devotion to family. She clung to life as courageously as she lived it. Her warmth, intellect, humor and caring for others will be deeply missed. She was married to her late husband John for over 50 years and is survived by her three children; Sherry (Bob), Bruce (Melissa), Laurie (Charlie), four grandchildren; Alyssa (Marco), Kara, Megan and Alex, and two great-grandchildren; Caitlyn and Caroline. Funeral services private.

ORDAN--Doris K. We mourn the passing of one of the most loving and generous spirited people anyone could know. She was full of love for her friends and family, including her grandchildren, for whom her love knew no bounds. Doris was the wife of the late Harry Ordan, and their love affair will continue in a better place. Please send any gifts in her memory to the National Council of Jewish Women (NCJW.org).

OPPENHEIMER--Judith Jordan. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, friend and teacher, Judith Jordan Oppenheimer, 89, of New York, died peacefully in her sleep at home on September 3, 2013. A writer and lover of language, Judy was a gifted English teacher at Packard Collegiate Institute, Friends Seminary and other schools. She is survived by her husband, Herbert Oppenheimer, daughters and partners Linda, Joep, Alissa, Bettina, Catherine and Garrett, and extra special grand children: Elliott and William. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 17 from 5:00 6:00 pm at Unitarian Church of All Souls at 1157 Lexington Avenue (80th Street). In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Planned Parenthood.

OBERHAUS--Dorothy Huff, renowned scholar, teacher, writer and lecturer died peacefully at home on September 5, 2013. Lover of American literature and especially Emily Dickinson, she devoted a major part of her academic career to analyzing Dickinson's complete works, especially her magnum opus, the Forty Fascicles. Dickinson was the subject of Dr. Oberhaus's Master's thesis, her Ph.D dissertation, and her first book, Emily Dickinson's Fascicles: Method & Meaning, Pennsylvania State Press, 1995. She also wrote dozens of articles and gave numerous lectures on Dickinson throughout the U.S. and Europe. She received her B.A. from Ohio Wesleyan University, her M.A. from Sarah Lawrence College, and her Ph,D from City University of New York Graduate Center. She began her teaching career in 1972 at Mercy College, Dobbs Ferry, NY and later served as Chair of the Mercy College Curriculum Committee and Chair of its English Department Curriculum Committee. Mercy College honored her and her beloved husband, Ed, at the 32nd Annual Mercy College Trustees Dinner this year at the Plaza Hotel in New York City with its Lifetime Achievement Award. She was a founding member of the Cupola Society, an advisory group at the Emily Dickinson Museum in Amherst, MA, and lectured frequently on Dickinson at Amherst events . At the time of her death she was completing her second book on the Dickinson Fascicles. Surviving are her husband, Ed Oberhaus, of Bronxville, NY, her daughter Ann Mackin, her son-in law Timothy Mackin, and her two grandchildren, Kate and Sean Mackin, all of Chagrin Falls, OH. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Bronxville, on Saturday, September 28, at 2pm.

MIYAMOTO TIMMINS--Anne. After a long battle with breast cancer, Anne Eiko Miyamoto (Timmins) passed peacefully at home, surrounded by family, on Sunday, September I, 2013. An actor and playwright, Anne's most iconic role was in the long-running 1970's Calgon detergent commercial that launched the phrase "Ancient Chinese Secret" into the pop culture lexicon. She appeared alongside Al Pacino in the Broadway show "The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel" and in David Hare's "Plenty" with Julianne Moore in Washington, D.C. In recent years, Anne's work as a fiction writer led to residencies at Yaddo, Ragdale, and Sarah Lawrence College. She won the Hawaii Prize in 2009 for her play, "The Mango Tree," which was presented the previous year by The Pan Asian Repertory Company. Anne has performed as an actor in many of their productions as an actor during her early years in New York. Born in Honolulu, Hawaii. Anne received her BA at the University of Hawaii, and M.S. degrees at New York University and Carnegie-Mellon. She is survived by her three children Mari Keiko Gonzalez, of Brooklyn; Justin Miyamoto Weiner and his wife Beth Foresta, also of Brooklyn, and Joshua Samuel Mitsuo Weiner, of Manhattan; three grandchildren Devon Kameko Gonzalez, Tyler Joseph Foresta Weiner, and Olivia Rose Foresta Weiner. She has one sister, Carol Miyamoto of Honolulu. Services will be held today Sunday, September 8, at 4pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, on 76th Street in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to panasianrep.org and in the notes section please indicate it is for the Anne Miyamoto New Works Fund.

MILLER--Eric T.,Of Carmel, CA, age 85, died on August 29, 2013 of complications from a brain tumor. He was the Chief Investment Strategist at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette (DLJ) from 1979-1998, and served as Senior Advisor with DLJ and its successor firm, Credit Suisse, First Boston, until 2002. At DLJ, he chaired the Investment Policy and Stock Selection Committees and his "Random Gleanings" encapsulating his commentary on a wide variety of financial, economic and political topics were a must-read on Wall Street for years. Eric began his investment career with the New York Trust Company (later Chemical Bank) in 1955 and then spent 13 years at Dominick and Dominick LLC, serving as head of the Investment Department and Research Director prior to becoming Chief Investment Strategist at Oppenheimer Capital until 1979. After leaving DLJ, he became a Senior Contributor to Bankstocks.com where CEO of the site, Thomas Brown, described Eric as "one of the most original thinkers on Wall Street". Eric graduated from his beloved Dartmouth College in 1950 and studied at NYU graduate school of business after serving as a Marine Corps Officer in Korea. Throughout his outstanding financial career, Eric invariably found time to serve his community and industry. Prior to moving to California in 1995 with his dear wife, Susan, he had been a lifelong and active community member of Bronxville, NY serving as President of the Community Fund of Bronxville, the Bronxville Recreational Council and President of the Bronxville Field Club where he was an avid tennis and squash player. He also served on the United Hospitals Investment Committee and on the board of trustees of Kimball Union Academy. In Carmel, Eric quickly became an active and generous member of his community, serving on the financial committees of the Community Hospital of Monterey County, the Carmel Public Library, the SPCA of Monterey County and the Community Foundation of Monterey. He also became a golf enthusiast in his sixties and played both golf and tennis regularly into his eighties at Quail Golf Club and the Pebble Beach and Tennis Club. His life was wonderfully productive, serving the public in the management of their savings, serving his community and profession, and serving to the improvement of education. Eric loved life fully. He lived his in a compelling spirit of strength, integrity, kindness and wit. He is cherished and remembered by countless friends; his wife of 33 years, Susan; his brother Don; his first wife, Eileen Stuhlreyer (who is the mother of his three children); his children, Kathy Beinfield, Eric J. (Peggy) Miller and Carolyn (Paul) Bednarz; 11 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Memorial Services on Cape Cod will be announced at a later date. Services directed by The Paul Mortuary, Pacific Grove, California.

MEYERS--Eugene (Gene), Architect, on September 1, 2013, of Muttontown, LI and NYC. Graduated from Pratt Institute in 1954. Spent most of his career at The NYS Housing Finance Agency and The NYS Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency from which he retired as Senior Executive Vice President. Beloved husband of Marietta. Devoted father of Michael and his wife Deborah and the late Michelle and her partner Josie Harper. Adored grandfather of Benjamin and Antonia. Also survived by his brother Bernard. A memorial service will be held on Sunday September 29th at 1pm at the Matinecock Meeting House, 267 Duck Pond Rd. (intersection of Duck Pond and Piping Rock Rds.), Locust Valley, NY 11560. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Norris Cotton Cancer Center (Gift recording offers), 1 Medical Center Dr., Lebanon, NH 03756. cancer.darthmouth.edu

MAZA--Dr. Carmen, of Redding, CT, formerly of NYC, passed away on September 2. She is survived by loving husband Dr. Howard Weiner, beloved children Allan and Tess, and loving mother Rita Maza. Visitation will be Monday, September 9 from 4-8pm at the Kane Funeral Home in Ridgefield, CT. Funeral mass will be at St. Patrick's Catholic Church in West Redding, CT at 11am on September 10. Donations in Carmen's memory may be sent to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation or a college fund for the children through the funeral home.

MAYER--Lloyd F.,MD. The Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai is deeply saddened by the passing of our dear colleague, Dr. Lloyd Mayer. To say that Lloyd was a gifted physician and researcher doesn't really begin to describe his contributions to Mount Sinai, to his patients and to science as a whole. Lloyd was brilliant and wonderfully fun to be around. He instilled in countless physicians a love of science and a love of innovation and discovery. Our hearts go out to his wife, Dr. Jill Fishbane-Mayer, and the entire Mayer family.

MAYER--Dr. Lloyd. We mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and former Division Chief, Dr. Lloyd Mayer. Brilliant physician, inspiring scientist, gifted educator, staunch patient advocate, Lloyd's worldwide contributions to gastroenterology are legendary. On behalf of all faculty and fellows who benefited from Lloyd's genius, we extend deepest condolences to his wife, Jill, and the entire Mayer family. Bruce Sands, MD Steven Itzkowitz, MD Division of Gastroenterology Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

MAYER--Lloyd F.,MD -- It is with profound sadness that we at The Mount Sinai Medical Center mark the passing of our cherished friend and outstanding colleague, Lloyd F. Mayer, MD. Dr. Mayer graduated from the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai in 1976 and received the Mosby Award for Clinical Excellence at that time. It was one of many awards he would receive for a lifetime of outstanding work, including the Saul Horowitz Award and the Irma T. Hirschl Trust Career Development Award, the Jeffrey Modell Foundation Lifetime Achievement Award, the Jaffe Food Allergy Institute Award for Scientific Excellence, and the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America (CCFA) Scientific Achievement Award. Dr. Mayer's interdisciplinary and internationally renowned laboratory focused on mucosal immunoregulation, inflammatory bowel diseases, and cytokine regulation of human B-cell differentiation. He and his team were the first to show that the epithelial lining cells of the intestine are active regulators of mucosal immune responses that are distinct from those that regulate systemic immunity. These findings had a profound significance in the development of highly effective anti-inflammatory drugs for IBD. Dr. Mayer, with support from The Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust, launched the IBD Center at Mount Sinai as well as established a national network of academic medical institutions for collaborative basic research in IBD. From 1980 through 1984, Dr. Mayer held joint appointments at Rockefeller University and Mount Sinai. In 1986, he was named the Chief of the Division of Clinical Immunology at Mount Sinai, and in 1990 he became Vice Chair of Medicine. Dr. Mayer was named the David and Dorothy Merksamer Professor of Medicine in 1994, and three years later, he became Professor of Immunobiology and Chair of the Immunobiology Center. He served as Chief of the Division of Gastroenterology from 2003 to 2010, and in 2007 he became Professor and Co-Director of the Immunology Institute. From 2008-2012, Dr. Mayer was also Chairman of the National Scientific Advisory Committee of the CCFA. Dr. Mayer spoke and published widely, and his research was consistently funded by the National Institutes of Health. He also leaves behind multiple generations of physicians who trained with and were mentored by him. We at Mount Sinai, and the scientific community at large, feel a tremendous loss at his death. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Dr. Jill Fishbane-Mayer, their three children, Sara, Marisa and Josh, as well as Dr. Mayer's extended family and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; and Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

MAYER--Lloyd, MD. The Trustees and staff of The Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust mourn the untimely passing of Lloyd Mayer, MD, Professor and Co-Director of the Immunology institute at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. As a trusted advisor, he was the architect of the Sinai-Helmsley Alliance for Research Excellence network and then helped build a $100 million program supporting scientists around the world to find a cure, and until then better treatments, for Crohn's disease. Having made seminal discoveries about Inflammatory Bowel Disease in his own research, his greatest legacy will be the dozens of doctors and scientists he mentored over his career. His work will continue in spirit in dozens of laboratories around the world. Above all, he was a wonderful human being, and will be missed deeply by all whose lives he touched.

MAYER--Dr. Lloyd, The Jeffrey Modell Foundation mourns the tragic passing of our founding scientific advisor and friend. Dr. Mayer had the unique talent to connect cutting edge research to compassionate clinical care. He was a treasure, a mentor and a giant in his field. The Foundation's Board of Directors expresses our sincerest and heartfelt condolences to Jill, Marisa, Sara, Josh and the entire family. Vicki and Fred Modell Co-Founders Jeffrey Modell Foundation
MAYER--Dr. Lloyd. The world has lost a great leader and physician. My condolences to the family. Samantha Parker

MAYER--Lloyd, MD. The volunteers and staff of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America are deeply saddened by the passing of Lloyd Mayer, MD, the immediate past Chair of our National Scientific Advisory Committee. Dr. Mayer was a visionary leader and a brilliant researcher who was involved with CCFA for almost 30 years. He was fundamental in helping us set our research agenda. This is a significant loss to the IBD Community. Our sincere condolences to his family.

MARTIN--Murray I.,of Long Island, NY, died on Thursday, August 29th at the Long Island Veteran's Home in Stony Brook, NY after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was 92. Born February 18, 1921, he graduated from City College in 1943. He served in the United States Army in the 643rd Tank Destroyer Battalion as a machine gunner, and bazooka operator. He fought his way through Belgium, France and Germany, where he was ultimately captured and placed in a P.O.W. Camp. He escaped his captors after 30 days, and made his way back to the Allied lines. Upon his discharge, he spent his entire career in the corrugated box industry as an owner, executive and salesman. He is survived by his wife of 67 years, Sylvia, also of Stony Brook, NY. Brother George Kowitt of Syracuse, NY. Daughter Lois and husband Peter Kanaris of Hauppauge, NY. Son Eric and wife Liz of Woodbury, NY. Grandchildren Jennifer, Alexander, Chelsea, Jeremy, and great-grandchild Joshua. Interment was in Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

LUCE--Iris Fisher, 81, wife of the late Robert B. Luce, died peacefully in Boca Raton, FL. Saturday, August 17. Iris had an illustrious career as a Theatre Director and Actress, in Washington D.C. with the Shakespeare Festival, Washington Theatre Club and D.C.'s Children's Theatre; in Westport, CT with Theatre East, The White Barn Theatre and the Westport Community Theatre. And in Florida, the Hollywood Playhouse and the Lake Worth Playhouse. She is survived by her daughters, Jennifer Luce Reynolds, Ann Luce Auerbach and Jan Luce Nance, her grandsons, Adam, Jake, Nick and Sasha.

LIFFLANDER--Matthew, of Hastings-on-Hudson, New York, passed away August 15th at the age of 80, following a brief illness. He was working on his third book and practicing law as the founding partner of Lifflander & Reich and Counsel to Dentons, up until his last days. The patriarch of the Lifflander family, Matt was preparing to marry for the third time. His main passions in life beyond his family were cigars, coffee, military and police hats, memorabilia from the 1939 World's Fair, pens, and politics. Born in New York City to Ben and May Lifflander in 1932, he grew up in Jackson Heights, Queens. He received an undergraduate degree from NYU and a law degree from Cornell University. Matt's first job was on the staff of Governor Averell Harriman, and included the task of manning the phone on the night of prisoner executions. He later became a vice president and chief international counsel at Hertz. After he struck out on his own, the car rental giant remained a client. Matt gained many other long term clients, including Liberty Lines bus company, Zurich American Group insurance and Ralph Lauren Footwear. Matthew served as CEO of Uniworld, an international master franchisor of Orange Julius hamburger shops. He worked tirelessly for the Democratic Party for his entire life. Matt was chairman of the unsuccessful New York State gubernatorial bids of Howard Samuels in the early 1970s. He had key roles in several presidential campaigns, including that of Senator Ed Muskie, for whom he served as national campaign chairman in 1972. He was Senator Henry "Scoop" Jackson's New York Campaign chairman in 1976 and New York head of the Democrats for Perot movement in 1992. He also twice served as finance chairman of the New York State Democratic Party. In 1979, W.W. Norton & Company published Matt's first book, Final Treatment, The File on Dr. X, a tale of his personal involvement in a multiple medical murder case. His second book was published by the New York State University Press in 2012. The Impeachment of Governor Sulzer, A Story of American Politics, tells the story of New York Governor William Sulzer, a popular congressman, who took office in January 1913 and was the only governor of the state ever impeached. He was removed from office in October of that year because he defied the all-powerful Tammany Hall machine. Matt's Op Ed pieces and articles have appeared in the New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, The Albany Times-Union, the New York Daily News, the New York Law Journal, the New York Sun, New York Archives Magazine, and The Journal of Privatization. His unfinished book, tentatively titled Scamming America, was about the causes and costs of perjury. Matt's extensive public service included work as a consultant for the Ford Foundation, Chief Counsel to the New York State Assembly's Medical Practice Task Force, a five year term as Acting Village Justice in Hastings, and seven years as chairman of the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. He also founded a secret society called The Legion of Reliable People (LORP), to honor those who always keep their word, no matter how difficult. He is survived by his sons Clay and Justin and their families -- including four grand children and two great grand children -- and his fiancee Sandra Isaacs. A memorial service will be held at Temple Beth Shalom in Hastings-on-Hudson on Thursday, October 10, at 4pm In lieu of flowers, donations in his name can be made to the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.

LAMONT--Lansing. Died September 3, 2013 in New York City, NY. Beloved husband of Ada Jung Lamont. Author, journalist, public affairs executive, trustee. Born March 13, 1930 in New York City. Educated at Milton Academy, Harvard College (A.B.), Columbia Graduate School of Journalism (M.S.). Served in U.S. Army Infantry to 1st Lt. Reporter, Washington D.C. Star, then a Washington and foreign correspondent for TIME Magazine 1961-75. In the 1980s he was Vice-President of the Americas Society and directed its Canadian Affairs program, widely recognized as the country's preeminent public forum addressing Canadian-American issues. At the time of his death he was Chairman of the American Trust for the British Library. Author and editor of seven books, including, Day of Trinity (1965), the best-selling narrative history of the first atomic bomb test. His third book Breakup (1994) was cited by The New York Times as one of the year's most notable books. Longtime trustee and Honorary trustee, American Museum of Natural History; also Milton Academy. William Cullen Bryant Fellow, Metropolitan Museum of Art. Member, Council on Foreign Relations; Carnegie Council; Century Association; Harvard Club of New York City. Avid birder, sailor, skier and jazz pianist. He leaves his devoted wife of 59 years and four children, Douglas Lamont of Dover, MA; Elisabeth Wolcott of Hamilton, MA; Virginia Cazedessus of Lake Arenal, Costa Rica; and Thomas Lamont II of Groton, MA; a brother, Edward Lamont, of Syosset, NY; a sister, Elinor Hallowell of Tucson, AZ; and twelve grandchildren. Service at St. James Church 865 Madison Avenue on Monday, September 16, 2013 at 2:30pm.

KOPLOW--Ellen Barbara (Goodstein), 63 years old, passed from this world on Wednesday afternoon, September 4, 2013 as a result of a brain tumor. A woman whose acts of kindness were experienced in her own community and in many others will be missed terribly by her family and friends. She is survived by her husband, Meyer, sons and daughters, Michael and Tovah Koplow of Potomac, Maryland, Jonathan and Jennifer Koplow of Skokie, Illinois, Aliza Koplow and fiance, Josh Goldberg of New Rochelle, and grandchildren, Joshua, Kira, Allyson, Zachary and Mikayla and her sisters, Sandra Goodstein Rosenblatt, Ricki Goodstein, and her brother, Fred Goodstein all of Philadelphia. Services will be held Sunday, September 8, 2013 at 11am at Young Israel of New Rochelle, 1149 North Avenue, New Rochelle with interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Shiva will be observed at her residence, 56 Lord Kitchener Road, New Rochelle, NY following the interment each day until 10pm through Thursday and Friday until 4. Donations in her memory may be made to Amit, 817 Broadway, NY, NY 10003.
HERZ--Sylvia, Ph.D.,of Hollywood, FL peacefully passed away on September 3, 2013. Services by Levitt Weinstein (305) 932-2700.

HENDLIN--Ruth Maltz, a retired educator, died at home during the late morning of August 18th. A graveside service for family and friends was held on August 22nd at B'nai Abraham Memorial Park. Ruth attended The Julliard School of Music while a student at Newark's Weequahic High School and went on to receive a Bachelor of Science in Music Education from New York University, where she served as accompanist for The NYU Chorus as well as several chamber groups and soloists in New York City. Following graduation, she taught at the Lower East Side's Henry Street Settlement, The 18th Avenue School in Newark and earned additional certification for grades K-6 from Kean University. She was employed by the Springfield Board of Education, first at The Thelma L. Sandmeier School and then, for nearly two decades, as an award-winning kindergarten teacher at The James Caldwell School. Following her retirement, Ruth accompanied her husband to Tokyo during his four-year tenure as a liaison in Microbiology. While residing in Tokyo, Ruth was a volunteer tutor for The Children's English Circle, a language program sponsored by The College Women's Association of Japan, and became a student of oil painting, Japanese flower arranging and the Japanese tea ceremony. Locally, Ruth was a Girl Scout Leader, a volunteer English as a second language instructor and a member of Temple Sha'arey Shalom's Sisterhood and Renaissance Group, Women's ORT, The League of Women's Voters and The National Council of Jewish Women. Born in 1920 and married in 1944, Ruth shared her life with Dr. David Hendlin until his death in 2006. She is dearly missed by her daughters, Susan Mooallem and Harriet Hendlin; her sister, Eleanor Plotkin; her grandchildren, Rebecca Goldblat and Jonathan Mooallem and their spouses, Harris Goldblat and Wandee Pryor; and her four great-grandchildren, Sam, Isla, Davis and Rose.

HALL--Eleanor Williams, died of a cerebral hemorrhage in Bellevue, WA on June 22, 2013 at the age of 90. Eleanor was born on January 30, 1923 in Boston, MA and graduated from Radcliffe College in 1944. She joined American Express Company in New York in 1951 where she worked until her retirement in 1983. She was one of the Company's first women to attain officer rank and held a number of senior positions, most recently in marketing and public relations with the Company's international banking subsidiary. A woman of elegant appearance, she is widely remembered for her consistently high standards of literary expression, accuracy and style. Memorial contributions may be made to the University of Washington Medical Center, Seattle WA.
GORDON--Andrew S. To my huckleberry friend, I'll miss you. Paul McCann

GOLD--Anita. Anita (Nina) Gold, daughter of Bella and Jacob Gabowitz, she came into the world on December 23, 1924. She left it with peace and love on August 29, 2013. She was surrounded by her adoring husband, Irving and dedicated daughters, Joanne and Elise. She leaves behind two devoted sons-in-law and four loving grandchildren Nina was predeceased by her precious child, Stephanie and sister, Millie. She graduated from Franklin K. Lane High School and Brooklyn College; both with honors. She was fulfilled in her professional career as well as her activism, working for civil rights and later for women's rights. She was an active member of Womanspace of Great Neck, a feminist organization. To that end, contributions may be sent to: www.onebillionrising.org. Nina lovingly raised two daughters who became successful in their professions as social workers. Her marriage to Irving spanned 64 years! It was filled with civil rights work, cultural activities and travel. It is therefore not an exaggeration to say that Irving's love for his precious Nina is one of glory for his everlasting love.

GLASER--Allan, April 25, 1920 - September 2, 2013 in Tucson, AZ. Born in New York City to May and S.J. Glaser, Allan passed peacefully. He attended DeWitt Clinton High School and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. He was a World War II Officer and Veteran. He was an accomplished Furrier, and a past President of the New York Furrier's Guild. He was preceded in death by the love of his life for 60 years, Roberta (Bobbi). He is survived by his two sons, Robert (Laurie) and Adam (Kathi) and his three grandchildren, Melina, Andrew and Steven. He loved his family, sports, the Democratic Party, the Wildcats, the horses and was the best card player anyone ever knew. We will miss him and were blessed to have him in our lives.
FURFEY--James D. July 30, 1944 - September 3, 2013. If you love life, life will love you back. Slainte!

EWING--Alison Pyne (March 29, 1920 - August 19, 2013), died peacefully with loving family at her side on August 19, 2013 in Albuquerque, NM. Alison was a kind and gentle soul, a generous and gracious lady who was loved and appreciated by all who knew her. She is greatly missed by her family and friends. We know her spirit is now set free to embrace and be embraced by love and joy. In lieu of flowers donations are appreciated and may be made to St Chads Episcopal Church in Albuquerque, NM or Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, NY.

EPSTEIN--Alan. The Board and staff of the Women's Housing & Economic Development Corporation mourn the untimely passing of Alan Epstein, our long-time counsel, champion and friend. Our thoughts and prayers are with Alan's wife Rachel Miller and daughters, Marni and Tessa. Alan's creative can-do lawyering led to the creation of thousands of affordable homes for New Yorkers. Hon. Analisa Torres, U.S. District Court Judge, Southern District of NY, Board Chair Nancy Biberman, President, WHEDco

EPSTEIN--Alan. Phipps Houses mourns the loss of Alan Epstein, a champion for community development and the underserved in New York City. His wisdom, good humor, and true friendship will be sorely missed. We will strive to carry on his remarkable work and that of his firm, Hirschen, Singer & Epstein. Our thoughts go to Alan's loving family, his wife Rachel and daughters Marnie and Tessa, and to his parents and sisters. Phipps Houses Ronay Menschel, Chairman Adam Weinstein, President

EPSTEIN--Alan I. The partners, associates and staff of Hirschen Singer & Epstein LLP are deeply saddened by the passing of our partner, colleague, mentor and friend, Alan Epstein, on September 4, 2013. Alan's indomitable spirit inspired all who worked with him. His creativity, curiosity for life and passion for creating safe and affordable housing will be missed. Our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Rachel and his adored children, Marni and Tessa, as well as his parents and the rest of his family.

EPSTEIN--Alan. The Board and staff of The Center for Alternative Sentencing and Employment Services (CASES) deeply mourn the loss of our Board Chair, advisor and supporter. For many years, Alan's wise counsel helped CASES serve the city's most vulnerable individuals, including those in need of help and shelter after becoming involved in the criminal justice system. His consistent engagement and his always asking the hard questions were both a comfort and a challenge to us. His presence will endure in our work. We will miss our friend always. Our thoughts are with Rachel, Marni and Tessa. Joel Copperman, President and CEO, CASES.

ELKINS--Larry Ray J.D. Larry Ray Elkins J.D.,74, retired Managing Partner and member of Management Committee, Chapman and Cutler; Board Member, Lincoln Park Village; formerly of Murphysboro and Oak Park; passed away September 5, 2013. Survived by his wife of 32 years, Nancy Palm Felton-Elkins; son Charlie; step-children Kimberley and Thadford; and grandchildren Graham, Alexandra, Keleher, Grayson, Mitchell, and Kate. Graduate of Proviso East High School, Albion College (where he loved and played varsity tennis), Harvard School of Law, and University of Chicago (Master of Liberal Arts degree). An avid reader and golfer, as a member of Chikaming Country Club (Lakeside, MI), Larry became a student of the game, winning several awards and teaching members of his family (and their friends) to enjoy the sport. Larry and Nancy were worldwide travelers: hiking, camping, biking and boating-- never content to just sit and watch from the window. Larry believed that the foundation on which to build a life rested on four tenets: health, freedom, love, and money. Private family memorial service. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Larry's honor to: Albion College, 611 East Porter St, Albion, MI 49224, www.albion.edu/giving/ making-a-gift or to Adaptive Sports Center (dedicated to improving the quality of life of people with disabilities), P.O. Box 1639, Crested Butte, CO 81224. www.adaptivesports.org.

EPSTEIN--Alan I.,beloved husband of Rachel Miller, adoring father of Marni and Tessa, devoted son of Harold and Sandra Epstein, wonderful brother to Julie Schneider and Marcia Caban and their spouses Steven and Noel, and special uncle to Ian, Carly, Rebecca and Ali. You will be deeply missed and in our hearts forever. "What we do for ourselves dies with us, what we do for another, remains eternal."--Albert Pike

EISNER--Norman. Social justice champion and prominent business leader, passed away August 25 at 91. A longtime Great Neck resident his active engagement in the civil rights and peace movement earned him a place on Nixon's Enemies List, and included SNCC and Business Executives Move for Vietnam Peace. In WWII he served with Operation Carpetbaggers, part of the OSS, flying spies and supplies to resistance fighters earning unit earned the Croix de Guerre. His wartime experience was a key influence in his commitment to peace and social justice. As the civil rights movement began, Eisner was a guard for the Peekskill Paul Robeson Concert, and later a Freedom Rider in Maryland. He co-founded the Great Neck Equal Housing Commission to help black families buy homes on Long Island. During the Vietnam War, he travelled with the Citizen's Mission to meet Cambodia's Prince Sihanouk, to promote peace efforts. His lifelong commitment to peace, included peace movements in Israel. Founder of Lincoln Graphic Arts, he was the printer and on the board of directors of Ramparts, the leading anti-War magazine of the 60's/ 70's. An arts advocate, Eisner co-produced "Claudine", a breakthrough Black American film and the hit Off-Broadway show 'Jacques Brel is Alive and Well and Living in Paris'. He was predeceased by daughter Nancy and wife Reba, and is missed dearly by daughters Madeline of New York Janet of Los Angeles, his companion Zelda Aronstein and her sons and families.

EISENBERG--Sam. Dad was born in 1915. As a young man he experienced acutely the economic privation of the Great Depression and emerged from that experience with a strong commitment to community and to social and economic justice. Deeply engaged in civic life, he served as Chair of the Mt. Vernon Zoning Board of Appeals, and was Associate Judge and then City Court Judge for the City of Mt. Vernon from 1978 through 1985. He served as President of the Emanuel Jewish Center, President of the Mt. Vernon Jewish Community Council, President of the Westchester Day School, President of the Westchester Jewish Conference, President of the Mt. Vernon High School P.T.A. and Vice-President of its Scholarship Fund, member of the Boards of Directors of the Beth El Center and the Mt. Vernon YMYWHA. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, he served as a Captain during World War II and was a founding partner of the firm Kurzman, Eisenberg, Corbin & Lever. He served his clients with wisdom, gentleness and affability. And he extended similar respect to all who came before him on the bench as he presided with the gravity appropriate to the circumstances leavened, at lighter moments, by a twinkle of humor. Predeceased by his wife Anne, he leaves his children Arthur, Carol and Deborah; their spouses Susan, Richard and Joel; grandchildren Adam, Evan, Ethan, Dani and Ari; great-grand children, Harry and Annabel; and many happy memories of family dinners, holidays and trips. Funeral services: Monday at 10am, Temple Beth-El, New Rochelle, NY.

COENEN--Dale. Innovator In Private Equity Transactions Dies At 85. Dale Coenen died peacefully after a brief illness, at the Danbury Hospital in Connecticut on August 28th. His wife of 40 years, Joan Parker was by his side. He was born in 1928 in Flint, Michigan to Stephen Coenen and Minnie Bagley. After graduating Valedictorian and President of his senior class at Mt. Morris High School, he earned a business administration degree at the University of Michigan where he was President of the Michigamua all campus senior honor society and later received a masters degree from N.Y.U. His career path gained him experience first in engineering at GE, then management at Booz Allen & Hamilton and investment banking at Laird Inc where he spearheaded the development of leverage buyouts and growth emerging companies. Starting up Coenen&Co in the late 60's the firm became known for their "Quality Of Earnings" report that was an early proponent of earnings analysis on Wall Street. In January of 1971, the firm became a member if the NY Stock Exchange. Selling his company later that year, he took a major interest in Trans Industries out of Rochester Hills, Michigan where he remained CEO and President until retiring in March of 2005. While serving on the Board Of Directors of Figgie International, in 1991 the company donated a million dollars to the University Of Virginia Business School for a Dale S Coenen Chair of Free Enterprise. He is survived by his wife Joan, his daughter Alison Abrams and son Stephen Coenen and stepdaughter Sarah Young and four grandchildren, Quinn, Eliza, Alexandra and Daniel who will dearly miss him. Visiting hours on September 12th from 5 to 7 at the Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel and Funeral Services September 13th at 10:30am at the Christ Church at 520 Park Avenue. Contributions can be made in his name to the University Of Michigan Program Support Of Master Entrepreneurship Fund 322073.

CLONEY--Gerard Paul, of Sharon, CT, Paget, Bermuda and New York City, quietly passed away on September 4, 2013. The cause of death was due to complications from MDS and AML. Dr. Cloney was born in New York City on January 27th, 1931. He is survived by his wife Annette deVallieres Frith Cloney, sons Christopher (Kate) and Jean Marc (Hilda) Cloney, daughter Janine Robertson and seven grandchildren. There will be no funeral services. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Gay Mens Health Crisis at 446 West 33rd Street, New York, NY 10001-2601

CHU--Samuel C Dr.,of Columbus, OH. March 25, 1929 - August 30, 2013. An unexpected but peaceful passing, after a fulfilling academic and personal life. Born in Shanghai, son of General Shih-Ming Chu and Madame Grace Zia Chu. Raised in Bethesda, MD in the early 1940's after the family's arrival in the United States. Educated at Dartmouth College (AB) and Columbia University (MA and PhD). Professor of East Asian Studies, Ohio State University (1969-1995). Retired as History Professor Emeritus 1995. Survived by wife of 56 years Lucy K. Chu, brother Daniel (Lenore Schiff), his children Elaine Chu (Elliot Fan), Laura Chu Stokes (Jimmy Stokes) and Jonathan (Sumana Kesh) and five grandchildren. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held Saturday, September 28, at 2pm in Columbus, OH at North Broadway United Methodist Church. A memorial donation may be made in Samuel Chu's name to Paul Dusseau, MD Endowment Fund, c/o Ohio Health Foundation , 180 East Broad St., 31st floor, Columbus, OH 43215.

CHURCH--Joseph Hawes. Polymath, humble gentle soul. MIT graduate (BS Electrical Engineer '38), patent attorney, held patents on electric razor, tennis ball pitching machine. Direct descendant of Commander Ezek Hopkins who founded U.S. Navy and Marines. Joe was born Providence, RI on December 22, 1915; died New York City, February 20, 2013. WWII Veteran awarded Victory Ribbon and four stars, Lt. Commander, USS LST 221 and USS Milwaukee, USS Minotaur. Founder/operator "City of Key West" ferry boat between Key West and Havana. My friend, due to your independent nature, I never realized how deeply you affected me. Now you're with me every day.

CHELNIK--Harriette Fieger, Passed away peacefully surrounded by family on September 3, 2013. Born in Brooklyn to Bessie Goodman Fieger and Arthur Fieger. She raised her family in Scarsdale and later lived in New York and Palm Beach. A talented artist, sculptor, interior designer, world traveler and philanthropist. Graduate and trustee of College of New Rochelle. Survived by devoted husband of 67 years, Martin Chelnik, founder of Chelnik Parking. Loving children Roberta (Jerry) Roth, Peter and Marc Chelnik. Beloved "Mimi" of Amy (Jim) Hall, Melissa Jurist and Charlie Chelnik. Special great-grandma of Jordan, Tyler, Brandon, Ella and Ryan. She will be greatly missed. Shiva beginning at 12pm Saturday and Sunday at their apartment. Donations can be made to a favorite charity.

BRUNSWICK--Sanford, 90, of Huntington, NY and Tucson, AZ, passed away September 2, 2013. Devoted and loving husband of the late Marian Brunswick, father of Helaine Ohayon, her husband Michel, daughters Elise and Lauren and five great-grandchildren and Elinor Appel and her husband Howard, daughters Alexandra and Emma. He will be remembered as a man with great integrity, a true raconteur, teacher and mentor, he lived a full life until his very last moment. He will be deeply missed.
BLACK--Page Morton. A celebration of her life will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., on Thursday, September 12, 2013 at 3:30pm.

BECKERMAN--Sylvia, 98, wife of the late George Beckerman, passed away peacefully in Palm Beach, on August 30th. She will be sadly missed by her devoted daughter Sonia, loving grandchildren, and great-grandchildren.

BARTELS--William, on August 22nd, 2013. Bill had a big heart and generous nature. He devoted his time in the non-for- profit and community organizations and served his country in the US Army. He was the epitome of a caregiver to the entire family. Beloved brother of John R. Bartels Jr. and sister-in-law Ji Sun and uncle to Gilpin, Kristen, Anne, Biz and Jack. Graveside funeral service on Friday, September 13th at 1pm at the Parkwood Cemetery Baltimore, MD.

BAER--Bertina, 85, passed away peacefully on July 22nd in Greenport, NY. Last surviving child of the late inventor, publisher and ''father of science fiction'' Hugo Gernsback. Bertina was a strong, beautiful and brilliant woman who will always be remembered as a loving mother, devoted wife, cherished friend and caring psychotherapist. She is survived by her husband Theodore, sons Andrew and Nolan, daughter-in-law Colleen Griffin and nephews Jeffrey and Barry Neichen. A memorial service will be held in Manhattan on October 19th. For information please call (212) 397-4822.

ALLEN--Ruth Golomb. The Golomb Cousins' Club mourns our beloved Ruthie, 58, first loss of her generation, dedicated nurse and volunteer. Survivors include husband David, father Barry, children Rachel, Rebecca, Tamara and Ralph, brother Wesley, and many loving grand and great-grandchildren, cousins and other family. Funeral September 10, Bangs Funeral Home, Ithaca, NY. Shiva will be held at the home of Barry and Adeline Golomb in Monroe Township, NJ from 2pm-5pm Wednesday through Friday. Memorial contributions to Hospicare, Ithaca, or Newfield, NY Fire Rescue Department.

DUNN--Oscar L.,1914-2006. With Oscar's spirit remember your high school band, support "C" students, then go fishing with a friend after mixed doubles. "Back home again in Indiana..." Alex

SZER--Wlodzimierz, 89, died August 31 in San Diego, CA. Born in Warsaw, Poland, he escaped to Russia when WWII began. An artillery officer, wounded by the Nazis, he became a Colonel in the Polish Army. He left service at 32, earned his PhD in biochemistry at 35, and joined NYU School of Medicine faculty in 1968. He published 160 scientific papers and taught generations of PhD candidates and medical students. An avid chess player and student of history, art and music, he spoke several languages, loved good food, family and friends, delighted in sharing knowledge and jokes. He is survived by Karina Rothzeid, Dr. Ilona Szer, five grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Donations to NYU Medical School are welcome.

ROSENTHAL--Patricia A. (Leavitt) 84, passed away September 1, 2013 following a brief illness. Daughter of the late Phillip B. and Dorothy W. Leavitt; Wife of the late Edgar Rosenthal; Beloved sister of Peter Leavitt of Newton Centre, MA, and the late Phillip A. Leavitt of Ashland, MA; and a fun-loving sister-in-law, aunt and friend. Retired financial adviser, adventurer and world traveler. Memorial Gathering Tuesday, September 10th, 11am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in Pat's memory to the New York Public Library.

MAYER--Dr. Lloyd Frederick, Our hearts shattered. Our world changed. We will miss you forever. Your loving Mom, adoring sister Florence, Peter, Greg, Libby, Harper and Dylan Frederick Alkalay, Leslie, Andy, Gabe and Jack Rafal

MANOFF--Richard K.,died peacefully at home on September 7, 2013; he was 97. Dick was a pioneering advertising executive, a public health innovator, writer, and patron of the arts. In 1956 he founded Richard K. Manoff, Inc., the first Jewish-owned advertising agency (clients included, Welch's grape juice, Bumble Bee Foods, and Lucky Strike, among other national brands). In the 1970s, he invented the discipline of Social Marketing which applies corporate advertising strategies to help solve developing nations' public health problems. Dick was the author of 'Social Marketing: A New Imperative for Public Health,' the first book on the subject. He was also the author of 'Fidel is Dead,' a novel, and his memoirs. He was the loving husband of Lucy Deutscher Manoff, who died in 1995. Dick is survived by his sons, Robert and Gregory Manoff; daughter-in-law Summer; grandchildren Moises, Una, Alexandra, Morgan, Ashi, Isaac and Hannah; nieces and nephews Cal Cohen, Lisa and Maria Deutscher, Tony, Lesley and Eric Kushner and Benjamin Levy. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel today, Monday, September 9th at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the student scholarship fund of The City College of New York.

LAMONT--Lansing. Longtime president and chairman of the American Trust for the British Library. Author, journalist, musician and warm friend to so many, a leader in securing American support for that greatest of repositories of world culture, the British Library, Lansing will be sorely missed. The Board, Council and Friends of the ATBL mourn his loss and extend to his wife, Ada, his children and his grandchildren our deepest sympathy and condolences. David Redden, President The American Trust for the British Library

KOPLOW--Ellen. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with deep sadness the passing of Ellen Koplow. Ellen and her beloved husband, Meyer, are dear friends deeply committed to strengthening the Jewish community through their unwavering leadership and generosity. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Meyer, to their children, Michael and Tovah, Jonathan and Jennifer, and Aliza and Josh, to their grandchildren, and to the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP and CEO

HORNIG--Jerome, died September 8, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Judith, loving father of George and Mady, treasured mother-in-law of Joan and devoted grandfather of Rusty, Julia and her husband David, Jessica and Max. Services will be held on Wednesday, September 11, 2013 at 11:30am at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory may be made to Jazz at Lincoln Center (jalc.org).

GREENHOUSE--Cyril, died Sunday, September 1, 2013, four weeks shy of her 89th birthday. Beloved mother of Jeffrey, Steven and Andrew. Cherished grandmother of Jared, Emily, Jeremy and Jenny. Adored mother-in-law of Sandy and Miriam. Friend to many. For 66 years, wife of the late, beloved Mortimer. Children's case worker for Nassau County. A woman of fierce intelligence, boundless idealism, great sensitivity and irrepressible spirit--with a huge heart and wicked sense of humor. A tireless champion of peace and social justice. Contributions in her name may be made to Doctors Without Borders and Heifer International.
GORDON--Andrew S. To my huckleberry friend, I'll miss you. Paul McCann

GOLDSTONE--Jonas Melvin, MD, 83, beloved husband of Joan Kaweske Goldstone, father to Amy Trumpeyter Seibert and John Goldstone, brother to Martin Mickey Goldstone and grandfather to Violet Goldstone and Lola and Aaron Seibert, died peacefully at his home surrounded by his family on September 7th, 2013 in New York, New York after a battle with leukemia. He was a highly accomplished hematologist and oncologist who practiced in Manhattan. A member of the American Board of Internal Medicine, the American Board of Oncology, the American Board of Hematology, the American Society of Hematology, the American Society for the Study of Blood, and the American Society of Clinical Oncology, Dr. Goldstone was born to Sydonia Weiner and Jack Goldstone. As a young man, his dream was to move to Manhattan. He graduated from P.S. 161 and Boys High School, where he was valedictorian, and then attended Harvard College on scholarship, graduating magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa in 1951. He was subsequently a cum laude graduate of Harvard Medical School in 1955, where he was a member of the Boylston Society. Jonas Goldstone began his medical career as an intern and resident at Boston City Hospital Harvard Medical Service in 1955. He then joined the army in 1957, and served as a Captain USAH, Camp Zama, Japan and M.A.S.H. unit Tong Du Shong, South Korea until 1959. In 1960, he returned to the United States and began his practice of oncology, hematology, and internal medicine. He began in the United States Public Heath Service as a fellow in Hematology at Cleveland Metropolitan General Hospital (Western Reserve University Medical School). In 1961, the pull to return home brought him back to New York where he cared for countless residents of the city. He worked from 1961 to 1963 as an assistant in the out-patient department as a clinical associate in the Hematology Unit at St. Luke's Hospital. From 1961 to 1971, he was an attending Physician at Columbia University Health Service. In 1963, he became an assistant attending Physician at St. Luke's Hospital, and by 1969 he was an Associate Attending Physician there. In 1974, he was appointed an Attending Physician at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital. In 1969, he became an Assistant Physician at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, and from 1984 to 2003, he was an Attending Physician at Columbia Presbyterian. Apart from practicing medicine, Dr. Goldstone got great satisfaction from teaching, and he had a way of instructing young physicians that often resonated with his students. He became an instructor of Medicine at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, and by 1968, he was an Associate in Medicine there. Dr. Goldstone was the Director of Acute Leukemia Group B at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital for 18 years, beginning in 1974. He also became the Associate Clinical Director of the Hematology Division at St. Luke's Hospital, and was Chief of Oncology there from 1976 to 1992. He joined the Medical Board at St. Luke's, and from 1982 to 1984 he was its Vice-President. He was then President of the Medical Board from 1985 to 1986. He was a member of its Board of Trustees from 1984 to 1987. In 1985, Dr. Goldstone joined the Courtesy Staff at Lenox Hill Hospital and in 1997, he became an Associate Adjunct-Attending Physician there. Dr. Goldstone served as a Member of the Board of Directors for the New York County Medical Society from 1986 to 1999. He was also the Chairman of the New York County Medical Society on Physician/Hospital Relations from 1986 to 1990. From 1987 to 1993, he was a Delegate to the Medical Society of New York State. From 1989 to 1991, Dr. Goldstone was the Secretary of the Governing Council in the Hospital medical Staff Section to the Medical Society of New York State. He was a Representative for St. Luke's Roosevelt to the Hospital medical Staff Section of the American Medical Association from 1992 to 1996. Dr. Goldstone served on the Executive Committee of the New York State Medical Society for Oncologists and Hematologists, and was the Vice President and Associate Medical Director for the Mid-Manhattan Medical Group. Dr. Goldstone was the Vice Chairman of the Cancer Committee for the Medical Society of New York State, a Member of the Governing Council for the Hospital-Medical Staff Section of the Medical Society of New York State and the Chairman of the Cancer Committee for the Medical Society of New York State. In 1999, Dr. Goldstone became and Adjunct Clinical Professor of Medicine at Cornell University Weill Medical College, and in 2000, he became an Attending Physician there. Dr. Goldstone was also a passionate baseball fan and greatly enjoyed his position as an Internist for the New York Yankees. He was an avid sportsman and loved tennis, skiing, and swimming. Throughout his life, loved the city and considered New York his hometown. He could often be spotted bicycling across Manhattan through the park up to St. Luke's, long before it was considered fashionable to do so. Service Monday, September 9, 2013, 11:30am at The Riverside 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory to cancer research would be greatly appreciated

EPSTEIN--Alan. Phipps Houses mourns the loss of Alan Epstein, a champion for community development and the underserved in New York City. His wisdom, good humor, and true friendship will be sorely missed. We will strive to carry on his remarkable work and that of his firm, Hirschen, Singer & Epstein. Our thoughts go to Alan's loving family, his wife Rachel and daughters Marnie and Tessa, and to his parents and sisters. Phipps Houses Ronay Menschel, Chairman Adam Weinstein, President

EISENBERG--Sam. Dad was born in 1915. As a young man he experienced acutely the economic privation of the Great Depression and emerged from that experience with a strong commitment to community and to social and economic justice. Deeply engaged in civic life, he served as Chair of the Mt. Vernon Zoning Board of Appeals, and was Associate Judge and then City Court Judge for the City of Mt. Vernon from 1978 through 1985. He served as President of the Emanuel Jewish Center, President of the Mt. Vernon Jewish Community Council, President of the Westchester Day School, President of the Westchester Jewish Conference, President of the Mt. Vernon High School P.T.A. and Vice-President of its Scholarship Fund, member of the Boards of Directors of the Beth El Center and the Mt. Vernon YMYWHA. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, he served as a Captain during World War II and was a founding partner of the firm Kurzman, Eisenberg, Corbin & Lever. He served his clients with wisdom, gentleness and affability. And he extended similar respect to all who came before him on the bench as he presided with the gravity appropriate to the circumstances leavened, at lighter moments, by a twinkle of humor. Predeceased by his wife Anne, he leaves his children Arthur, Carol and Deborah; their spouses Susan, Richard and Joel; grandchildren Adam, Evan, Ethan, Dani and Ari; great-grand children, Harry and Annabel; and many happy memories of family dinners, holidays and trips. Funeral services: Monday at 10am, Temple Beth-El, New Rochelle, NY.

EBER--Jack, 91 years old, died peacefully on September 5, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn. Devoted and loving father of Henry and Stuart. He was a member of the Civil Lodge. Services Tuesday 12 noon at Riverside Nassau North Chapels; 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR); Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

BENDER--Andrew Lee,Passed away September 5, 2013. He was my brother and my children's uncle. A person of unique intellect and questioning mind which enabled him to excel as a physician. One of the first to recognize the possibilities of the computer and applications in medical analysis. Devoted to his children, Rachel and Deborah, their late mother, Elaine and his current wife, Janet. A true connoisseur of classical music, his wide ranging interest provided me with the broad spectrum of my own musical exposure. I miss him and will continue to miss him. Liebwohl, Iiebwohl! Susan Bender, Eve Blumstein Zibel, Zachary Blumstein
