MCKEON--Robert B. 8/6/1954 - 9/10/2012 The wisdom and grace of your irreplaceable spirit is always with us. Your loving family
DUNN--Oscar L.,1914-2006. With Oscar's spirit remember your high school band, support "C" students, then go fishing with a friend after mixed doubles. "Back home again in Indiana..." Alex
BEDDARD--Anita. We love, honor and remember you, not only today, but always. Devon, Fred and Michael

TORRANCE--Donna. December 17, 1949 - September 09, 2013. Eight Communications expresses our profound sympathy to the family and friends of our beloved founder and president, Donna Torrance at her passing. We extend our condolences to Tom Jaffe, her life long partner, her niece Caprice and her Goddaughter, Elizabeth. Donna was a great leader, friend and mentor whose passion for art and design was surpassed only by her love for helping those in need. She was a kind soul who inspired those she met with her energy and optimism. Her spirit will remain in our hearts and studio forever. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Donna Torrance MSKCC Giving Page at www.mskcc.org. A private memorial service will be held in the coming weeks.
TORRANCE--Donna. My beautiful Friend and Sister in spirit-your love will stay with me forever. Roe

TORRANCE--Donna. The wholehearted being of Donna, her love, care, generosity, superb mind, humor, curiosity, special touch with people and openness to all things human, will be sorely missed. The huge gifts she has given will keep on nourishing us. We extend our deepest condolences to her loving Tom. Alex and Giselle

TORRANCEDonna. December 17, 1949 - September 09, 2013. My darling Donna. You have been the love of my life for our 20 years together. You have lived every minute with grace and beauty. Your optimism and wisdom never ceased to inspire me. Your sense of humor was beyond compare. For me, you were magic. I am a lucky man to have shared art and travel and all our friends and experiences with you. Your heart will live in my heart forever. Your Tom.

SZER--Wlodzimierz, 89, died August 31 in San Diego, CA. Born in Warsaw, Poland, he escaped to Russia when WWII began. An artillery officer, wounded by the Nazis, he became a Colonel in the Polish Army. He left service at 32, earned his PhD in biochemistry at 35, and joined NYU School of Medicine faculty in 1968. He published 160 scientific papers and taught generations of PhD candidates and medical students. An avid chess player and student of history, art and music, he spoke several languages, loved good food, family and friends, delighted in sharing knowledge and jokes. He is survived by Karina Rothzeid, Dr. Ilona Szer, five grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Donations to NYU Medical School are welcome.

RUBENSTEIN--Melvin. Born April 2, 1929, died September 8, 2013. Mel was a loving husband to Shirley for 62 years, devoted father to Alan and Eric, and father-in-law to Kirby; beloved grandfather of Cale and Will. A US Army veteran, he graduated from NYU and continued his professional studies at Dartmouth. He achieved prominence in his career in finance as president of his national trade association. Mel volunteered for many charities and, being a theatre buff, he served as financial advisor to the Actors Studio. He will be remembered for his love of family, generosity, and great sense of humor.

MAYER--Dr. Lloyd. As do all centers of inflammatory bowel diseases, we at Lenox Hill Hospital mourn the death of Dr. Lloyd Mayer. He was a brilliant scientist and discoverer of immunological mechanisms leading to better understanding and treatment of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. His extended professional family shares this great loss with Jill, their children and all of his relatives and friends who loved him. Gregory B. Haber MD Chief of Gastroenterology at LHH Burton I. Korelitz MD Chief Emeritus of Gastroenterology at LHH David H. Robbins MD Program Director, Division of Gastroenterology at LHH
MAYER--Dr. Lloyd. Our hearts shattered. Our world changed. We will love and miss you forever. The Mayer family
LOEWENGART--Marten. You were a very special part of our lives and will be in our hearts forever. Carolyne and Ed Levy

LERNER--Evelyn, passed away on September 8, 2013 at the age of 93. Devoted and loving wife of the late Jack Newton Lerner, Esq; mother of Iris and Richard (Ana); grandmother of Jennifer (Jofie) and Adam (Rand); siblings Cyrus (Gail) and Lila. Service private. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery.

LAMONT--LANSING. The Trustees and community of the American Museum of Natural History are saddened by the death of Lansing Lamont, Trustee and Honorary Trustee for over three decades. An acclaimed journalist and author, he brought keen intelligence and passionate support to the Museum and its Library, notably continuing his family's longstanding support of the Museum's ornithology research and collections. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife, Ada, and the entire Lamont family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President

LAZAR--Rose. 98, of Margate, FL, formerly of Spring Valley, NY. Predeceased by Jules, father to Dr. Stephen (Marlene) of New City, NY, and predeceased daughter Barbara Ann Meyerson (Larry). Four grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, aunt and great-aunt. Funeral in Florida. No shiva due to holiday tradition. A really great lady.

LAMONT--Lansing. Died September 3, 2013 in New York City, NY. Beloved husband of Ada Jung Lamont. Author, journalist, public affairs executive, trustee. Born March 13, 1930 in New York City. Educated at Milton Academy, Harvard College (A.B.), Columbia Graduate School of Journalism (M.S.). Served in U.S. Army Infantry to 1st Lt. Reporter, Washington D.C. Star, then a Washington and foreign correspondent for TIME Magazine 1961-75. In the 1980s he was Vice-President of the Americas Society and directed its Canadian Affairs program, widely recognized as the country's preeminent public forum addressing Canadian-American issues. At the time of his death he was Chairman of the American Trust for the British Library. Author and editor of seven books, including, Day of Trinity (1965), the best-selling narrative history of the first atomic bomb test. His third book Breakup (1994) was cited by The New York Times as one of the year's most notable books. Longtime trustee and Honorary trustee, American Museum of Natural History; also Milton Academy. William Cullen Bryant Fellow, Metropolitan Museum of Art. Member, Council on Foreign Relations; Carnegie Council; Century Association; Harvard Club of New York City. Avid birder, sailor, skier and jazz pianist. He leaves his devoted wife of 59 years and four children, Douglas Lamont of Dover, MA; Elisabeth Wolcott of Hamilton, MA; Virginia Cazedessus of Lake Arenal, Costa Rica; and Thomas Lamont II of Groton, MA; a brother, Edward Lamont, of Syosset, NY; a sister, Elinor Hallowell of Tucson, AZ; and twelve grandchildren. Service at St. James Church 865 Madison Avenue on Monday, September 16, 2013 at 2:30pm.

KOPLOW--Ellen. AMIT mourns the loss of our dear friend, Ellen Koplow, Board member, past officer, longtime leader, benefactor, and volunteer extraordinaire. She was not only a wonderful partner to her husband, Meyer, mother to children Michael (Tova), Jonathan (Jen), Aliza (fiance, Josh) and beloved grandmother, but also a consistent voice of down to earth wisdom and advice to AMIT. Ellen was truly passionate about our work, seeing our accomplishments through the eyes of the children we support. She established, through the Harvey Goodstein Foundation the Harvey Goodstein Sports Complex in our youth village in Ra'anana, Israel. Ellen's can-do attitude and kindness to everyone will be sorely missed. May her memory be a blessing for us all.

KOPLOW--Ellen. SAR Academy/ SAR High School is deeply saddened by the passing of Ellen Koplow, beloved wife of Meyer Koplow, Board member and benefactor of SAR, mother of Michael, Jonathan and Aliza (SAR alumni). May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President

JOHNSEN--Millicent M.,age 90 of Rumson, NJ on Saturday, September 7th; beloved wife of Niels W.; loved mother to Niels M., Ingrid J. Barrett and Gretchen J. Moyer; adored grandmother and great-grandmother and beloved sister of Douglas D. Mercer and Henry D. Mercer, Jr. Visitation will be held on Wednesday, September 11th, 4-7pm at the Thompson Memorial Home, 310 Broad St., Red Bank. A funeral service will be celebrated on Thursday, September 12th, 2pm at the Elberon Memorial Church, 70 Park Avenue, Elberon, NJ. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial donations be made in her memory to The Horticultural Society of New York, 148 W. 37th St., New York, NY 10018 or Twin Lights Historical Society, Twin Lights Historic Site, Lighthouse Road, Highlands, NJ 07732.

HORNIG--Jerome, died September 8, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Judith, loving father of George and Mady, treasured mother-in-law of Joan and devoted grandfather of Rusty, Julia and her husband David, Jessica and Max. Services will be held on Wednesday, September 11, 2013 at 11:30am at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory may be made to Jazz at Lincoln Center (jalc.org).

GOLDSTONE--Jonas M.,MD. The entire St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center (SLR) family acknowledges with sadness the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Jonas M. Goldstone, MD, who served with great distinction on the medical staff at SLR for many years, providing outstanding care to our patients and serving as a role model for several generations of physicians in training. Dr. Goldstone was recognized for his particular expertise in Hematology/Oncology and served as Chief of Oncology from 1976 to 1992. In addition, he represented the institution with numerous medical societies on city, state and national levels. Dr. Goldstone also gave considerably of his personal time to SLR, serving for many years on SLR's Medical Board, including a term as President. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him and worked with him. To his family, friends and all of his loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Frank J. Cracolici President, SLR Gae Rodke, MD President, Medical Board Bruce Polsky, MD Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Michael Grossbard, MD Chief of Hematology/Oncology
FELDMAN--Benjamin P. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

FELDMAN--Benjamin P.,age 89, on September 8, 2013. Veteran of WWII, graduate of Syracuse University, former President of Rand cleaners, former Partner of Jeeves cleaners, consultant to Victor Kramer Co until his last illness; former president of Congregation Beth Elohim, former Trustee of U.RJ. Survived by his wife Iris Kellner Feldman, daughter Renee Grandin (Steve), son Steve Feldman (Donna), step-daughter Carol Cataldo (Jim) and Ruth Pomerance, nine grandchildren and one great- granddaughter, sisters Lois Shapiro (Jack) and Ellen Dnofrio (Dick). Visiting hours will be held at Frank E. Campbell 81st St. and Madison Ave. on Wednesday September 11 from 6:30pm to 8:30pm where the funeral will take place Thursday morning, September 12 at 11am.

EISENBERG--Sam. Dad was born in 1915. As a young man he experienced acutely the economic privation of the Great Depression and emerged from that experience with a strong commitment to community and to social and economic justice. Deeply engaged in civic life, he served as Chair of the Mt. Vernon Zoning Board of Appeals, and was Associate Judge and then City Court Judge for the City of Mt. Vernon from 1978 through 1985. He served as President of the Emanuel Jewish Center, President of the Mt. Vernon Jewish Community Council, President of the Westchester Day School, President of the Westchester Jewish Conference, President of the Mt. Vernon High School P.T.A. and Vice-President of its Scholarship Fund, member of the Boards of Directors of the Beth El Center and the Mt. Vernon YMYWHA. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, he served as a Captain during World War II and was a founding partner of the firm Kurzman, Eisenberg, Corbin & Lever. He served his clients with wisdom, gentleness and affability. And he extended similar respect to all who came before him on the bench as he presided with the gravity appropriate to the circumstances leavened, at lighter moments, by a twinkle of humor. Predeceased by his wife Anne, he leaves his children Arthur, Carol and Deborah; their spouses Susan, Richard and Joel; grandchildren Adam, Evan, Erica, Ethan, Dani and Ari; great-grand children, Harry and Annabel; and many happy memories of family dinners, holidays and trips.

EBER--Jack, 91 years old, died peacefully on September 5, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn. Devoted and loving father of Henry and Stuart. He was a member of the Seville Lodge. Services Tuesday 12 noon at Riverside Nassau North Chapels; 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR); Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

BROWN--Michael K. (1953-2013). Curator, Bayou Bend Collection & Gardens, The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. The world of American Decorative Arts deeply mourns the untimely loss of a remarkable friend, colleague, art historian, author and curator extraordinaire. Michael's professional life was dedicated to Bayou Bend and, among many accomplishments, he co-authored and co-curated the exhibition Duncan Phyfe: Master Cabinet Maker in New York, shown at The Metropolitan Museum of Art in 2012. Michael was always proud of his Lowville, New York family background, and helped to discover, identify and assemble collections of related art and objects for the Lewis County Historical Society. Knowledgeable, generous, sympathetic, and possessed of a wonderful, twinkling sense of humor, Michael was himself one-of-a-kind, with no imitations possible or copies extant. Deepest sympathy is extended to his partner Bart, his brothers and family, as well as to legions of friends and colleagues across the country who are now utterly devastated that he is lost to us. Martha J. Fleischman

BROWN--Michael K. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, and Bayou Bend Collection and Gardens convey their profound sadness at the passing of Michael K. Brown, longtime curator of the Bayou Bend Collection. Michael was an exemplary curator, known for his passion and keen connoisseurship, and a remarkable individual whose grace and gentility touched everyone he encountered. Our sincere condolences to Michael's family, to his many friends and colleagues, and to Bart Truxillo. The Museum will hold a memorial for Michael in October. The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston

BOLAND--William T. Jr.,84, died peacefully in his sleep after a short illness. Bill was born and grew up in Elmira, NY. He is survived by his loving wife of 55 years, Patricia Krouse Boland. Survived also by his daughter Elizabeth Krugman and son-in-law Jon of Reading, MA, son, William T. Boland III, and daughter-in-law, Leighann of Richmond, VA, and Charles of New York City. Lovingly remembered by his five grandsons Alex, Zack, William IV, Robert Gray and Thomas. Bill graduated from Phillips Exeter and received his BA degree from The University of Virginia. After serving several years in the U.S. Army, he returned to UVA Law School where he received his J.D. Upon graduation, Bill joined the New York Intellectual Property Firm, Kenyon and Kenyon and retired in 2000 after 42 years of loyal and distinguished service. Bill enjoyed travelling with family and friends, particularly the biking trips. He will be remembered for his generosity, kindness to all and especially his subtle humor. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Central Park Conservancy or The New York Public Library. The family will hold a private service at Woodlawn Cemetery in Elmira, NY and a memorial service will be held in New York City at a later date.
ANGEL--Rita. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to her family. David J. Nathan, Parnas

ANGEL--Rita. We are very saddened by the news that Rita Angel, wife of our esteemed and beloved Counsel and friend, Josh Angel, has passed away. Rita and Josh were sweethearts from the moment they met, right up to yesterday. Only because of the love and devotion that Josh, and Nicole and Spencer (Josh and Rita's wonderful children), showered upon Rita 24/7 these past many months was Rita able to live and enjoy her family for as long as she did. We express our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to Josh, to Nicole and David and their children, Michael and Matthew, to Spencer and Alexis and their children, Sophia and Joshua, and to the other members of Rita's and Josh's extended family. Herrick, Feinstein LLP
ANGEL--Rita. Rita lived a beautiful life and inspired others. She will be greatly missed. Herb and Sandi Feinberg

ANGEL--Rita (nee Altchek), September 18, 1938, passed away September 9, 2013. My wife Rita was the youngest child of Solomon and Blanche Altchek. Thus the origin of the sobriquets "Baby Rita" and "Rita Babe" to which she answered throughout her life. She was the much loved sister of her physician brothers Albert Altchek, and Martin Altchek. The adored, beloved, beatified mother and mother-in-law of Nicole Wachter, and her husband David; Spencer Angel and his wife Alexis. The doting grandmother of Michael and Matthew Wachter, and Sophia and Joshua Angel. For 52 years, no matter how gloomy the immediate circumstances she brought a smile to my heart, and taught me to appreciate life. She was my most trusted, and wisest business partner, my best friend, and the constant and eternal love of my life. Our families had similar European origination backgrounds, and were friends. We however, were not, and our initial meeting was by chance, and totally serendipitous. That meeting resulting in my immediate falling madly in love with Hunter College's most beautiful and luminous graduate of any year. Rita was not similarly smitten, and over the next two years she skillfully evaded my successive proposals of marriage. Her hesitation in the marriage department probably emanated from my combined lack of dance skills, mediocre career prospects, and general boorishness. I suspect that her reluctance to say yes was overcome only after her father, clearly tired of my mooning around, ordained that she had wasted enough time on me, and should either move on, or marry the dope. In those years women listened to their fathers, and thus we married on July 4, 1963. Over the next 50 years we were extremely fortunate in raising two exceptional and wonderful children as we prospered, and enjoyed a storybook family life and marriage. My only regret in that regard being the present certainty of no more storybook years to come. She was the kindest and most caring person I have ever known. Totally devoid of any kind of malice or guile Rita throughout her life was uniquely possessed of an infectious schoolgirl naivety, and charm. Blessed with an artless, ingenuous, and eternally youthful persona she was amazingly intelligent, caring, selfless, and the most beautiful person imaginable. Rita's single most endearing quality was her ability to transmit her unique flair for life to all who knew her. Destined to expire on the floor of a Manhattan disco, or the slopes of Saint Moritz, Rita was instead fickle fated by a return visit from cancer two years ago. The disease, which she had vanquished over thirty years ago, returned this time in diabolic form, and was ultimately lethal. Despite heroic effort of dedicated teams of Mount Sinai Hospital associates, Zoya her home care provider, the overall extraordinary loving supervision of our daughter Nicole, and Rita's natural combativeness, it was the disease, rather than the defenders who dictated the story's end. For Rita and Josh all that now remains is in the words of a World War II song - "I'll never smile again until I smile at you." Our Jewish mythology has man and woman as a single soul, separated at birth, rejoined in marriage and ultimately re-united in death. Who knows, and if perchance there is a remelding of souls to be had in a life after life, so to speak, then I'm all for it. Goodbye my love, and thank you for having given my life its substance and meaning. For me our romance will never be finished, and should our souls chance to remeld I promise next time to be more amusing, and a better dance partner. Service at Riverside Memorial, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Tuesday, September 10 at 11:45am. Remembrances to The Pancreas Center, New York Presbyterian Hospital Columbia University, 161 Fort Washington Avenue, New York, NY 10032.Joshua Angel

TORRANCE--Donna. The lawyers and staff of Stern Tannenbaum & Bell extend our deepest condolences to our client and dear friend Tom Jaffe on the passing of his beloved life partner, Donna Torrance. We were privileged to know Donna as a client, advisor and friend; she was a woman of great warmth, talent, energy and optimism. We, too, will miss her terribly.

SAARI--Dr. Margaret M.,DVM. Manhattan was the adopted home of veterinarian Marge Saari, who died at Mount Sinai Hospital on August 4 at age 74. Born in small-town Wisconsin, higher educated at the UW-Madison and UC-Davis, she arrived in New York City in 1972 and never left. For 25 years she was a small animal vet at the animal hospital of the ASPCA. She never made much money working for a non-profit; rent control enabled her to live in a small apartment on Second Avenue. She added to the professional expertise concentrated in this city. For 60 years she compiled records on top producers and show dogs among Cocker Spaniels, her favorite breed. The American Spaniel Club inducted her into its Hall of Fame in 2011. To the unaware, she may have appeared as just another old woman with a crutch laboring along the streets and stairs of New York; to us who knew her, she was a gem of kindness, both to animals and people. She leaves behind a grieving sister (Jo Face of Taos, NM) and brother and sister-in-law (Jon and Christine Saari of Marquette, MI). A private burial of her ashes will take place in late September in Wausau, WI.

RUBENSTEIN--Melvin. Born April 2, 1929, died September 8, 2013. Mel was a loving husband to Shirley for 62 years, devoted father to Alan and Eric, and father-in-law to Kirby; beloved grandfather of Cale and Will. A US Army veteran, he graduated from NYU and continued his professional studies at Dartmouth. He achieved prominence in his career in finance as president of his national trade association. Mel volunteered for many charities and, being a theatre buff, he served as financial advisor to the Actors Studio. He will be remembered for his love of family, generosity, and great sense of humor.

PULLEN--Irene, passed away on September 6th. For 38 years she was the loving spouse of Phil Pullen who died two years ago. She will be sorely missed by her Monday lunch buddies, Emily, Judy and Reba, who valued her warmth, intelligence and sensitivity.

O'BRIEN--Donal C. The National Audubon Society mourns the passing of Donal C. O'Brien, Jr., who was a visionary conservation leader and a driving force at Audubon for a generation. His passion, leadership, keen eye, steady hand and mentoring spirit have inspired many and will be deeply missed. Our hearts and deepest condolences go to Donal's beloved wife, Katie, their family, and all those whose lives he touched. David Yarnold, President and CEO; B. Holt Thrasher, Chairman

NELSON--Gloria Seltzer, passed away peacefully on September 6, 2013. She was born in Brooklyn, NY on July 15, 1922, graduated from Madison High School and Syracuse University. She married Dr. Irving Nelson on April 20, 1947 and they had a wonderful partnership for more than 60 years. She committed herself to raising their family and to helping maintain her husband's thriving practice as a pediatrician. She is survived by her devoted children Francine (Murray Grossman) and Mitchell (Leslie) Nelson. She was the adored "Nanny" to her five loving grandchildren, Joshua and Scott Grossman and Jeffrey, Kate, and Thomas Nelson. The service was private.
LOEWENGART--Marten. You were a very special part of our lives and will be in our hearts forever. Carolyne and Ed Levy

LAWRENCE--Dr. Bessie. The leadership, staff, and worldwide community of the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of our beloved friend, Dr. Bessie Lawrence. Bessie was an indefatigable advocate of science education. She served on the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science's Midwest Regional Board of Directors and National Board of Directors. In 1969, Bessie established the Dr. Bessie F. Lawrence International Summer Science Institute at Weizmann to advance scientific knowledge among young people. The renowned program enables some 70 gifted recent high-school graduates from around the world to study at the Institute every year. Alumni of the International Summer Science Institute can be found in the most prestigious academic institutions and in prominent positions in the private sector. Bessie's passion for science and learning continues to help build the next generation of researchers. Her generous and inquisitive spirit will always be remembered. We extend heartfelt condolences to her children, Michael and Karen; to her grandchildren, Tony and Cindy; to her great-grandchildren, Julia, Jacob, Eden, and Laney; and to the entire family. May Bessie's memory be for a blessing. Lawrence S. Blumberg, Chairman, American Committee; Pennie Abramson, President, American Committee; Marshall S. Levin, Executive V.P. and C.E.O., American Committee; Mandy Moross, Chair, Weizmann Institute; Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President, Weizmann Institute.

KIMMELFIELD--Arthur L.,died peacefully at the Amsterdam Nursing Home on September 8, 2013, after a brief illness. Arthur was the beloved husband of Marilyn Braveman and will be remembered with love and admiration as father to Robert and Neil, step-father to Lynn Bravewomon and Wayne Braveman, brother to Carolyn Balleisen, grandfather to Bruce, Isabel, Josh, Leon, Rebecca, Rosie, and Sam, father-in-law to Annie, Helen, and Margaret, and uncle to Edward, Ellen, and Wendy. Arthur, your family and many friends salute you for a life of integrity, compassion, and love. You will be deeply missed. Private family memorial service.

LAUDY--Mary Louise (Corrigan), died peacefully on September 6, 2013. She was 82 years old. She is survived by her son Mark, daughter-in-law Janet, grandchildren Kate and Sam, brother Michael, sisters-in-law Sybil and Barbara, and nieces Cathy and Michele. Mrs. Laudy was born in New Bedford, MA, on June 17, 1931, to Edmund and Helen (Miller) Corrigan. She attended Colby College and received a nursing degree from Cornell in 1954. She lived in San Francisco in the 1950s before joining the Visiting Nurse Service in New York. She lived for many years in Westchester County, where she raised her family, worked as a volunteer librarian and was an active member of the Whippoorwill Club. Her interests included reading, cats, golf, and friends and family. She will be remembered for her great intellect and her warm heart, her quirky ways and infectious laugh. Funeral services will be held at 10:30 am Saturday at Coffey Funeral Home, 91 North Broadway in Tarrytown. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

JOHNSEN--Millicent Mercer, The officers and directors of the Garden Club of America express deep sorrow on the death of their former president Millicent Mercer Johnsen and extend their deepest sympathy to her husband Niels, W., and her family and friends. She served the Garden Club of America with great distinction, inspiration and extraordinary ability as its 25th president (1983-1985) and in many other capacities that began with her membership in the Rumson Garden Club. Prior to becoming president, she provided leadership at the national level that included serving as a director and as a member of the Finance and Policy Committees. She was a recipient of the organization's Medal of Merit and Creative Leadership Award. She will be remembered for her keen mind, her inclusive and generous spirit, her commitment to working for the greater good of the organization and above all, for her warm and gracious manner. She was an inspiration to all who knew her throughout her life.

JOHNSEN--Millicent M.,age 90 of Rumson, NJ on Saturday, September 7th; beloved wife of Niels W.; loved mother to Niels M., Ingrid J. Barrett and Gretchen J. Moyer; adored grandmother and great-grandmother and beloved sister of Douglas D. Mercer and Henry D. Mercer, Jr. Visitation will be held on Wednesday, September 11th, 4-7pm at the Thompson Memorial Home, 310 Broad St., Red Bank. A funeral service will be celebrated on Thursday, September 12th, 2pm at the Elberon Memorial Church, 70 Park Avenue, Elberon, NJ. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial donations be made in her memory to The Horticultural Society of New York, 148 W. 37th St., New York, NY 10018 or Twin Lights Historical Society, Twin Lights Historic Site, Lighthouse Road, Highlands, NJ 07732.

GOLDSTONE--Jonas, The members of the Division of Hematology and Medical Oncology at Lenox Hill Hospital mourn the passing of Jonas Goldstone, MD. Dr. Goldstone was a brilliant physician, gifted educator and role model for countless students, residents and other professionals over many decades of his career. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Joan, and the entire family. Nathaniel Wisch, MD Division Cheif, Hemotology/Oncology Colette Spaccavento, MD Program Director, Division of Hemotology/Oncology

GOLDSTONE--Jonas. The New York State Society of Medical Oncologists and Hematologists mourn the loss of our long time board-member, Dr. Jonas M Goldstone, a superb and caring physician. His keen intellect and wise counsel will be sorely missed. Abraham Mittelman, MD, President Edward Ambinder, MD, Past President Richard A Silver, MD, Past President Seymour M Cohen, MD, Past President

GHIGGERI--Marietta. Born in 1927 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, the eldest of four children. She returned to her eternal home on September 5, 2013, at Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan, where she resided for more than a year. Marietta was a devoted Catholic, who generously served the Church and its community, particularly, St. John's the Capuchin Church, Our Lady of Pompeii and Mary Manning Walsh Home. At her bedside were her daughter, son-in-law and her dedicated friend of many years. In addition to the loved ones already mentioned, she is survived by her brother, step-daughter and many step-grand and step-great-grand children, nieces, and nephews. The viewing will be at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home on Thursday evening 5pm - 8pm, and a Mass said at Our Lady of Pompeii Church Friday 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations in Marietta's name to Mary Manning Walsh Home would be appreciated.

GARFINKEL--Burton, MD, 83, died September 10 at home. Survived by his beloved wife Eleanore of 59 years. Brother of Irwin and the late Rubin. Extraordinary father of Richard (Lisa), Joanne Grazi (Victor) and Steven (Wendy). Proud grandfather of Sam (Jaclyn), Carrie, Paulette Cohen (Joseph), Simone Hidary (Abe), Maurice, Jason and Jordan. Loving great-grandfather of Sam Cohen. Burt was a graduate of the University of Buffalo and the Chicago Medical School where he later became a member of the Board of Trustees. He was a dedicated physician with a distinguished career in OB/GYN. Burt was also noted for his wit. He served his country in the Air Force and over the years he established long lasting friendships with many. He will be missed. Funeral services 10am, September 11, Nassau North Chapel in Great Neck.

FELDMAN--Benjamin. The Board, clergy, staff and members of Congregation Beth Elohim mourn the loss of Benjamin Feldman, our esteemed and revered past president. Under his leadership, with his love of life, strength of spirit, wisdom and counsel, deep love of Judaism and Jewish life, he enabled our synagogue to grow in meaningful directions and made important contributions as a Trustee to the URJ/ UAHC. Our deepest condolences to his beloved wife, Iris, and to the entire family. May he be remembered by all the people he touched throughout his life. Charles Nathan, President Andy Bachman, Senior Rabbi Gerald I. Weider, Rabbi Emeritus

FELDMAN--Benjamin P.,age 89, on September 8, 2013. Veteran of WWII, graduate of Syracuse University, former President of Rand cleaners, former Partner of Jeeves cleaners, consultant to Victor Kramer Co until his last illness; former president of Congregation Beth Elohim, former Trustee of U.RJ. Survived by his wife Iris Kellner Feldman, daughter Renee Grandin (Steve), son Steve Feldman (Donna), step-daughter Carol Cataldo (Jim) and Ruth Pomerance, nine grandchildren and one great- granddaughter, sisters Lois Shapiro (Jack) and Ellen Dnofrio (Dick). Visiting hours will be held at Frank E. Campbell 81st St. and Madison Ave. on Wednesday September 11 from 6:30pm to 8:30pm where the funeral will take place Thursday morning, September 12 at 11am.

FELDER--Marvin, 97, passed away on Sunday, September 8th. A native New Yorker, Marvin proudly served his country in World War II as a First Lieutenant in the United States Army Air Corps. Afterwards, he headed up the family leather goods business founded in 1902 by his father. A longtime resident of New Jersey, Marvin immersed himself in a wide range of activities coupled with a continuing quest for knowledge throughout his life. He was a member of the same book club for over 40 years, was a masterful chess player, an avid follower of current events and world affairs, and an active and longtime congregant of Temple Sinai of Bergen County. He passionately loved music, and always relished his role as a proud and appreciative audience during the many recitals and musical soirees given by his family and musician friends. Survived by his devoted wife of 66 years, Sara, children Joan and Mitchell, daughter-in-law Susan, grandsons Justin and Sam, and brother Kenneth. Donations may be made to a favorite charity.
BLACK--Page Morton. A celebration of her life will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., on Thursday, September 12, 2013 at 3:30pm.
ANGEL--Rita. Our Family mourns the passing of the beloved mother, mother- in-law and grandmother of our dear friends Nicole, David, Michael and Matthew Wachter. Lisa, Gregg and Wylie Rechler

BAER--Bertina, 85, passed away peacefully on July 22nd in Greenport, NY. Last surviving child of the late inventor, publisher and ''father of science fiction'' Hugo Gernsback. Bertina was a strong, beautiful and brilliant woman who will always be remembered as a loving mother, devoted wife, cherished friend and caring psychotherapist. She is survived by her husband Theodore, sons Andrew and Nolan, daughter-in-law Colleen Griffin and nephews Jeffrey and Barry Neichen. A memorial service will be held in Manhattan on October 19th. For information please call (212) 397-4822.

ANGEL--Rita (nee Altchek), September 18, 1938, passed away September 9, 2013. My wife Rita was the youngest child of Solomon and Blanche Altchek. Thus the origin of the sobriquets "Baby Rita" and "Rita Babe" to which she answered throughout her life. She was the much loved sister of her physician brothers Albert Altchek, and Martin Altchek. The adored, beloved, beatified mother and mother-in-law of Nicole Wachter, and her husband David; Spencer Angel and his wife Alexis. The doting grandmother of Michael and Matthew Wachter, and Sophia and Joshua Angel. For 52 years, no matter how gloomy the immediate circumstances she brought a smile to my heart, and taught me to appreciate life. She was my most trusted, and wisest business partner, my best friend, and the constant and eternal love of my life. Our families had similar European origination backgrounds, and were friends. We however, were not, and our initial meeting was by chance, and totally serendipitous. That meeting resulting in my immediate falling madly in love with Hunter College's most beautiful and luminous graduate of any year. Rita was not similarly smitten, and over the next two years she skillfully evaded my successive proposals of marriage. Her hesitation in the marriage department probably emanated from my combined lack of dance skills, mediocre career prospects, and general boorishness. I suspect that her reluctance to say yes was overcome only after her father, clearly tired of my mooning around, ordained that she had wasted enough time on me, and should either move on, or marry the dope. In those years women listened to their fathers, and thus we married on July 4, 1963. Over the next 50 years we were extremely fortunate in raising two exceptional and wonderful children as we prospered, and enjoyed a storybook family life and marriage. My only regret in that regard being the present certainty of no more storybook years to come. She was the kindest and most caring person I have ever known. Totally devoid of any kind of malice or guile Rita throughout her life was uniquely possessed of an infectious schoolgirl naivety, and charm. Blessed with an artless, ingenuous, and eternally youthful persona she was amazingly intelligent, caring, selfless, and the most beautiful person imaginable. Rita's single most endearing quality was her ability to transmit her unique flair for life to all who knew her. Destined to expire on the floor of a Manhattan disco, or the slopes of Saint Moritz, Rita was instead fickle fated by a return visit from cancer two years ago. The disease, which she had vanquished over thirty years ago, returned this time in diabolic form, and was ultimately lethal. Despite heroic effort of dedicated teams of Mount Sinai Hospital associates, Zoya her home care provider, the overall extraordinary loving supervision of our daughter Nicole, and Rita's natural combativeness, it was the disease, rather than the defenders who dictated the story's end. For Rita and Josh all that now remains is in the words of a World War II song - "I'll never smile again until I smile at you." Our Jewish mythology has man and woman as a single soul, separated at birth, rejoined in marriage and ultimately re-united in death. Who knows, and if perchance there is a remelding of souls to be had in a life after life, so to speak, then I'm all for it. Goodbye my love, and thank you for having given my life its substance and meaning. For me our romance will never be finished, and should our souls chance to remeld I promise next time to be more amusing, and a better dance partner. Service at Riverside Memorial, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Tuesday, September 10 at 11:45am. Remembrances to The Pancreas Center, New York Presbyterian Hospital Columbia University, 161 Fort Washington Avenue, New York, NY 10032.Joshua Angel

YORAN--Shalom. The Board of Directors and staff of American Friends of Tel Aviv University mourn the passing of our cherished friend and Board member Shalom Yoran. Mr. Yoran was a member of the American Friends Board for more than 25 years. In 1997, he received the Fund for Higher Education "Flame of Truth" award for his lifetime achievements in defiance of the perpetrators of the Holocaust; a year later, he received an Honorary Doctorate of Philosophy. Mr. Yoran cast a giant shadow for all his 89 years. He was born in Warsaw in 1925. When the Nazis killed his father and mother in 1942, he and his brother Musio fought as partisans against the Germans. Mr. Yoran moved to Israel; served in the Israel Air Force; and spent 22 years helping to build Israel Aerospace Industries into an internationally recognized company. His memoir, The Defiant A True Story of Escape, Survival & Resistance was published in 1996 and Manhattan Borough Ruth Messinger proclaimed September 12th, 1996, as "Shalom Yoran Day." We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Varda, their daughters Yaelle and Dafna, sons-in-law and grandchildren. American Friends of Tel Aviv University. Jon Gurkoff, Chairman Gail Reiss, President & CEO

TORRANCE--Donna. December 17, 1949 - September 09, 2013. Eight Communications expresses our profound sympathy to the family and friends of our beloved founder and president, Donna Torrance at her passing. We extend our condolences to Tom Jaffe, her life long partner, her niece Caprice and her Goddaughter, Elizabeth. Donna was a great leader, friend and mentor whose passion for art and design was surpassed only by her love for helping those in need. She was a kind soul who inspired those she met with her energy and optimism. Her spirit will remain in our hearts and studio forever. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Donna Torrance MSKCC Giving Page at www.mskcc.org. A private memorial service will be held in the coming weeks.

TORRANCE--Donna. The wholehearted being of Donna, her love, care, generosity, superb mind, humor, curiosity, special touch with people and openness to all things human, will be sorely missed. The huge gifts she has given will keep on nourishing us. We extend our deepest condolences to her loving Tom. Alex and Giselle

TORRANCE--Donna. The lawyers and staff of Stern Tannenbaum & Bell extend our deepest condolences to our client and dear friend Tom Jaffe on the passing of his beloved life partner, Donna Torrance. We were privileged to know Donna as a client, advisor and friend; she was a woman of great warmth, talent, energy and optimism. We, too, will miss her terribly.

TORRANCEDonna. December 17, 1949 - September 09, 2013. My darling Donna. You have been the love of my life for our 20 years together. You have lived every minute with grace and beauty. Your optimism and wisdom never ceased to inspire me. Your sense of humor was beyond compare. For me, you were magic. I am a lucky man to have shared art and travel and all our friends and experiences with you. Your heart will live in my heart forever. Your Tom.

SEROTA--Randi Rimerman. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center community joins with the Board of Trustees and senior leadership of the hospital's parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with tremendous sadness the passing of Randi Rimerman Serota, beloved daughter of our dear friend, devoted colleague and generous benefactor, Ira S. Rimerman, a longtime member of the Continuum Board. Randi waged a valiant battle against cancer and died peacefully earlier this month. To Ira, his family and all of his daughter's loved ones, we extend our most heartfelt condolences. Steven Hochberg Chairman Continuum Board of Trustees Alan Mirken Chairman Beth Israel Board of Overseers Stanley Brezenoff President & CEO, Continuum Harris M. Nagler, MD President, Beth Israel

RABIN--Herbert Larry, on September 10, 2013. Beloved husband of Carole, loving father of Andrea and Richard Phillips, Julie and Erick Einhorn. Adored grandfather of Jason and Alexandra. We will all miss you.

MEYERSON--Bernice. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of a devoted member from its founding generation, a former trustee and WRJ president, and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Helene K. Gray, President Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor

LAUDY--Mary Louise (Corrigan), died peacefully on September 6, 2013. She was 82 years old. She is survived by her son Mark, daughter-in-law Janet, grandchildren Kate and Sam, brother Michael, sisters-in-law Sybil and Barbara, and nieces Cathy and Michele. Mrs. Laudy was born in New Bedford, MA, on June 17, 1931, to Edmund and Helen (Miller) Corrigan. She attended Colby College and received a nursing degree from Cornell in 1954. She lived in San Francisco in the 1950s before joining the Visiting Nurse Service in New York. She lived for many years in Westchester County, where she raised her family, worked as a volunteer librarian and was an active member of the Whippoorwill Club. Her interests included reading, cats, golf, and friends and family. She will be remembered for her great intellect and her warm heart, her quirky ways and infectious laugh. Funeral services will be held at 10:30 am Saturday at Coffey Funeral Home, 91 North Broadway in Tarrytown. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

KAHN--Stanley D.,Passed away on September 8, 2013 in Aptos, California. Born to Helen and Louis Kahn in Brooklyn, NY on July 31, 1931, graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in 1952. Beloved husband of Marilyn Miller Kahn from 1953 until her death in 1998. Active in many professional, community and philanthropic activities, president of the NY Electrical Contractors Association from 1977 to 1979 and mayor of Lawrence, NY from 1981 through 1988. He remained active on electrical code committees through the end of his life. Beloved friend to many, a man of unmatched integrity, an inspiration to all who knew him well, always humble and caring, most of all he was our beloved father, grandfather and father-in-law. We are grateful for his life and will miss him forever. Services September 12, 10am at Boulevard-Riverside in Hewlett, NY. Linda Kahn Ganz, Richard Kahn & Thomas Lutazi, Michael Ian Ganz

KAGWA--G. Winifred, on September 8, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Benjamin Hope Kagwa, MD. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home 352 East 87th St. NYC, Saturday September 14, at 8:30am followed by a Service at 10am. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Mustard Seed Communities, 29 Janes Avenue Medfield, MA 02052

JOHNSEN--Millicent. The Trustees, Advisors and Staff of the Horticultural Society of New York mourn the loss of our beloved longest-standing board member, Millicent Mercer Johnsen, an avid gardener and a guiding light in horticulture. She will be remembered for her leadership, generosity, keen intellect and bold spirit. She served as Chair of the Board and Chair of the Nominating Committee, and remained an active board member who continued to contribute her wisdom and support until just weeks before the end of her life. Through her words, actions and deeds she inspired many others, and we will miss her so very, very much. Our thoughts go out to her husband, Niels, and her family.

FLEISCHMAN--Grace S.,age 74. Born Brooklyn, NY January 6, 1939. Graduate of Brooklyn College, (BS Ed) (MS Ed) and New York Law School (JD). A warm, loving, caring person survived by husband of 56 years, Howard, sons Charles (Carol Evans) and Richard (Jessica), grandchildren Robby, Jane, Elan and Adin, nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grand- nephews. Predeceased by sister Adele Ditkoff. Every acquaintance became her friend. Grace ran a warm, friendly house where all were welcome. Services Friday, 10am at Community Synagogue, 150 Middle Neck Road, Port Washington, NY. Burial at Beth Moses Cemetery. Remembrances to Dorot, The Inn, Fisher House or a charity of your choice.

FARGUE--Dominique. The partners, associates, counsel and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of our former partner, current Of Counsel, friend and colleague, Dominique Fargue. We express our deepest sympathies to his wife Kristine Karsten, daughters Katherine and Sophie, sons Adrien and Paul and to all other members of the family.

DeMENASCE--Pierre, died peacefully at home on September 11th, at the age of 89. Pierre was a lifelong resident of New York City. Until a few years ago, he was an avid walker all over Manhattan. Also, he was a great fan of the old Hollywood movies, which he would view at the Museum of Modern Art and in his final years, on television at home. During the last three years, he was cared for beautifully by his devoted aide, Councillia Razack. He is also survived by his cousins, Eric Vincendon, Jacques Mawas, Fiona Ellison Coster and Beatrice Emir. As Pierre expressly requested, there will be no funeral service. Contributions in his memory may be made to Selfhelp Community Services, Inc. or Metropolitan Jewish Hospice.

COOLEY--Noah Bower, May 13, 1982- September 5, 2013. With profound sadness we mark the passing of our beloved Noah Bower Cooley. Noah graduated from the Allendale Columbia School, studied graphic design at Rochester Institute of Technology, and was a Graduate of the French Culinary Institute. Noah was a talented musician-- a violinist, drummer, dj, and creator of electronic music. He possessed a great wit and he kept those around him laughing and happy to be in his company. He planned someday to try his hand at stand up comedy. He discovered though, that his great passion was cooking. Noah was an outstanding Chef. He worked in some of the top kitchens in San Francisco, New York City and most recently in Orange County, California. It was there that he found the outlet for his creativity and attention to detail. Noah is survived by his parents Thomas and Patricia, his brothers Aaron and Joshua, sister Rikki, sister-in-law Hanh, and niece Lola-Rose, as well as numerous cousins and legions of friends. We all miss him desperately-- his wit, his laughter, his loving warmth, and most of all his company. You left us far too soon, dear Noah. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the name of Noah to the Center for Research on Addiction Disorders, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY.

CANTOR--Dr. Joshua. Members of the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine at the Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the loss of our colleague and friend, Dr. Joshua Cantor. He was brilliant, kind, confident, humble, sharp, funny, a leader, champion for people with Brain Injury, mentor, insatiably curious and eager to learn. As one of his patients said, "You just don't find all these things in one person." He will be so deeply missed by us all. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 15, 2013 at 2:30pm at Temple Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, New York, 11215. In lieu of flowers, his family requests that donations be made to the Joshua Cantor Trust Fund, c/o The Rehabilitation Medicine Department, 3 East 101st Street, New York, NY 10029. The fund will be used to provide continued support to Joshua's family. Kristjan T. Ragnarsson, MD Lucy G. Moses Professor and Chairman Wayne A. Gordon, Ph.D., Jack Nash Professor, and Vice Chair Department of Rehabilitation Medicine The Mount Sinai Medical Center

SEGRETO--John on July 24, 2013 after a prolonged illness. John was the author of "Cheesecake Madness" and "The Triskelion." Mr. Segreto was born July 19, 1930 in Brooklyn, to Mrs. Providenza Ventimiglia and Mr. Girolamo Segreto of Italy. He was a member of Epiphany R.C. Church in Manhattan where he lived for many years. He was preceded in death by his wife, Winifred Agres Segreto. John is survived by his son Paul and his wife Laureen of Spring, TX, grandchildren: Paul Segreto Jr. and his wife Erin, Kristen Segreto, Brad Segreto, Jennifer Lawson and her husband Michael, and great-grandchild, Michael; his daughter-like friend, Audrey Snyder of Charlottesville, VA; and brother Jack Segreto of Jupiter, FL. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 14th at 1:30pm at Calvary Hospital Hospice, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Calvary Hospital Hospice At Home Program or Epiphany Church, 239 East 21st St, New York, NY 10010.

PETHER--Penelope. We mourn the untimely loss of Penelope Pether, our former officer. A superb teacher, excellent scholar, activist and friend. The Law & Humanities Institute, Richard Weisberg (Pres.), Daniel Tritter (VP).

O'BRIEN--Donal C.,Jr. The Trustees of the Trust for Mutual Understanding (TMU) in New York mourn with deep sadness the passing of Don O'Brien, longtime attorney for the Rockefeller family and founding Trustee of TMU, an American foundation dedicated to cultural and environmental exchange with Russia and Central and Eastern Europe. A lifelong advocate for environmental conservation, Don was a leader in the creation of conservation policy in the United States and his voice will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Katie, and the O'Brien family. Barbara Lanciers, Director, Trust for Mutual Understanding

O'BRIEN--Donal C.,Jr. The Rockefeller family mourns the passing of Donal C. O'Brien, Jr., who managed the legal affairs of our family for many years. David Rockefeller

O'BRIEN--Donal Clare Jr.,who was the Rockefeller lawyer for five decades, died on September 8, 2013. He was 79 years old and lived in New Canaan, Connecticut, and Nantucket, Massachusetts. Mr. O'Brien had a life long interest in conservation and the environment and served on the board of a number of not-for-profit organizations; including the National Audubon Society, where he served as Chairman for 25 years and the Atlantic Salmon Federation, which he chaired for 11 years. Mr. O'Brien was a retired partner in the law firm Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, which he joined in 1959. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, September 18th at 11:00am in the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, 178 Oenoke Road, New Canaan, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the National Audubon Society for the Chair of Advocacy and Public Policy, the Atlantic Salmon Federation and The Quebec Labrador Foundation.

FLIGEL--Florence, formerly of New York City and now residing in Pompano Beach, FL, passed away on September 10, 2013 at the age of 96. Her interest in fashion led to a career as a sportswear buyer for Hartfield Zody's Associated and others. Florence was highly respected and honored in the fashion industry. She was awarded the Sportswear Industry Achievement Award by the Have A Heart Foundation Inc. for her work as a fundraiser and former president. Florence traveled all over the world for pleasure and business. She loved the arts, music and theatre. Florence is predeceased by her parents Louis and Esther Passman and sister Eleanor Ettinger. She will be greatly missed by her niece Emily Joy Ettinger of Encino, CA family and friends. She was the best aunt anyone would ever want. The burial will be on Tuesday, September 17, 2013 at 11am, at Mount Hope Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Donations can be made to The American Diabetes Association donations.diabetes.org or to B'nai Brith www.bnaibrith.org.

DAVIS--Harold. Died on September 5, 2013, at 91. Beloved husband of 59 years of Sheila, father of Zack and Tracy, grandfather of Morgan. CONNEY--Dr. Allan H. The faculty and staff of Rutgers University Ernest Mario School of Pharmacy are saddened by the passing of Dr. Allan H. Conney, on September 10. Dr. Conney was a world-renowned pharmacologist and cancer researcher. Born in Chicago in 1930, he earned his pharmacy degree and a Ph.D. in cancer research at the University of Wisconsin. Conney, the William M. and Myrle W. Garbe Professor of Cancer and Leukemia Research and Director of the Susan Lehman Cullman Laboratory for Cancer Research, had a long, distinguished record of research, teaching and service. He pioneered work on the toxicological effects of environmental and dietary substances that act as triggers in the formation of cancer and made important discoveries on how caffeine, exercise and liposuction inhibit skin cancer. A beloved Rutgers faculty member in the Department of Chemical Biology, Conney was the driving force behind the creation of the Lab for Cancer Research. He was among the seven most cited scientists in the world in the field of pharmacological science from 1965-1978, according to the Science Citation index. Conney was elected to the National Academy of Sciences (USA) in 1982, was a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and was selected as a Pioneer of Cancer Prevention. Conney published more than 500 articles of original work in scientific literature. Conney is survived by his wife, Diana Locke Conney, two sons, Steven Conney and Michael Conney, daughter-in-law Yulin Conney, granddaughter Melissa Conney and sister, Ruth Adrian. Funeral services are Sunday at 1pm at Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 1534 Pennington Rd, Ewing Township. Donations may be sent to the Ernest Mario School of Pharmacy, c/o Dr. Renping Zhou, Rutgers University, 164 Frelinghuysen Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854-8020.
CLAYMAN--Esther. In memory of our past president. We extend our condolences to the family. NCJW, Brooklyn Section

CLASS--Constance Marie passed away, age 63, on September 11th in hospice in St Paul, MN after a long battle with cancer. Trained as a hair cutter/stylist at Vidal Sassoon Salon in NYC, she worked at Miano-Veil Salon in NYC for many years and serviced a loyal clientele in the Twin Cities area. She competed in speed-skating in her teens, ran for Warren Street Social & Athletic Club in NYC and later won many awards in cross country skiing in her native mid-west and also was an accomplished seamstress. She was devoted longtime companion to George Leibson of NYC, loving daughter to her parents Robert and Helen Hipp Class and guiding light sister to Mark, Nancy, Annette, Paula, Rob and Katie and many nieces and nephews. Private services will be held in St Paul and a memorial will be held at a later date in NYC. Contributions may be made in her name to Our Lady of Peace, 2076 St Anthony Ave, St Paul, MN 55104 and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York.

CANTOR--Dr. Joshua. Members of the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine at the Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the loss of our colleague and friend, Dr. Joshua Cantor. He was brilliant, kind, confident, humble, sharp, funny, a leader, champion for people with Brain Injury, mentor, insatiably curious and eager to learn. As one of his patients said, "You just don't find all these things in one person." He will be so deeply missed by us all. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 15, 2013 at 2:30pm at Temple Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, New York, 11215. In lieu of flowers, his family requests that donations be made to the Joshua Cantor Trust Fund, c/o The Rehabilitation Medicine Department, 3 East 101st Street, New York, NY 10029. The fund will be used to provide continued support to Joshua's family. Kristjan T. Ragnarsson, MD Lucy G. Moses Professor and Chairman Wayne A. Gordon, Ph.D., Jack Nash Professor, and Vice Chair Department of Rehabilitation Medicine The Mount Sinai Medical Center

VARZI--Farahdokht, age 89, of Wayne, NJ passed away on Thursday, September 12, 2013. Born in Mashad, Iran, Mrs. Varzi lived in Tehran and then in Wayne for 18 years. She received her Bachelor's Degree in Iran and rose to the rank of director of one of the Iranian State Ministries. Mrs. Varzi's first marriage to Abbas Yamani ended after 14 years. She was married for over 36 years to her second husband Abol Hassan Varzi, one of the most famous poets, who died in 1994. She raised three children and was also a member of the Iranian Writers (Pen) Association. Mrs. Varzi was a pioneer in the struggle for women's rights in Iran and she was among the first female drivers in the country. Beloved mother of Mehdi and his wife Soraya Varzi, Farrinaz and her husband William Cress, and Hamid and his wife Mina Varzi. Devoted grandmother of Shahriar and Keyvan Pourreza, Kamyar, Kamrooz and Azadeh Varzi, and Cyrus and Anahita Varzi. Services are private and entrusted to Moore's Home For Funerals, 1591 Alps Rd, Wayne, NJ. www.mooresinfo.com

OSBORNE--Betty Lou, passed on September 11, 2013 surrounded by her family and friends. She had a wonderful life. She would like to thank the past and current staff of the New York Times. It was a very important part of her life.
NETZER--Corinne T. Noted author and an amazing friend died 5 September 2013. Memorial service to be announced.

MUNRO--Betty (Patterson), age 87, died quietly at home in Bronxville NY on September 8, 2013. A Juilliard graduate, she performed extensively, singing in recitals and summer stock as well as on Broadway, and gave pleasure through hospital concerts and classes for young people. Adored and adoring wife of 62 years to William P. Munro, she is also survived by daughter Constance; grandchildren William, David, and Anne; and brother Gordon Patterson. She was predeceased by her beloved daughter Leslie. Donations may be sent to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, or Elmsford Animal Shelter/Pets Alive Westchester.

WHALEN--Joseph P.,M.D., 80, of New York City, died in Syracuse, New York on September 3rd after a brief illness. A native of Troy, New York, Dr. Whalen was born on June 18, 1933 to the late Philip J. Whalen and Mary Doyle Whalen. A graduate of Catholic schools in Troy, he received his A.B. degree from Fordham University in 1955 and his M.D. degree from the State University of New York at Syracuse in 1959. After a year of internship in internal medicine followed by three years of residency in radiology at the State University of New York at Syracuse, Dr. Whalen began a career as a radiologist that would last for decades and eventually carry him to the heights of his profession. Passionately committed to education as well as to medicine, Dr. Whalen combined an academic life with that of a practicing physician, accepting a position as instructor in Radiology at Albany Medical College and then at the State University of New York at Syracuse in the mid-1960s. In 1968 he was invited to become Associate Attending Radiologist at the New York Hospital (presently the New York Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell Medical Center) in New York City. Within three years he was named Attending Radiologist, and in 1976 he became Radiologist-in-Chief, a position he held until 1992. From 1989 until 1992 he was the Medical Director of the same institution. For sixteen years he served as Professor and Chairman of the Department of Radiology at the Weill-Cornell Medical College, educating many of the most prominent radiologists in practice today. During his time at the New York Hospital, Dr. Whalen was responsible for bringing the first CT scanner to New York City. Always in the vanguard of his profession, he pioneered the use of the first MRI in a New York Hospital, as well as the first Electron Beam CT Scanner. In 1992 Dr. Whalen left the New York Hospital to accept the position of Dean of the College of Medicine and Vice President of Biomedical and Medical Education at the State University of New York Health Science Center in Syracuse, New York, remaining there until 1995. A sought-after educator, Dr. Whalen held numerous visiting professorships, including: the Medical School of the University of Dublin, Ireland; the Postgraduate School of Medicine, Hammersmith Hospital, London; The Pathology Department of the School of Medicine at Cornell University, Ithaca, New York; and the School of Veterinary Medicine at Cornell University, Ithaca, New York. At the time of his death he was a fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons, Ireland; the New York Academy of Medicine; the American College of Radiology; and the Royal Society of Medicine. Dr. Whalen, who was awarded a D. Sc. degree by the State University of New York at Syracuse in 1989, was an active member of numerous professional societies, including the Radiological Society of North America, the American College of Radiology, the New York Roentgen Ray Society, and the Harvey Society. A founding member of the International Skeletal Society and the Society of Gastrointestinal Radiologists, he was an honorary member of radiologic societies throughout the United States and Canada. He was also a board examiner for the American College of Radiology. Although ardently committed to the field of radiology, Dr. Whalen was a man whose interests were too broad to be confined to one area of specialty. His research into the role of calcium in health and disease has had an impact on the treatment of medical conditions as diverse as osteoporosis and periodontal disease. A prolific writer as well as a meticulous researcher, Dr. Whalen was the author or co-author of over two hundred peer-reviewed scientific articles as well as four medical textbooks. Until his death, he was the editor-in-chief of Clinical Imaging, a journal of radiology. In his retirement Dr. Whalen devoted much of his time to his family and to charitable endeavors, especially serving as President of the John, Marie, and Joseph Whalen Foundation and the Mons Concepit Foundation. In recent years he divided his time between his homes in New York City, Shelter Island, and Mannin Beg, County Galway, Ireland -- a place he deeply loved. Intensely proud of his Irish heritage, Dr. Whalen was always eager to do whatever he could to help the land from which his forebears had emigrated. At the time of his death he was in the process of establishing a scholarship program for underprivileged and deserving Irish students, which he had intended to name in honor of his beloved sister Marie. Dr. Whalen is survived by his wife Elizabeth Varga Whalen, as well as three children, Philip J. Whalen (Frances) of Briarcliff Manor, New York, Joseph P. Whalen, Jr. (Mary) of Oceanport, New Jersey, and Mary P. Whalen of New York City, as well as six grandchildren: Casey (fiance, Cyril Galvin), Ryan (Amy), Timmy, Devin, Lindsey Marie, and Jenna Frances Whalen. He is survived, as well, by a stepson, Charles Bouchard (Teresa), of Schenectady, New York, three step-grandchildren: Charlie, Julianne, and Caroline Bouchard, also of Schenectady, and his "grand-dog" Eddie Doyle of New York City. Dr. Whalen was preceded in death by two older siblings, the Reverend John P. Whalen and Marie T. Whalen. A Mass of Christian Burial was celebrated in the chapel of the Provincial House of the Sisters of Saint Joseph of Carondelet in Latham, New York on Saturday, September 7, 2013. Interment was at Oakwood Cemetery in Troy, New York. Donations in Dr. Whalen's memory may be made to the John, Marie, and Joseph Whalen Foundation in care of Sister Serena Thompson, CSJ, 385 Watervliet-Shaker Road, Latham, New York 12110-4799. Details of a memorial service in New York City are pending.

MILES--Ellen F. age 82, of Denver passed away on Thursday, August 29, 2013, at Denver Hospice Care Center in Denver. Ellen was born in Wurtzburg, Germany on November 21, 1930, to Louis and Gertrude (Rosenberg) Fleischman and married Norman Miles of Rochester, NY in September 1953. Ellen was a graduate of George Washington High School in Manhattan, and then pursued a brief modeling career before furthering her education at Syracuse University. After moving to western New York she raised her family and worked for over three decades as a researcher and Quality Assurance Officer at the University of Rochester Environmental Health Sciences Center, Department of Environmental Medicine, and EPA PM Center. After moving to Denver in 2003, she continued working as a Quality Assurance Officer for the Boston-based Health Effects Institute and as part of a joint U.S.-Chinese research team participated in a study released in March 2013 of Chinese efforts to reduce air pollution during the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games. She also pursued additional interests as a Panel Member of the Colorado Multiple Institutional Research Board, a docent at the Denver Zoo, and President of the Board of Directors as well as Production Manager at the Heather Gardens Frolics Theater. She was an avid gourmet cook, voracious reader, loved opera and the outdoors, and enjoyed painting, horseback riding, tennis, and golf. Ellen is survived by three children, Todd (Pamela) of Tarrytown, NY, Scott (Emily) of Conifer, CO, and Julie Walker (Tim) of Parker, CO; nine grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Private family services and interment were held in Denver. For a more lasting memorial, friends are asked to consider the Denver Hospice Center at www.thedenverhospice.org

MARCUS--Dr. Philip I.,of Storrs, CT, passed away on Sunday, September 1, 2013 at the age of eighty-six. He spent the past forty-four years on the faculty at UConn, known to many as a compassionate professor who donated his time unselfishly to colleagues and students. He was born June 3, 1927 in Springfield, MA; the son of Julius Marcus and Marley Spier (Sheffield, England), and the brother of Maxine Altshuler, and Emil Marcus, who all predeceased him. In 1945 he graduated Springfield Technical High School, the STEM system of its time. During WWII, while in high school, he worked at the great forges in the Springfield Armory immortalized by Longfellow's poem "The Arsenal at Springfield." He enlisted in the Army Specialized Training Reserve Program and was assigned in 1945 to attend UConn in Storrs, CT. After six months each at UConn and UMaine (in Orono) he had earned two years of college credit. Assigned to active duty in the US Air Force and stationed in Istres, France, he rose to the level of staff sergeant within a year. The GI Bill enabled him to attend college, the first in his family to do so. He received degrees from the: University of Southern California (B.S. in Bacteriology, 1950); University of Chicago (M.S. in Microbiology, 1953); and University of Colorado Medical Center (Ph.D. in Microbiology/ Biophysics, 1957). While at the University of Chicago, he worked with Aaron Novick and Leo Szilard and later with Paul Talalay. In Colorado, he became codiscoverer of the clonogenic assay and the feeder cell system, making it possible to grow clones from single mammalian cells as in stem cells. He was the first to clone the immortalized HeLa cells. That procedure led to the first determination of human cell sensitivity to X-rays. Over fifty years later he documented at a luncheon conversation with Leo Szilard, the nuclear physicist, led to the concept and physical setup for the first clonogenic assay. Dr. Marcus then spent nine years on the faculty of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York supported by a ten-year U.S. Public Health Service Research Career Development Award. While there he showed the dynamic movement of virus molecules on the surface of infected cells, and with a pediatrician colleague, Dr. David Carver, developed a new test to detect rubella virus. During this time in New York, he was Director for nine years of the post-doctoral Course on Quantitative Animal Virology and Cell Culture that was taught in the summer at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory (New York). In 1969 Dr. Marcus returned to UConn where he was appointed Head of the then Microbiology Section. He spent the remainder of his career at UConn where he administered the first Program Project on campus supported by the National Institute of Health, chaired the first Biosafety Committee, created a Virus and Interferon Research Laboratory recognized internationally for its innovative studies, published over 130 scientific papers, and was awarded five U.S. patents. As an early director of the Biotechnology Center, he helped attract companies with a focus on biotechnology to Connecticut. Then, for twelve years as director of the Biotechnology/ Services Center, he expanded the acquisition of state-of-the art instruments, which drew scientists to the facility. He continued to advance biotechnology in Connecticut as a charter member of the Connecticut Academy of Science and Engineering and was pleased to know that the Research Park planned for Storrs, CT, will be realized. In 1987 he received the UConn Alumni Association Award for Excellence in Research, and in 2003 was recognized as a Board of Trustees Distinguished Professor. His annual course in Virology, taught for thirty-six years, was both sought after, and evaded, the former by students looking to be challenged. These students were a source of great pride. Decades later he continued to receive accolades from students expressing appreciation for the opportunity. Dr. Marcus was a member and active participant in a number of professional scientific societies including the American Society for Virology and the International Society for Interferon and Cytokine Research, which in 2005 named him as an Honorary Member. Serving eighteen years as Editor-in-Chief of the Journal of Interferon Research (later renamed the Journal of Interferon and Cytokine Research (JICR)), he went on to serve as Senior Consulting Editor of the JICR for ten years until the present day. For twenty-five years he was an Editor for the Journal of Cellular Physiology. He typically mentored two Ph.D. candidates and two undergraduate honors students doing research in the lab. The bulk of his research at UConn was in collaboration with long-time associate and faculty member, Dr. Margaret J. Sekellick. Three highlights included: the discovery of the world's most efficient inducer of interferon a single molecule of double-stranded RNA; the molecular cloning of the first non-human interferon (avian); and the discovery that influenza virus populations contained previously unknown large subpopulations of noninfectious viruses that were nonetheless biologically active. He was an avid reader who, while developing ways to win the war between viruses and cells, imagined how humankind would lose if we destroyed ourselves first. He showed palatable disdain for politicians who did not appreciate the role of basic science in understanding and caring for the world and its many inhabitants. He is survived by Angela, his wife of 60 years; his son Craig F. Marcus (Coventry, CT); daughter Wendy Marcus Gogel and her husband Gary Gogel (Brighton, MA); daughter Valerie Marcus Nassiff and her daughters Madison and Sydney (Bolton, CT); cousin Bernard A. Marcus and family (Webster, NY); niece Bari Edlin and family (Sherman Oaks, CA); niece Susan Avisar and her husband Eytan and family (Sherman Oaks, CA); and niece Jacqueline Marcus (Los Osos, CA). Donations in memory of Dr. Philip I. Marcus may be made to The Philip I. Marcus Graduate Student Virology Support Fund. Please make checks payable to: The UConn Foundation, Inc. at the following address: 2390 Alumni Drive Unit 3206, Storrs, CT 06269. A memorial service to be held at the University of Connecticut is being planned to honor his passion for education, scholarship, research and creativity.
