SNELL--Ida, beloved wife of Philip, mother of Jeffrey, William and Stephen, grandmother, great-grandmother and nurse died peacefully at her home September 14, 2013.

SIMENAUER--Peter. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on September 14, of Peter Simenauer, who served in the Orchestra from 196098 including as Associate Principal and Solo E-Flat Clarinet. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his widow, Jacqueline, and the rest of his family.

SIMENAUER--Peter. The world has lost a great musician. Peter Simenauer, former Associate Principal Clarinetist of the New York Philharmonic for 38 years passed away on September 14th in Naples, Florida. A child prodigy Peter excelled at many instruments including the violin, viola and saxophone. Born in Berlin Germany, Peter grew up in China and then went on to join the Israel Philharmonic for nine years. As a young artist he won the Mozarteum Competition and concertized worldwide before joining the New York Philharmonic in 1960. His recording of the Mozart Clarinet Concerto with the Pascal String Quartet has continued to sell for over 50 years. His loving family survives him.

SESSA--Leonard, 93, of Palm Beach, FL and Manhattan, passed away peacefully at home Sunday, August 18, 2013, with his loving wife Sunny, at his side. Lenny was an enormously successful man who always lived La Dolce Vita. His success and his larger than life personality will be missed by all who knew him. He always remembered his beginnings and was available to all who knew him for his sage advice and guidance. He was born in Brooklyn, the son of Sicilian immigrants. After working since age seven, he created a nationally recognized system of multi-level catering. His famous Leonard's of Great Neck, on Long Island, is still the standard in the catering industry. In 2004 he received an honorary doctorate in commercial sciences from St. John's University commemorating his achievements. In Palm Beach he was heavily and very successfully involved in various real estate ventures. He owned and operated La Famiglia restaurant and Club L. Lenny loved Sunny. He also loved to sing, enjoyed great food, his cars and, of course, his shoes. He is survived by his children Leonard (Janine), Denise and Robert; his two grandchildren Virginia and Lee; and his great-grandchild Jackson. In Palm Beach, his Charities included The Kravis Center (Major Benefactor) and L.I.F.E.

SACHS--Leon September 17, 2013. Professor Sachs De La Sorbonne! I can see you now, emphasizing in your inimitable way, the correct way to pronounce "La Sorbonne"! We mourn the tragic loss of Leon, who over the last 30 years, quickly grew from being "our Professor of French" into an adored and cherished member of our family. Soon, his beloved wife and soulmate, Sheila, and the daughters on whom he doted; Deborah and Anne; her husband David, and their children, Lindsey Rachel, and Max all became family. They were the planets that revolved around this delightful man's special world. Leon was a wealth of information, a brilliant scholar whose depth of knowledge spanned the world of languages, music of every kind, opera, haute cuisine --the best of everything, including, where to get the best cappuccino in town. Who will I call from Tel Aviv to find out where to get the best falafel? Who will I phone from Paris to make sure that my wording is the "most chic"? And who will call me to say where our next lesson will be, (they were frequently conducted in 3-star restaurants, naturellment!) Who else could I be with, conjugating verbs and munching on amuse bouches, at Le Cirque or Daniel, only to have our lesson interrupted by Sirio or Daniel themselves, the celebrated restaurateurs, who always stopped by to exchange pleasantries with The Professor?? I will never forget our hilarious and heartwarming taxi rides around NYC. Leon, leaning forward to determine the driver's native tongue, and a split second later, regaling the driver with wondrous words that not only amazed him but convinced him that he was in the company of a fellow countryman! Leon wove his special magic both in song and in fluent French, Arabic, Yiddish, Italian.and conversed in Ordu, Indian dialects, Pakistani, Greek and Creole masterfully enough to send listeners into gales of laughter, the most universal language of all. Leon, you will be missed by so many. There will never be anyone as charming and playful as you. Only a truly gifted teacher such as you could share his wisdom and knowledge with so many spanning all ages, in a breadth of settings with so much success and joy. From Brearley to the Boardroom, you enchanted and left your unforgettable imprint. We will all miss you so very much. Our hearts and thoughts are with Sheila, Deborah, Anne, David and their children. Love, Catherine, Fred, Christopher, Freddie P.S. I hope that in heaven you will have an unending supply of Le Petit Ecolier, in dark chocolate of course!

ROSTON--Ronald. The theatre world lost one of its most passionate members this year. Director Ronald Roston died August 30 in New York City. A Milwaukee native (born August 16, 1935), he graduated from the University of Wisconsin in Madison and Hunter College of the City University of New York. His career as director, teacher, and mentor spanned five decades, with his final work as Associate Professor in Acting and Directing at the University of West Florida and Artistic Director of the Pensacola Little Theatre. His long and distinguished professional life included being the Artistic Director of the Writers' Circle in New York; Head of the MFA Directing Program at Rutgers University; and Artistic Director of the Renegade Theater Company in Hoboken, New Jersey. He also directed "A Jazz Nativity" in New York and various productions at the Manhattan Theater Club, the Westchester Regional Theater, the Circle Repertory Company, and the Theatre of the Living Arts in Philadelphia. He is survived by his wife of nearly 50 years, Ellen; his sons, Aaron and Adrian; daughter-in-law Elizabeth Meadows; and three grandchildren, Nicolas, Lincoln and Brooklyn. Contributions in his memory may be made to the University of Wisconsin or the Pensacola Little Theatre. A Celebration of Life will be held at the Pensacola Little Theatre on September 29, at 2:30pm.

ROBBINS--Wendy Lee (Klein), on September 17, 2013. An artist and animal lover, Wendy was loved and will be missed by her sister and brother-in-law Jo and Jon Keroes, of San Francisco, and her nieces, Amy Keroes and Amanda Cohen.

POLSTEIN--Lynn. May 14, 1931 - September 18, 2013. Beloved and loving wife of Bob for 58 years. Adored mother of Janet (Irving Hirsch), Nancy (Bruce Donatuti) and John (Martha). Doting grandmother of Sara, Matthew, Emily, Michael, Jeb and Billy. Lynn spent her professional career as a psychiatric social worker at Pleasantville Cottage School, working with troubled children. She loved her family, her home at Truro, travel to the far corners of the world, her many dear friends, and her dog Tucker. The world will be a poorer place without her. Services at Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY at 12 noon on Sunday, September 22. Contributions in her memory may be made to Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

PHILLIPS--Jessie Ewing Butler, died peacefully on September 18, 2013 at the age of 94. Beloved wife of James Butler and Lewis G. Phillips, both deceased, she is survived by her sons James Butler, Jr. and William Ewing Butler, daughters Tara Butler Economakis and Dorothy Conron Butler as well as ten grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. Mrs. Phillips was the daughter of William Ewing, a founding partner of Morgan Stanley Inc. and Maria Valle' Taylor. She loved and was loved by her family, her friends and all the four footed animals she knew. Mrs. Phillips was a member of the Colony Club of New York, Colonial Dames of America and the Devon Yacht Club. Friends and family are invited to a memorial service at 40 Cove Woods Road, Oyster Bay, LI, NY on September 28, 2013 at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, you may make donations to the North Shore Animal Hospital.

PALMER--James. Basketball legend, Jim Palmer, 79, died September 17, 2013 at his home Catwalk in Catskill, NY. Jim played with the Cincinnati Royals 1958-59 and the New York Knicks from 1959-1961. Bigger than life at 6'8", he was a gentle giant who stood tall as a role model of great humor and kindness to all. He is survived by his beloved wife Purcell Palmer of 45 years and Catwalk, an artist residency on their Hudson River estate that they founded in 2004. A private memorial service is scheduled at Catwalk. MillspaughCamerato.com. Memorial contributions may be made to CommunityHospice.org
MOSS--Joseph H.,age 94, peacefully passed away in Hobe Sound, FL on June 29, 2013. Son of late restaurateur/host Joe Moss and the late Octavine Ware. For info: joemoss@comcast.net

MOSES--Henry Clay, of Bishop Gadsden Retirement Community, Charleston SC, husband of Lora Green Moses, died September 13, 2013, at the age of 96. Services by J. Henry Stuhr Downtown Chapel. Henry was born in New York City, NY, the son of the late Helen Beatrice Anderson of London, England and the late Henry C. Moses of Montgomery, AL. He lived most of his life in New Rochelle and Bronxville, NY and later in Westerly, RI. After graduating from Princeton, and Harvard Law School, he worked as a legislative assistant to Senator Robert A. Taft, then served in the Office of Naval Intelligence and the Naval Amphibious Forces. Henry took park on D-Day in both the Normandy and Southern France invasions, and thereafter as Commanding Officer of an LST in the Pacific. Following WWII he engaged in the private practice of law, then became counsel and later General Counsel of Mobil Oil Company, after which he was, for eleven years, Vice President of Mobil Oil Corporation, responsible for their interests in the Middle East. Among his other activities after retirement in 1973, were climbing with Tenzing Norgay to 17,000 feet on K3 in the Himalayas, a position as a "name" in Lloyds of London, and his chairmanship of three European concert tours for a large chorus in Westerly, RI in which he and both wives sang. He was a member of First (Scots) Presbyterian Church of Charleston, and his wife remains so. He was an elder in the Presbyterian Church. In addition to his wife, Lora, Henry leaves two children, Margery Phillips of Norwich, VT, Catherine Barber of Westerly, RI and daughter-in-law Mary Sarah Holland of Bristol VT; nine grandchildren, 17 great-grandchildren and five step-children, a brother, John Moses of Rexford, NY. He is predeceased by his first wife, Barbara Frost in 1986, and his son, Henry in 2008. Memorial gifts in honor of Henry C. Moses may be made to the Hearing Loop Project, c/o Bishop Gadsden, 1 Bishop Way, Charleston, SC 29412.

MARX--Charlene Aber, of Palm Beach, Florida, died peacefully on Sunday, September 8th. She was 101. Born in Texas, she married David Marx of the Louis Marx toy company, who predeceased her in 1987. Together they had four children: Charles Marx, Marlene Twaddell, Pamela Loxton, and Clara Dale. They all survive her along with 12 grandchildren and 23 great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 4 o'clock on September 28th, at the First Presbyterian Church, 4 East River Road at Park Avenue, Rumson, New Jersey. Friends seeking further information are directed to an Internet site receiving expressions of sympathy: thompsonmemorial.net

MARCUS--Dr. Philip I.,of Storrs, CT, passed away on Sunday, September 1, 2013 at the age of 86. He spent the past 44 years on the faculty at UConn, known to many as a compassionate professor who donated his time unselfishly to colleagues and students. He was born June 3, 1927 in Springfield, MA; the son of Julius Marcus and Marley Spier (Sheffield, England), and the brother of Maxine Altshuler, and Emil Marcus, who all predeceased him. In 1945 he graduated Springfield Technical High School, the STEM system of its time. During WWII, while in high school, he worked at the great forges in the Springfield Armory immortalized by Longfellow's poem "The Arsenal at Springfield." He enlisted in the Army Specialized Training Reserve Program and was assigned in 1945 to attend UConn in Storrs, CT. After six months each at UConn and UMaine (in Orono) he had earned two years of college credit. Assigned to active duty in the US Air Force and stationed in Istres, France, he rose to the level of staff sergeant within a year. The GI Bill enabled him to attend college, the first in his family to do so. He received degrees from the: Univ. of Southern California (B.S. in Bacteriology, 1950); Univ. of Chicago (M.S. in Microbiology, 1953); and Univ. of Colorado Medical Center (Ph.D. in Microbiology/ Biophysics, 1957). While at the Univ. of Chicago, he worked with Aaron Novick and Leo Szilard and later with Paul Talalay. In Colorado, he became codiscoverer of the clonogenic assay and the feeder cell system, making it possible to grow clones from single mammalian cells as in stem cells. He was the first to clone the immortalized HeLa cells. That procedure led to the first determination of human cell sensitivity to X-rays. Over 50 years later he documented at a luncheon conversation with Leo Szilard, the nuclear physicist, led to the concept and physical setup for the first clonogenic assay. Dr. Marcus then spent nine years on the faculty of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in NY supported by a ten-year U.S. Public Health Service Research Career Development Award. While there he showed the dynamic movement of virus molecules on the surface of infected cells, and with a pediatrician colleague, Dr. David Carver, developed a new test to detect rubella virus. During this time in New York, he was Director for nine years of the post-doctoral Course on Quantitative Animal Virology and Cell Culture that was taught in the summer at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory (NY). In 1969 Dr. Marcus returned to UConn where he was appointed Head of the then Microbiology Section. He spent the remainder of his career at UConn where he administered the first Program Project on campus supported by the National Institute of Health, chaired the first Biosafety Committee, created a Virus and Interferon Research Laboratory recognized internationally for its innovative studies, published over 130 scientific papers, and was awarded 5 U.S. patents. As an early director of the Biotechnology Center, he helped attract companies with a focus on biotechnology to Connecticut. Then, for 12 years as director of the Biotechnology/ Services Center, he expanded the acquisition of state-of-the art instruments, which drew scientists to the facility. He continued to advance biotechnology in Connecticut as a charter member of the Connecticut Academy of Science and Engineering and was pleased to know that the Research Park planned for Storrs, CT, will be realized. In 1987 he received the UConn Alumni Association Award for Excellence in Research, and in 2003 was recognized as a Board of Trustees Distinguished Professor. His annual course in Virology, taught for 36 years, was both sought after, and evaded, the former by students looking to be challenged. These students were a source of great pride. Decades later he continued to receive accolades from students expressing appreciation for the opportunity. Dr. Marcus was a member and active participant in a number of professional scientific societies including the American Society for Virology and the International Society for Interferon and Cytokine Research, which in 2005 named him as an Honorary Member. Serving eighteen years as Editor-in-Chief of the Journal of Interferon Research (later renamed the Journal of Interferon and Cytokine Research (JICR)), he went on to serve as Senior Consulting Editor of the JICR for ten years until the present day. For twenty-five years he was an Editor for the Journal of Cellular Physiology. He typically mentored two Ph.D. candidates and two undergraduate honors students doing research in the lab. The bulk of his research at UConn was in collaboration with long-time associate and faculty member, Dr. Margaret J. Sekellick. Three highlights included: the discovery of the world's most efficient inducer of interferon a single molecule of double-stranded RNA; the molecular cloning of the first non-human interferon (avian); and the discovery that influenza virus populations contained previously unknown large subpopulations of noninfectious viruses that were nonetheless biologically active. He was an avid reader who, while developing ways to win the war between viruses and cells, imagined how humankind would lose if we destroyed ourselves first. He showed palatable disdain for politicians who did not appreciate the role of basic science in understanding and caring for the world and its many inhabitants. He is survived by Angela, his wife of 60 years; his son Craig F. Marcus (Coventry, CT); daughter Wendy Marcus Gogel and her husband Gary Gogel (Brighton, MA); daughter Valerie Marcus Nassiff and her daughters Madison and Sydney (Bolton, CT); cousin Bernard A. Marcus and family (Webster, NY); niece Bari Edlin and family (Sherman Oaks, CA); niece Susan Avisar and her husband Eytan and family (Sherman Oaks, CA); and niece Jacqueline Marcus (Los Osos, CA). Donations in memory of Dr. Philip I. Marcus may be made to The Philip I. Marcus Graduate Student Virology Support Fund. Please make checks payable to: The UConn Foundation, Inc., 2390 Alumni Drive Unit 3206, Storrs, CT 06269. A memorial service to be held at the University of Connecticut is being planned to honor his passion for education, scholarship, research and creativity.

LILIENFIELD--Barbara G.,81. Formerly of Scarsdale, NY on September 18, 2013. Wife of the late Robert Lilienfield, beloved mother of Tracy (Barry Heins, Todd and Terry (David Kearney). Cherished grandmother of Benjamin and Kelsey Heins, and Rebecca Sanders. Retired real estate agent at Julia B. Fee, Barbara was a passionate art collector, avid traveller, and ballet and theatre patron. A devoted mother, grandmother and friend. She will be missed. Memorial information: www.lilienfield.weebly.com Donations in her memory to Compassionandchoices.org or CurePSP.org

KEHAYA--Helga Luise, of Jupiter Island, passed away quietly at home on September 17, surrounded by her family. Wife of the late Ery Whitaker Kehaya, she is survived by her son, Mark Kehaya, his wife Hannah, and two grandchildren, Mary Louise and Ery. She is also survived by her beloved sister, Karin Paz Pena De Vire, and nephew Bernardo, step-son Whit Kehaya, his wife Sharon, and their children James, Julian, Robert and Alex, and step-daughter Lisa Kehaya. Helga was born in Rendsburg, Germany on October 17, 1934. Growing up during WWII left lasting memories that she shared with her family over the years. Prior to working at the Atlantic Hotel in Hamburg, where she met her lifelong love, Ery, she lived and worked in both England and Switzerland. Throughout their life together, she supported her husband in building Standard Commercial Corporation, as a helpmate, hostess and sounding board. After residing and raising their son in Grosshansdorf, Germany, Helga moved to Florida with her husband in 1983, where she felt particularly embraced by the friends she met on Jupiter Island. Helga is known for her warmth and philanthropy. She had special interest in supporting Duke University, St Paul's School, Asheville School, St. Andrews College, and various local charities. A service celebrating her life will take place on November 26 at 4:00pm, at Christ Memorial Church on Jupiter Island. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in her honor to Christ Memorial Church, PO Box 582, Hobe Sound, FL 33475.

KAHN--Morton, on September 19, 2013. Beloved husband of Helen, loving father, and generous and witty friend. Survived by children Jeffry, Kenneth, and Douglas, their wives and five grandchildren. Private service.

HERSH--Esther, passed away peacefully at her apartment in Atlanta on September 13 at the age of 102. A retired teacher in the New York City school system, she had previously lived in Manhattan, Brooklyn, and North Miami Beach. Beloved wife of the late Isaac "Pat" Hersh, devoted mother of Robert (Louise) and Carolyn Garfein (John), loving grandmother and great-grandmother. A unique individual, she will be missed by all.

HENRIE--Peggy, age 74, passed away on September, 12, 2013 after a long illness. Peggy was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Victor Wierman, Jr. of Bryn Mawr, PA. She attended the Agnes Irwin School and graduated from the Oldfields School. Peggy was predeceased by her late husbands, Cdr. Edwin J. Henrie, MD, and Capt. J. Winsor Baker Jr. She is survived by her two sisters, Emilie W. Carpenter and Susanna C. Prause, and by her children, J. Winsor Baker, III, Daintria McClure, Wendy Scott, and Richard S. Baker, and by eight grandchildren. She will be buried at Harrisburg Cemetery on September 28, at 11am.

HENDERSON--Keith F.,of Tempe, AZ, passed away on July 1, 2013, at age 61. He was born in New York City on June 3, 1952 to the late Robert F. and Jane K. Henderson. His grandfather Albert Henderson was a longtime Surrogate of Bronx County. A brilliant scholar, writer, and journalist, Keith was known for his towering intellect. He is survived and greatly missed by his sisters, Susan Brown of Golden, CO, and Elaine Henderson of New Milford, CT.

HELFAND--Florence, beloved wife of the late Ted Helfand, sister, mother, grandmother, aunt and friend, passed away September 17. Services, celebrating her life, are Sunday, September 22nd at 10:30am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY.

HEFLIN--Marta, known for roles on Broadway, in films and in cabaret passed away September 18, after a long illness. Broadway: Fiddler on the Roof, Hair, Jesus Christ Superstar, Come Back to the Five and Dime, Jimmy Dean Jimmy Dean (and film).Off Broadway: Salvation. Films: A Perfect Couple, A Wedding, A Star Is Born. Television: The Doctors, Playing For Time, Gentleman Bandit. Marta was a favorite on the New York cabaret stage: Reno Sweeneys, Elaine's and other venues. Donations may be made in Marta's name at: animalhavenshelter.org. A future memorial service will be announced.

HARTMANN--Dr. Ernest L.,79, of Newton, MA on August 7. A memorial will be held October 6 at 2pm at Wilson Chapel, Andover Newton Theology School, Newton, MA. In lieu of flowers, please consider the Sierra Club.

GRAFF--F. Malcolm, Jr. The Trustees and Staff of the Bagby Foundation for the Musical Arts mourn the loss of our beloved Chairman Emeritus, F. Malcolm Graff, Jr. Malcolm joined our board in 1970 and served with great distinction as Treasurer, Vice President, President and Chairman. Malcolm inspired his fellow Trustees with his unstinting commitment to Bagby and its mission. His unique combination of wit, wisdom and grace will be sorely missed and always remembered. We extend our deepest condolences to his lovely wife, Yveta, their son, Steve Love, Steve's wife, Jeanie, and their son, Chase Graff Love. Winthrop Rutherfurd, Jr., Chairman Blanche Lark Christerson, President J. Andrew Lark, Executive Director

GRAFF--F. Malcolm, Jr.,The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of F. Malcolm Graff, Jr., a devoted opera lover and great friend of our company, who served on the Met board for more than three decades. On behalf of everyone at the Met, we extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Yveta, and to his family and friends. Ann Ziff, Chairman of the Board Kevin W. Kennedy, President & CEO Peter Gelb, General Manager

GRAFF--F. Malcolm, Jr. The Board of Directors and staff of the Metropolitan Opera Guild are profoundly saddened by the death of our dear friend and esteemed board member, F. Malcolm Graff, Jr. Malcolm joined the Guild's board in 1970, and served with distinction as our Secretary, Treasurer and Vice President. He supported our programs and mission in every possible way, inspired by his great love of opera and music. Our deepest sympathies go to Malcolm's beloved wife Yveta Synek Graff, their son, Steve Love, his wife Jeanie and their son Chase Graff Love. Winthrop Rutherfurd, Jr., Chairman Richard J. Miller, Jr., President Stewart Pearce, Managing Director

GRAFF--F. Malcolm, Jr. A Manhattan banker and philanthropist who was a passionate champion of opera, died on September 18 at his home in Montecito, CA., at the age of 82. The cause was cancer, said his wife, Yveta Synek Graff, a Czech opera coach, translator and transliterator. Malcolm was a retired private wealth banker in Manhattan for the Bessemer Trust Company, which he joined in 1996. Prior to that, his career in trusts and estates spanned for over 40 years at the Banker's Trust Company. From 1970 until his death, he served on the board of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, and in 2008, was awarded the Eleanor Belmont Medal for his distinguished services. The Guild provides a wide variety of educational programs, publishes the magazine Opera News and presents a number of public programs celebrating the opera world, and Malcolm was instrumental in expanding all of these activities, at various times serving as Secretary, Treasurer and Vice President. He became a Member of the Metropolitan Opera Association in 1981 and has actively served as an Advisory Director of the Met board since 1989. He was also active in a wide range of other causes. He was the chairman of the Bagby Foundation of Musical Arts, and was on the boards of the American/French Friends of the Paris Opera, The Save Venice Foundation, as well as a founding member of the Opera Orchestra of New York. Born in Oakmont, PA, to Frank M. Graff and Julia Westin Graff, Malcolm was a graduate of Princeton University and Harvard Business School. He considered his greatest blessing to be his forty year marriage to Yveta to whom he was passionately devoted and extremely proud. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his step-son, Steve Love, and his wife, Jeanie, of Studio City, CA, his grandson, Chase Graff Love and his god-son, Marc Chazaud.

GOLDFRANK--Susan M.,of Ossining, NY, died on September 17, 2013, after a rapidly progressive illness, having spent the last weeks of her life at home with her loving family and friends. Susan was the cornerstone of the family: nurturing children and grandchildren; creating a warm home and gardens with magnificent designs of flowers, trees and vegetables; preparing unique and inspired cuisine, preserves and other delectables; weaving, knitting and sewing rugs, clothes and tapestries; mentoring many as listener and muse; and enjoying life endlessly. Susan was the ultimate partner in life as an inspirational wife and homemaker, daughter, mother, sister-in-law, aunt, cousin, grandmother and friend. Susan was a devoted lay leader for decades in the American Ethical Union and the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester who worked tirelessly to encourage all to strive to create a better world. Susan volunteered for many years with exceptional compassion and skill for the Phelps Hospice. Susan's wisdom, demeanor, standards, love, creativity and remarkable appreciation for life will allow all of us to perform our future tasks more effectively and ethically. Donations can be made to the American Ethical Union or the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester.

GLATT--Herman L. A founder of the law firm of Stutman, Treister & Glatt, and a luminary in the field of bankruptcy and corporate restructuring, died on September 8 at sea just offshore of Charleston, SC. Mr. Glatt was on a cruise with his wife celebrating their 20th wedding anniversary. He was 84. Mr. Glatt was an innovator in his field and widely-regarded for his creative approach to problem solving. He served as Chairperson of the Business Bankruptcy Committee of the Business and Banking Section of the American Bar Association, and was a Fellow of the American College of Bankruptcy. Mr. Glatt also taught at the University of Southern California School of Law, and served as an adjunct professor of law at Loyola University School of Law. Mr. Glatt was born in New York on May 3, 1929. In his youth, he attended Franklin & Marshall College, UCLA and the Harvard Law School. While attending law school, Mr. Glatt served in the Army and was stationed in England during the Korean War. In 1955, he joined the firm now known as Stutman, Treister & Glatt, which specializes in business bankruptcy and corporate restructuring, and he remained with the firm for more than fifty years. Mr. Glatt was a nationally-known leader in the field of corporate reorganization, having represented clients such as Itel Corporation, Storage Technology, Doskocil/Wilson Foods, the Hunt Brothers, John DeLorean, and the Public Service Company of New Hampshire. Aside from his love of law, Mr. Glatt was an avid sports fan. Being from New York, he was a lifelong Yankees fan. He was also a long-time devoted supporter of UCLA Bruin athletics. He spent the majority of his later years traveling the world, and developed a true passion for ocean cruises. During his travels, he enjoyed sampling diverse cuisines and developed a palate for fine wines. He also was a voracious reader, and enjoyed crossword puzzles. He valued his friends, family, and had a love of fine art. Mr. Glatt is survived by his wife Jeanne, and their children Wendy Glatt, Russell (and Mercy) Glatt, Tina-Marie (and Denis) Gauthier, Jessica Glatt, Adam Glatt, Darla White, and Scott (and Alissa Bach) White; and five grandchildren: Chloe Gauthier; Dillon Timmer; and Aidan, Eva, and Gunnar White. A public service will be held at Hotel Bel-Air on Saturday, October 5, 2013 from 11am to 2pm.

GERSHUNY--Caroline. April 11, 1914-September 17, 2013, passed away peacefully at home. Beloved wife of the late George, mother of Diane and Donald, mother-in-law, grandmother, and aunt to many who was the center of family life for 70 years. She will be in our hearts forever.

FUHRER--Leonard. November 23, 1929-September 20, 2013 surrounded by his loving family. Devoted husband to Frances (Kossin) for 60 years. Survived by children Leslie (Richard), Robert (Judy), and David (Cathy), and eight loving grandchildren, Evan, Ross, Rachel, Sam, Alex, Lara, Daniel, Matthew, and his brother, Robert (Joan). Funeral at 1:30pm Monday, September 23 at Temple Beth Elohim, Wellesley, MA.

FUHRER--Leonard. The Board of Directors of America-Israel Friendship League expresses its deep regret at the passing of Leonard Fuhrer, a long time member and supporter of AIFL and its programs. We send our condolences to his wife Fran and to the other members of his dear family.

ELLIS--Sybil Scallet. Died September 18, 2013. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Robert. Survived by her loving children, James (wife Carol) and Julie Sandor (husband Andrew), grandchildren Carrie (husband Kevin), Emily, Sarah, Jacob, and great- grandsons Griffin and Duncan. A private gathering at her home, Saturday, September 28th, 3-5pm.

EDMONDS--John L.,Esq. The Harlem-native real estate developer and lawyer was 87. As one of the city's largest minority developers, he built numerous units of affordable housing including Logan Plaza, Lakeview Apartments and St. Charles Condominiums. He was an owner of the Amsterdam News and Inner City Broadcasting, parent of WLIB/WBLS. He played a role in Harlem politics allied to the likes of Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Percy Sutton and David Dinkins, and pressing since the 1950s for greater political clout for the city's black community. His wife, Jamaica Hospital cardiologist Dr. Edith Reid, preceded him in death. He is grievously missed by friends and family, including five siblings, a sister-in-law and 15 nieces and nephews.

EDEL--Candace Kim. (1943-2013). Professor Edel, Kim to her friends, passed away peacefully on August 30th, to join her beloved husband Matthew. She leaves behind sons Nathan Keir, Gareth, Stephan, daughters-in-laws Marie and Helene, and a granddaughter Nadia. She leaves too many she deeply loved to list completely; a few are Dene, Byron, Cameron, Dana, Suzy, Trudy, Debby and Teddy, David and Jeffrey, Ellen and Joel, Laurie, Jean. She spent her youth as a cowgirl in the rural west with her mother Lorraine, and graduated high school in Laramie, WY, then from UC Berkeley. Kim married Matthew Edel in 1973 and settled in Sunnyside, Queens. She put her whole heart into everything she did. Prior to her academic career, she acted in theater, served in the Peace Corps, and participated in protests and social movements from the 60s until her death. For more than twenty years, she applied her compassion and intelligence as professor, teaching at CUNY Queens College (where she founded the Women's Center) as well as Fordham University. Her academic interests related to social justice, urban studies and sociology. Contact the family at the family home, or by email at ckedelmemorial@gmail.com. A public memorial will be announced later at www.edelfamily.com

DUNLOP--Charles Lane ("Lane"), an award winning translator of French poetry and of classic Japanese literature, died on August 31 in New York at the age of 76. He translated A Late Chrysanthemum that won the Japan-United States Friendship Award for Literary Translation. In 1997 he received an Academy Award in Literature from the American Academy of Arts and Letters recognizing him for the "assertive mastery that is evident not only in his fluent translations but also in his choices of texts." He graduated from Yale in 1957 and began a career as a translator first of French works and then pre 1960's Japanese literature. His first translation was Soap, by Francis Ponge. Ezra Pound had the translation read aloud to him by his wife and praised it as 'a flash of light among the shades'. Lane then studied Japanese and earned a scholarship to study under Ivan Morris and Donald Keene at Columbia University. His translations include The Paper Door and Other Stories, Palm of the Hand Stories, Autumn Wind, the novellas During the Rains and Flowers in the Shade, and the novel Floating Clouds. According to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Mr. Dunlop's anthologies "introduce(s) the reader to a number of authors of great subtlety and power one realizes the richness of this fresco of Japanese life over the last century; and in conveying that wealth of observation, Dunlop never makes a misstep." His work has been translated into Arabic and Urdu.

DUFFICY--Timothy M.,age 74, of Westborough, MA, formerly of North Salem, NY, died Thursday, September 19, 2013 at his home. Husband of Carole Dufficy, father of Jeffrey, Christine, Sean and Hilary, grandfather of Jeffrey, Timothy, Alexandra, Kegan and Ryan. Pre-deceased by his parents and a sister. Funeral Mass Wednesday, September 25, 2013, 10:00am at St. Josephs Church, Croton Falls, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven, Hawthorne. Calling Hours Tuesday 3pm-7pm at the Beecher Funeral Home, 1 Putnam Avenue, Brewster, NY. (845) 279-3615.

DaCOSTA--Jacqueline, 86, former advertising executive Jacqueline DaCosta passed away on Monday, April 29th at her home in New York City. The cause of death was not given though she had been in failing health for the past two years. Ms. DaCosta had served as vice president of media from 1967 to 1986 at Ted Bates Advertising which was sold in 1986 to the London based marketing firm of Saatchi & Saatchi. She had spent most of her 40 year career in advertising at the Bates company after graduating from Hunter College where she majored in business administration and languages. Jackie, as her wide circle of friends called her, was deeply involved in civic, cultural, and humanitarian affairs. These endeavors included being president of Hamilton Madison House, a social services agency on the lower east side of New York, and vice president of the Puerto Rican Family Institute. Jacqueline DaCosta was born in Manhattan on January 21, 1927, the daughter of Joaquin and Tirsa DaCosta. As a child she attended Catholic school in addition to New York's well known Music and Art High School. During her tenure at Bates, Jackie pioneered and orchestrated a new system for fairer TV buying rates during the month-long sweeps of each quarter during the year. With her newfound influence, Jackie often appeared on TV talk shows and took part in countless seminars, many of which she chaired. The awards came as well. She was named New York's Advertising Woman of the Year in 1974, and the City's Puerto Rican Woman of the Year in 1982. Jackie was also an avid theater, concert, and opera-goer, with her own seat at the Shed at Tanglewood besides being a supporting member of the Opera de Puerto Rico. Yet, throughout it all, her greatest satisfaction came from friend and family get-togethers. It was Jackie's deep rooted commitment to her faith, family, and friends that prompted countless celebratory gatherings at her homes in New York and Puerto Rico. "She had this never ending sense of generosity and desire to help others," a family member noted.

COVEY--Joy. The Board and Staff of NRDC mourn the loss of our beloved friend and trustee, Joy Covey. Joy was an intrepid traveler and true adventurer who worked tirelessly to help protect our oceans, wildlife and last wild places. Her indomitable spirit and her passion for nature were infectious to all who knew her. As NRDC's treasurer, Joy was a bold and brilliant financial leader who helped shape NRDC's financial vision to ensure we can carry out our mission. Joy embodied the values and spirit that drive our work, and her legacy will continue to inspire us. Our deepest sympathies go out to her son and everyone who knew, loved and respected her, as we did. Daniel R. Tishman, Chairman; Frances G. Beinecke, President; Peter Lehner, Executive Director; John H. Adams, Founding Director

BLOOM--William H.,September 19, 2013. Son of the late Samuel and Anna (Pinsker) Bloom of Granville, NY, preceded in death by his dear wife, Barbara, and sister Shirley. Survived by four children, 10 grandchildren, and loving children-in-law, friends and cousins. Alumnus of Green Mountain College, Union College and University of Buffalo Medical School. Veteran of WWII and Korean War. After training at NYU and Mt. Sinai he was a neurosurgeon for 40 years on Long Island. Generous, with a gift for lifelong friendship, he was also heartened by the many lives he saved. Athletic, musical, and artistic, he loved writing and encouraged others to expand their talents as well. This world is a better place for his having been part of it.

ABRAMS--Irene Hanelin. Incredible, talented lady who lived life "her way." She will be missed by her life partner Pat Izzo, grandaughter Lauren Alfaro, sister Blossom Nagler, daughter Aren Alfaro, nephews Cliff and Terry Nagler and their families.

WEINBERG--Catherine Goldman, 67, died suddenly in Greenwich, CT on September 19. Devoted wife of I. Ladd Weinberg, beloved mother of Gillian Ladd and Joanna Lawless, adoring grandmother of Beatrix Lawless, cherished sister of Peggy Goldman, and loving aunt of Spike Friedman. She was a lifelong avid reader and fan of fine arts and theater, an unstoppable proofreader, and an encyclopedic resource on everything to her family and friends. A tireless mother and spouse, she was deeply involved in the lives of those she loved. Charitable, and a consummate caretaker to a series of very pampered standard poodles, Cathy was authoritative and whimsical, intelligent and compassionate. She will be missed immeasurably. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, September 24, at Greenwich Library at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: LupusResearchInstitute.org.

STORY--June Eve. 19322013. Broadway Gypsy. Energy, Glitter, Flair. First National Tour of Carnival. Taught Dance at HB Studio 1969-2006. Legions of loving students found her 'you can do it' teaching changed their lives. Broadway: Maggie Flynn, The Daydreamer, Foxy, I Had A Ball. Film: The Night They Raided Minskys. Graduate Philadelphia Museum College of Art. Grieving: Ted Story, Cynthia Crane, Alexandra Story, Samantha Story.

PHILLIPS--Jessie Ewing Butler, died peacefully on September 18, 2013 at the age of 94. Beloved wife of James Butler and Lewis G. Phillips, both deceased, she is survived by her sons James Butler, Jr. and William Ewing Butler, daughters Tara Butler Economakis and Dorothy Conron Butler as well as ten grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. Mrs. Phillips was the daughter of William Ewing, a founding partner of Morgan Stanley Inc. and Maria Valle' Taylor. She loved and was loved by her family, her friends and all the four footed animals she knew. Mrs. Phillips was a member of the Colony Club of New York, Colonial Dames of America and the Devon Yacht Club. Friends and family are invited to a memorial service at 40 Cove Woods Road, Oyster Bay, LI, NY on September 28, 2013 at 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers, you may make donations to the North Shore Animal Hospital.

MARX--Charlene Aber, of Palm Beach, Florida, died peacefully on Sunday, September 8th. She was 101. Born in Texas, she married David Marx of the Louis Marx toy company, who predeceased her in 1987. Together they had four children: Charles Marx, Marlene Twaddell, Pamela Loxton, and Clara Dale. They all survive her along with 12 grandchildren and 23 great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 4 o'clock on September 28th, at the First Presbyterian Church, 4 East River Road at Park Avenue, Rumson, New Jersey. Friends seeking further information are directed to an Internet site receiving expressions of sympathy: thompsonmemorial.net

LEISURE--Peter K.,84, loving father and devoted husband, passed away on September 17, 2013. KLAW--David. It is with deep sadness that we announce the passing of David Klaw. David was a longtime resident of Roosevelt Island who recently moved to the Bronx. He attended the Putney School in Vermont, School of Visual Arts and received his Masters in Education at Hunter College in NYC. David was a wonderful teacher who taught Art for many years at PS/IS 217. Most recently, he was teaching Art and Physical Education at Washington Heights Academy. David will be remembered as a gifted teacher who touched the lives of many young students. David is survived by his mother, Bonita Chapman, MD, his father, Robert Klaw, MD, his sister Susan Klaw and his dogs, Rocco and Jake. Those wishing to honor David's memory may make a donation in his name to The Humane Society of NY.

ILLMAN--Arnold M.,MD, Orthopedic Surgeon on September 20, 2013. Beloved husband of Lois B. (nee Brochstein). Devoted father of Susan IIlman and Nancy IIlman (Paul Newman). Graveside service was held Sunday September 22, 2013 at the Beth Moses Cemetery.

BOLLMAN--Mark Brooks, Jr. of Greenwich, CT, passed away on September 14th. Mr. Bollman, a decorated World War II veteran, graduated from Princeton University and Harvard Business School. He began his career in advertising at McCann Erickson in 1951 and retired from N.W. Ayer in 1995. Mr. Bollman is survived by his wife, Barbara, his three sons, seven grandchildren, and his sister, Harriet Oman. BECKER--Alan Daniel, died at the age of 86 on September 16, 2013. A celebration of his life will be held at 3:00pm on September 29, at Sinai Memorial Chapel in San Francisco.

BARKIN--Elaine Rappaport, June 14, 1913 September 21, 2013. An extraordinary and courageous woman of enormous spirit, died at the age of 100 on September 21, 2013 in Hadley, MA. Born in Brooklyn, NY on June 14, 1913 and schooled in Brooklyn at the Adelphi Academy, she graduated from Smith College in 1933 and earned her Master's in Social Work in 1935 from the Smith College School for Social Work. She worked at the Jewish Board of Guardians (JBG) where, in 1942, she job-shared her work on delinquency and family problems, and also represented the New York Jewish agencies in the court system. After leaving the JBG, she worked for the Child Adoption Committee. Later, she focused on career counseling, psychotherapy, and then geriatric services. She was appointed to boards that looked at the needs of elders throughout Massachusetts, including one at the University of Massachusetts Medical School. She served on the first board of the Franklin County Home Care for 25 years and represented her community during this time. In addition, she was appointed by the Governor of Massachusetts to be one of six national Ombudsman on the Board of Registration of Nursing Home Administrators, a position she held for a number of years. She married Solomon Barkin in 1940, a prominent labor economist, and enjoyed his companionship for almost 60 years. The family lived in Manhattan, Great Neck, NY, and Paris, France, where her husband was in the diplomatic corps assigned to the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). The family returned to live in Leverett, MA where her husband had a tenured professorship in the Economics Department at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. Survivors include her three children, David, Roger, and Amy and three grandsons, Adam, Michael and Benjamin, two great-grandsons, Jacob and Eli, and a large circle of friends. Elaine was a feisty, dedicated, socially active and colorful woman who remained mentally alert until her death. She had a life-long love of learning and appetite for life. Up until her last days she took courses in the local Five College 'Learning in Retirement' program. She was a lover of opera, music, theatre, bridge, gourmet cooking, reading and travel. She will be remembered as a deeply loving mother, a generous and devoted friend and confidant, a 'bon vivant', an extraordinary listener and advisor to the young (and not so young), a hostess, an eternal optimist, a 'raconteuse extraordinaire', and a role model for graceful aging! She was a kind and selfless person, beloved by all she met. She brightened the lives of those she touched and left footprints on our hearts, and we will never be the same. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: The Franklin County Home Care Corporation, Roseann Martoccia, Executive Director, 330 Montague City Road, Suite 1, Turners Falls, MA 01376. www.fchcc.org, 413-773-5555. A memorial service will be held in the near future.

UNGAR--William. Temple Israel of Great Neck mourns the loss of its former president, William Ungar. The congregation, as well as the greater Jewish world, benefited by Bill's years of selfless devotion, dedication and bold leadership. A Holocaust survivor from humble beginnings, Bill became a forceful voice in the Jewish, Holocaust survivor, and business communities. He served as a member of the Board of United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism and was an officer of the Synagogue Council of America. He and his late wife, Jerry, were major benefactors of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Israel's Yad Layeled Museum dedicated to the children lost in the Holocaust, as well as our Waxman High School and Youth House. The congregation extends its deepest sympathy to the Ungar's daughters, Florette, Joan, Denise, and Rita, and the extended Ungar family. Alan Klinger, President; Howard Stecker, Rabbi

TENNEY--Charles. Charles Thomas (Tom) Tenney born October 4, 1920 died September 20, 2013 from complications of cancer at The Mayo Clinic, Ponte Vedra, Florida. Surrounded by his loving family, he passed with the strength and dignity that befit him in life. Tom was the son of Harral Straat and Helen Thomas Tenney of Greenwich, CT. He was predeceased by them along with his sisters Rebecca Agnew, Suzanne Sutter and brother, Harral Straat Tenney, Jr. Tom is survived by his wife, Eunice Edwards, also of Greenwich, CT, whom he married on November 6, 1942. They proceeded to have five children: Susan Noble (Howard), Vicki Graboys (Tom), Scott (Patricia), Tim (Carolyn) and Duncan (Virginia). He also leaves nine grandchildren; Topher Black, Jennifer Hinton, Carson Baker, Olivia Baker, Straat Tenney, Kathryn Eunice Tenney, Grace Tenney, Thomas Tenney and Elizabeth Tenney and six great grandchildren; Charlie, Scarlett, Lucia, Huckleberry, Boone and Benjamin. Tom was a long time resident of Newburgh, NY, Ponte Vedra, FL, Woodstock, VT and Fenwick, Old Saybrook, CT. Tom graduated from Greenwich Country Day, Governor Dummer Academy and while in his junior year at the University of Virginia he was called into the arena of WWII. He was a B17 pilot in the German theater during WWII and after victory in Europe he began training in the Far East before victory was declared in Asia as well. After returning from the war he went to work for the Pepsi Cola Company. Early in Pepsi's history the parent company sold franchise rights to qualified individuals throughout the United States to establish a nationwide distribution system. When the Pepsi-Cola Newburgh Bottling Company became available in 1946, he purchased it. Through hard work and perseverance he grew the Pepsi brands and re-invested in the business to make it successful. His never ending effort is what the next generation of Tenney's have as the driving force behind the thriving franchise. Most live by the adage of "...an apple a day..." but Tom's secret was to "drink a Pepsi a day". And his motto was "when it's time to work, you work hard and when it's time to play you play hard"! His abiding passion and guiding force in his life was always his wife of almost 71 years, "Euny". Tom and Euny grew up together in Greenwich enjoying the thrills of athletics including many a feverish tennis match and very competitive golf games. Their union was the model that kept and grew the combined Tenney and Edwards Family. He became the patriarch of the extended tribe that celebrated every Thanksgiving together, sometimes totaling almost 100. He was passionate about the success from hard work not only in business but all endeavors. He was an avid hunter and fisherman whether it was fly fishing in the Catskill Mountains of New York or the Triton Club in Canada. And, of course, he was always devoted to his friendly German Shepherds especially his latest, Benji. Included in his many Board memberships were: Pepcom Industries, the Newburgh YMCA, Highland National Bank, Mount St. Mary's College, in Newburgh, NY, founding member and Board member of Clinton's Ditch Cooperative and Pepsi Cola Bottlers Association. As an inspiration and a role mode, his example of hard work and great love for his family will be felt for generations to come as he will be sorely missed by all. A memorial service will take place at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Tom's memory, honoring his great-grandson, Charles Tenney Baker, who participates in the Pegasus Therapeutic Riding Program in Brewster, NY. Gifts can be sent to Syreeta Jones c/o Pegasus Farms, 310 Peach Lake Road, Brewster, NY 10509.

LEDERER--Lt. Henry Bernard, born March 19, 1920 in Bridgeport, CT, passed away Sunday, September 22, 2013 at 93. At age 14 he "struck a deal" to get flying lessons in exchange for cleaning out aircraft at Miller's Air Field, SI. At 21 he enlisted in the Army Air Corps, turning down a commission as flight instructor for combat duty. He joined the 361st FG, 374th FS and was stationed in 1943 at Bottisham UK where he flew the P-47 Thunderbolt on 92 missions through D-Day. Henry received the Distinguished Flying Cross with two OLCs and Air Medal with two OLCs. He named his aircraft "Duchess of Manhattan" after his childhood sweetheart, Rita Haberman, whom he married in 1945. Henry founded Lederer Brothers in 1946, a jewelry manufacturer, known for "Lady Ellen" pearls and patents for magnetically interchangeable jewelry. He flew the P-47 again at Republic Airport's Lindbergh Day Celebration May 16-17, 1977. He was employed at Fairchild Republic as senior engineer for the A-10 Thunderbolt II, and at Northrop Grumman. He served as Flight Training Director for Cosmopolitan Aviation where he held several FAA ratings and was a Certified Flight Instructor and Examiner. Henry served as President of the P-47 Thunderbolt and P-51 Mustang Pilot Associations. Henry was active in incorporating the Village of Atlantic Beach NY. He loved travelling the world with Rita, classical music, chocolate, discussing world affairs, the internet and email. Henry is survived by Rita, his wife of 68 years, and their three children Dr. Jane Lederer, Dr. Lynn Lederer and Wayne Lederer, CEO and founder of Magnacoustics, their spouses Harry, Peter and Lisa and families. A memorial service will be held at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett NY on Tuesday, September 24 at 12 noon followed by interment at Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Avenue Paramus NJ.

CLARK--Christine Ann, 54, died of heart failure in the early-morning hours of September 22, 2013, in Manhattan. Born in Toledo, Ohio, and raised in south Florida, Chris moved to Manhattan from Houston in the late 1980s to pursue her advertising career and be closer to her future husband, Gary Vineberg. A University of Florida Gator and Zeta Tau Alpha alumnus, she served as an account executive at several prestigious agencies, retiring from Ogilvy Health World in 2008. For more than three decades, Chris worked tirelessly on campaigns for a variety of clients, including airlines and pharmaceutical companies, becoming an expert in women's healthcare along the way. Never one to be idle, she later joined Corcoran Group, launching a second career as a real-estate salesperson. Chris was passionate about her city and Greenwich Village home, working on her building's roof garden. She could often be spotted in the Village shopping, picking up a Patsy's pizza, or sipping a frozen margarita with her husband during Sunday brunch. She and Gary traveled the globe together, counting Cambodia, Ecuador, Palau and South Africa among their many destinations. She always looked forward to her annual "3B" reunion trip with college roommates Jan Healy and Joanne Gelfand, a tradition that lasted 30 years. A few weeks ago, the couple, joined by Chris's mother, explored northwestern England and north Wales with local friends they had met in Fiji. Her creative side was generous, as she would shower family and friends with photo montages and videos on special occasions. She enjoyed socializing -- "Build Me Up Buttercup" never failed to get her up to dance -- as well as skiing and working out at the gym. Overflowing with love and good cheer, Chris was loved by so many and will be sorely missed. She is survived by her husband Gary, her mother, Catherine Clark of Dallas, her aunt Janet Mather of Denver, and her aunt Joyce Clark of San Francisco, as well as other relatives and countless friends. A service will be held in her memory at the East End Temple, 245 East 17th Street, at noon on Tuesday, September 24. In lieu of flowers, please remember Chris with donations to research and treatment of heart disease or other worthy causes.

BRANDE--Ralph T.,a long time New York City educator and school leader, passed away on September 22, at the age of 91. Born in Brooklyn to Raphael Aloysius Brande and Laura Marie Brande (Maroselli) on November 24, 1921, he was a graduate of New Utrecht High School, Brooklyn College and Columbia University. Mr. Brande served his country during World War II as a Second Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Air Corps before beginning his career as a teacher and administrator. His marriage to RoseMarie Roubian in 1944 lasted until her death in 1999. Predeceased by his son, William, and brother, Rev. Edward W. Brande, S.J., he remained the loving father to three daughters and three sons. During his 38 years in education, he served as a Social Studies teacher at Midwood High School and Junior High School 57, a supervisor at the Board of Education, principal of the John F. Hylan Elementary School, and from 1968 to 1984 as Community Superintendent in Districts 14 and 22. He was the author of books on American History, reading skills, and school leadership. During his retirement, he served as a consultant to the NYC Board of Education in the training of community superintendents. Recognized by Stanford University for exemplary leadership and by Brooklyn College as a distinguished alumnus, he was one of NYC's most well known and respected school leaders during the 1970s and 80s. He was a long time member of St. Raymond's Roman Catholic Church in East Rockaway and Our Lady, Queen of Martyrs in Centerport. He is survived by his loving second wife, Celeste Pasquariello and her family, daughters Kathryn Killelea (Michael), Bonnie Fortney (Frank), and Jill Hissong (Joseph), sons Richard (Maureen), John (Gay) and Christopher (Alison), 15 grandchildren, and 11 great-grandchildren. The family will receive friends Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Perry Funeral Home, Inc. 118 Union Avenue Lynbrook, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10:45am at St. Raymond's RC Church. Interment to follow at Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers please make memorial contributions to Long Island Alzheimers.

AUBRY--Blossom McKinley, age 94 on September 16, 2013. Adoring and devoted wife of Marcel, kind and loving mother of Philippe and Michel, and daughter-in-law Doreen, and grandmother of her beloved Nicholas. She dearly loved Paris, Nantucket, and her mother's native Sweden. May she rest in peace, her memory forever secure in our hearts. Memorial Service will be private.

UNGAR--William. Temple Israel of Great Neck mourns the loss of its former president, William Ungar. The congregation, as well as the greater Jewish world, benefited by Bill's years of selfless devotion, dedication and bold leadership. A Holocaust survivor from humble beginnings, Bill became a forceful voice in the Jewish, Holocaust survivor, and business communities. He served as a member of the Board of United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism and was an officer of the Synagogue Council of America. He and his late wife, Jerry, were major benefactors of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Israel's Yad Layeled Museum dedicated to the children lost in the Holocaust, as well as our Waxman High School and Youth House. The congregation extends its deepest sympathy to the Ungar's daughters, Florette, Joan, Denise, and Rita, and the extended Ungar family. Alan Klinger, President; Howard Stecker, Rabbi

TRAMONTINE--John O.,retired senior partner at Fish & Neave LLP, law firm, NYC and member of the American College of Trial Lawyers, passed away September 21, 2013 at his home in Hastings on Hudson, NY. He died of natural causes following years of illness. John was born on September 21, 1932 in Iron Mountain, MI. He was a graduate of Notre Dame University and he received his law degree from New York University. He served in the United States Marine Corps and as a board member at Saint Andrew's Golf Club, New York. We wish him Godspeed. Memorial Reception will be held at the McGrath Funeral Home in Bronxville (914-337-6770) on September 28th, 5-8pm.

Walker and wife Eileen of Ridgefield, CT: nephew Evan Walker and wife Jaclyn of Bedford, NY; and niece Lindsey Walker of Arlington, VA. Wendy was pre-deceased by her mother Jeannette Cane Walker.

MASON--Arnold I.,87, passed away September 23 from Parkinson's Disease. He leaves behind his devoted wife of almost 60 years, Lenore, and loving son and daughter, Robert Mason and Kara Mason Cronin (Joe), his adored grandchildren, Matthew Mason and Nicole and Danielle Cronin. Arnold was a Trustee of Temple Israel of New Rochelle. He was also a Past Commodore of the Mamaroneck, Beach, Tennis and Yacht Club and former President as well. He and his wife moved to Boca Raton, Florida in 2000. Arnold was well known in the furniture industry, representing various companies over the years. LaNatra--George. Long time resident and past Board President. Died unexpectedly September 14, 2013. He will be greatly missed Treescape IIA Board

LINK--Gordon, of New Smyrna Beach, FL, passed away Tuesday, September 24, 2013. He was diagnosed with ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease) in April, 2013. He was born in New York City and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1958 where he was a member of the Sphinx Society, the senior honor society, president of the junior class, and manager of the Penn varsity football team. He was a life-long Penn football fan. Gordon spent his career in advertising, starting as a trainee at BBD&O in 1959. After five years at Ogilvy & Mather, he joined McCann-Erickson where he was named vice president and account supervisor for Coca-Cola. He was integral in the development and implementation of the Coca-Cola campaign "It's the Real Thing." In 1970, Gordon joined the ABC Television network where he became vice-president and Eastern sales director. When he joined ABC, the network was in last place. He proudly worked with a team under the leadership of founder Leonard Goldenson. During Gordon's 14 years at ABC, the network catapulted to first place. In 1984, Gordon was enticed back to McCann-Erickson as Executive Vice President and Director of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Media. He was commonly referred to in the press as the "Dean of worldwide media." He spent nine years overseeing 117 agencies in 63 countries. He loved to regale family and friends with real-life "Mad Men" stories. In 1993 Gordon retired to West Cornwall, CT, and then to New Smyrna Beach, Florida in 1999. During his retirement, he became an avid oil painter winning numerous awards. Gordon is survived by his loving wife of 30 years, Susan, and by his three daughters, Helen Egger, MD, Durham, NC (husband Daniel Egger), Jennifer Fernald Link, MA, New Smyrna Beach, FL, and Katherine Link, MD, Northampton, MA. He is also survived by six grandchildren, Rebecca, Sasha, Leo, and Oliver Egger, and Maggie and James White. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the ALS Association www.alsa.org/donate. A celebration of Gordon's life and art will be held in September, 2014. Condolences may be made online at: settlewilderfuneralhome.com Services are being handled by Settle-Wilder Funeral Home and Cremation Service, 406 S. Orange Street, New Smyrna Beach, Florida 32168.

LAIKIN--Lawrence, 85, of Tenafly, NJ, passed away on Monday, September 23, 2013. Born in Weehawkin, NJ, he grew up in North Bergen and spent much of his life in Teaneck and Tenafly, NJ. Larry received his Professional Engineering degree from Stevens Institute of Technology and was then stationed at Fort Monmouth, serving as an engineer. He then started a building development and management company, Larrin Management, with properties in New York, New Jersey, and Maryland. He was a dedicated board member at Holy Name Hospital for many years. Larry was an avid athlete; he enjoyed skiing, boating, and traveling with his beloved wife, Elaine. He is survived by Elaine, his sister Fern, children Janis and David, and grandchildren Jenna, Alexis, Eli, and Jessica. He is predeceased by his parents, Frieda and Louis. Larry's best moments of his life were spent surrounded by adoring nieces, nephews, cousins, and friends, who fondly remember sharing summers on Candlewood Lake with him. He is remembered for his philanthropy, integrity, and most of all his devotion to his family. Funeral services will be today at 10:15am at Gutterman and Musicant Funeral Home in Hackensack, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Friendship House in Hackensack or Temple Israel Community Center in Cliffside Park, NJ.
GOLDFEIER--Moritz. Rachel Pauley and Daniel Litowitz mourn the loss of their dear friend Moritz Goldfeier and extend heartfelt condolences to the entire Goldfeier family.

GOLDSTEIN--Rita Davis, 94, Merrick, NY. Devoted and adored wife of Mort for 67 years. Beloved mother of Marcia and Les Ratcliff, Amy Goldstein, and Jane and Ron Jackson. Incredibly loving and proud grandmother of Blake and Jordan Ratcliff and Ben and Evan Jackson. Services at Gutterman's Rockville Centre on Wednesday at 2:30pm. So loved and so loving, we will always hold her in our hearts.

GOLDFEIER--Moritz Moshe, Our friends, family and industry suffered an irreplaceable loss today. We mourn the passing of Moritz Moshe Goldfeier. Ten years have passed since the Patriarch of our family; William Goldberg was taken from us at the height of his life. Moritz, a most devoted, loyal friend and confidant, like our Father, exemplified the upmost honorable qualities as a leader in the diamond industry. He was a true "Mensch" who found contracts and lawyers useless in the face of a solid, firm handshake. Moritz rose above the loss of family members as a survivor of the atrocities of the Holocaust to build a successful business from his humble booth's surroundings in the diamond district. We share the loss of this most precious gem with our dear friend, his wife Angie of 65 years and his loving children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. The William Goldberg Family

GLICK--Claire Lasky, 100 years old, devoted wife of Charles Lasky and Jacob J. Glick, loving mother of Candy (Candice Norma) Edelbaum and Lawrence Lasky and Helene Lasky, adoring grandmother of Cynthia and Jack, Amanda and Neal, Adam and Ivy, Kate and Doug, proud great-grandma to Jake, Ethan, Cole, Claire, Max and Ryan. Claire lived life to its fullest and made the world's best noodle pudding! She will be missed.

GALLAGHER--Maria Anne, died on September 21, 2013 in New York City. She was born on July 4, 1963 in Philadelphia daughter of Maria C. Gallagher and Thomas Gallagher. She spent her childhood in Philadelphia and high school years in Los Angeles. An adventurous spirit and a true beauty, Maria modeled in Paris as a young woman and returned to Los Angeles to attend USC Film School where she started her career in film and television. Maria's early years in Los Angeles were marked by her important role in LA nightlife, where she danced at the club Power Tools, was once painted by Keith Haring, and co-founded the seminal parties The Botswana and El Dorado. She also resided in Paris and most recently in New York where she lived with her husband, Sebastian de Gzell. In her professional life, Maria leaves behind many friends and colleagues in the fields of film, fashion and advertising. Her extensive work as a producer spanned the globe, working with such luminaries as Madonna, Jean Baptiste Mondino, Peter Lindbergh and Miuccia Prada. With a passion for the arts and an uncompromising eye for the new and the innovative, Maria sought out young talent and helped foster connections to support original work. Maria was known for living life to the fullest. With dazzling style, Maria was a person who lit up rooms, lives and whole decades with her energy, intellect and humor. Along with her mother, father and husband she is survived by a large caring family and many good friends. Memorial donations can be made to the Lower Eastside Girls Club. Funeral services will be held at 10:00am Saturday, September 28, 2013 at The Basilica of St. Patrick's Old Cathedral, Mott Street in New York City.

FREUND--Beatrice Lindheimer, passed away on September 23, 2013 at age 99. Bea lived a long, full life. She loved her family deeply, so much so that she never fully recovered from her husband's (Fred Freund) passing, or her beloved son-in-law's (Moe Schwarz) passing. Her daughter, Vivian Schwarz, took incredible care of her with love, patience, and grace during all those difficult years. Vivian passed away just five days before her mother. Grandme, as all of her grandchildren and great-grandchildren called her, is survived by her son-in-law David Sackser, grandsons Wayne, Matthew, and Evan, her granddaughters-in-law Lori, Rebecca, and Jocelyn, and her great-granddaughters Melanie, Jordan, Marni, Phoebe, Courtney, Sabrina, and Maddi. The funeral will be held on Wednesday, September 25th at 10:30am at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ.

FONTAINE--John Clovis, of New York City and West Stockbridge, MA, died Monday of the complications of pancreatic cancer. He was 81 years old. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, the former Elizabeth Ellis (Betty); daughters Lizanne (Robert Buckholz), Amy (Mete Kok) and Alison Engel (Peter); eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild; his brother, Edward Fontaine; his sister, Anne Marie Fontaine; and his brother's widow, Carole Fontaine. Jack graduated from the University of Michigan and Harvard Law School. He was a partner at Hughes, Hubbard & Reed in New York and later was General Counsel, Executive Vice President, and then President of Knight-Ridder, Inc. He was a member of the board of Century Aluminum Company. Jack was the former Chairman and Trustee Emeritus of the National Gallery of Art; Chairman of the Samuel H. Kress Foundation; and Chairman of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival and the Florida Philharmonic. On Saturday, September 28, 2013, there will be a gathering in his honor from 4pm to 7pm in the Reception Room at Plymouth Church, 75 Hicks Street, Brooklyn NY. On Monday, December 9, 2013 there will be a memorial service at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66th Street, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Fontaine Family Fund, Berkshire Taconic Foundation (www.berkshiretaconic.org) or the Berkshire Medical Center (www.berkshirehealth systems.org/bmc), in gratitude to Dr. Jeffrey St. John.

EUTEMEY--Loring P.,died on September 22nd in his apartment in Manhattan, at age 82, after a short illness. Son of Bert V. Eutemey and Lousie Hope Holmes Eutemy, brother of the late Edward Eutemey. Loring grew up at Revere Place in Brooklyn, and graduated from Samuel J. Tilden High School. After graduating from Cooper Union, where he trained as a graphic designer, he began his career at Push Pin Studios during its early days. Later he became a freelance illustrator and graphic designer, widely recognized for his distinctive album cover designs for Atlantic records. His two marriages ended in divorce. He was a military veteran, a collector of rare books, and an avid bicycler around New York. He will be greatly missed by his friends and neighbors.

ELSWIT--Muriel (Glassman). September 22, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Eugene Elswit, loving mother of Larry and Bob, grandmother of Rebecca, Justin and Sarah, mother-in-law of Bernice Speiser. Graveside service Thursday September 26, 11am, Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

EDELMANN--Chester M. Jr.,M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the passing of our distinguished university professor of pediatrics and former chair of our institutional review board. An Einstein faculty member for more than 50 years, Dr. Edelmann served in numerous administrative roles, including chair of pediatrics and senior associate dean. Also renowned for his research and clinical accomplishments, he established an outstanding division of pediatric nephrology that was acknowledged as a world leader in developmental renal physiology. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the entire Edelmann family. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Edward R. Burns, M.D. Executive Dean Judy Aschner, M.D. Michael I. Cohen, M.D. Chair of Pediatrics Albert Einstein College of Medicine

COHEN--Esther, also known as "Aunt Esther" of Camp Kewanee. Funeral services Wednesday, September 25th 12:00 Noon at Star of David Chapel, 1236 Wellwood Ave., W. Babylon, NY. View complete obituary and share a memory: www.starofdavidchapel.com

BRAFMAN--Florrie S.,died suddenly at her Upper Westside apartment on September 22nd at age 56. Beloved daughter of Fred and Alicia Brafman, sister of Terri Nettboy and Neil Brafman, sister-in-law of Judith Bender, aunt of Amanda and Scott Nettboy. She was an irreplaceable family member and friend who left us too soon. Florrie studied and worked at Barnard College for 40 years. Barnard enriched her life and benefited from her many talents. She spent her entire life in New York City, delighting in the world's best theater and restaurants.

BERMAN--Jim, The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved longtime member, Jim Berman. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest sympathy to his wife Peggy, sons Chris and Andy, daughters-in-law both named Katherine, grandchildren Meredith, Doug, Sara and Riley, and the entire family. Michael Tannenbaum, President Bryna Sweedler, Secretary

BERMAN--James K.,of Greenwich, CT, passed away on September 22nd at the age of 89, losing a valiant two week bout with pneumonia. He was a man of many passions, not the least of which was skiing, which he did until he was 80. His greatest passion was always his wife, Peggy (Tenenbaum), to whom he was married for 62 years. He was born in New York City on May 10, 1924 to Louis and Marie Berman. He graduated from Fieldston School and earned an engineering degree from MIT in 1949. His college tenure was interrupted by World War II, when he served in the US Army Air Corps as part of the Europe weather forecasting team stationed in Greenland. He married Peggy in 1951, and they had two sons: Chris, born on his father's birthday in 1955, and Andy, born in 1957. Jim worked for four decades for Raisler Corporation, a mechanical contracting firm prominent in commercial real estate building in metropolitan New York for close to a century. He retired as Executive Vice President. He lent his expertise freely... to the Town of Rye, NY, where the family lived for a quarter century, to Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, to Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, or later as a volunteer for IESC by advising burgeoning ventures. He loved the outdoors, most notably in Sun Valley, Idaho, where he maintained a residence in Andy's home town for the past 25 years. An avid skier, hiker, and bicyclist, Jim enjoyed both winters and summers in the Sawtooth Mountains. Earlier he and the family enjoyed similar activities around Weston, Vermont. He was an avid pilot, which he took up on a whim at age 40 and continued into his 70's. He played tennis and golf, and in his younger days was part of a sailing crew that raced regularly on the Long Island Sound. Jim especially enjoyed having season tickets for the NY Jets at Shea Stadium, where he and his young sons were ardent supporters of the football team and the AFL. Undoubtedly those days spurred Chris on to a long career at ESPN. Jim is survived by his wife Peggy, his sister Virginia Slaughter, his two sons Chris and Andy, and their wives, both named Katherine Berman. He will be greatly missed by his grandchildren Meredith, Doug, Sara, and Riley. A remembrance will be held Friday September 27th at 11am at Congregation Emanuel of Westchester in Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy may be made to Greenwich Hospital, MIT, or the Sun Valley Ski Education Foundation. To leave an online condolence please visit www.leopgallaghergreenwich.com

AUBRY--Blossom McKinley, age 94 on September 16, 2013. Adoring and devoted wife of Marcel, kind and loving mother of Philippe and Michel, and daughter-in-law Doreen, and grandmother of her beloved Nicholas. A veteran of nearly 40 years at the United Nations, Blossom was born on Long Island, but moved to Manhattan at an early age, and lived there her entire life. She dearly loved Paris, Nantucket, and her mother's native Sweden. May she rest in peace, her memory forever secure in our hearts. Memorial Service will be private.
